headline: Executive Life: The Boss; A Castle and a Vineyard
abstract: Compagnie Financiere Richemont chief executive Alain Dominique Perrin reflects, in The Boss column, on his life and work; photo (M)

headline: In the Wings, Rugged Rivals to an Aging Memory Standard
abstract: Chip makers are seeking replacement for flash and other types of memory in use in wireless industry and may end up reverting to technologies that have been shelved for many years; ovonic unified memory was described in technical article written 32 years ago by Intel co-founder Gordon Moore and inventor Stanley Ovshinsky and is sparking interest today along with other technologies that were abandoned years ago; drawing (M)

headline: Georgia Hearing Heavy Footsteps From Russia's War in Chechnya
abstract: Russia's war in Chechnya spills across its border with Georgia, worsening already tense relations between two countries; Georgian officials accuse Russian fighter jets and helicopters of repeatedly crossing into Georgian territory, evidently in pursuit of Chechen fighters; Russian aircraft reportedly bomb gorge in Georgia two miles from border; Russia denies crossing into Georgia, but senior Russian officials accuse Georgia of harboring rebels fighting Russian forces in Chechnya and demand that Georgia root out rebels using Georgian territory as base; some Russians suggest launching strikes even deeper into Georgia; Georgian officials discount possibility of full-scale Russian operation in Georgia, but fear futher incursions or raids by Russian aircraft; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Register.Com Shares Plunge
abstract: Shares of Register.com fall 33 percent as second-quarter profit falls by more than half at company; shares drop $2.39, to $4.86 (S)

headline: Japan Savers May Find They're Paying Banks
abstract: Japan, racked by deflation and eager to stave off bank crisis, is considering pushing its rock-bottom interest rates on some bank accounts below zero; lawmakers have already suggested exception to law ending government's guarantee on savings and other accounts that would allow full guarantee to remain for no-interest accounts that businesses use to pay their bills; now, government is considering allowing individuals as well to have government guaranteed settlement accounts that would earn no interest, but these accounts would charge fees (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Executive Makes a Case For WorldCom's Survival  John W. Sidgmore, the chief executive of WorldCom, left, called the company's survival a matter of national security and said his management team was not responsible for the company's accounting problems.     Separately, the telecommunications company IDT offered $5 billion for WorldCom's MCI long-distance operations and its local telephone assets. A WorldCom spokesman said such a deal would be unlikely. [Page C5.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Units Merge To Focus On Publishing
abstract: Holding di Partecipazioni Industriali will merge with its RCS Editori unit, publisher of Italy's two most-read daily newspapers; chief executive Maurizio Romiti comments; photo (S)

headline: Study Finds Bias on the Job Is Still Common
abstract: Study by Rutgers School of Law Profs Alfred W and Ruth G Blumrosen shows women and minorities appear to be benefiting from greater employment opportunities in US, but discrimination remains significant problem; study concludes that about two million workers were affected by intentional discrimination in 1999; authors say roughly one third of employers studied appeared to have discriminated against women or minorities in at least one job category; study was based on information collected from employers by Equal Employment Opportunity Commission from 1990 through 1999 (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Media Executive Quits
abstract: Granada says chief executive Stephen Morrison will leave at end of September; replacement is not expected to be named (S)

headline: Mideast Strife Loudly Echoed in Academia
abstract: Mona Baker, Palestinian professor in Machester, England, fires Prof Miriam Shlesinger and Gideon Toury from board of two academic journals she publishes because they are Israeli; resulting academic outcry focuses attention on two petitions signed by hundreds of European scholars, one calling for boycott of Israeli institutions and the other calling on European Union to deny grants to Israeli universities and scientific institutions; rival petition criticizing boycott petition for its 'unjustly righteous tone, which distorts the complexity of the situation' garners more signatures than two original petitions urging boycotts (M)

headline: Amgen Reports Its Takeover Of Immunex
abstract: Amgen completes its acquisition of Immunex, gaining control of rheumatoid arthritis drug Enbrel; cash-and-stock deal is valued at less than $10 billion, down from $16 billion valuation when move was announced last December (M)

headline: A Downgrade In Insurance For Conseco
abstract: A M Best downgradesÈ

headline: Outlook Improves For Magazine Ads
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau reports magazine ad pages fell 1.2 percent in June from June 2001; says for first six months of year pages declined 9.9 percent, compared with period in 2001 (S)

headline: On Tip, Dutch Border Police Detain Iraqi Kurdish Militant
abstract: Norwegian and D

headline: Israel Expels 2 of Nablus Militant's Kin to Gaza
abstract: Israeli military expels from West Bank jailed sister and brother of Ali Ajuri, Palestinian militant accused by Israel of organizing July suicide bombing in Tel Aviv; drops two, Intissar and Kifah Ajuri, off on dunes south of Gaza City; charges they aided in bombing; killed brother in Aug and razed his family's Nablus home; United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan calls expulsion violation of international law; Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat scores move; Ajuris hold news conference, Gaza (M)

headline: CHENEY SAYS PERIL OF A NUCLEAR IRAQ JUSTIFIES ATTACK
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney presents Bush administration's most forceful and comprehensive rationale yet for attacking Iraq, speech, Veterans of Foreign Wars convention, Nashville; warns Pres Saddam Hussein will 'fairly soon' have nuclear weapons and would seek domination of entire Middle East, take control of great portion of world's energy suplies, directly threaten America's friends throughout region and subject US or any other nation to nuclear blackmail; administration officials say Cheney's views mirror those of Pres Bush, and are part of ongoing effort to convince allies, Congress and American public of need for regime change in Iraq; State Dept will begin four-day program on August 27 to train 17 Iraqi expatriates in publicizing brutality of Hussein's rule; is using its Middle Eastern radio service to broadcast remarks by third-ranking Pentagon official calling for Iraqi people to overthrow Hussein; administration press secretary Ari Fleischer, citing White House attorneys, says Pres Bush does not need Congressional approval to attack Iraq; says previous Congressional resolutions, as well as president's power as commander in chief, already bestow such authority; photo (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: The War Against Spam To the Editor:.

headline: Trespasser Sets Off Alert at Arms Depot
abstract: Chemical weapons disposal plant in Utah sounds terrorist alert, its first since Sept 11, after four National Guardsmen report seeing figure dressed in black on grounds; say trespasser ran when guardsmen approached; photo of military personnel guarding entrace to Deseret Chemical Depot in Tooele, Utah (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Rolls Profit Down 45%; BRITAIN: Chief Executive Arrested; GERMANY: Profits Dip At Steel Maker;.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Talk With North Korea; BANGLADESH: 'Regrets' By Pakistani; JAPAN: With A Cup Of Sake, L'Chaim!;.

headline: From Maid to Rio Governor, and Still Fighting
abstract: Benedita da Silva, who became governor of State of Rio de Janeiro and Brazil's first black woman governor in April, when governor stepped down, likes to remind country's almost exclusively white political establishment that she started out as a maid and cleaning lady and that she speaks for millions of black Brazilians who remain poor and disenfranchised; polls leading up to October election show her running strong third in field of eight; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Revision On Growth
abstract: Second-quarter British economic growth was slower than 0.9 percent originally reported; it actually rose 0.6 percent; decline in manufacturing caused revised statistic (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Words and Mascara In a Marketing Deal
abstract: Latina, monthly magazine for bilingual Hispanic women, joins with Avon Products to sell subscriptions; photo (S)

headline: White House Denies Report Qaeda Funds Are Flowing
abstract: Bush administration is locked in dispute with critics at United Nations who argue that efforts to shut down Al Qaeda's financial network have hit dead end; draft report of United Nations Sanction Committee contends that Al Qaeda's network of raising and distributing money for terrorist operations is 'fit and well' and that American-led efforts to freeze terrorists' assets have slowed to crawl; Treasury Dept quickly denounces report as flawed and 'incomplete'; announces agreement with Italy to freeze money linked to 25 people and organizations whose activities are scattered from Milan to Istanbul to tax havens like Liechtenstein and Bahamas; UN's draft report says efforts to freeze assets are being hampered by Al Qaeda's increased reliance on gold and gems and by informal networks that work outside regulated banking system (M)

headline: A One-Home Stand Against a Florida Golf Resort
abstract: Vivendi Universal SA and 92-year-old Clarence Moore are engaged in legal battle over rights to Moore's home in Orlando, Fla, that Vivendi Universal has acquired for golf course; Moore bought house for $2,000 in 1959, and Universal bought it for $1 million in 1994; Moore has been trying to rescind sale since shortly after transactions, in series of legal actions that have stalled Universal's development plans; Judge Joseph P Baker ruled in favor of Universal on Aug 15 after trial in which Universal lawyer argued that while Moore's relatives may have defrauded him in sale, that did not affect validity of sale; separate lawsuit is pending that could allow company to force Moore to pay property taxes that have accrued while he stalled their resort; document was executed on Feb 20, 1987 granting property to his step-granddaughter Mary Jean Smith; Smith sold ownership of land to Universal in 1994; Moore and his lawyers charge she kept money for herself, charge that her lawyer does not deny; Moore sued her and company, seeking to have 1987 transaction of deed to Smith dissolved; photo (M)

headline: Results Take Opposite Paths at 2 Large Banks
abstract: FleetBoston Financial posts second-quarter loss of $386 million compared with net income of $531 million year earlier; revenue fell 12 percent, to $2.66 billion; Bank of America's net income rose to $2.22 billion from $2.02 billion (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Initial Stock Offer Canceled
abstract: Cantrell & Cochrane Group, Irish fod and beverage maker, cancels its initial public offering on Dublin and London stock exchanges 48 hours before new stock is scheduled to begin trading; cites market volatility for withdrawal; chairman Anthony O'Brien comments; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: TURKEY: Legislators Approve Early Elections; CROATIA: Ex-Bosnian Warlord Sentenced; RUSSIA: Orthodox Church Berates Vatican; GERMANY: Berlin Official Quits; GREECE: Guerrilla Group Asserts Itself;.

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: CANADA: Mine Bid Extended; CANADA: Bce Sells New Shares;.

headline: As Recession Drags On and Coalition Crumbles, Turkey's Premier Calls Early Elections
abstract: Turkey's ailing prime minister Bulent Ecevit succumbs to pressure and calls early elections for November after more defections from his wobbly coalition; photo (M)

headline: Argentina Charges Ex-Dictator and Others in 'Dirty War' Deaths
abstract: Judge Claudio Bonadio orders arrest of Gen Leopoldo Galtieri, Argentina's former military dictator, and more than 30 other military officers on charges that they abused human rights during 'dirty war' against leftists more than 20 years ago; officers, most of them retired, are accused of ordering or taking part in kidnapping, torture and execution of more than 20 members of left-wing Montonero guerrillas (M)

headline: 3 Die in Gunfight at East Jerusalem Market
abstract: 19-year-old Palestinian gunman and Arab bystander die in gun battle with paramilitary Israeli border police in Arab East Jerusalem; battle erupts after gunman opens fire on truck beloning to Israeli telephone company, killing security guard and injuring driver; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Will Get Power, and Pollution, From Mexico
abstract: Two huge power plants under construction in Mexicali desert near US border will generate billions of watts of electricity for State of California, handful of jobs for Mexicans and pollution on both sides of border; Mexico's Energy Sec Ernesto Martens says they will be first of many built in Mexico specifically to provide power for US under terms of North American Free Trade Agreement, and will mark new phase in relations between both nations; plants will represent new way of generating wealth and power by capitalizing on economic and legal differences between both nations; will be powered by natural gas piped from Texas and cooled by Mexicali's sewage; will be part of California's power grid by 2003; are being built by InterGen and Bechtel Corp; map; photo (M)

headline: In Mining, Some Glints, But Little That Glistens
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin Market Insight column interviews Lehman Brothers metals and mining analyst Peter D Ward about prospects for investing in industry; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; NASD Sues Star Analyst Over Research
abstract: NASD, formerly known as National Association of Securities Dealers, sues Salomon Smith Barney former analyst Jack B Grubman and his assistant Christine Gochuico, contending they wrote misleading research of Winstar Communications; fines Salomon $5 million for issuing research; NASD contends reports by Grubman and Gochico failed to disclose true risks of investing in Winstar, which filed for bankruptcy protection in April 2001; says two worked closely with Winstar managers, who paid Salomon $24 million in investment banking fees from February 1999 to August 2001; adds analysts also wrote reports denigrating research from other firms that was critical of Winstar; NASD president Mary L Schapiro says situation is serious breach of trust between Salomon and its investors; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Chief of British Mortgage Bank Quits Under Pressure
abstract: Ian Harley, chief executive of Abbey National, one of largest British mortgage banks, resigns six weeks after disclosing that bad loans will sharply depress lender's annual profits; chairman Lord Burns is named as temporary successor; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Developer's Profit Falls
abstract: China Resources Enterprise Ltd says first-half profit slipped 8.6 percent, to $92 million (S)

headline: Japan Carves Out Major Role in China's Auto Future
abstract: Honda Motor of Japan says it will build first car plant in China dedicated to exports; Honda's president Hiroyuki Yoshino says new plant will be able to turn out as many as 50,000 vehicles a year, starting in 2004; adds quality of cars company plans to build in China will match those made in Japan, but costs in China will be 20 percent lower, speech to Beijing International Auto Show; photos (M)

headline: Text of Fed Panel's Statement
abstract: Text of statement by Federal Reserve after Fed's monetary policy panel, Open Market Committee, decides to leave interest rates unchanged (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Federal Government to Post $165 Billion Deficit in 2002  The Bush administration said the federal government would run a deficit of $165 billion this year, a sharp turn for the worse after four years of surpluses and further evidence of how the stock market's long slide is rippling through the economy.    Administration officials said the main reason for the swing from a $127 billion surplus in the fiscal year that ended last Sept. 30 to the projected red ink for the current fiscal year was a steep falloff in tax revenue from capital gains and other receipts associated with the stock market. [Page A1.]

headline: Airborne Announces 2nd-Quarter Profit
abstract: Airborne Inc posts second-quarter net income of $457,000, compared with year-earlier net loss of $6.4 million (S)

headline: Al Qaeda Paid For Car Bomb At U.S. Office, Pakistani Says
abstract: Pakistani Interior Min Moinuddin Haider says Al Qaeda paid for car bombing outside American Consulate in Karachi in June that killed 12 people; also says foreign terrorists operating inside Pakistan were probably behind suicide bombing in Karachi in May that killed 11 French citizens, as well as murder of American reporter Daniel Pearl (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: 2 Companies To Share Costs
abstract: European Commission says it will let mobile phone operators T-Mobile and MMO2 share costs of setup in Britain for third-generation mobile telephones; Europe's competition commissioner Mario Monti says customers will benefit from arrangement because it would speed introduction of new technologies (S)

headline: VISX, A MAKER OF LASERS, EXPECTS PROFITS TO FALL SHORT
abstract: Visx shares fall 18 percent after c

headline: LOCKHEED MARTIN'S PROFITS DOUBLED IN 2ND QUARTER
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp says second-quarter profit more than doubled on increased sales of aircraft; net income rose to $339 million from $144 million year earlier; sales increased to $6.29 billion from $5.7 billion (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Editors Have Countless Reasons to Use Numerology
abstract: Marie Claire fashion and beauty magazine breaks four-digit barrier on cover story, offering 1132 'new looks and sexy steals;' editor in chief Lesley Jane Seymour defends number as real and important; cover numerology has taken on life, and momentum, of its own in newsstand magazines; photo (M)

headline: Herbert B. Max -- Lawyer, 71
abstract: Herbert B Max, retired lawyer and financier who wrote book on private equity investing, dies at age 71 (S)

headline: Sports Fantasy Is Catching Up With Reality
abstract: Sports video games represent 22 percent of game sales in $10.8 billion interactive entertainment business; sports gaming will get even bigger as major producers Sony, Microsoft and Nintendo prepare to offer online versions of their games, which will allow players to compete with others via Internet; it is most important technological leap in quest for authenticity and realism, and requires complex combination of real-life athletes and skilled computer programmers; process of creating electronic versions of athletes and simulating them in action described; photos (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bank Posts Gain
abstract: Royal Bank of Scotland says first-half net income rose to 1.34 billion pounds ($2 billion) from 1.1 billion a year ago, while revenues rose by one-fifth, to 8.18 billion pounds (S)

headline: Leaked Letter From Prince Charles Stirs Protests
abstract: Prince Charles found himself embroiled today in an embarrassingly public dispute over his habit of writing letters tilting at red tape, political correctness and the creeping invasion of a "blame culture" in Britain.

abstract: Compagnie Financiere Richemont chief executive Alain Dominique Perrin reflects, in The Boss column, on his life and work; photo (M)

abstract: Granada says chief executive Stephen Morrison will leave at end of September; replacement is not expected to be named (S)

abstract: Mona Baker, Palestinian professor in Machester, England, fires Prof Miriam Shlesinger and Gideon Toury from board of two academic journals she publishes because they are Israeli; resulting academic outcry focuses attention on two petitions signed by hundreds of European scholars, one calling for boycott of Israeli institutions and the other calling on European Union to deny grants to Israeli universities and scientific institutions; rival petition criticizing boycott petition for its 'unjustly righteous tone, which distorts the complexity of the situation' garners more signatures than two original petitions urging boycotts (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None    TUESDAY  Consumer Confidence: Sept.

headline: Canadian Auto Workers Open Talks With the Big 3
abstract: Canadian Auto Workers, representing 46,000 Canadian auto workers, begins talks with big three North American automakers on new labor contract that might set precedents for similar talks next year in US; General Motors is expected to be union's primary, and most accommodating, target; Al Green, vice president for personnel at General Motors of Canada, and union president Buzz Hargrove comment; Canadian contracts expire Sept 17; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Quantum To Cut Jobs
abstract: Quantum, maker of computer data-storage devices, will cut its work force by 1,100 as its new chief executive Richard Belluzzo seeks to pare costs and return to profitability by March 2000; about 80 percent of workers cut will be hired by Jabil Circuit Inc, which is taking over some Quantum manufacturing; graph (S)

headline: Safety Problems at Japanese Reactors Begin to Erode Public's Faith in Nuclear Power
abstract: Rock-solid consensus favoring nuclear energy that has existed in Japan for decades erodes amid scandal involving Tokyo Electric, Japan's largest nuclear power company; reports of safety lapses, fraudulent repairs and 16 years of cover-ups of serious flaws in apparent effort to preserve public trust show potentially catastrophic pattern of cost-cutting; failures include systematic falsification of inspection and repair records at 13 reactors at company; disclosures have forced resignations of five senior officials of company and enraged government officials; chart; photo (M)

headline: Britain Names a Liberal as Archbishop of Canterbury
abstract: Britain today named Rowan Williams to be the new spiritual leader of the world's 70 million Anglicans.

headline: Mutual Funds Report; To Growl and Bear It: They Did
abstract: Article on second-quarter performance of three top-performing actively-managed diversified mutual funds: Comstock Capital Value Class A, Eclipse Small Cap Value and Hussman Strategic Growth; fund managers comment on market outlook; photos; performance graphs (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Death Sentence For Blasphemy
abstract: Anwar Kenneth, Pakistani Catholic who wrote letters questioning central tenet of Islam, is convicted of blasphemy and sentenced to death; case reviewed (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Gay Marriage Ruling Faces Challenge
abstract: Justice Min Martin Cauchon says government will appeal Ontario provincial court ruling that Canada must extend marriage rights to homosexual couples; sees no consensus for move among general population or courts; photo (S)

headline: Tight Corporate Belts and Even Tighter Wallets
abstract: DIARY Tight Corporate Belts And Even Tighter Wallets.

headline: Migrants to Chinese Boom Town Find Hard Lives
abstract: More than 100 million rural Chinese from Nanba area have migrated to cities, with more than half ending up in southern province of Guangdong and forming vast new urban underclass; seldom able to become legal residents, they are blamed for every social ill; many turn to sex trade as financial backstop, with their cheap labor fueling Guangdong's thriving economy, which accounts for half of China's gross domestic product; few reap any benefits, remaining unwanted outsiders for many years in strange and often hostile region; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Refiner Cuts Jobs
abstract: TonenGeneral Sekiyu KK, Japanese subsidiary of Exxon Mobil Corp, plans to eliminate 300 jobs, or 7.3 percent of its work force, by next June (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Fred Cook, chief client officer at Golin/Harris International, Chicago, was named to the added post of president, which had been vacant.

headline: Is Uncertainty the Only Thing That Is Certain?
abstract: From small brokerage offices to sprawling trading floors, investors are asking what else can go wrong in corporate America.

headline: Coaxing Out the Truth
abstract: Walter Read letter on July 18 article notes randomized false numbers have been added to consumer surveys for decades

headline: Commitment Of WorldCom's Latest Chief Is Questioned
abstract: Assertions by WorldCom Inc's new chief executive, John W Sidgmore, that he was not aware of accounting problems because during last leg of his time on board he had little involvement in day-to-day operations, disturb corporate governance experts, who say he should have been more involved, or should not have accepted millions of dollars in pay and stock options for what was largely figurehead role; his commitment to company's rescue effort is being called into question by some big investors; he acknowledges that he remains chairman and chief executive of Ecommerce Industries and continues to serve on board of Boingo Wireless and advisory board of Frazier Technology Ventures; photo (M)

headline: New Business and Takeovers Push Omnicom's Profit Up 24%
abstract: Second-quarter earnings for Omnicom Group increase 24 percent, to $187.3 million, as sales are helped by string of acquisitions and new accounts (S)

headline: A Believer in Gays and Women as Clerics To Become the Archbishop of Canterbury
abstract: Dr Rowan Williams, Welsh cleric outspokenly in favor of gays and women as clergy and against 'Western militarism,' will become 104th Archbishop of Canterbury, spiritual leader of world's 70 million Anglicans; photo; Williams, 52, succeeds retiring Dr George Carey and is first Anglican leader from outside England to lead church since break with Rome in 16th century; he has written 14 books, speaks seven languages and is married with two children (M)

headline: Registration Lagging for Pope's Canada Visit
abstract: Organizers of World Youth Day, gathering of international Roman Catholic youth, disclose that registration is lagging for weeklong festivities in Toronto this month, which will include gala morning mass attended by Pope John Paul II; less than week before pope's scheduled July 23 arrival in Toronto, organizers have registered only 195,000 youthful pilgrims, from 170 countries (M)

headline: US Airways Is Near A Pact With Pilots
abstract: US Airways and its pilots' union near tentative accord on cost cuts; accord could boost airline's bid for $900 million federal loan guarantee (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: War Crimes Indictment Sent Back
abstract: Cr

headline: An Idea Gone Haywire: Linking Executive Pay to Sales
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on governance and accounting of corporations whose executive compensation rose with corporate revenue; finds that paying executive bonuses based on company performance may underlie some corporate cheating and accounting shenanigans (M)

headline: Consolidation Move by Morgan Stanley
abstract: Morgan Stanley will regroup about 400 bankers who underwrite global stock and bond sales into single division as demand for investment banking slumps; Jon Anda and Walid Chammah will co-manage combined unit (S)

headline: Hollywood Group Offers First TV Spot on Tolerance Aimed at Arab World
abstract: Hollywood 9/11 International Group, formed by Hollywood producers and executives at Pres Bush's request to produce pro-American messages for both domestic and international audiences, is set to release its first public service commercial promoting peace and tolerance; advertisement, aimed at Arab world television audiences, features Moroccan Olympic champion Nawal el Moutawakel-Bennis; was produced in Morocco by company owned by film director Ridley Scott; makes general plea for understanding and forgiveness, never overtly mentioning United States and only briefly referring to Sept 11; experts on Arab world question its effectiveness; group has not yet won commitments from Arab television outlets to run ad (M)

headline: Threat to retaliate on tariffs remains : U.S. retreat on steel fails to satisfy EU
abstract: PARIS:—  The European Union refused Friday to withdraw its threat of retaliation over U.S. steel tariffs, saying that Washington's most recent list of exemptions was encouraging but insufficient.

headline: I.B.M. Agrees to Expand Its Use Of the Linux Operating System
abstract: IBM and Red Hat enter alliance to expand range of IBM computers and software products that run on Linux operating software distributed by Red Hat; will jointly sell products and support services to big business customers using Linux systems (M)

headline: Avaya Cuts Jobs After Quarterly Loss
abstract: Avaya Inc is cutting jobs after reporting fiscal third-quarter loss of $37 million compared with net income of $24 million year earlier and 29 percent decline in sales; sales in period ended June 30 fell to $1.22 billion from $1.71 billion (S)

headline: A Screen That Cuts The Cord
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column on design of Panasonic MDWD (Mobile Data Wireless Display), which employs wireless signals to connect computer to its screen; says setup offers great degree of flexibility; plastic stylus can be used to point, click and drag on screen's surface; drawing; photo (M)

headline: Kuwait Tries to Rein In Drug Addiction
abstract: Kuwait is struggling to contain surge in drug addiction that officials acknowledge is spinning out of control; drug smuggling networks view Kuwait, where per capita income is $20,000, as ready market; Kuwait has 20,000 addicts, 1 percent of population; health and law enforcement officials point to several factors: Iraqi invasion left residents traumatized, population is getting younger, bored, affluent youths find little entertainment in religiously conservative emirate, and Islamic ban on alcohol that augments allure of drugs; most treatment is channeled through government-run psychiatric hospital, which makes many addicts reluctant to seek help; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: ClearOne Shares Plunge On Forecast
abstract: ClearOne Communications Inc shares fall as much as 50 percent, biggest decline ever, after company says it will break even in fiscal first quarter; graph (S)

headline: Buoyed by World's Focus on Terror, Spain Cracks Down in Basque Region
abstract: Government of Prime Min Jose Maria Aznar of Spain has seized on new international support for fight against terrorism to toughen its already hard line against Basque violence; it has stepped up political and police pressure on separatist group ETA; Spanish Judge Baltasar Garzon is pressing his own long-standing campaign against separatist violence, moving to seize $23 million in assets of radical party Batasuna; he has argued that Batasuna acts on ETA's orders or to finance its attacks; government's new actions go well beyond its previous antiterrorism stance, marking end to policy of accommodation with more moderate Basque nationalists that Spanish leaders have generally followed since 1975; photo; graph from Spain's interior minister showing numbers of killings from ETA violence each year, totaling 812 since 1968 (M)

headline: A Top AOL Manager Has Left Company
abstract: David M Colburn, one of top deal makers at America Online, left job last week; is unclear whether he resigned or was fired; Myer Berlow, who ran AOL's interactive marketing department, has ceased day-to-day involvement in company, although he still technically remains employee (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen drops against US dollar after Standard & Poor's Corp says Japanese government is not doing enough to revive country's economy; yen settles in New York at 118.57 from 117.69 (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Charges Of Bribery
abstract: Leaders of South Korea's opposition Conservative Party accuse government of paying bribe of nearly $400 million to North Korea to persuade its leader, Kim Jong Il, to play host to South Korea Pres Kim Dae Jung in June 2000 (S)

headline: Governments have not yet figured out how to cooperate : Indonesian smoke is choking Asia
abstract: SINGAPORE:—  A plan recently unveiled by the Singapore government promises to give this prosperous island-state a green future, including at least 310 days of clean air per year by 2012.

headline: Researcher Cuts Sales Forecast For Computers Through 2003
abstract: International Data Corp researchers cut personal computer market forecasts for both 2002 and 2003 to reflect weakening demand among busineses and consumers; expect global PC shipments to reach only 135.5 million in 2002, gain of 1.1 percent, and to grow 8.4 percent in 2003 (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Network Associates Alters McAfee Bid
abstract: Network Associates Inc extends its $131.2 million offer for rest of McAfee.com after less than 5 percent of shareholders of computer-security company accept bid; graph (S)

headline: Getting There, the Old-Fashioned Way
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper longs for days when paper maps were standard, and finds them available at AAA online and other purveyors; contends online driving directions do not measure up to old-fashioned maps; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Profit At Bank
abstract: Bank of China says first-half pretax profit fell 37 percent; bank earned $7.02 billion yuan ($848 million) pas pretax profit fell 79 percent, to 961 million yuan; profit from overseas rose 6 percent, to $733 million (S)

headline: Krishan Kant, 75, Vice President Of India and Advocate of Rights
abstract: India Vice Pres Krishan Kant, who fought against both British rule and Indira Gandhi's suspension of democracy, dies at 75; photo (S)

headline: A Talk on Corporate Integrity Heard in the Street and the Suite
abstract: Chief executives widely praise Pres Bush's speech, saying it would help restore confidence in American business; but many Wall Streeters and those who run large pension funds that own billions of dollars in stocks express disappointment Bush did not offer more specific proposals to clean up corporate wrongdoing; two points of view represent competing visions of current scandal over corporate behavior: executives who feel their credibility is at stake and investors angered by cascading series of financial losses and string of accounting failures; institutional investors feel more sweeping changes in boardroom rules and accounting oversight are needed, while others, mainly business leaders, say they oppose any move toward greater regulation; Felix Rohatyn, longtime Wall Street financier, says he was hoping for more commitment to regulatory reform and to corporate governance reform; United Technologies Corp chief executive George David says speech was needed because people are losing confidence; Bethlehem Steel Corp chief executive Robert S Miller says Bush struck nice bipartisan balance; Sealed Air Corp chief executive William Hickey suggests jail time for executives who rob shareholders; Thermo Electron Corp chief executive Richard F Syron says companies should put as much emphasis on traits like integrity and honesty as they do on technical skills when selecting executives; Albertson's chief executive Larry Johnston praises Bush's speech; California Public Employees' Retirement System chief executive James E Burton says his concern is whether speech was just more political rhetoric or whether it was truly call for action; Council of Institutional Investors executive director Sarah Teslik expresses disappointment; Corporate Library executive Robert A G Monks says nonsense of not calling stock option an expense should be stopped; Peter G Peterson, chairman of Blackstone Group, calls speech 'too little, too late and too general'; Goldman Sachs chief executive Henry M Paulson Jr says Bush is serious about driving abuses out of system; Morgan Stanley chief executive Philip J Purcell says corporate wrongdoing is 'not systemic at all'; Citigroup chief executive Sanford I Weill praises Bush; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Trial On Racist Attack Starts
abstract: Five young men go on trial in Moscow on charges of leading racist rampage at city market, in which three people died (S)

headline: Seeking Perfection And a Finish Line
abstract: Charles Herold reviews video games Stuntman and Freekstyle; photos (M)

headline: Private Sector; Chrysler's Numbers? He'd Back Them
abstract: Dieter Zetsche, chief executive of DaimlerChrysler's Chrysler unit, says he would personally certify Chrysler's accounting; parent company, based in Germany, is not required by new United States rules to get chief executive's certification; photo (M)

headline: The Need for Cooperation Remains an 'Old Truth' In a Changed World
abstract: Article in series Perspectives interviews Christopher Patten, European Union's commissioner for external relations, on Sept 11 terrorist attacks and their effect on public life and policy; he says to justify action against Iraq, and to get cooperation from allies, Bush administration must provide evidence that Pres Saddam Hussein is greater threat to world now than he has been for last decade; says Washington must also give assurances that it is prepared to stay the course to keep new government in Iraq stable; says he worries about effect of Iraq war on international coalition against terrorism, because it might open up gulf between Muslim world and west; sees three dominant issues arising: how rest of world relates to extraordinary power of US, whether 'global rule book' about military intervention in sovereign states must be adjusted, and Islamic and other fundamentalism that regards modern world as threat to their values; photo; biographical data; excerts from interview (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Accounting board proposes a new rule on a hot topic: options.
abstract: Financial Accounting Standards Board says it will propose requiring that values of stock options be disclosed in footnotes of every quarterly financial statement filed with Securities and Exchange Commission; those valuations have been buried deep in footnotes of annual reports, with no quarterly update required; some analysts expect companies will reduce number of options issues, particularly to more junior employees, to make earnings look better (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Unemployment Rises
abstract: Seasonally adjusted unemployment rate in Hong Kong increased to 7.7 percent for three-month period from April through June, compared with 7.4 percent for March through May, as Hong Kong economy remained stagnant (S)

headline: Some fear a global recession if the shooting starts in Iraq : War talk shakes up oil markets
abstract: LONDON:—  The intensifying U.S. drumbeat for a war in Iraq is driving up oil prices, shaking already fragile confidence in world equity markets and could, some analysts say, tip the global economy back into recession if the shooting starts.

headline: DataBank; A Rally, Then a Fall to a 5th Week of Losses
abstract: Summary of week's trading activity in stock markets; charts; tables (M)

headline: ICAHN WILL BUY $362 MILLION IN DEBT FROM XO HOLDERS
abstract: Financier Carl C Icahn says holders of $362 million in senior secured loans of XO Communications Inc have accepted his offer to buy debt of bankrupt company; Icahn says purchase will bring his onwership to $947 million of $1 billion in face value of bank debt; Icahn comments (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Gregg Geider, executive vice president and managing director at Thomas Ferguson Associates, Parsippany, N.J., was promoted to group managing director.

headline: Rudiger Dornbusch, 60, an Economist of Outspoken Views
abstract: Rudiger Dornbusch, economist at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, dies at age 60; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Billionaire To Buy Retail Chain
abstract: British retail chain Arcadia's board will recommend shareholders accept offer to be acquired by billionaire Philip Green for $1.2 billion (772 million pounds) (S)

headline: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE IMPACT -- Brokers' Lament; No One Wants To Buy Stocks
abstract: Stockbrokers say problem is not that too many people are selling stock, it is that nobody wants to buy in light of corporate scandals; say clients are becoming more distrustful of, and more concerned about, fairness of market; Legg Mason financial adviser Jim Hartman, and Prudential Securities senior vice president Charles Andriole comment (M)

headline: REGULATORS ALLOW RELIANT ENERGY TO RESTRUCTURE
abstract: Reliant Energy Inc, biggest electricity company in Texas, says federal regulators approved new holding company structure, step needed to complete spinoff of Reliant Resources, its energy-trading arm (S)

headline: What's Wrong at Amtrak
abstract: Letter from John P Tiernan comments on June 16 article about Amtrak and its financing

headline: Arafat Calls U.S. Meetings 'Very Positive'; Sharon Sees 'Trick'
abstract: Yasir Arafat says meetings between his representatives and American officials in Washington last week were 'very positive,' then quickly says that Israel is not looking for peace; Prime Min Ariel Sharon charges that Palestinians' provisional agreement to Israeli security plan is 'a trick'; security plan, put forward by Defense Min Benyamin Ben-Eliezer, comes under fire from several Israeli ministers on right; plan calls for tentative pullback of Israeli troops in Gaza as test of whether Palestinians can stop attacks on Israel; talks have broken down, with Palestinians accusing Israelis of reneging on agreement to include Bethlehem in initial pullback and Israelis saying Palestinians are insisting on Ramallah; seven of eight Palestinian cities in West Bank are now under control of Israeli troops; spate of violence continues on ground; map (M)

headline: MGM Mirage Seeks to Lure The Gamblers Of Cyberspace
abstract: MGM Mirage plans to start Internet casino, first United States casino to offer games of chance to gamblers through their computers; bets from residents of US, where it is illegal to offer gambling online, will be refused; multiple organizations will scrutinize new endeavor for legal compliance, moral effect and competitive consequences (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Province Won't Appeal Same-Sex Ruling
abstract: Ontario provincial government says it will not appeal court ruling that province must extend marriage rights to same-xex couples (S)

headline: Citing a Tight Bond Market, G.E. Makes a Loan to a Buyer
abstract: General Electric Co lends $235 million to Francisco Partners, which is purchasing GE's electronic commerce unit Global eXchange Services for $800 million, because money is not available from bond market; will profit $300 million from sale (M)

headline: Iraq Is Defiant as G.O.P. Leader Opposes Attack
abstract: Rep Dick Armey, House majority leader, warns that unprovoked attack against Iraq would violate international law and undermine world support for Pres Bush's goal of ousting Saddam Hussein; Armey's remarks are most prominent sign of Congressional unease that administration is moving rapidly toward war against Iraq; remarks are especially striking coming from leading conservative and staunch Bush ally; White House has little reaction to Armey's comments, which come on same day that Hussein delivers television speech warning that 'forces of evil' would 'die in disgraceful failure' if Iraq is attacked; Pres Bush has pledged to consult with Congress befoe ordering any invasion, but he has not promised to ask for vote authorizing attack; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising account changes noted (S)

headline: Private Sector; Joining Poorer Brethren in a Moneyed Club
abstract: New Federal Reserve governor Susan Schmidt Bies owns assets worth as much as $23 million, making her wealthiest of group (M)

headline: Interview With Donald H. Rumsfeld
abstract: Following is an interview with Donald H. Rumsfeld, the secretary of defense, reflecting on events since the Sept. 11 attacks. Remarks that were not intended for publication are omitted.

headline: Europe Lists Hundreds of U.S. Exports That May Face Tariffs
abstract: European Commission compiles list of hundreds of American products on which it may impose retaliatory tariffs if US refuses to eliminate tax break for American exporters; list is heavily weighed to penalize American farm exports; also singles out many categories of clothing and textiles and takes especially heavy aim at iron and steel products, industry in which Europe is already battling American tariffs; World Trade Organization has already ruled that US has violated international trade rules with tax breaks that favor foreign sales subsidies of American manufacturing companies; new list covers products worth $10 billion to $15 billion; European officials say they will not impose any sanctions immediately, and they are hoping that Congress will pass legislation that repeals or at least rewrites export tax breaks in ways that do not violate international trade rules (M)

headline: Bosses Are Bad (Except Mine)
abstract: Survey of 659 working adults by Gallup Organization reveals that most chief executives are still trusted by their employees (S)

headline: What's in a Name? A Good Bit, Really
abstract: Federal government is signaling more welcoming attitude toward idea of 'trusted traveler' program that would allow frequent fliers to be profiled in registry, and to use identification card to avoid many of extra security searches at airports; Adm James M Loy, head of Transportation Security Administration, testified before Senate committee last week and spoke of his plan 'to bring common sense into aviation security area' with 'aggressive steps to reduce hassle factor at airports'; John C Hermansen, founder and chief executive of intelligence company called Language Analysis Systems, is working with Transportation Security Administration to devise workable trusted traveler system that manages to accommodate strong objection to any form of ethnic or religious profiling that has been hallmark of federal government's approach to airport security; drawing (M)

headline: Grubman Attended 10 Board Meetings
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney, Citigroup unit, tells House committee that analyst Jack B Grubman attended at least 10 meetings of boards of directors of companies he rated for investors; companies included WorldCom, Qwest Communications International, Global Crossing and Broadwing; investigators may subpoena more data to help determine whether Grubman or Salomon used shares of sought-after initial public offerings to reward executives for hiring firm as investment banker; photo (M)

headline: 'Retreat' Seems to Fit Mood Of Media's Big Gathering
abstract: Mood is somber at annual retreat of top communications industry executives held by investment banker Herbert Allen in Sun Valley, Idaho; topics of conversation include cash squeeze gripping media industry and new scrutiny of its accounting techniques; falling stock prices mean that top executives' jobs are no longer so secure and atmosphere is rife with gossip; some industry executives comment; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Elan Shares Fall
abstract: Shares of Irish drug maker Elan fall 19 percent after company says it might have to write down about half of its market value; graph (S)

headline: Enron Trader Had a Year To Boast of, Even If . . .
abstract: John D Arnold, 27-year-old star of Enron Corp's energy trading desk, had kind of year in 2001 that traders dare only dream about; Arnold booked $750 million in profits by trading natural gas contracts, profits that flowed directly to Enron's bottom line; trading experts describe size of Arnold's market gains as astonishing; competitors say they are improbable; Arnold says he made most of his money doing something that Enron always insisted it did not do: speculating on direction of energy prices; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Buyer for Hospitals Agrees To Change Its Practices  Under pressure from Congress, Premier, a company that helps about a quarter of the nation's hospitals buy drugs, medical devices and other supplies, has agreed to change the way it does business.    Premier has agreed to contract with more companies, stop investing in supply companies and limit how much money it accepts from companies that receive contracts. Negotiators are trying to reach a similar agreement with another buying group, Novation. [Page A1.]

headline: AIR POWER ALONE CAN'T DEFEAT IRAQ, RUMSFELD ASSERTS
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld holds air power alone cannot destroy all of Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, including mobile biological-weapons laboratories, news conference; holds Saddam Hussein has concealed his weapons programs in ways that would make inspections ineffective, even if he agrees to let inspectors return; makes it clear that Bush administration has not settled on specific plan for unseating Hussein and eliminating his arsenal; has stepped up his drive to warn of arsenal, strategy some say is meant to lay groundwork for possible war with Iraq; Gen Joseph Hoar, set to testify at Senate hearings on Iraq, expresses wariness about using military force before other avenues are exhausted, phone interview; growing number of lawmakers from both parties are voicing concern that Bush administration is heading precipitiously toward war (M)

headline: Russia Indicates It Might Reconsider Iran Nuclear Plants Plan
abstract: Russia indicated today for the first time that it was prepared to reconsider plans to build nuclear reactors in Iran.

headline: New Study on Antiterror Spending Is Fodder for Rival Camps
abstract: Congressional Budget Office study finds government has spent nearly $37 billion in response to Sept 11 attacks and is on track to spend more than 10 times that much to counter terrorism over next decade; Democrats seize on figures as evidence that new spending on security means that government faces deficits and painful tradeoffs because Pres Bush's tax cuts have consumed so much of projected budget surplus; Bush administration officials say figures buttress their case that Congress, and Democrats in particular, must do more to keep spending on nondefense programs in check to avert uncontrolled growth in deficit; chart (M)

headline: SWS GROUP DISCLOSES $21 MILLION IN VARIOUS CHARGES
abstract: SWS Group, which operates Internet brokerage firm Mydiscountbroker.com, says it spent $21.7 million to shut down poor-performing division, settle lawsuits and write down value of some investments (S)

headline: IRAQ SAID TO PLAN TANGLING THE U.S. IN STREET FIGHTING
abstract: Pentagon officials and former US government experts say Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq will try to compensate for his armed forces' glaring weaknesses by raising specter of urban warfare if Bush administration moves to launch military strike; say Iraq has already started military preparations in anticipation of military strike; forces have been digging defensive positions for military equipment around Baghdad; have been moving air defense units around country and dispersing army units in field to make them less vulnerable to surprise attack; current and fomer US military officers express confidence US will ultimately triumph, but differ about how difficult military campaign involving urban warfare would be; photos; map (M)

headline: A Development in Security Software
abstract: Group of Bell Labs computer researchers will describe new network security software intended to protect personal digital information and increase security when connecting to remote computers and Web sites (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Equity Offerings Scheduled for Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      LipoScience, Raleigh, N.C., an initial offering of 5.7 million shares. Merrill Lynch.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Accounting Snarl For Banker
abstract: Jean-Claude Trichet, governor of Bank of France and leading candidate to become next president of European Central Bank, is ordered by French judge to stand trial on charges of accounting fraud; Trichet is accused of helping Credit Lyonnais hide losses in early 1990's and trial would jeopardize his chances of getting position at central bank; Trichet was head of French Treasury in early 1990's and served as government representative on bank's board; Paris prosecutor's office, which recommends that Trichet be cleared, has five days to appeal decision (S)

headline: Qwest Communications Under Criminal Investigation by U.S.
abstract: Burdens confronting Qwest Communications International increases when company discloses it is under criminal investigation by Justice Department; subject of investigation is undisclosed; says it will cooperate fully (M)

headline: The Mundane Whiteboard Gets Its Own Internet-Era Makeover
abstract: Smart Technologies develops system aimed at creating easy, instant record of whiteboard presentations and preparing them for posting on Internet; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: MobilCom Buyout
abstract: MobilCom's former chief executive Gerhard Schmid expects Germany's securities regulator to order France Telecom to buy shares of MobilCom that it does not own; Schmidt, who holds 49.9 percent stake in MobilCom, says he and minority shareholders are entitled to at least 14.50 euros per share, 90-day average price on June 21, day he was ousted; photo (S)

headline: Executive Life; Men Put Plastic Surgery on the Résumé
abstract: Some men elect to have plastic surgery performed to make them more competitive in executive job market; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; When Volatile Is the Word, Traders Scramble for Footing
abstract: Summer on Wall Street has been one of unusual volatility; key measure of market volatility surges in late July to its highest level since 1987 crash and has been sustained for a period not recorded since after Sept 11 attacks and collapse of Long-Term Capital in 1998; to some, extraordinary volatility is indicator that market will soon turn; professional day traders welcome stock market volatility; photos; graph (M)

headline: Secret Court Weighs Wiretaps
abstract: US Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court of Review, nation's most secret appellate court meets, apparently for first time in its 24-year history, to consider request from Justice Department for broad new wiretap powers; hearing is disclosed after Congressional staff members and civil liberties groups complain about being denied access as participants at hearing (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: UNIVERSAL EXPRESS INC., New York, said its subsidiary, Virtual Bellhop, a door-to-door transporter of checked baggage for airline travelers, would form a marketing partnership with Travel & Leisure Elite Traveler, a 65,000-member club and a brand extension of Travel & Leisure Magazine.

headline: Milosevic Says Srebrenica Was a Plot to Frame the Serbs
abstract: Slobodan Milosevic presents in court his long-held theory that destruction of Yugoslavia was Western conspiracy, The Hague; it is novel explanation of unfolding of massacre at Srebrenica, worst bloodbath in Europe since World War II; as many as 7,000 unarmed Muslim men and boys were killed in Muslim enclave of Srebrenica in July 1995; all the evidence points to Bosnia Serb army, Serbian police and their paramilitary helpers as perpetrators; but Milosevic contends people really responsible for mass killings were French intelligence operatives, Muslim officials from Bosnia and mercenaries (M)

headline: WYNDHAM IS SELLING 13 HOTELS TO CUT DEBT
abstract: Wyndham International Inc, hotel company controlled by investors Thomas Lee and Leon Black, agrees to sell 13 hotel properties in US to Westbrook Hotel Partners IV for about $447 million to reduce its debt (S)

headline: The Crash in Chechnya: Russia's Gaping Wound
abstract: Analysis: catastrophic loss of Russian military helicopter exposes all that has gone wrong with Moscow's war in Chechnya and potential political consequences of Pres Vladimir V Putin's inability to end it; at very least, crash has shattered Russia's efforts to portray situation in Chechnya as stable, if not mormal, and has resurrected lingering doubts about strategy for winning conflict that increasingly seems unwinable; there has been little public or political debate in Russia about war; crash may make war impossible to ignore (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Steel Growth Possible; FRANCE: Drug Maker Drops Treatment; ITALY: Slow Economic Growth;.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: SRI LANKA: Optimism At Peace Talks; KASHMIR: Pro-Indian Editor Shot;.

headline: E.D.S. Says Profit Rose Despite WorldCom Ties
abstract: Electronic Data Systems reports earnings rose slightly in second quarter even after it set aside $101 million to cover bills that may never be paid by WorldCom Inc; net income rose to $316 million from $300 million year earlier; revenue rose 7.5 percent, to $5.48 billion from $5.09 billion; chairman-chief executive Richard H Brown comments (M)

headline: On Mexico Visit, Pope Will Find Divided Catholic Country
abstract: It has been 23 years since John Paul II visited Mexico on his first foreign trip as pope, and now he is to return for what many here quietly consider a final farewell.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Major Stock Gauges Plunge As 4-Month Rout Continues  Stocks continued their plunge in a four-month rout that has sent the major indexes below their lows of last September and to levels that, if they hold, will make this the worst year for the market since the 1970's.    The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is at its lowest level since June 1997 and is down 44.5 percent since its high in March 2000. The S.& P. fell 33.80 points, or 3.8 percent, to 847.76. The S.& P. is down 26.2 percent for the year. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 390.23 points, or 4.6 percent, to 8,019.26. The worst performer remains the Nasdaq, which dropped 37.80 points, or 2.8 percent, to 1,319.15. It is down 32.4 percent for the year. [Page A1.]

headline: Tighter Rules For Options Fall Victim To Lobbying
abstract: Powerful business lobbying groups, including Stock Option Coalition, triumph over congressional efforts to tighten rules for options given as compensation to corporate executives; current proposals to overhaul securities and accounting laws contain no mention of stock options; photo (M)

headline: Hip-Hop Transforms Radio As Stations Seek Ad Dollars
abstract: Number of radio stations around nation have shifted from playing R&B oldies to hip-hop format, which has greater appeal to younger listeners advertisers increasingly covet; sharply defined hip-hop stations began emerging in mid-1990's and now number about 150; 23 cities have two competing hip-hop stations; photos (M)

headline: Israeli Forces Enter Nablus in Reprisal Raid
abstract: Penning Nablus with scores of tanks, bulldozers and armored vehicles, Israel sent soldiers today in pursuit of explosives laboratories and suspected extremists.

headline: On the Far Side of Day, Some Find Greater Opportunities to Shine
abstract: People who work night and overnight shifts find it rich opportunity to advance their careers; Labor Department reports that 9.7 million Americans work full-time evening or night shifts, up from 8.9 million in 1997, and phenomenon is significantly more widespread in Northeast than nationally; photo (M)

headline: Vote to Reopen Secret German Files
abstract: German Parliament's lower house passes law that may open East German secret police archives to researchers; approval by upper house would give archivist Marianne Birthler power to decide case by case if public interest outweighs individual privacy rights (S)

headline: BLAIR IS CONFIDENT OF TOUGH U.N. LINE ON IRAQI WEAPONS
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain expresses confidence of securing UN approval for tough new Security Council resolution on Iraqi weapons; says in BBC interview that Pres Saddam Hussein will be disarmed, one way or another; refuses to rule out acting along with US if UN fails to endorse military strikes against Iraq; signals London might be willing to soften terms of draft currently being circulated in Paris and Moscow; notes, in particular, France's proposal for two separate Security Council resolutions, with only second threatening use of force; photo (M)

headline: Treasuries Dip as Fear of Attack Eases
abstract: US Treasury prices fall; price of 10-year note falls 15/32, to 102 18/32; yield rises to 4.06 percent from 4 percent; price of 30-year bond falls 23/32, to 107 17/32; yield rises to 4.88 percent from 4.84 percent; graph on Freddie Mac yields; chart on key US interest rates (S)

headline: F.D.A. Tells Barr to Delay Cancer Drug
abstract: Food and Drug Administration says Barr Laboratories must delay introducing its own version of AstraZeneca's Tamoxifen cancer drug; Barr says it will sue agency; Barr sells Tamoxifen through agreement with AstraZeneca and had hoped to introduce its own formula on Aug 20; ruling will delay that to February 2003 (S)

headline: In Cheney's Words: The Administration Case for Removing Saddam Hussein
abstract: Excerpts from speech by Vice Pres Dick Cheney before Veterans of Foreign Wars justifying military action against Iraq (L)

headline: Moving a CD Collection Into Your Hip Pocket
abstract: Q. I have a few hundred compact discs of classical music. Is there a portable device on which all these CD's can be stored and indexed? How much sound quality is lost when you convert a song from a compact disc to the MP3 format?    A. A variety of portable digital music players have enough capacity to store your music collection. These players usually have a 5- to 20-gigabyte hard drive for storing songs that have been copied on your computer from CD's into a digital audio file format like MP3.

headline: Equity Offerings Planned This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      NN Inc., Johnson City, Tenn., 6.5 million shares. McDonald Investments.

headline: For Defector, A Lonely Death Brings an End To a Life Alone
abstract: Edward Lee Howard, former CIA agent who fled to Soviet Union in mid-1980's, led lonely life in Russia that included, in his later years, running insurance company; Igor Prelin, former KBG colonel, says Howard was alone at his dacha when he died earlier this month, at age of 50; says he longed for wife and child he left behind in US when he escaped to Russia after his spying for Moscow became known (M)

headline: Justice Dept. Investigating AOL's Accounting
abstract: AOL Time Warner said today that the Department of Justice had begun a criminal investigation into accounting at its AOL division, following a civil investigation begun by the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Jobless Rate Falls
abstract: Hong Kong's seasonally adjusted unemployment rate unexpectedly falls to 7.6 percent, June-Aug, from 7.8 percent in three months ended in July (S)

headline: A Senior Palestinian Official Urges End to Suicide Attacks
abstract: Abdel Razak Yehiyeh, Palestinian minister who has been negotiating cease-fire with Israel, denounces suicide bombings as 'murders for no reason,' interview in Israeli newspaper; says he has told all Palestinian factions to stop attacks because they hurt Palestinian cause; admits neither Hamas and Islamic Jihad, nor radical wing of Yasir Arafat's Fatah have agreed to end terrorism; Muhammad Dahlan, Arafat's top security adviser, predicts current violence will end in peace, Israeli newspaper interview; photos (M)

headline: Neiman Marcus Earnings Beat Expectations
abstract: Neiman Marcus Group reports fiscal fourth-quarter profit of $5.32 million compared with loss of $20.6 million year earlier; sales in period ended Aug 3 rose 4.8 percent, to $666.4 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Parents Of Truants Face Jail
abstract: New Irish law intended to prevent excessive truancy requires schools to inform new Education Welfare Board if students are absent for 20 days in year and sets fines and jail terms as last resort for parents of truants (S)

headline: Bronfman Joins The Board Of Fandango
abstract: Edgar Bronfamn Jr joins board of Fandango, online movie ticket company (S)

headline: U.S. Peacekeepers Given Year's Immunity From New Court
abstract: UN Security Council, ending weeks-long confrontation with intense closed-door negotiations, unanimously adopts resolution that effectively gives American peacekeepers year's exemption from prosecution by new International Criminal Court; also renews mandates of UN peacekeeping missions in Bosnia and Prevlaka, Croatia (M)

headline: India Freezes Sale of State-Owned Shares
abstract: Widening rift in Indian cabinet has disrupted, at least temporarily, ambitious program to reduce government's pervasive involvement in business and economy by selling many state-owned companies; coalition government of Prime Min Atal Behari Vajpayee announces three-month freeze on sales of strategic stakes in state-owned companies while process is reviewed; pending sales immediately affected by freeze are Hindustan Petroleum and Bharat Petroleum; bidding for two petroleum companies was expected to attract multinational companies; photo (M)

headline: F.B.I. AND MILITARY UNITE IN PAKISTAN TO HUNT AL QAEDA
abstract: Pakistan has become laboratory for how American power could be used to combat terror; American law enforcement agencies are working with American military in Pakistan in hunt for Al Qaeda fighers who fled sanctuaries in Afghanistan and hope to revive their group; FBI agents are helping local police in Pakistani cities to break up what senior American intelligence and law enforcement officials regard as depleted but still dangerous network that carried out deadly attacks against Westerners in Karachi and Islamabad in recent weeks; never before have traditionally independent military and law enforcement organizations worked so much in concert; similar, if smaller, American operations appear to be unfolding in Philippines and Yemen; photos; map (L)

headline: Little Sympathy for Vivendi's Ousted Chief (a 'Glutton,' and Overpaid)
abstract: France turns savagely against Jean-Marie Messier, former Vivendi Universal chairman and chief executive; he is called glutton in Parliament and portrayed as crybaby in editorial cartoons (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Helicopter Toll At 117
abstract: Death toll in crash last week of Russian military helicopter near main Russian base in southern republic of Chechnya rises to 117 as contradictory reports about cause of crash emerges (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Surviving A Telecom Slump
abstract: Ericsson says 30 billion kronor ($3.2 billion) it is raising in share sale will be enough to help it survive current slump in demand for telephone equipment; is selling new shares to existing investors at 3.80 kronor to pay back debt and pay for severance packages; chief executive Kurt Hellstroem comments; photo (S)

headline: North Koreans in China Now Live in Fear of Dragnet
abstract: March dash by North Korean asylum seekers into Spanish Embassy, Beijing, while focusing attention on plight of North Korean refugees, has spurred ferocious Chinese crackdown; hundreds of thousands of North Korean refugees who remain illegally in China now face high level of scrutiny, detention and deportation; measures reflect China's effort to discourage further asylum seekers and placate North Korea; have shut down crucial source of food for North Korea's hard-hit northeastern provinces, since migrants frequently send food and money home; map; photo (M)

headline: Merged Hospitals Gain Both Power and Critics
abstract: Merged hospitals are gaining power and critics; discontent with managed care and creation of large networks have given hospitals tremendous leverage; in seeking better prices, they are ones threatening to drop health plans, risking disruption of medical care for thousands of patients; Federal Trade Commission, which has little success blocking mergers, is going back to look at some merged hospitals; regulators are examining merger in Illinois that took place two years ago at Evanston Northwestern Healthcare; state attorneys general are also re-examining some mergers; Massachusetts General Hospital's merger with Brigham and Women's Mass General resulted in about $250 million in cost savings; employers are increasingly worried about power of Mass General and its parent system Partners HealthCare, created in 1994; Mass General's president Dr James J Mongan will become chief executive of Partners next year; graphs; photo (M)

headline: U.S. in Criminal Inquiry on Metabolife Product
abstract: Justice Department is conducting criminal investigation into Metabolife International, leading manufacturer of herbal stimulant ephedra, to determine whether executives lied about what thty knew about safety of substance; Food and Drug Administration Deputy Comr Lester M Crawford says agency has asked Justice Department to pursue investigation because after years of seeking company reports on consumer complaints Metabolife has repeatedly refused to cooperate with FDA; in 1998, Michael Ellis, president of company at time, said in statement to FDA that company never received one notice from consumer that any serious adverse health event has occurred because of ingestion of Metabolife 356; company spokeswoman Jan Strode says Ellis has not made any false statements to FDA; Metabolife says it will release its record of consumer complaints; contends it has about 13,000 complaints, including some dated before Ellis's statement; about 80 mentioned serious injury or death, and 100 to 200 involved hospitalization (M)

headline: Senators Question Powell on Arms-Cut Treaty
abstract: Members of Senate Foreign Relations Committee from both parties question Sec Colin Powell sharply about effectiveness of recent Treaty of Moscow, which commits US and Russia to deep cuts in nuclear arsenals over coming decade, but offers no guidelines on verification; Powell says conditions would only clutter treaty (S)

headline: Al Qaeda Money Trail Runs From Saudi Arabia to Spain
abstract: Spanish and American investigators believe that hundreds of thousands of dollars flowed from Saudi Arabia into accounts of Spanish companies that were used as conduits for money to Al Qaeda and other radical Islamist groups; officials in Spain and United States say they know very little about who in Saudia Arabia might have provided funds sent to Spain; photos of Mohamed Zouaydi and Ghasoub al-Abrash Galyoun, Syrian-born businessmen accused of helping finance Al Qaeda (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Leader Says India Lies About Kashmir
abstract: Pakistan Pres Pervez Musharraf dismisses Indian assertions of high voter turnout in first stage of state assembly elections in Indian-held Kashmir; contends only 10 percent of voters cast ballots in first round on Sept 16; India says 47.6 percent voted; photo (S)

headline: Interview With Bob Graham
abstract: Following is the full text of an interview with Senator Bob Graham, the Florida Democrat who is the chairman of the Intelligence Committee, as recorded by The New York Times:.

headline: On an Anniversary, Chinese Leader Tells Hong Kong to Be Loyal
abstract: Pres Jiang Zemin of China delivers tough speech in Hong Kong to mark fifth anniversary of its transfer from British to Chinese rule; urges residents to be more loyal to 'motherland' (S)

headline: Debate Is Shifting on Chemical Commonly Found in Food
abstract: Weeks remain before publication of first study showing that starchy foods contain acrylamide, potential carcinogen, yet much of once-acrimonious debate over its appearance in staples like French fries, bread and potato chips has already been quelled; food industry acknowledges that no longer is there much doubt that chemical, long known as industrial agent in manufacture of plastics and adhesives, somehow forms in certain carbohydrates after they are baked or fried at high temperatures; Swedish study, to be published in two weeks, finds high levels of acrylamide in fried foods; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Having Too Much Fun to Leave
abstract: Rumors circulate that General Motors vice chairman and all-around car czar Robert A Lutz, 70, formerly with Chrysler, may remain working longer than three years he had committed to; automotive projects he instigated remain in pipeline; photo (M)

headline: Destitution Seen for Palestinians
abstract: The senior U.N. official in the region on Thursday painted a devastating picture of the Palestinian economy in which a large majority was "scrambling to survive" on less than $2 a day.

headline: Record Labels Try to Force Internet Servers to Block Music Site
abstract: Group of 13 record companies, testing new tactic to combat online piracy, asks Federal court to order four major Internet service providers to block Americans from viewing Listen4ever, China-based Web site that offers thousands of copyrighted songs free of charge (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: NORTH KOREA: Warm Words Follow Bullets; INDONESIA: Taking Aim At Rebels;.

headline: MediaTalk; Lou Dobbs to Weigh In As Regular in U.S. News
abstract: US News & World Report will carry columns by Lou Dobbs on money and politics and Dr Bernadine Healy on health; photo (M)

headline: In Blast Police Call Accident, Muscovites See Terrorist Hand
abstract: Russian officials say they suspect that explosion that killed eight residents of apartment building in northeast Moscow was caused by natural gas leak; many Muscovites are openly doubtful of official explanation, underscoring deepening distrust of authorities and growing suspicion of outsiders; blast was so powerful that it awakened memories of series of apartment bombings that killed more than 300 people in Russia in 1999 and led to second war in Chechnya (M)

headline: Yousuf Karsh, Photographer of the Famous, Is Dead at 93
abstract: Yousuf Karsh, photographer of famous and powerful, dies at age 93; photos (M)

headline: Argentina Says It Will Skip International Loan Payment
abstract: Argentina's Economy Min Roberto Lavagna says his country will no longer use its diminishing foreign reserves to pay back loans from International Monetary Fund and other lenders and will thus miss at least one payment due in October, move that pushes Argentina closer to formal break with those bodies; says government will not renounce its policy of social assistance, even if it means further delaying negotiations with IMF that have been bogged down for months; IMF director Horst Kohler says IMF wants to reach deal with Argentina (M)

headline: Interview With Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg
abstract: Following are excerpts from an interview with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Production Halted
abstract: Daewoo Motor Co has stopped making cars at its three Korean plants after its leading supplier Korea Delphi Automotive System stopped shipping parts ahead of boycott planned for Aug 29 by all 191 companies that make parts for its vehicles (S)

headline: Staking Out Space in a Hand-Held for Higher-Fidelity Sound
abstract: Matshushita Electric is working to develop technology that will allow for better sound in smaller space; electrodynamic technology, which is what is currently used in almost all sound systems, described and differences between it and Matsushita's new concept explained; photo (M)

headline: Rapid-Reaction Force Gets Support From NATO Ministers
abstract: NATO defense ministers gave broad support today to American proposals for a rapid-reaction force.

headline: D'AGOSTINO TO BUY BRITISH-OWNED MARKETS IN NORTHEAST
abstract: Marks & Spencer Group sells its Kings Super Markets chain in US to D'Agostino Supermarkets for $160 million (S)

headline: After Attack on Temple, Indian City Remains Quiet
abstract: Ahmedabad and most parts of India's Gujarat State remain quiet days after gunmen's siege of Hindu temple complex and battle with police forces ends with 31 dead, including 3 police commandos; documents on attackers' bodies suggest they were Muslims seeking vengeance for killings of Muslims last February by Hindu mobs, as police stood by and did nothing; Hindu mobs in turn were seeking vengeance for death of Hindu activists in train car set alight by Muslims; Police Comr K S Kaushik, who was not in charge in February, says he is determined to prevent further violence (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Accessories Resource Team, Charlotte, N.C., the association of decorative accessory makers and retailers, to the Coastal Group, New York, as its first agency of record.

headline: S.E.C. to Consider Disclosure Of Mutual Funds' Proxy Votes
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission will consider proposal that would require mutual funds to revel how they vote shares in corporate proxy contests; commissioners are scheduled to take up proposed rule on Sept 19 that would force investment companies to report their proxy voting records to SEC and make information available to shareholders; action comes as SEC is trying to restore investor confidence in wake of accounting scandals; Morningstar Inc managing director Don Phillips comments; SEC is also scheduled to consider other rules related to mutual fund industry, including requiring mutual funds and other registered management investment companies to disclose policies and procedures they use to determine how to vote proxies involving portfolio securities (M)

headline: To avoid looking exploitive, a great many big marketers will not run advertising tomorrow.
abstract: More marketers, concerned about being considered crass or exploitive, have decided against running advertising of any kind on Sept 11, whether or not it would appear during coverage commemorating terrorist attacks; advertising will be sparser than usual in media outlets from television and radio to magazines and newspapers (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Battered From Above And Below
abstract: Typhoon Sinlaku, with winds of 90 miles per hour, pounds northeastern Taiwan (S)

headline: Executive Life; Squeezing Yourself Out (for the Company)
