abstract: Former ONI Systems chief executive Hugh C Martin comments on negotiating deal to have fiber optic company absorbed by corporate partner Ciena Corp, only to realize move would cost him his job; photo (M)

headline: Handling of Floods Lifts Schröder's Standing in Polls
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's steady leadership during recent floods in Germany helps lift his standing in polls, although he still lags behind his conservative challenger, Edmund Stoiber, with elections only a month away; Stoiber benefits from perception that he would do better job that Schroder on the economy; photo (M)

headline: US Airways Puts New Terms On Nonrefundable Tickets
abstract: US Airways is imposing more stringent conditions on most of its nonrefundable tickets, including requiring passengers to buy another ticket if they miss their original flight and want to take later one; passengers until Aug 27 could get on later flight as long as seats were available and they paid change fee; now, on flights originating in US, Caribbean and Canada, they will have to buy new ticket; also announces that it will bar passengers with most nonrefundable tickets from flying standby; that it will not count miles earned with such tickets toward elite status in frequent-flier program; and that it will cut corporate discounts; passengers will also be charged $25 for each paper ticket and will not be able to have alcoholic beverages in economy class on trans-Atlantic flights (M)

headline: DoubleClick Sells Its Media Sales Business to L90
abstract: Internet advertising company DoubleClick sells its North American media sales business to L90 for $9.4 million in cash and stock and possibly another $6 million if performance thresholds are met; L90 will change its name to MaxWorldwide when deal closes (M)

headline: The Fed's Evolving Comfort Zone
abstract: Richard W Stevenson Economic View column on evolution of Federal Reserve's manipulation of interest rates to control inflation; holds inflation is currently not dangerous to American economy; graph shows consumer price changes since 2000 (M)

headline: In Quietly Courting Africa, White House Likes Dowry
abstract: Africa is rising in strategic importance in Washington policy matters because of its oil; it now provides 15 percent of US's crude oil imports, but its share is expected to grow rapidly from new production in West Africa and construction of pipeline linking southern Chad to Atlantic ports; recently discovered offshore reserves are expected to enable West Africa to outproduce North Sea's oil rigs within next decade, and capture as much as 25 percent of America's oil-import market; new African oil could reduce dependence on countries like Saudi Arabia, although it probably will not flow fast enough to compensate for lost Iraqi production if US begins invasion; African oil has several advantages: much of it lies beneath Atlantic or near West African coast, making it simpler to transport to US than oil from Persian Gulf or Caspian Sea; much of Africa's new production will not be constrained by any cartel quotas, since Nigeria, lone sub-Saharan country that belongs to OPEC, is considering quitting as Gabon did in 1995; Bush administration has not trumpeted its interest in African oil, to avoid antagonizing Middle Eastern allies and to avoid appearing to be interested only in Africa's resources; but administration sent Secretary of State Colin L Powell there two weeks ago on three-nation tour; photo; map; graph (L)

headline: dRush Agency to Be Dissolved
abstract: An agency formed in 1999 by Deutsch in New York and the rap impresario Russell Simmons, which specializes in campaigns aimed at younger and urban consumers, is closing, effective in 90 days.

headline: El Salvador Embraces Foreign Investors
abstract: DIARYEl Salvador Embraces Foreign Investors.

headline: Restrained End To Volatile Year In Stock Markets
abstract: A subdued trading session produced only small moves in the stock market yesterday as a quiet day of remembrance ended an extraordinarily volatile year on Wall Street that reflected increased uncertainty in the wake of the terrorist attacks.    The Dow Jones industrial average, up for much of the abbreviated session, slipped in the final hour and ended down 21.44 points, or 0.2 percent, to 8,581.17, leaving it off 10.7 percent since the World Trade Center and Pentagon were attacked. Other averages have suffered more, making 2002 appear likely to be the third consecutive losing year, something that last happened early in World War II.

headline: Runoff in Russian Governor's Race
abstract: Aleksandr V Uss and Aleksandr G Khloponin, candidates backed by two powerful Russian business groups, win first round in an election to replace late Aleksandr I Lebed as governor of Krasnoyarsk, vast Siberian region (S)

headline: One Terror Plot May Have Been Foiled, but a U.S. Base in Germany Is Still Vulnerable
abstract: Focus on reported plot by Turkish-German man and American-German fiance to bomb US military base in Heidelberg, Germany; terrorism experts and US military officials say plot had mix of ingredients that made it extraordinarily difficult to predict and stop; suspects, Osman Petneczi and Astrid Eyzaguirre, who are believed to have acted alone, lived unremarkable lives in village of Walldorf; Eyzaguirre, whose father is American military officer, worked at military base; Petneczi allegedly stole chemicals to make bomb from factory where he worked; photo (M)

headline: Looking At Stocks With a Stake In War
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin interviews Merrill Lynch analyst Byron K Callan about effects of potential war with Iraq on stocks of companies that generate revenue from international conflict; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Vivendi Executive Leaving
abstract: Vivendi Universal says Philippe Germond is leaving as head of its telecommunications unit to become Alcatel chief operating officer (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; S.& P. 500 drops 7 foreigners, maybe aiding market over all.
abstract: Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is going all-American, and in process it is producing little bit of buying power for struggling stock market; announces that it is dropping seven companies in index that are not based in US; companies being added are not as large--in market value--as those being removed, and, in world where indexing is huge investment strategy, that could provide significant buying power for stocks remaining in index; companies being dropped and added noted (Market Place column) (M)

headline: VW Factories in Brazil Look to Export Markets
abstract: Brazil's automotive industry appears ready to go global; big automakers invested $20 billion in Brazil over last six years, expanding capacity rapidly in country that, for most of that time, enjoyed strong, stable growth; Brazil's economy has stalled, however, and now VW and other automakers seek export opportunities outside South America as domestic market cools and economies of other countries in region face their own crises; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing
abstract: ASIANORTH KOREA: READY FOR TALKS, RUSSIAN SAYS After concluding a two-day visit, Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov said North Korea was prepared to resume negotiations with the United States and Japan

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Macedonia: Kidnapping Fans Tensions
abstract: Hundreds of heavily armed Macedonian police officers seal off valley where ethnic Albanian gunmen are believed to be holding five Macedonians hostage, fanning fears of renewed ethnic conflict; Western powers appeal for end of provocations ahead of Sept elections; kidnappers are demanding release of group of demobilized ethnic Albanian guerrillas arrested this week and charged with murdering two policemen; map (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Builder In Bankruptcy
abstract: Dai Nippon Construction, Japanese general contractor, files for bankruptcy protection with $2.3 billion in debt (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Compensation Sought For Slave Labor
abstract: Ten Chinese men file lawsuit in Tokyo demanding compensation from Japanese government and four Japanese companies for being held as slave laborers at Hokkaido coal mines during World War II (S)

headline: Young, Hip -- and Talkative
abstract: Harris Interactive survey finds young adults 18 to 24 talk on their cellphones longer and use their phones more frequently than wireless subscribers over all; finds 35 percent of wireless subscribers in age group use over 500 minutes a month; table of cellphone use patterns; photo (S)

headline: Calvert to Manage College Plan
abstract: District of Columbia selects Calvert Group, which runs socially screened mutual funds, to manage its college savings plan, known as a 529 plan (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Far-Right Group Banned; GEORGIA: Rebuff To Putin On Chechen Rebels; TURKEY: Schools Group Seeks Kurdish Curriculum; TURKEY: Publisher Fined For American Book;.

headline: German Candidates Unscathed After First TV Debate
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder holds first American-style, televised campaign debate with challenger Edmund Stoiber, conservative coalition candidate; opponents display dislike for each other in repeated clashes but land few solid blows; neither makes egregious errors or adds to known positions on central issues; photo (M)

headline: This Time, a Layoff Hits Home
abstract: Rachel Zuckerman My Job column describes her being laid off as akin to 'being dumped by a boyfriend I never liked'; photo (M)

headline: QWEST DENIES IT IS UNDER CRIMINAL INQUIRY
abstract: Qwest Communications International says that it is unaware of any criminal probe after Wall Street Journal reports Justice Department is investigating company (S)

headline: Bombay Journal; The Mobster and the Movie Star: A Melodrama
abstract: Bollywood, movie industry in Bombay, India, has ties to organized crime; producers and actors have been caught partying with dons; those who resist sometimes end up dead; latest installment of long-running serial causes scandal nonetheless, because it involves Sanjay Dutt, Indian superstar; Dutt is heard chatting with Chota Shakeel, Karachi-based underworld boss and one of India's most-wanted men, in tape played at trial of film producer accused of consorting with mob; because Dutt is considered movie royalty, tape provokes new round of hand-wringing in media about organized crime's hold on Bollywood; photos; map (M)

headline: Insider Trades Point to a Rising Market (Eventually)
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column holds marked slowdown in insider stock sales indicates eventual stock market strengthening; graph of lag time between insider selling and public awareness of negative corporate news (M)

headline: As Currency Sinks, Brazil Seeks Fresh Aid
abstract: Brazil's battered currency reaches new low, as concerns grow about nation's fragile finances; government dspatches mission to Washington for talks with International Monetary Fund; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: SOUTH KOREA: Navy Can Open Fire; INDONESIA: Ex-Foe Visits Capital; INDONESIA: Kidnapping By Rebels Suspected; CAMBODIA: Compromise On Khmer Rouge Trial?;.

headline: French Discover Explosives On a Plane From Morocco
abstract: French authorities find explosive material during random check of Royal Air Maroc jet after it lands in French city of Metz on Sept 25, raising concerns of another terrorist plot to blow up airliner (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Norway: Central Bank Raises Rates
abstract: Norway's central bank raises its benchmark deposit rate by half point, to 7 percent, first increase in almost two years; suggests it might raise rates further because inflation could exceed its 2.5 percent target in two years (S)i

headline: People
abstract: Peter Bauer, publisher of People magazine, is promoted to president, assuming some of duties that had been handled by Nora McAniff, who has been named executive vice president of Time Inc (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: British Energy Falls; CZECH REPUBLIC: A New Brewer; SWEDEN: Fiber Optic Cuts;.

headline: Texas Pacific Hopes to Revive Another Airline
abstract: Texas Pacific Group, private equity firm that took Continental Airlines and America West out of bankruptcy, is putting its money behind US Airways; Credit Suisse First Boston and Bank of America, along with Texas Pacific, have put up total of $500 million in financing to help keep airline operating as it reorganizes under protection of bankruptcy court; Texas Pacific has also agreed to buy $200 million worth of stock in US Airways when--and if--it emerges from bankruptcy, giving it 38 percent stake in airline and 5 of 13 seats on its board; chart; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Phone Unit Sale Postponed
abstract: Enei SpA writes down value of its Wind telecommunications unit by 1.51 billion euros ($1.47 billion) and postpones sale of unit for at least two years (S)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Retelling The Tales Of Vanguard
abstract: Edward Wyatt reviews book Character Counts by mutual fund pioneer and Vanguard Group founder John Bogle; photo (M)

headline: Miss the Sound of Vinyl? Try Super Audio CD's
abstract: Q. I am starting to see compact discs in music stores labeled ''Super Audio CD,'' and was wondering what this means. I assume the sound quality is better, but can these discs be played on a regular CD player?    A. Super Audio CD is a compact disc format developed by Sony and Philips Electronics that offers recorded music with more clarity and a higher sound quality than what can be heard on regular compact discs. The SACD format was introduced in 1999, and there are now about 600 titles -- high-quality versions of albums by everyone from Louis Armstrong to Jennifer Lopez -- and more in the works.

headline: Small Loans to Small Concerns in Brazil
abstract: Brazil's Banco Real, which is owned by ABN Amro, has opened one-branch loan operation serving shantytown Heliopolis's estimated 100,000 inhabitants and 3,000 small, mainly informal, businesses, first such effort by major bank in Brazil to offer credit to small businesses; if successful, it could help spread commercial lending to thousands of small Brazilian companies starved of credit; 23 loans of $60 to $1,500 have been granted for periods of 4 to 12 months, but bank spokesman Flavio Weizenmann predicts many more clients; photo (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Tales of manipulation and design flaws from the crypt of auction history.
abstract: Hal R Varian Economic Scene column on auction design, focusing on recent paper written by Paul Klemperer, Oxford economist, which includes many amusing, and sobering, stories of auction manipulation; Klemperer argues that principles of good auction design are same as for any other market: try to encourage entry and try to discourage collusion; photo (M)

headline: Foot Locker May Trim Orders of Nike's Most Expensive Shoes
abstract: Foot Locker, the largest United States retailer of athletic shoes, said that it might trim orders of higher-price shoes from Nike because of tepid demand.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Ghirardelli Chocolate, San Leandro, Calif., part of Lindt & Sprungli, named Publicis & Hal Riney, San Francisco, part of the American operations of the Publicis Groupe, to handle its account. Billings were estimated at $2 million.

headline: Congressman Says Bush Would Mislead U.S.
abstract: Reps David E Bonior, Mike Thompson and Jim McDermott, Democratic congressmen visiting Iraq, cause anger among some Republicans after questioning Pres Bush's rationale for possible military action against Iraq; McDermott accuses Bush of being willing to mislead American people over whether war is necessary with Iraq; says administration has vacillated between citing supposed links between Iraq and Al Qaeda terrorist network and Iraq's supposed attempts to obtain weapons of mass destruction; he and Rep Bonior say it may still be possible to work out new inspection approach that would satisfy Iraqis but fall short of waht Bush wants; strong criticisms of them by Republican Sens Don Nickles and John McCain noted; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Cisco Executive Leaves To Join Symbol
abstract: Cisco Systems senior vice president Bill Nuti resigns to become president of Symbol Technologies; president Richard Bravman is promoted to chief executive, succeeding founder Jerome Swartz, who will remain executive chairman and chief scientist (S)

headline: Private Sector; Breaking All Kinds of Barriers
abstract: Swiss watch company TAG Heuer signs sponsorship deal with auto racing celebrity Sarah Fisher in bid for segment of women's watch market; photo (M)

headline: Treasury Prices Fall as Stocks Pull in Cash
abstract: US Treasury bond prices fall; 10-year note falls 15/32, to 103 2/32; yield rises to 4.47 percent from 4.42 percent; price of 30-year bond falls 1, to 100 13/32; yield rises to 5.35 percent from 5.28 percent; chart on key US interest rates (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: YUGOSLAVIA: Montenegro Convicts Serb; RUSSIA: Destruction Of Sunken Sub;.

headline: Then Again, Is It a Tool or a Cellular Trap?
abstract: Katie Hafner, self-described cellphone addict, tells how she got hooked, kicked the habit and is now able to moderate her usage; drawing (M)

headline: Pope Is in Poland, With Each Hoping to Do the Other Good
abstract: Pope John Paul II arrives in Poland, where he acknowledges economic hardships Poles are enduring after nine years of brisk development and appears to add his voice to those criticizing government for not providing more assistance to people hurt by downturn; three-day visit will confine itself to Cracow area, underlining pope's much-diminished strength; stamp issued to commemorate visit calls it pope's seventh to Poland, even though he has visited nine times; 'mistake' makes stamps popular with collectors; map; photo (M)

headline: Hunting Tax Cheats, I.R.S. Vows To Focus More Effort on the Rich
abstract: Internal Revenue Service says it will pursue tax cheats in new way, easing its examination of ordinary wage earners and devoting more of its attention to wealthy taxpayers suspected of hiding income received from their businesses, partnerships, investments and offshore accounts; says it has developed secret statistical technique to identify taxpayers who fail to report their full income; Comr Charles O Rosotti says there is mounting evidence of cheating that agency is failing to detect; says criticism of way agency has allocated its auditing staff is valid; says new policy is intended to protect fairness and faith honest taxpayer has in system; says several hundred revenue agents would be trained as fraud specialists; photo; graph (M)

headline: High hopes for sales of the video versions of 'Lord of the Rings.'
abstract: Marketing campaign costing $65 million is planned for video versions of The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring; photo (M)

headline: After the Bubble: Are Low Rates Enough?
abstract: Floyd Norris column on whether Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan was right to ignore stock market bubble in 1999; says Greenspan could have used his bully pulpit to warn of overinvestment in certain areas of economy and could have raised margin requirements to make it more expensive to gamble on stock prices; says lower interest rates cannot prompt capital investment, where demand does not exist; suggests making additional tax cuts this year while repealing cuts scheduled for later years to stimulate economy; photo (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: The 3-D Intruder To the Editor:.

headline: Analysts Retreating on Forecasts of Further Fed Rate Cuts
abstract: Calmer markets and signals from Fed officials have led some economists back away from predictions that rate cuts are on the way.

headline: P. Wamba, 31; Wrote of Life As African And American
abstract: Philippe Wamba, son of Congolese rebel leader, who wrote about his family's complex and often disorienting existence as both Africans and Americans, dies in car accident in Kenya at age 31 (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Soldiers Said To Smuggle Rare Birds
abstract: Animal Conservaton for Life accuses Indonesian soldiers of smuggling endangered birds from eastern provinces of Maluku and Papua (S)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Fidelity Tries to Regain Its Old Contrarian Edge
abstract: Fidelity Investments, world's biggest mutual fund company, tries to recover reputation of its funds as smart and contrarian, despite fact that they outperformed only 58 percent of competitors during first half of 2002; Abigail P Johnson, who runs Fidelity's funds, comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Economic Growth Slow Again
abstract: World Business Briefing: Germany: Economic Growth

headline: WAL-MART REPORTS SALES ON LOW END OF FORECAST
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores says August sales at stores open at least one year are near low end of its forecast as shoppers bought less clothing last week than expected (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of July 7 article on Fiat; its auto components business is Magneti Marelli, not Magnetti Mirelli

headline: Compressed Data; Free Weblog Service And a Vampire, Too
abstract: Several fictional characters from O Beijo do Vampiro (Kiss of the Vampire), soap opera beginning on Brazil's Organizacoes Globo, are offering own free Weblogs through partnership between Globo.com and Pyra Labs; Pyra chief executive Evan Williams comments, interview; photo (M)

headline: Dell Profits Are Up 11% For Quarter
abstract: Dell Computer Corp says second-quarter profits improved and product shipments increased at time when other computer makers are suffering; product shipments rose 18 percent worldwide in quarter ended Aug 2, while overall industry volume declined 4 percent; sales of powerful servers and workstations increased 20 percent; revenue was $8.5 billion, up 11 percent from quarter year ago; net income was $501 million; chairman-chief executive Michael S Dell comments; photos (M)

headline: The Euro Did It!
abstract: Shoppers in Italy stage nationwide strike against merchants, who many consumers say have exploited transition to common European currency by marking up price of everything; consumer groups in Greece call on shoppers there to refrain from buying fruit and vegetables next week; these are latest ripples in wave of anger that has swept across Continent since euro notes and coins became legal tender in 12 European countries in January; European Central Bank bank president Wim Duisenberg says effects of changeover are over and that inflation is not problem; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Airlines Investigated
abstract: Fair Trade Commission will investigate whether Japan Airlines, All Nippon Airways and Japan Air System violated Japan's monopoly law by reducing fares to match those of upstart carrier Skynet Asia Airways (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Liberate To Buy Sigma Systems For $62 Million
abstract: Interactive television software maker Liberate Technologies will buy Sigma Systems Group for about $62 million in cash; Sigma provides high-speed voice and data services to cable TV companies (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Sept 15 profile of Robert Bishop, chief executive ov Silicon Graphics

headline: Rights Workers in Honduras Still Live in Fear
abstract: Honduras no longer pursues policy of suppressing dissent, but critics say government has yet to ensure impartial justice when rich and powerful are involved; they cite organized criminals who traffic in drugs and guns, and landowners who are involved in illegal logging and use strong-arm tactics to settle land disputes with peasants; rights advocates say they are alarmed by what they see as smear campaigns by commentators and politicians that put their lives at risk; complex forces at play in country are exemplified by case of Jose Santos Callejas, rights worker who was slain after challenging organized criminals and big landowners; his death is fifth unresolved killing of human rights worker in 14 years; it came days after he gave information to police about gang members, leading his supporters to suspect that police tipped off gang; photos; map (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Random House Executive Will Step Down
abstract: Phyllis Grann is reportedly leaving as Random House vice chairwoman; photo (M)

headline: Records of Two Utilities Are Subpoenaed
abstract: Duke Energy Corp and El Paso Corp say that they had received subpoenas for trading records from authorities looking into sham transactions in natural gas and electricity; case reviewed (S)

headline: Jewish Settlers Accused of Selling Bullets to Palestinians
abstract: Five Jewish settlers, four of them soldiers, and a reserve officer have been arrested on suspicion of selling thousands of rounds of stolen military ammunition to Palestinians.

headline: Polishing the Snifter, Dusting Off the Ears
abstract: DIARYPolishing the Snifter, Dusting Off the Ears.

headline: BP CUTS GROWTH GOALS BECAUSE OF SHUTDOWNS
abstract: BP cuts its goal for growth in oil and gas production this year because of shutdowns at oil fields in Alaska and British natural gas pipeline; expects growth of 4.5 percent to 5 percent, less than 5.5 percent previously forecast (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: McDonald's Cuts Prices
abstract: McDonald's Holdings Co, eager to regain market share, will cut prices on its hallmark products in Japan (S)

headline: The Essay, IM Style
abstract: Masha Bell letter on September 19 article on instant text-messaging holds English language rules are antiquated

headline: The N.B.A. regretfully cancels a Lorillard sponsorship.
abstract: National Basketball Association and Lorillard Tobacco Co are blaming anti-tobacco activists for decision to remove cigarette maker's Youth Smoking Prevention Program as sponsor of popular youth basketball tournament; decision is disclosed by league and Lorillard after league quietly cancels contract with Lorillard to sponsor tournament; league acts after American Cancer Society, American Heart Association, American Lung Association and Campaign for Tobacco-Free Kids urged NBA Comr David Stern to discontinue sponsorship; executives at league and Lorillard contend that anti-smoking activists are hurting their cause by attacking educational programs like Lorillard's; coalition of health organizations reject charge; photo (M)

headline: Now Steve Is Running to Revive Forbes
abstract: Forbes magazine president and editor in chief Steve Forbes faces biggest challenge to magazine since Depression; magazine, which became one of nation's richest as totem for conspicuous wealth, has fallen to third in ad pages in its category, has lost almost half of its ad pages and faces 14 percent drop in newsstand sales in 2002 first half; he says company's prudence in cutting costs should not be mistaken for panic; his return, after relinquishing control of company to his brother, Timothy C Forbes, during his two runs for Republican presidential nomination, has led to confusion about who runs company; Steve Forbes says he controls majority of voting stock, interview; graphs of ad pages and revenue; photo (M)

headline: How to Break the Ceiling?
abstract: Fifty-two percent of professional women surveyed by World Women in Technology, businesswomen's networking group, feel that their gender keeps them from progressing in their careers (S)

headline: North Korea Adding a Pinch Of Capitalism to Its Economy
abstract: North Korea is introducing significant economic liberalization measures after half-century of almost complete control under Communist rule; new measures center on large wage increases for workers and even larger increases in prices for everything from food and electricity to housing; food rationing coupons may be eliminated and state subsidies for many failing industries have been halted; analysts do not agree on what inspired changes, but do agree that they are unlike anything North Korean government has tried before, and may even represent first moves toward economy that mixes capitalism and socialism; Kim Jong Il's government has issued no major statements explaining changes; diplomats from Western countries posted in Pyongyang say political dimensions of recent changes are at least as important as economic details; say that for leadership that has never acknowledged failings in its policies or tolerated any challenges to them, recent economic measures, combined with equally striking shift in diplomatic tack, suggest new willingness to break with past practice; photo (M)

headline: Yankees' Absence Lowers Revenue
abstract: Cablevision Systems reports revenue for its Madison Square Garnden division was down 15 percent in quarterly ending June 30, to $153.8 million, largely owing to fact that MSG Network lost right to carry Yankee games at end of last season (S)

headline: Diageo Is Set To Consolidate Its Distribution
abstract: Diageo plans to name sole distributors for its wine and spirits in individual states; expects to name Peerless Distributing as sole carrier in New York an Southern Wine and Spirits as distributor for Florida, California, Hawaii and Kentucky (M)

headline: Ronaldo scores twice in victory over Germany : Brazil:champions again
abstract: YOKOHAMA, Japan:—  Soccer history and a wonderful personal comeback combined Sunday in Yokohama to give Brazil its record fifth World Cup, and to give Ronaldo back the prowess and peace of mind he lost in the last final, four summers ago.

headline: ALLEGHENY ENERGY SUES MERRILL OVER A TRANSACTION
abstract: Allegheny Energy sues Merrill Lynch & Co, accusing firm of fraud in sale of trading unit to Allegheny last year for $409 million; Allegheny says Merrill officials inflated revenue and engaged in sham trades with Enron that artificially lifted value of Merrill's trading unit in 1999 (S)

headline: Interview With Vicente Fox
abstract: MEXICO CITY, Sept. 10 -- Following is a transcript of an interview with President Vicente Fox of Mexico, conducted in Spanish and translated by The New York Times. Q. I want to take you back one year ago; we want try to get your thoughts about Sept. 11 in Mexico. A little more than a year ago you were in Washington and you challenged the U.S. to adopt new immigration laws, and doing so you also challenged the U.S. to look at Mexico as more than a poor neighbor; as an equal partner. Some analysts in Mexico have said that after the United States and Afghanistan, Mexico has been the country most affected economically and politically by Sept. 11. How do you see the scope of the impact? A. The first thing, I would confirm that, yes, there was an unprecedented effect on Sept 11. It was unexpected, surprising but at the same time of the highest impact. This impact was felt in the United States, in Mexico and in the whole world. It was a shock for the whole world. And in Mexico's case it hit us at a summit in our relationship. At that moment we were in Congress, where we had won favorable reaction to our proposals. We were at the closest possible point to an agreement with the government of President Bush both on immigration and on a deepening of integration under NAFTA. That is why for us the impact is stronger; to go from the summit of optimism, of positive results, to the unprecedented shock of the terrorist attack. And this effectively forced the United States to concentrate its attention on the issue of security. By dedicating so much concentration to the issue of security, bilateral matters pass to a secondary level. Those matters continue to have enormous importance to us. I ask myself if it is necessary to choose between the two issues. I believe that work can be done on security, in combating terrorism in Mexico we have done our part in this area. But at the same time, the world must continue working. The world must continue advancing, and even more our bilateral relations with the United States. So beginning from Sept. 11, we did introduce in our agenda the issue of security and commitment to fighting terrorism. It's a commitment that we not only made to the U.S. government but also particularly with United Nations Resolution 1373. But at the same time we're working on putting our bilateral agenda back into discussion and the truth is that we haven't managed to reach the levels we had before Sept. 11. So what are we doing? As a consequence we are working on issues that have to do with migration but they are only partial [steps] such as issuing the identification card, the consular identification card, as a security measure in that it fully identifies our compatriots. On the other hand, it also advances the recognition of the rights of illegal immigrants who work in the U.S., who work with U.S. companies, who work with U.S. families, who work with U.S. citizens, and who merit the greatest respect and the greatest acknowledgment for what they do. Q. After Sept. 11, political costs of your support for the United States began to mount. People began to criticize you as having a subservient attitude toward the United States, that you were giving so much and getting nothing in return. You canceled trips to the United States. Congress denied permission for you to travel there. There have been disputes with the United States over the death penalty, water, trade. How do you feel? A: My first clear and resounding answer is that the relationship continues, just as strong, just as friendly. Our partnership is increasingly more committed to the U.S., our partnership for prosperity _ the document signed in Monterrey (inaudible). Regarding your comment, we would have to separate the response into various baskets. One: the reasons for which I did not go on two trips to the United States. The first because effectively the Congress denied me permission to leave. And on this matter I take the opportunity to comment that in Mexico, I find contradicting reactions in regards to relations with the United States. On one side, citizens have great respect for the United States, they have a great feeling of friendship. That is solid. But in the opposition and in the political arena I often find criticism of the closeness of relations with the United States. That is a reality. And it is a reality that flares up every time a new issue arises. And the issue comes up every day. The death penalty, the execution of Javier [Suarez Medina], the Mexican citizen executed in Texas, for us the defense of human rights is a very important issue. It's a priority and we express it each time that a situation that has to do with human rights comes up as in the case of this execution. We had to let the governor of Texas know that we do not share support the death penalty. At the same time we had to let the justice system of Texas know that some elemental rights of this Mexican were violated, as in not having advised the Mexican Consulate of his arrest and of the charges against him. This is a commitment that both Mexico and the U.S. have signed in the Convention of Vienna and which requires us to advise the consulate when this situation arises. And thirdly, well, I could not make a visit to Texas eight days after this Mexican was executed. I let the governor of Texas know. I asked for clemency or that Javier's sentence be changed. I asked that the execution be postponed so that documents could be presented showing the violation of Javier's rights. I asked that the time-frame be extended to make the visit and I did not receive a response. So I saw myself obligated to cancel the trip. As far as the dispute over water is concerned, I think that it was on very good terms. It's an issue where a resolution was pending. The conditions of the Rio Grande River Basin have changed. The level of rainfall that we receive each year has changed and so we have to change the the responses we give. Fortunately, as always happens, we found the response through dialogue with United States authorities and now the the issue of the Rio Grande River Basin is resolved for the next five years. Conflicts like this are constantly arising, problems that we deal with and resolve in a relationship as intense as the one between Mexico and the U.S.. Q. But are you frustrated that your efforts to embark on a new relationship with the United States has not been reciprocated? A. There are feelings on my part that I would not describe as frustration or resentment. But I feel strongly that we need to deal with bilateral issues. I constantly make it known to the American government that we need the same kind of attention for Latin America. Things aren't going well in Latin America and we have to work very hard so that things improve in Latin America. The U.S., Canada and Mexico right now enjoy better conditions of stability and economic development and so we are the most obligated to pay attention to Latin America. In the case of the U.S. and Canada, they should pay attention to Mexico. So, without it being a complaint, without it being a product of frustration, I do constantly call on the administration of President Bush to dedicate more time to bilateral and Latin America issues. Q. Your foreign minister said in an interview recently that Mexico would embark on a new strategy to get the immigration back on the U.S. agenda. Talk to me about that. A. It isn't anything spectacular or terribly innovative. We simply realize that at this moment while the U.S. elections process is going on it won't be possible to raise the migration agenda. In the same way it wasn't possible immediately after Sept. 11. So we are waiting for an important window of opportunity after the U.S. elections. I think that it is the right time to push this theme strongly. And there we would expect reciprocity. We would expect fulfillment of goals. President Bush himself expressed that he would really be an ally in the cause of migration, that we would work together to return the issue to the highest priority, [that we would] work with U.S. legislators as well so that they would look favorably upon this development. This window of opportunity next year [will occur] because the U.S. economy will surely begin growing again and it will require more and more workers [to fill] more and more jobs. So the strategy is to take advantage of this window of opportunity. We will have a very active migration policy next year. Q. Will you work directly with (political) parties and Congress? A. With everybody, legislators, local levels where there is a strong Mexican presence, where the presence of Mexicans is appreciated and valued such as Texas, California, Chicago, and in other parts of the U.S. At the local government level, with the governors, with the state congresses we will have a very active policy on this issue so that hopefully we can fulfill our intention of reaching a result by the end of 2003. Q. Will those plans be successful if there is an attack on Iraq? A. The consequences of an attack on Iraq are not predictable. It appears to me that it would have very broad effects at the global level on many things and it would have very broad effects on bilateral issues and issues on the Latin American agenda. I believe that the issue of Iraq must be the product of deep reflection. It seems to us that this is a matter that should be channeled through the United Nations Security Council; that there should be an opportunity for a visit by United Nations inspectors to Iraq. We, as a country, will be pushing strongly in that direction; in that it will be the U.N. that makes the visit, that it's the U.N. which certifies what conditions are there. But first [we need] objective information to be able to then reflect on the best decisions to take. I think the Iraq situation would have an impact that would affect the whole world. Q. Would you support President Bush? Last night on Televisia, a poll showed that 70 percent of Mexicans are opposed to an attack against Iraq. How does your government feel. A. At this moment we can't take a position, nor make a decision precisely because information is lacking. It would be very important to really know what are Iraq's activities regarding terrorism, what are Iraq's activities regarding weapons of mass destruction, what are its activities in terms of its ability to deliver these weapons. The debate which must take place in the United Nations and in the U.N. Security Council, where we are present, is also important. So for me and for Mexico first we need a lot of information, a lot of objectivity, deep reflection and then we will be able to give an opinion. Q. Last question., you call yourself the president the 123 million Mexicans, including 23 million who live in the United States. Since Sept. 11 deportations have increased, arrests on the border have declined but the number of Mexicans dying on the border has not. How have Mexicans in the United States been affected by Sept. 11. Are their rights in danger? A. Well, as long as we do not reach a solution on immigration, which is the intention, these painful circumstances will occur. We are trying to avoid these painful deaths. We're there on the border, we're in the mountains, we're there with the army. We're there with our border agents dedicated to migration issues. We're working intensely to try to stop these deaths from happening. In the same way, we continue to be very committed to Mexicans in the U.S. We have managed to get the consular identification card accepted throughout the U.S. banking and financial system. With this, migrants can now open checking accounts. We have managed to get this accepted as a full identification card by city, country and state authorities. We have managed to get the card accepted so that Mexicans, even if they are in the United States illegally, can apply for driver's licenses in various cities and counties. We have managed to remove discrimination against them regarding their entry into state universities. In sum, we are working through the consulates to be close to our compatriots and to help them as much as possible. But in the end the best solution is a migration accord.

headline: Stanley Works Backs Away From a Move To Avoid Taxes
abstract: Stanley Works is abandoning its proposal to reincorporate in Bermuda, plan that would have allowed it to reduce its taxes but has drawn objections from employees and lawmakers; attributes its reversal to growing prospect of legislation in Washington to resolve what it characterizes as inequities in United States tax laws (M)

headline: Orthopedics Maker Ousts Chief In a Dispute Over Management
abstract: Centerpulse, Europe's biggest maker of orthopedic products formerly called Sulzer Medica, dismisses chief executive Dr Stephan Rietiker because of clashes with chairman Max Link and other managers over how to run company; Link will act as chief executive for foreseeable future; Centerpulse has been struggling to right itself after settling lawsuits in US over faulty hip- and knee-replacement joints that nearly bankrupted it; photo (M)

headline: Porous 'Island of Russia,' Kaliningrad Fears Moat
abstract: Kaliningrad, small wedge of land near Baltic Sea that is part of Russia but separate from it, fears that halting efforts to open up after decades as secret Soviet military zone will be stymied by strict new border controls planned by Poland and Lithuania as part of their efforts to join European Union; ease of travel, along with low tariffs and taxes, have facilitated free-wheeling trade, with lots of smuggling of cigarettes, vodka and other goods; photos; map (M)

headline: JUDGE APPROVES XO BANKRUPTCY PLAN
abstract: XO Communications wins bankruptcy judge's approval of reorganization plan, clearing way for company to try to enforce $800 million investment agreement with Forstmann Little & Co and Telefonos de Mexico; two companies once planned to invest $400 million each in XO, but backed out in June, citing XO's deteriorating finances (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Rock Group Finds a New Way to Sell Out
abstract: Music group Grey Eye Glances has raised funds through private offering to start Grey Album, company to produce, manufacture and promote its seventh album; financing innovation comes as big labels increasingly shy away from acts that cannot sell at least 500,000 copies of album; most of company's 40 members, who could each invest up to $20,000 each, are fans; photos (M)

headline: Constantine Leventis, 64, Businessman and Art Benefactor
abstract: Constantine Leventis, head of Greek Cypriot Coca-Cola Hellenic Bottling Co and major benefactor of Hellenic art at Metropolitan Museum of Art and other museums, dies at age 64 (M)

headline: A Push to Improve Labor's Lot Overseas
abstract: Lisa Rahman, 19-year-old garment worker from Bangladesh, is touring US for two seemingly contradictory reasons: to publicize poor working conditions and low pay at her factory in Dhaka and to urge Walt Disney Co to continue making shirts there; soon after labor rights group began publicizing factory's conditions last year, Disney license that produces Winne the Pooh shirts pulled out of factory; Rahman says Disney should send new business to factory and make sure its conditions improve; photo (M)

headline: Charmed by Six Feet of Circuitry
abstract: Grace, short for Graduated Robot Attending Conference, is focal point of 18th annual meeting of American Association for Artificial Intelligence; gives PowerPoint presentation after stunning entrance to conference center where she registers, takes elevator to designated floor and shows up at specific time; Grace is design of Reid Simmons, research computer scientist at Carnegie Mellon Robotics Institute and Alan C Schultz, computer scientist at Naval Research Laboratory; photos (M)

headline: Forecast Too Sunny? Try the Anxious Index
abstract: David Leonhardt Economic View column reports on Anxious Index calculated by Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank using economists' predictions about odds economy will shrink over coming year; index is markedly more accurate at predicting rise and fall of American economy than forecasts of Wall Street economists who have vested interest in optimism that emboldens stock buyers; graph (M) of economists' forecasts (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; I.B.M. Will Pay Pricewaterhouse $3.5 Billion for Consulting Unit
abstract: International Business Machines Corp will buy PricewaterhouseCoopers' consulting unit for $3.5 billion in move that will speed IBM's shift from selling just computers and software toward future of providing information technology to corporate customers as utility-like service; PricewaterhouseCoopers, which has been exploring ways to spin off unit for two years, drops earlier plan to sell shares in consulting firm to public; planned sale leaves just one big accounting firm, Deloitte & Touche, with large consulting operation, which Deloitte plans to spin off by end of year; photo (M)

headline: 15 Suspected Qaeda Members Are Being Held by Italian Police
abstract: Italian law enforcement officials announce arrest in Sicily of 15 Pakistani men suspected of being members of Qaeda terrorist network; Italian and American officials say they have no evidence that men were plotting attack; 15 men are charged with several crimes, including association for aim of international terrorism (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Panel Wants To Derail Royal Train
abstract: Committee of Parliament overseeing monarchy's expenses recommends that Queen Elizabeth II give up royal train, perk dating back to Queen Victoria, saying it costs twice as much per mile as air travel; photo (S)

headline: O'Neill Encourages Brazil in I.M.F. Talks
abstract: Treasury Sec Paul O'Neill assures Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Washington's support in Brazil's negotiations with International Monetary Fund, meeting, Brasilia; says he and Cardoso hold 'cordial and very useful talks' about how how to help Brazil cope with its worst financial crisis since sharp devaluation of its currency in 1999; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MORTON'S RESTAURANT GROUP, New Hyde Park, N.Y., a steakhouse chain at the center of a takeover fight, said its shareholders approved a $71.2 million offer from Castle Harlan Inc., New York.    SWISS ARMY BRANDS INC., Shelton, Conn., distributor of Swiss Army pocket knives, said it agreed to a buyout offer from its supplier, Victorinox, Ibach, Switzerland, of about $24 million, or $9 a share.

headline: In Angola, Seeking a Generation Uprooted
abstract: Millions of Angolans struggle to piece together lives torn apart in 27 years of civil war, journeying along roads that were impassable for years to get back to villages and look for long-lost relatives; many survivors gather in capital and hold up photos to be shown on television news program; nearly 7,000 people are reported reunited as result; photos; map (M)

headline: Shutdown next year underlines problems of other new markets : Germans give up on Neuer tech exchange
abstract: FRANKFURT:—  Germany's Neuer Markt, the leading stock exchange in Europe for innovative technology shares, will shut down next year, Deutsche Boerse AG announced Thursday, underscoring the dire condition of technology exchanges around the world.

headline: Energy Concerns Said to Be Near China Pipeline Pact
abstract: Some of world's largest energy companies are in final stages of negotiations with one another and Chinese government to form consortium that would build natural gas pipeline across China; agreement would allow venture to begin lining up loans to help cover $3.8 billion needed to develop gas field in remote area of western China and additional $5.2 billion to construct pipeline to carry gas nearly 2,500 miles east to Shanghai; pipeline is to carry nearly $2 billion a year worth of natual gas across China for more than four decades after becoming fully operational, probably in 2008; China is in separate talks to buy liquefied natural gas from Australia, Indonesia or Qatar, to be shipped by sea to Guangdong province in southeastern China (M)

headline: Citigroup Is Subpoenaed in I.P.O. Inquiry
abstract: House Financial Services Committee issues subpoena to Citigroup, asking for documents on any role that analyst Jack B Grubman might have played in allocating potentially lucrative stock to WorldCom executives; subpoena is issued after Citigroup, parent of Salomon Smith Barney, fails to respond adequately to request for information; subpoena seeks records on any WorldCom executive's purchase of initial offering shares sold by Salomon Smith Barney since 1996 and documents on any role Grubman had in sales (M)

headline: 2 Big Advertisers Revise Assignments
abstract: Burger King Corp is consolidating most of its advertising at agencies owned by Interpublic Group of Cos, including Deutsch/LA and Media First International; assignments had been handled by D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles and MediaVest; Unilever Bestfoods division of Unilever is consolidating creative duties for certain products at DDB Worldwide, including work previously handled by Bartle Bogle Hegarty (M)

headline: Flooding Elbe Batters Towns Along Its Path
abstract: Elbe river dams break, inundating German towns upriver from Dessau; photo of rescuers in Meissen; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
abstract: DOCUMENTS UNSEALED IN GATOR CASE; TMP POSTS BIG DROP IN EARNINGS;.

headline: Alliant Energy's Net Falls
abstract: Midwest utility owner Alliant Energy reports its profit fell 83 percent, to $6.32 million, down from year-earlier $37.7 million; revenue rose 0.6 percent, to $615.2 million (S)

headline: A Different Kind of Brezhnev in the Making
abstract: Profile of Andrei Y Brezhnev, who has begun improbably ambitious political campaign propelled by little more than fact that he is grandson of late Soviet Communist leader Leonid I Brezhnev; he hopes to recruit those left behind by transition to quasi-capitalism and small business owners like himself; he comments on woes of small business owners, interview; photo (M)

headline: Infatuated Investors May Be Missing Dell's Flaws
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on deterioration of Dell Computer Corp's balance sheet; notes that working capital declined markedly in recent years, that liabilities are up 48 percent while assets are up only 17 percent, that shareholders must takes on faith Dell's valuation of its investments at $4.6 billion and that there is also $1 billion liability associated with Dell's previous sales of put options on its shares; graph (M)

headline: California Lottery Asks for New Bids
abstract: There have been developments involving challenges to the awarding of two lottery accounts.    The California Lottery Commission is asking four finalists in a review for its account, a five-year contract with total billings of $125 million, to submit new bids for the media part of the assignment. The rebidding came at the request of one finalist, the Los Angeles office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, which protested a decision in July to award the account to a team composed of two agencies owned by the Interpublic Group of Companies, the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding and the Los Angeles office of Initiative Media.

headline: House and Senate Reach Initial Deal on Trade Powers for Bush
abstract: House and Senate negotiators agree on details of legislation that would give Pres Bush authority to make international trade deals that could be approved or rejected--but not amended--by Congress; issue is one of White House's top legislative priorities this year; final approval from both chambers would be big victory for Bush (M)

headline: Pediatric Book on Breast-Feeding Stirs Controversy With Its Cover
abstract: Some American Academy of Pediatrics leaders are outraged that group lets Ross Products unit of Abbott Laboratories, maker of Similac infant formula, print its corporate logo on cover of special edition of academy's book New Mother's Guide to Breastfeeding; academy has long recommended breast-feeding over use of formula; discourages hospitals from partaking in programs in which Ross and other formula makers give free samples to mothers; photo (M)

headline: Feeling Its Own Pain
abstract: French government faces serious dilemma; owns 55 percent of France Telecom, which saw exit of its chief executive after announcing $12 billion first-half loss and must raise cash somehow to survive; government cannot allow company to collapse, but cannot directly subsidize it without breaking budget deficit limits set by European Union; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: AUSTRIA: Haider Ready For Comeback; THE HAGUE: First Phase Of Milosevic Trial Ends; FRANCE: Billions More For The Military; RUSSIA: Another Catholic Priest Barred; RUSSIA: Accusation Against Kremlin Critic; BRITAIN: Not As Dumb As They Look;.

headline: A Fossil Unearthed in Africa Pushes Back Human Origins
abstract: French scientists, led by Dr Michel Brunet, uncover scull in Chad that is virtually complete and almost seven million years old, belonging to individual that they say is earliest known member of human family; cannot say whether skull represents species on direct ancestral line to humans, but believe it may provide telling evidence of life when human and chimpanzee lineages diverged; specimen, whose formal name is Sahelanthropus tchadensis, has apelike braincase but face and teeth that are more like a human's; suggests evolutionary complexity and diversity in human origins that seem to defy description by simplified family trees of past; photos; chart; map (M)

headline: Court Says Israel Can Expel 2 of Militant's Kin to Gaza
abstract: Israeli Supreme Court rules that army may expel brother and sister of Palestinian terrorist from West Bank to Gaza Strip because they were involved in his actions and pose security threat; photo; Ali Ajuri was accused of organizing suicide bombing in Tel Aviv in July in which five people were killed; was killed by Israeli troops August 6; court finds that expulsions of terrorists' relatives to Gaza does not violate international law, but can only be used in case of security threats, not as general deterrent; bars expulsion of Abdel Nasser Asida, brother of wanted militant (M)

headline: Joining Trend, Taiwan's Biggest Insurer Buys a Bank
abstract: Taiwan's Cathay Financial Holding Co agrees to buy United World Chinese Commercial Bank for $3.38 billion in stock; deal is second purchase of Taiwan bank by insurer in less than week, and clear sign that consolidation of Taiwan's financial sector is accelerating; Fubon Financial Holding acquired Taipeibank on Aug 8 for $2.4 billion in stock (M)

headline: Gator Loses a Round to Web Sites in Fight Over Pop-Up Ads
abstract: Gator Corp appears to have lost first round in its fight against 10 Web site publishers who sued company, saying that its use of online pop-up advertisements violate copyright and trademark laws; US Judge Claude H Hilton will issue preliminary injunction; publishers include New York Times Co, Gannett Co, Tribune Co and Washington Post (M)

headline: Another Drop in Stock Sharpens Concern for Vivendi's Future
abstract: Vivendi Universal shares plunge, arousing renewed concern about company's survival; analysts downgrade company (M)

headline: 3 Pakistanis Die Battling Group Linked To Al Qaeda
abstract: Four suspected members of Al Qaeda and three Pakistani police officers are killed during shootout in rugged North-West Frontier Province, second time in week that Pakistani soldiers have died hunting suspected terrorists; Pakistani military is pouring troops and police officers into tribal areas, where hundreds of Qaeda men are believed to be hiding (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: SWEDEN: Executive Replaced; GERMANY: Department Store Loss;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Sales Stronger In May
abstract: Semiconductor Industry Association says worldwide sales of computer chips rose 2.8 percent in May, to $11.37 billion (S)

headline: Market Place; Shares Plunge As Interpublic Delays Report On Earnings
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies says that it will postpone release of second-quarter earnings by a week, sending company's stock tumbling nearly 24 percent (M)

headline: For Well-Heeled, Stock Tips Are Served With the Canapés
abstract: Charges that Dr Samuel D Waksal, former chief executive of ImClone Systems, engaged in insider trading and investigation into stock trading of Martha Stewart draw attention to grapevine of well-heeled people in Manhattan among whom exchange of corporate information is burgeoning social custom, not necessarily crime; such friendships often coincide with business relationships where power, access and social advantage intersect; information that most Americans would think of as exceedingly privileged is passed among them at cocktail parties as casually as canapes; photos (M)

headline: Economic Havoc From European Floods
abstract: Insurers and analysts have begun to tally economic impact of rains and flooding in Central Europe, even as floodwaters continue to surge downstream and burst banks of rivers; much of billions of dollars in damage will soon be reflected in insurance claims, hammering already beleaguered industry; tourism and transportation are suffering direct disruptions that will be hard to overcome; August is height of tourist season; river shipping is also being disrupted at time of year when huge amounts of bulk farm produce are commonly moved by barge; Danube River shipping companies, which have been struggling, cutting jobs and breaking up idle barges for scrap metal, see flood-related disruptions as last straw; early estimates of total damage in Austria are approaching $3 billion and tally is likely to exceed $1.9 billion in Czech Republic; German Farmers' Association puts likely agricultural losses at $1.5 billion; Austrian Insurance Association expects industry's losses in country to total 100 million euros ($98 million), only about 3 percent of preliminary estimates for total damage; German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, who comes up for re-election in September, has already announced $378 million in aid; photo (M)

headline: Ozzy Osbourne and his ilk breathe life into glam rocks : Gothic undead
abstract: LONDON—  Madman of Metal" Ozzy Osbourne makes an unlikely fashion icon. Yet 2002 is shaping up as a Jubilee year for the former lead singer of Black Sabbath. Ozzy's fashion clout is thanks largely to his newfound cult status as King of MTV. "The Osbournes," a fly-on-the-wall show spying on mad dad Ozzy, banshee mother Sharon plus their teenage children, Kelly and Jack, is the network's most popular show of all time (attracting 8 million viewers in the United States alone).

headline: Web Surfing at Work? Just the News, Honest!
abstract: In a recent survey, employees acknowledged that they spend about one day each week surfing sites unrelated to their jobs.

headline: Afghan Killing May Be Linked to Drug Trade
abstract: Afghans mourn slain Vice President Hajji Abdul Qadir as officials investigate possibility that he was killed by drug lords double-crossed during Western-backed campaign to destroy country's poppy crop; he was overseeing Western-financed campaign begun in April to destroy fields; Afghan officials have been paying farmers about $500 per acre to destroy poppy plants (M)

headline: The C.E.O. Gene
abstract: Terex Corp head Ronald M DeFeo writes, in The Boss column, about his working experiences; notes that he and his two brothers are all chief executive officers of corporations; photo (M)

headline: Afghans, Too, Mark a Day of Disaster: A Hero Was Lost
abstract: Afghans begin three days of official commemmorations to mark anniversary of assassination of Ahmed Shah Massoud, most celebrated hero of Afghan resistance who was killed by suicide bombers two days before September 11 terrorist attacks in US; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: Growth In Software; INDIA: Xerox Investigation; SOUTH KOREA: Investigation Of Oil Company;.

headline: U.S. Studying Merrill Lynch In Enron Deal
abstract: Justice Department probes 1999 deal in which Enron sold part-interest in electricity-generating barges in Nigeria to special-interest entity established by Merrill Lynch; Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations looks more deeply into role financial institutions may have played in hiding Enron's true financial condition (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYConstruction SpendingMay.

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: GERMANY: Porsche Sees Rising Profits; BRITAIN: Lloyd'S Votes For An Overhaul; POLAND: Elektrim Declares Bankruptcy; BRITAIN: Easyjet Founder To Resign Sooner;.

headline: Bank of America Asks Agencies to Compete
abstract: Bank of America ask parent companies of advertising agencies that work for it to assemble teams to compete for assignments that make up most of its account, with spending estimated at $165 million to $170 million (S)

headline: It's Almost September: Time to Help Parents
abstract: Numerous Web sites offer helpful advice to parents whose children are about to return to school (M)

headline: Ex-Executive Says Dynegy Asked His Help To Cook Books
abstract: Bradley P Farnsworth, controller and chief accounting officer at Dynegy from 1997 to early 2001, charges in lawsuit against company that he was fired after refusng to go along with plan to alter company's accounting standards in summer of 2000 to hide energy trading losses and boster profits; says he was told that without change, company would not meet third-quarter profit forecast, which it ultimately did; does not say whether Dynegy adopted changes without him; photo (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYNone.

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Weak Economy Shortens Draft
abstract: Brazil's army will send 80 percent of its draftees home before their one-year term of duty ends; army has reportedly received barely half of $2 billion it was allotted this year (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Member Of Parliament Attacked
abstract: Two assailants seriously injure Magomet Tekeyev, member of Russia's Parliament, and kill his aide in attack outside legislator's home in southwestern republic of Karachayev-Cherkessia (S)

headline: Big Names but No Authority to Prosecute
abstract: Pres Bush says his Corporate Fraud Task Force will operate as 'financial crimes SWAT team,' but group has no direct authority to investigate or prosecute cases and no new financial resources or added manpower for effort; official role of task force, as defined in presidential executive order, is to provide strategic direction to Justice Department in corporate crimes and make recommendations to Atty Gen John Ashcroft on how to improve coordination between agencies involved in financial crime enforcement; Ashcroft says Justice Department has been and will continue to investigate fully reports of corporate fraud, and hold guilty parties accountable for misleading shareholders and employees; task force will be led by Deputy Atty Gen Larry D Thompson; members of task force include Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill, Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Harvey L Pitt, heads of Federal Energy Regulatory Commission, Federal Communications Commission and Commodities Futures Trading Commission; FBI Dir Robert S Mueller III will also have seat on panel; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Ex-President In Limbo
abstract: Zambian high court judge postpones ruling on whether former president, Frederick Chiluba, can be stripped of immunity from prosecution; Chiluba has been accused of presiding over widespread corruption during 10 years in office; photo (S)

headline: Market Place; Despite a summer under intense heat, Martha Stewart's own nest remains well-feathered.
abstract: Martha Stewart continues to control and get generous salary and benefits from Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia despite probes of her possible insider trading in ImClone Systems that have driven down her company's stock price; company is undertaking complicated partial disengagement from Stewart, move it says was long planned; stock price graph (M)

headline: KitchenAid Selects Saatchi & Saatchi
abstract: KitchenAid, appliance and kitchen-equipment maker owned by Whirlpool Corp, selects Saatchi & Saatchi to handle its advertising account; billings estimated at $30 million; assignments had been handled for 20 years by N W Ayer & Partners (S)

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: ZIMBABWE: More White Farmers Arrested; ZAMBIA: Ex-President In Limbo;.

headline: JACK IN THE BOX EXPECTS EARNINGS GROWTH OF 10%
abstract: Jack in the Box Inc hamburger chain forecasts per-share earnings growth of 10 percent to 15 percent next year (S)

headline: Malaysia Suggests Jailed 9/11 Suspect Had Innocent Role
abstract: malaysia suggests jailed 9/11 suspect had innocent role**Malyasian home affairs minister says that Yazid Sufaat, biochemist who has been in jail in Kuala Lumpur since December on charges that he was host of critical meeting for two hijackers in Sept 11 terror attacks, was unaware of men's identities and what they discussed; Suffat has been linked to Jemaah Islamiya, regional Islamic militant group with ties to Al Qaeda; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Australia
abstract: STRICTER ACCOUNTING RULES; SLOWDOWN PROJECTED;.

headline: Bernard Canavan -- Executive, 66
abstract: Bernard Canavan, former president of American Home Products, dies at age 66 (S)

headline: National Science Foundation Announces Grant Winners
abstract: National Science Foundation announces series of awards as part of three-year-old information technology research program, which is intended to advance computer science by focusing on wide range of scientific and engineering problems; foundation is planning to award $144 million, including spending on seven major programs at US universities that range from $5 million to $13.5 million; Laboratory for Computer Science at MIT, University of California at Berkeley, International Computer Science Institute, New York University and Rice University receive $12 million grant to try to make next generation Internet system that is resistant to failure and attack; other researchers at University of California at Berkely in partnership with Vanderbilt University and University of Memphis are awarded $13 million to design software systems that can be used in wide range of applications; optical computer, called OptIPuter by scientists developing system, will be $13.5 million five-year effort drawing together 15 faculty members and 33 graduate students for five years (M)

headline: Legal Journal; Not Answering Can Raise Lots of Questions
abstract: Whether former WorldCom Inc chief executive Bernard J Ebbers waived his Fifth Amendment rights by giving speech to House committee is open question; what is clear is that speech, which followed score of opening statements by members of committee, ran afoul of strictly enforced Congressional monopoly on grandstanding; Repr Max Sandlin asked that Ebbers immediately be held in contempt; said he is not aware of new theory of selective Fifth Amendment, referring to possibility that Ebbers's speech precluded him from declining to testify about subjects his speech had touched on; added that it is his position that Ebbers waived his Fifth Amendment protections for all purposes; legal experts are divided on waiver question but united in their dismay about questions posed to Ebbers after it was clear that he would decline to answer any of them; photo (M)

headline: Student Skill Is Expected To Bolster Technology
abstract: New study holds that today's college students, first truly wired generation, are far more Net-adept than general population, and will graduate with expectations of high-speed Internet world that could push technology development of workplace and home; provides snapshot of emerging young digital class; author is Steve Jones of University of Illinois-Chicago (M)

headline: Bush Seeks Stiff Corporate Penalties
abstract: Responding to accounting scandals that have shaken investor confidence and could become a political liability, President Bush called for tougher penalties for corporate criminals.

headline: 'We Are One Family': A Mideast Story
abstract: Young Arab girl in Jerusalem receives kidney transplant from Jewish student killed in suicide bombing; decision by relatives of Yoni Jesner to donate his organs forges unforeseen but elemental link with family of Yasmin Abu Rumeileh, bridging blood-soaked divide between Jews and Arabs; Yasmin's grateful father says 'we are one family'; photos (M)

headline: Getting From Here to There . . .
abstract: America Online plans to introduce the 8.0 version of its software in October. Here are some of the features it hopes will stem defections by its members.

headline: The Plot Leaders and Lingering Questions
abstract: Chart depicting alleged links between ringleaders of September 11 terrorist attacks from October, 1999

headline: A Province Celebrates Karzai's Narrow Escape
abstract: a province celebrate

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Belarus: European Official Expelled
abstract: Belarus government expels acting head of Minsk mission of Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe; Pres Aleksandr Lukashenko has been at odds with organization over crackdowns on press and political opposition and recent charges that Belarus is selling weapons to Iraq (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Italy: Who Will Be The Godfather?
abstract: After years of litigation, Sicilian Mafia man was permitted to provide sperm to his partner, who then used in-vitro fertilization and is pregnant; mobster, who is not identified, will be permitted brief visitation with baby at maximum-security prison in central Italy where he lives (S)

headline: DISNEY SAYS IT EMPLOYED RELATIVES OF 4 DIRECTORS
abstract: Walt Disney Co says four of its independent board members had relatives who were employed by company in 2001; practice runs counter to proposed new standards of independence for directors (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Taming Saigon
abstract: Vietnamese authorities issue ban on nightlife in Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon; nightclubs and karaoke parlors will have to keep down music and close at midnight (S)

headline: Business & Investing; Tollbooth Technology Meets the Checkout Lane
abstract: Many types of merchants experiment with payment systems that use radio frequency identification like that utilized at toll plazas in some states; devices identify and charge purchasers who have set up credit or debit accounts; photo; graph of industry's growth (M)

headline: Private Sector; A New York Accent at Rothschild
abstract: Profile of Gerald Rosenfeld, chief executive of investment bank Rothschild North America; he is known for his direct, no-nonsense style; his unconventional background is asset at time when motives of typical Wall Street bankers are suspect; photo (M)

headline: Balking at a Compromise That Might Save a Deal
abstract: Analysis: Antitrust opposition to EchoStar Communications' pending acquisition of DirecTV is mounting, and Echostar chairman Charles W Ergen's opportunity to overcome it may lie in striking side deal with Cablevision chairman Charles F Dolan; Cablevision has proposed that regulators allay their antitrust concerns by transferring some of EchoStar's licenses to newly created Cablevision satellite operation; Ergen seems to be holding out for total victory rather than embrace compromise even though his deal appears to be foundering in Washington; antitrust officials in Washington seem to be leaning against EchoStar's plan to acquire Hughes Electronics and its DirecTV unit; photo (M)

headline: Lions and Obies Honor Ad Work
abstract: Advertising spot for Nike Inc by Wieden & Kennedy showing adults playing tag wins Grand Prix for commercials at International Advertising Festival in Cannes, France; other winners noted; Boone/Oakley takes top honors at Obie Awards for creativity, sponsored by Outdoor Advertising Association; other winners noted (S)

headline: I Think, Therefore IM
abstract: Some middle school and high school teachers are dismayed to see breezy form of Internet English jump from e-mail to schoolwork; others dismiss it as fad and are just happy that students are writing; shortened words, abbreviations, improper spelling, capitalization and use of typewriter characters cause some teachers to deduct points from students' work, but many students are so used to informal usage from Instant Messaging, that they are not aware of mistakes; photos (M)

headline: Improper Accounting Leads Interpublic to Restate Results
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies will restate its financial results back to 1997 because it improperly accounted for $68.5 million in expenses; attributes restatement to transactions between units of company involving European operations of McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising; chief financial officer Sean Orr says new management is in place in McCann Europe (M)

headline: Philip Morris Profit Up 14%, Helped by Foreign Sales
abstract: Philip Morris Companies says profits grew 14 percent in second quarter; operating profit rose to $1.45 billion from $1.38 billion year earlier; net profits were $2.6 billion compared with $2.28 billion year ago (M)

headline: European Union to Tackle Overhaul of Farm Subsidies
abstract: European Commission approves proposals to overhaul 40-year-old system of farm subsidies, which eat up nearly 45 percent of European Union's budget; changes, pressed by aricultural commissioner, Franz Fischler, would cut link between amount farmers produce and subsidies they receive; new flat-rate payments would be based on previous production and be dependent on compliance with environmental, animal welfare and farm safety standards; payments to biggest farms would be capped at 300,000 euros a year, and farmers who get 5,000 to 300,000 euros in yearly aid would have their payments reduced by 3 percent a year for seven years; savings would be directed to rural develoment programs; plan faces strong opposition from France, system's leading beneficiary; photo; graph (M)

headline: Blackstone Amasses a Record Equity Fund
abstract: Blackstone Group says it raised $6.45 billion for its Blackstone Capital Partners IV private investment fund, largest private equity fund ever raised (S)

headline: The Case of the Banned Boomerangs
abstract: Article on Betsylew Miale-Gix, who was arrested at Bradley International Airport near Hartford, Conn, for carrying boomerangs in her luggage; says Miale-Gix, lawyer and member of US team for 2002 World Cup in boomerang, was arrested and charged with breach of peace at airport on June 30; holds Miale-Gix was boarding flight home to Brier, Wash, from tournament in Amherst, Mass, with several dozen small boomerangs in her carry-on bag; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Hog Herd Is Down
abstract: United States hog farmers, faced with widening economic losses, reduce breeding herd to smallest size since records began in 1963, foretelling diminished pork supplies by early 2003 (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Rises
abstract: Surplus in Japan's current account nearly doubled in June, mostly because of 8.7 percent increase in exports; surplus grew 90.3 percent, to 1.5 trillion yen ($12.6 billion), from year ago; imports declined 4.6 percent because of Japan's weak economy (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Peter Campbell was named executive vice president and creative director at the SKM Group, Williamsville, N.Y.

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Wine.com Raises $9 Million In Financing
abstract: Wine.com, formerly known as eVineyard, says it raised $9 million in financing, with option to raise another $1 million within 60 days, bringing total raised to $39.8 million; chief executive Peter Ekman says latest round of financing will be last company will need in order to become profitable (S)

headline: PATENT OFFICE IS REVIEWING CHIRON CANCER TREATMENT
abstract: Chiron Corp's patent for breast cancer treatment is being reviewed by Patent and Trademark Office as company and Genentech Inc fight over patent in court; patent office is reviewing whether Chiron was first to invent treatment; University of Pennsylvania challenged patent; Chiron's patent can be revoked if patent office determines that university came up with idea first; Chiron sued Genentech for patent infringement in 2000, saying Genentech's Herceptin drug uses Chiron's invention (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Hotels.com Posts Surge In Profit
abstract: Hotels.com says second-quarter net income rose to $18.8 million from $4.65 million year ago; sales rose 66 percent, to $229.7 million from $138.3 million (S)

headline: Private Sector; Walton Endowment Intrigue
abstract: Arkansas state judge exempts University of Arkansas from state's Freedom of Information Act, allowing it to keep secret any details concerning conditions possibly attached to late Wal-Mart Stores founder Sam Walton's $300 million bequest; Arkansas Times, Little Rock weekly newspaper, sought clarification; portrait (M)
