headline: Calpers Adopts Policy On Analyst Conflicts
abstract: California Public Employees' Retirement System adopts policies intended to end conflicts of interest by Wall Street investment bankers and portfolio managers; requires firms doing business with it to end links between analysts' compensation and investment banking and to create review committee to monitor research recommendations (M)

headline: MEADWESTVACO NAMED IN 500 ASBESTOS CLAIMS
abstract: MeadWestvaco Corp says it has been named in 500 asbestos-related complaints, setting off 20 percent decline in its share price (S)

headline: Destitution Seen For Palestinians
abstract: United Nations special coordinator Terje Roed-Larsen says more than half of all Palestinian households have lost at least half their income because of Israel's 'draconian security measures' in Gaza and West Bank; says humanitarian crisis only fuels anger and supports terrorism (S)

headline: Court Blocks Reader's Digest Stock Plan
abstract: Delaware Supreme Court blocks attempt by Reader's Digest Association to replace its two classes of stock with one class that gives all shareholders equal voting rights (S)

headline: South African Village, Fearing AIDS, Trusts God More Than Drugs
abstract: AIDS sufferers in remote Hlabisa, South Africa, where about 35 percent of adults are believed to be infected with HIV, turn to faith healer Rev Solomon Mahlangu and church he founded; his followers believe faith alone will protect them, refusing precautions urged by AIDS counselors; map; photos (M)

headline: Reconstituted S.E.C. Tightens Rules on Insider Stock Deals
abstract: The S.E.C. adopted rules today requiring executives to disclose company information and their own stock trades more quickly.

headline: Car Rentals Are Unexpectedly Strong
abstract: Car rentals are unexpectedly strong; traffic is strong, rates are steady or even rising, and cars are even running short in some places, including New York area; industry officials and analysts estimate customers are paying as much as 10 percent more on daily rental contracts than last summer, when rental companies competed feverishly in tepid travel market; photo (M)

headline: Heady Days for Makers of Luxury Vehicles
abstract: All world's major vehicle manufacturers parade their luxury cars in debuts at Paris auto show; industry steps up production of expensive models in seeming defiance of current economic realities; luxury offerings are priced from $50,000; photos (M)

headline: Portugal and Italy Run Afoul Of Euro Pact Without Penalty
abstract: Portugal and Italy, which agreed along with 10 other European nations to abide by firm fiscal rules when single euro currency was established, acknowledge that their national budgets are breaking those rules; European Commission is responding by putting off having to recognize breaches and looking for ways to ease requirements; Portugal's prime minister says when final figures are available, he believes his country's budget deficit for last year will be about 3.9 percent of gross national product, well above 3 percent ceiling laid down in euro rules; Italy said in its latest four-year economic plan that it was aiming for deficit of 0.8 percent in 2003, abandoning commitment under pact to bring its budget near to balance (M)

headline: BANKNORTH AGREES TO BUY AMERICAN FINANCIAL
abstract: Banknorth Group acquires American Financial Holdings for $709.3 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: HELEN OF TROY IS ACQUIRING SIX BRANDS FROM P.&G.
abstract: Helen of Troy Corp, maker of hair care products, acquires Vitalis and five other consumer brand names from Procter & Gamble (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Cable Bidders Selected
abstract: Deutsche Telekom selects five international consortium bidders for company's cable television units (S)

headline: A Sentiment Gauge Takes an Odd Turn
abstract: Relationship between volume traded on New York Stock Exchange and in Nasdaq market, long a gauge of investor sentiment, is skewed by speculative boom in handful of cheap, battered Nasdaq issues (M)

headline: Creditors to Control Marconi Under Accord to Forgive Debt
abstract: Marconi agrees to hand over almost complete control of company to creditors in return for forgiveness of most of its debts; says existing shareholders will probably wind up owning only 0.5 percent of company, though they will have right to buy additional 5 percent in future (M)

headline: Massage, Aromatherapy, Oils and a Root Canal
abstract: Growing number of dentists in Manhattan are offering extra services, such as foot massages and aromatherapy, to attract patients; photo (M)

headline: Discount Stores Aided Rise In Retail Sales Last Month
abstract: Goldman Sachs retail composite index shows retail sales in June at stores open at least one year rose 4.5 percent following gains of 3.5 percent in May and 1.6 percent in April; says retail sales rose 3.4 percent in June, excluding Wal-Mart, which accounts for more than third of index; chart (M)

headline: Think Before You Scrub A Fragile L.C.D. Screen
abstract: Q. My 6-year-old son lovingly placed a peel-off sticker in the middle of my new computer's L.C.D. screen. I peeled it off, but adhesive remained on the screen. My wife has all kinds of solvents that will remove the adhesive, but I'm afraid they will remove much more than that. What should I do?    A. Using a household cleaner or industrial solvent on a liquid crystal display (L.C.D.) screen can severely damage it. The alcohol or ammonia used in most cleaning products can have a destructive effect on the plastic used in most L.C.D. screens.

headline: Fortune Editor Named to Top Job at Entertainment Weekly
abstract: Time Inc. announced today that Rick Tetzeli, deputy managing editor of Fortune magazine, would become managing editor of Entertainment Weekly.

headline: Microsoft Seen In Wireless Deal
abstract: Microsoft plans to announce partnership with AT&T Wireless Services to offer wireless software and services (S)

headline: C'mon, Computer, Light My Fireworks
abstract: Today's fireworks displays are fired electrically from safe distance, with choreography handled by computer which delivers firing cues with split-second precision in time with music; most large companies have adopted this new technology because it makes their work much safer, however, designing programs is extremely laborious and time-consuming; shows like Macy's annual display in New York City produced by Grucci can cost $100,000 or more; design of show and creation of fireworks described; photos (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Financing Eased On Acquisitions
abstract: India, in effort to bolster its privatization program, says it will permit companies that take over government stakes in businesses to finance acquisitions, and subsequent buybacks of publicly held shares, through external commercial borrowings; under country's takeover laws, company that acquires 15 percent or higher stake in state-owned company must offer to buy additional 20 percent from remaining public shareholders (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Sun Reins In Outlook For Quarter
abstract: Sun Microsystems says first-quarter sales will be little changed from $2.86 billion in sales year ago; chief financial officer Steve McGowan comments (S)

headline: Companies Fault G.O.P. Bill Aimed at Bermuda Loopholes
abstract: House Republicans introduce their bill to stop companies from avoiding US taxes by acquiring Bermuda address, but their plan immedietely comes under attack from prominent companies, which say it would punish legitimate corporate financing without closing Bermuda loophole; National Association of Manufacturers, National Foreign Trade Council and Organization for International Investment, all of which represent global corporations, sharply criticize bill; bill, sponsored by Repr Bill Thomas, would put three-year moratorium, retroactive to March 20, 2002, on companies acquiring Bermuda address; Republicans say bill does nothing to prevent use of royalty and management fees to eliminate American taxes, but such provisions may be added later; Rep Jim McCrery says bill makes tax code friendly for American-based companies, which in end will preserve, and create more, American jobs; Organization for International Investment says bill is seriously flawed; photo of Thomas and Sen Phil Gramm (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Japanese yen sinks to three-month low against US dollar as expectations mount that Japan's economic rebound has stalled; in New York, yen settles at 123.79 cents, up from 123.35 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: The 2 Koreas Set a Site for Family Reunions
abstract: North and South Korea agree to set up permanent meeting place in North for reunions of families divided by Korean War (S)

headline: In Japan, phones make mischief
abstract: TOKYO—  Europe may be anticipating the arrival of the camera-equipped cell phone that lets people swap snapshots over the mobile network, but in Japan, photo-phone use has shown a nasty underbelly.

headline: Personal Business: Career Arc; Ways to Move Up When the Economy Moves Down
abstract: Management and career experts say that, even though times are currently difficult for employees and employers, workers who survive cutbacks can still stand out and make positive differences to their companies and their careers; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.75       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.25       Federal funds   1.75   1.74   3.75       3-month T-bills   1.56   1.61   3.39       6-month T-bills   1.52   1.59   3.29       10-yr. headline: China Juggles Conflicting Pressures of Society in Transition
abstract: The Times interviewed people from different walks of life to give a sense of who the Chinese are today.

headline: Buying Group For Hospitals Changes Ways
abstract: Pressure from Congress forces private company Premier Inc, purchasing group for hospitals, to agree to sweeping changes in how it does business; group, which helps about quarter of nation's hospitals buy billions of dollars in drugs and medical devices and other supplies, will contract with more companies and stop investing in supply companies; will limit how much money it accepts from companies that get Premier contracts; Congressional negotiators press efforts to reach similar agreement with Novation, other major buying group; both companies remain subjects of ongoing federal investigations; Sens Herb Kohl and Mike DeWine, ranking members of antitrust subcommittee of Senate Judiciary Committee trust subcommittee, laud Premier's decision; plan hearing to monitor reform plan (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: Kaplan Thaler Group, part of Bcom3 Group, forms strategic alliance with another Bcom3 agency, Semaphore Partners, by which Semaphore will serve as interactive services partner to Kaplan Thaler for new business (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Telecom Joint Venture
abstract: Pacific Century CyberWorks Ltd, Hong Kong's biggest phone company, and China Telecom, which operates most of fixed-line phones in China, announce joint venture to offer computer and telecommunications services for back offices of banks, insurers and securities firms in mainland China; Pacific Century will initially have 48.5 percent stake in venture, while China Telecom will have 51.5 percent stake (S)

headline: Israel Says Target in Gaza Raid Was Wounded, but Escaped
abstract: Israeli officials acknowledge that helicopter strike in Gaza City failed to kill its target, Muhammad Deif, bombmaker for militant group Hamas who has been on Israel's wanted list for decade; photo of Hamas gunmen (M)

headline: Europeans Try Air Fares Without the Fine Print
abstract: British Airways has radically simplified its fare structure on European routes to keep business travelers from defecting to low-cost competitors; other big European airlines are doing same; United States airlines, while tinkering with prices and minimum-stay rules on few competitive routes, are generally reluctant to make it easy for business people to get cheap fares; may be forced to act if British Air extends simplified fares to trans-Atlantic routes; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Machinery Orders Rise
abstract: Machinery orders in Japan unexpectedly rise in June, third consecutive monthly gain, but government forecasts suggest rebound will be short-lived (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Accountability Law Puts Executive Benefit in Doubt  The new corporate accountability law has put in doubt the status of billions of dollars in life insurance policies used to compensate executives. The policies, known as split-dollar insurance, can amount to huge windfalls for executives. The law banned company loans to executives, and the insurance premiums could be considered interest-free loans.     The uncertainty has virtually halted the sale of the policies, pending clarification. Their demise could have widespread implications. Insurance companies are expecting declines in revenue, and agents are looking at a future without the commissions. [Page A1.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Software Profit Rises
abstract: India's Infosys Technologies says first-quarter profit rose 14 percent from year earlier; photo (S)

headline: Marketing Medicine
abstract: Prescription drug advertising seems to be making impression on consumers; Intermedia Advertising Group, lists 10 most effective television drug ads; table; photo (S)

headline: Afghans Intercept Fuel Truck Aimed at U.S.-Run Air Base
abstract: Maj Gen Hilmi Akin Zorlu of Turkey, who leads 4,700-man International Security Assistance Force in Kabul, reports that on Sept 14, Afghan police intercepted booby-trapped tanker gorged with jet fuel and destined for American military air base at Bagram, 40 miles to north; discovery underlines continuing threat that faces 7,800-member American military force in Afghanistan; photo (M)

headline: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Approval of Hepatitis B Drug
abstract: FDA advisory committee unanimously recommends approval for Gilead Sciences drug adefovir for hepatitis B (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: National Semiconductor Posts Net Income
abstract: National Semiconductor says net income was $1.3 million in first quarter ended Aug 25 compared with loss of $54.6 million year earlier; sales to $420.6 million from $339.3 million (S)

headline: Luxury Car Sales in U.S. Lift Earnings At Toyota
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp says that its profit more than doubled in first fiscal quarter as result of strong demand for its luxury models, weak yen and strong dollar, and one-time gain from its pension fund; company earns 352 billion yen in quarter--about $2.8 billion--up 117 percent from quarter year ago (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The American Advertising Federation, Washington, introduced a unit to focus on multicultural advertising, marketing and diversity to be called the AAF Center on Multiculturalism. Two of the initial programs led by the center will be the Mosaic Awards and the Multicultural Resources Expo. Representatives Carolyn Cheeks Kilpatrick, Democrat of Michigan and Robert Menendez, Democrat of New Jersey, are honorary chairwoman and chairman of these events.

headline: Czech Capital Overwhelmed by Floodwaters
abstract: Floodwaters swept through the historic center of Prague today as the Vltava River burst its banks.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Accusation Against Kremlin Critic
abstract: Boris Berezovsky, former Kremlin insider who is now fierce critic of Russian Pres Vladimir V Putin, and partner are charged with embezzling 2,033 cars from AvtoVaz through dealer they controlled; Berezovsky denies charges (S)

headline: Flexible Camcoder Lets You Shoot, Edit and Play on DVD
abstract: Hitachi introduces three digital camcorders with editing features; they serve as portable cameras and home-video DVD players; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Telecom Loss
abstract: Alcatel reports second-quarter loss of 177 million euros ($176.2 million), beating analysts' predictions of loss of 235 million euros; chief executive Serge Tchuruk comments (S)

headline: Annan Tells Iraq It Must Allow Unfettered Weapons Inspections
abstract: Secretary General Kofi Annan tells Iraq it expects 'full and unconditional cooperation' with United Nations weapons inspectors when they return to country; American officials charge that Iraq is seeking to limit sites that inspectors can examine (M)

headline: Sept. 11 Photo Exhibition Touches a Nerve in Berlin
abstract: Exhibition of photographs taken in aftermath of Sept 11 terrorist attacks in New York City and Washington opens in Berlin, in show partly financed by Germany's Interior Ministry; opening is quiet event, with patrons moving silently from one image to another; show will travel to 14 cities across Europe, including Paris, London, Zurich and Stockholm (M)

headline: China Frees AIDS Activist After Month of Outcry
abstract: China's most prominent advocate for AIDS patients, Dr. Wan Yanhai, was unexpectedly released today after nearly a month's detention by China's State Security apparatus.    The release came after an international outcry over his arrest, with an extraordinary range of voices, including the State Department, United Nations officials, and Act Up, the protest group concerned with AIDS issues, expressing their concerns.

headline: Timetable Softened on Gene-Modified Wheat
abstract: Monsanto pulls back from its stated timeline for bringing first genetically modified wheat to market by 2005 (S)

headline: Willing to Sweat, After All These Years
abstract: International Health, Raquet and Sportsclub Association says that health club memberships among people 55 and older almost quintupled from 1987 to 2001; graphs (M)

headline: IRANIAN PRESIDENT SAYS U.S. LEADERS 'MISUSED' SEPT. 11
abstract: Iranian Pres Mohammad Khatami accuses Pres Bush and other senior American officials of misusing September 11 terrorist attacks to create atmosphere of violence and war across world that could sow seeds for still more destruction, news conference, Kabul, Afghanistan; warns widening campaign against terrorism could unleash chain reaction that could engulf countries other than intended targets in new round of violence, implying that US itself could be among victims; his visit to Afghanistan is first in 40 years by Iranian head of state; criticisms turn visit, first in 40 years by Iranian head of state, into forum for airing Iran's bitter differences with US rather than to demonstrate Iran's backing for government of Pres Hamid Karzai; photo (M)

headline: Productivity Rise Is Tied to Agility Of Employers In Rapid Layoffs
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics reports annual growth rate of productivity rose 1.1 percent in second-quarter; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Pilot Error Cited In Crash
abstract: Two SU-27 fighter jet pilots that crashed at air show in Lviv, Ukraine, on Jul 27 deviated from original flight plan according to investigators of National Security and Defense Council; they were trying unauthorized stunt when plane crashed into crowd of spectators, killing 85 and injuring more than 200; both pilots survived and face prosecution (S)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: Deaths From Spoiled Food; SOUTH KOREA: A Rare Flag Sighting; CHINA: Dalai Lama'S Envoy Visits Tibet;.

headline: Some London Hotels Offer the Future for Guests
abstract: Several hotels in London have moved to forefront of providing high-technology amenities by combining fully equipped personal computers, high-speed Internet access and digital movies and music on demand in one unit; system is designed by Neos Interactive; Lanesborough Hotel became first hotel in London to install system two years ago; Dorchester Hotel is installing same system in every one of its 250 rooms; Dorchester management consultant Sue Moore comments; photo (M)

headline: Bomb Kills 7 in Jerusalem; Hamas Claims Responsibility
abstract: A bomb believed planted by a Palestinian group exploded in a cafeteria at Hebrew University in Jerusalem today.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Hispanics' Use Of Web Surges
abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings survey shows Hispanics' use of World Wide Web at home is growing faster than that of any other ethnic group in US; finds online Hispanic population grew 13 percent, to nearly 7.6 million, compared with overall Web population growth of 3 percent, to almost 105 million; percentage of Web users who identify themselves as Asian or Pacific Islander grew 6 percent, to nearly 2.4 million; Caucasian group grew 4 percent, to more than 94 million; African-American users increased 3 percent, to nearly 7.8 million (S)

headline: Year After 9/11, Cyberspace Door Is Still Ajar
abstract: Few American businesses or organizations have responded to heightened fears of cyberterrorism in wake of Sept 11 attacks with new measures to safeguard their computing systems from intruders; fears and effort led by White House cyberspace security adviser Richard A Clark to establish computer security framework have not spurred spending on security; little money has been spent to enhance other areas of computer security, like disaster preparedness of information technology systems, that have also come under scrutiny since Sept 11; graphs of results of survey of people who run information networks; photos (M)

headline: PRESIDENT REBUFFS MOVES BY GERMANY TO MEND RELATIONS
abstract: German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder moves to repair damaged relations with Washington after winning narrow re-election on platform that opposed any US military action against Iraq, but is rebuffed by Pres Bush who breaks with protocol and refrains from making customary congratulatory telephone call; says Justice Min Herta Daubler-Gmelin, who compared Pres Bush's actions to those of Hitler, will not be member of new government; says basis of relationship between both countries is so secure that fears played up during election are unfounded; Foreign Min Joschka Fischer says government will work hard to repair damage; says good relations are especially crucial for Germany; Schroder's stance on Iraq has also irked NATO allies, making common European position difficult since it was made without consultation; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld is blunt about Schroder campaign at meeting of NATO defense ministers in Prague; says way German election campaign was conducted was 'notably unhelpful' and had effect of poisoning relationship; refuses to meet with German counterpart Peter Struck; senior Bush administration official says Schroder government has long way to go to repair damage from excesses during campaign; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Vietnam: Shake-Up By Central Committee
abstract: Central Committee of Vietnamese Communist Party dismisses two senior officials linked to corruption scandal (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Farms For Sale, For Citizens Only
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin signs legislation intended to create legal system for buying and selling Russia's farmlands for first time since Bolshevik Revolution in 1917; bill is part of Putin's efforts to revive country's agricultural economy (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Second-Quarter Sales Fall At Nvidia
abstract: Shares of Nvidia Corp, which has restated profits since 2000 amid federal accounting inquiry, falls nearly a third after it warns that second-quarter revenue will fall well short of expectations (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: WorldCom Adds $3.3 Billion To Accounting Troubles  WorldCom, which sought bankruptcy protection last month after disclosing that it had improperly accounted for $3.8 billion in expenses, has uncovered $3.3 billion in additional accounting irregularities. The new disclosure focused on practices that began in 1999, two years earlier than most previous problems.     The disclosure may pose additional problems for Scott D. Sullivan, the chief financial officer, and David Myers, the controller, who have been charged with securities fraud and filing false statements. [Page A1.]

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Agere Posts Narrowed Net Loss
abstract: Agere Systems says its third-quarter loss narrowed because of cost reductions; net loss narrowed to $332 million from $1.11 billion year ago; sales fell to $560 million from $927 million; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Utility Posts Profit
abstract: Net profit for government-controlled Korea Electric Power Corp increased sharply in first half and in second quarter of year despite protests by workers fearful of impact of privatization; company says profit in first half was 1.5 trillion won ($1.3 billion) compared with 890 billion won in first half of 2001; profit for second quarter was 718 billion won ($613 million) compared with 481 billion won last year; sales for quarter totaled 4.9 trillion won, up 8 percent from second quarter of last year (S)

headline: DataBank; A Small Decline for a Distracted Market
abstract: Summary of week's market trading; graphs; tables (M)

headline: Red Square's Pinkish Tinge
abstract: More than 6,000 Mary Kay cosmetics consultants in Russia attend two-day annual convention in Moscow; company rents Kremlin, biggest hall in all Russia, for event (M)

headline: Brand Benefits
abstract: InStat/MDR survey of information technology professionals finds Cisco Systems seems to benefit from enormous brand recognition in network equipment market; 65.5 percent of respondents name Cisco as most recognizable brand; graphs (S)

headline: Russia Says It May Reconsider Its Nuclear Plant Deal With Iran
abstract: Minister of Russia's nuclear energy agency, Aleksandr Y Rumyantsev, after three days of meetings in Moscow with Bush administration officials led by Sec Spencer Abraham, says Russia will weigh 'political' factors in deciding whether to continue building nuclear reactors in Iran, which United States fears could be used covertly to build nuclear arms; insists Russia's cooperation with Iran is limited to civilian development of nuclear energy (M)

headline: Chief Says U.S. Security Needs Links To WorldCom
abstract: WorldCom Inc chief executive John W Sidgmore says that survival of company is national security issue and that his management team is not responsible for company's accounting problems; does not rule out bankruptcy filing; IDT Corp offers $5 billion for WorldCom's MCI long-distance operations and its local telephone assets; WorldCom says any serious offer will be considered, but it will be highly unlikely that company will consider selling any of its core assets like MCI or local assets; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says he is not worried about any security risks arising arising from WorldCom's difficulties; photo (M)

headline: BONE LOSS CITED IN STUDY OF PHARMACIA CONTRACEPTIVE
abstract: Study by National Institute of Child Health and Human Development indicates that women taking Pharmacia's contraceptive drug Depo-Provera may suffer bone loss (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Ex-Foe Visits Capital
abstract: Jose Alexandre Gusmao, who as leader of East Tir

headline: World Briefing: Africa
abstract: ZIMBABWE: Getting Tougher With Whites; CENTRAL AFRICAN REPUBLIC: Deal With Libya;.

headline: A PC Helps This Remote To Do It All
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column describes Harmony remote control, which promises to simplify control of home theater components by combining technologies of programmable and all-in-one remote control devices; discusses set-up procedure and notes several glitches, but finds it to be generally useful tool; drawing, photo (M)

headline: Nokia to Join With I.B.M. In 2 Ventures On Software
abstract: Nokia and IBM will announce agreement to develop software to distribute music and other media securely to cellphones over wireless radio networks in effort to broaden market for wireless services beyond telephone service and simple text messages; are also announcing licensing deal in which Nokia's wireless software will be integrated with IBM's digital media software and will be sold and supported by IBM's big services unit; software used by Nokia and INM is based on Java, programming language developed by Sun Microsystems; analysts say announcements represent attempt by two companies to open door to richer set of wireless media offerings in future and deflect emerging threat from Microsoft in market for software for mobile handheld devices (M)

headline: JOHANNESBURG SUMMIT : U.S. critics at Earth summit dispute Bush on environment
abstract: JOHANNESBURG:—  A delegation of U.S. congressmen and mayors told the UN World Summit for Sustainable Development Thursday that a growing number of Americans disagree with President George W. Bush's environmental policies, particularly his rejection of the Kyoto Protocol on climate change.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Fujitsu Hard Drive Problem
abstract: Japan's largest maker of business computers, Fujitsu Ltd, discovers fault in its hard disk drives that may force it to replace as many as 300,000; its share price declines 4.9 percent (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: England: Invensys Sells Division
abstract: Invensys, British manufacturer of factory controls, agrees to sell its sensor business, based in Shelby, NC, to Honeywell International for net $394 million; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: More Jobs Cut At Bank
abstract: Dresdner Bank AG confirms it is to cut 2,700 to 3,000 jobs as part of new $684 million cost-cutting program; says 1,000 to 1,200 of job cuts will come at bank's troubled investment banking operation Dresdner Kleinworth Wasserstein (S)

headline: Swami Satchidananda, Woodstock's Guru, Dies at 87
abstract: Swami Satchidananda, guru with gigantic cottony beard who opened Woodstock festival by calling music 'the celestial sound that controls the whole universe,' dies at age 87; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; ChevronTexaco Gets Some Help From $30 Oil
abstract: ChevronTexaco is getting some financial help from rise in oil price to nearly $30 per barrel; ChevronTexaco's stock price has dropped nearly 15 percent since Jan 23; company's problems have been attributed in large part to its involvement with Dynegy; ChevronTexaco owns 26.5 percent of Dynegy; ChevronTexaco's second-quarter earnings declined 81 percent because of slump in energy prices and $531 milion write-off that it took on its Dynegy investment; some analysts say that confidence in ChevronTexaco has been eroded more by problems in its core business rather than by Dynegy's troubles; ChevronTexaco's chief financial officer John Watson comments; graph; photo (Market Place column) (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia/New Zealand: Rate Activity Is Mixed
abstract: Reserve Bank of Australia leaves overnight cash target interest rate at 4.75 percent; New Zealand's central bank raises its main interest rate quarter-point, to 5.75 percent; photo (S)

headline: G.M. Profit Doubles, but Worries on Pensions Hurt Stock
abstract: General Motors Corp reports earnings of $1.29 billion in second quarter compared with $477 million year earlier; revenue rose to $48.27 billion from $46.22 billion; GM's share of US auto market increased, to 28.1 percent in quarter from 27.3 percent in quarter year earlier; says value of its pension fund declined 3 percent in first half of year; company had projected 10 percent gain; GM shares fall $2.08, or 4.3 percent, to $45.84; chief financial officer John M Devine comments (M)

headline: CHESAPEAKE REDUCES PROFIT FORECAST ON LOWER SALES
abstract: Chesapeake Corp cuts full-year profit forecast to $1.30 to $1.50 a share (S)

headline: AIRLINES RESCIND INCREASE IN COMPANION FARES
abstract: Major air carriers led by American Airlines rescind $20 round-trip rise in some leisure fares for travel companions (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Mexico: TV Azteca To Spin Off Phone Stake
abstract: TV Azteca will spin off its stake in Unefon, mobile phone operator, to its shareholders, who will be asked to approve move next month (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: CNOOC In Deal
abstract: CNOOC Ltd, China's largest offshore oil producer, plans to pay British Petroleum $275 million for 12.5 percent stake in Indonesia's Tangguh natural gas fields; BP would retain 37.5 percent stake (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Bae Names a Director
abstract: BAE Systems appoints Michael Portillo as nonexecutive director; photo (S)

headline: Being the Joneses
abstract: Letter from Herbert J Gans replies to Aug 4 On the Contrary article concerning greed

headline: Zambian Anti-Corruption Effort Pits President vs. Predecessor
abstract: Anti-corruption drive by Zambia's new Pres Levy Mwanawasa pits him against predecessor Frederick Chiluba, who chose him to be presidential candidate, apparently confident that he would safeguard darkest secrets of government that by many accounts stole with little fear and even less shame; Mwanawasa is pushing Parliament to lift Chiluba's immunity from prosecution following recent disclosures of questionable state payments and allegations of other corruption; move could land Chiluba in court and even in jail; Mwanawasa has managed to dodge questions about his own election, winning applause from people who questioned legitimacy of his victory and from skeptics who predicted he would be Chiluba's puppet; maps (M)

headline: Taxing matters : Permanent U.S. expatriates can face hefty liabilities
abstract: A permanent move overseas can be an effective way of reducing your tax liability and widening investment horizons, but there are traps for the ill-prepared. Pre-expatriation tax advice should always be sought to make the most of planning opportunities in these areas.

headline: Some U.S. Travelers Now Guided by Politics
abstract: Survey by Euro RSCG Worldwide indicates that Americans have altered their travel criteria since 2001 terrorist attacks; Americans now express reluctance to travel to certain countries that exhibit strong anti-American and anti-Semitic attitudes and actions (M)

headline: Interview With Jacques Chirac
abstract: PARIS, Sept. 8 — Following are excerpts from an interview with President Jacques Chirac of France. The interview was conducted in French and translated by The New York Times.

headline: Hostility and Drama Swamp Palestinian's Hearing
abstract: Marwan Barghouti, Fatah leader in West Bank and most prominent Palestinian leader to be put on trial by Israel, makes his scond court appearance; Barghouti's three teen-age children appear in court, giving new dimension to drama, as do shouts of rage from Israelis who lost relatives in suicide attacks he is accused of orchestrating; Israeli newspapers are increasingly questioning government's wisdom in putting Barghouti on public trial; until current uprising he was accepted in Israel as political moderate, staunch supporter of Oslo peace agreements and as potential successor to Yasir Arafat; photo (M)

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for DR. RAYMOND L. WOOSLEY; Terror Adds to Safety Issues Awaiting New F.D.A. Chief
abstract: Dr Raymond L Woosley, pharmacologist and vice president for health sciences at University of Arizona, answers questions on challenges facing Dr Mark B McClellan, newly nominated chief of Food and Drug Administration, whose job has been expanded to include review and approval of drugs for protection from terrorism (M)

headline: WORKERS AT DIAL SOAP PLANT RATIFY 4-YEAR CONTRACT
abstract: Union for Dial Corp's workers at plant in Aurora, Ill, ratifies new four-year labor agreement after voting down contract proposal earlier in month; union represents 300 workers at plant, where company manufactures Dial soap (S)

headline: Tuneup Lets Mac Go Full Throttle
abstract: David Pogue State of the Art column explores upgrade for Apple's Mac OS X; when new operating system was released, Mac fans were not enamored of it, but this upgrade, called Jaguar, restores speed and adds some new features; drawing (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Karen Blair was named to the new post of director for production services and account supervisor at Kurman Communications, Chicago.

headline: Chemical threat exists, and 'nuclear wild card' is raised : A report on Iraqi arms spells out risks
abstract: PARIS:—  Iraq probably does not have enough chemical or biological weapons or long-range missiles to offer serious military resistance to U.S. armed forces protecting nearby countries or even invading Iraq itself, according to an independent assessment by a leading Western think tank.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Brewer's Profit Down
abstract: Interbrew says first-half earnings fell 12 percent, compared with first six months of 2001 (S)

headline: Jitters for Securities Industry As Goldman Plans New Job Cuts
abstract: Several hundred more investment bankers and traders are likely to lose their jobs before end of year as firms, including Goldman Sachs Group, try to reduce costs as market slump drags on; some firms like Lehman Brothers Holdings say they will try to avoid broad layoffs and will resort instead to paying smaller bonuses to many employees; Goldman Sachs reports 11 percent increase in third-quarter profit ended Aug 30; company earned $522 million, up from $468 million year earlier; overall revenue was flat at $3.65 billion; revenue from investment banking fell 40 percent, to $652 million; Lehman Brothers reports 37 percent decline in earnings; revenue from trading stocks and bonds dropped 63 percent, to $234 million, pulling down net revenue 17 percent, to $1.35 billion; net income dropped to $194 million, down from profit of $309 million last year; Goldman's chief financial officer David Viniar comments; graphs (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: British Cable TV Operator Closer to Deal With Malone  The Liberty Media Corporation, headed by John C. Malone, has moved a step closer to taking control of Telewest, a British cable operator, after Telewest said it would begin talks with bondholders about restructuring its debt.    Telewest and other telecommunications companies in Europe borrowed heavily to finance multiple acquisitions. Now those companies face a shortage of funds, and Mr. Malone appears ready to cash in. [Page C4.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Consumer Borrowing Soared In May
abstract: British consumers borrowed record amounts in May as mortgage lending soared; consumer lending rose 8.3 billion pounds ($12.7 billion) in May, up from April's revised increase of 7.8 billion pounds; mortgage loans surged by 6.8 billion pounds; Britons are taking advantage of lowest borrowing costs since 1964 to buy houses (S)

headline: Doctor's Hand-Held Helper
abstract: Dan Jacob letter on August 22 article notes doctors must, by law, safeguard patient information stored in hand-held devices

headline: Wider Loss for Redback
abstract: Shares of Redback Networks Inc drop after company, maker of broadband and optical-networking equipment, warns that its third-quarter loss will be wider than expected because of weak sales (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Rightist Web Site Closed ; NETHERLANDS: Rightist Leader To Step Down ;.

headline: Bush Selects A Texas Ally As Ambassador To Mexico
abstract: Pres Bush to nominate Antonio O Garza, longtime Texas political ally, as US ambassador to Mexico succeeding Jeffrey Davidow (S)

headline: Tyco Workers Say Faith In Company Is in Shambles
abstract: Accusations of financial chicanery by top management at Tyco International demoralize many of company's hundreds of thousands of employees worldwide; article explores situation at small Tyco subsidiary, Amp Inc, in Rock Hill, SC; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Merrill Replaced Analyst On Enron, Inquiry Finds  In 1998, eager to win more investment business from Enron, Merrill Lynch replaced a research analyst who had angered Enron executives by rating their stock ''neutral'' with one who soon upgraded the firm's rating, Congressional investigators said.    The move highlights the debate over one of the most contentious issues on Wall Street: To what degree do investment banks adjust their stock ratings in order to try to win business from the same companies. [Page A1.]

headline: South Korea in Plan to Attract Capital
abstract: South Korea plans bill to offer tax breaks and other incentives to foreign investors in bid to double foreign investment to fifth of gross deomestic product from current 10 percent; will also set up special economic zones (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: Phone Company Loss; CHINA: Appliance Trade Case; SOUTH KOREA: Bond Issue Planned; SOUTH KOREA: Bank Stake Sold;.

headline: Technology Briefing: Internet
abstract: PAYPAL TO BUILD COMPLEX IN NEBRASKA; EARTHLINK STOCK BUYBACK;.

headline: The Fraternity Of Corporate Exiles: Europe Executives Undone
abstract: Thomas Middelhoff's ouster as Bertelsmann chairman and chief executive reportedly followed clash with Reinhard Mohn family, which controls company, over his aggressive plans to remake old-line media company as new-era media machine and issue public shares; also represents rejection of American way of doing business; similarity of his ouster to that of Jean-Marie Messier at Vivendi Universal discussed; graphs of revenue and income at Bertelsmann units; photos (M)

headline: Floods in Europe Leave Behind a Muddied Political Landscape
abstract: Waters from calamitous floods in Europe this summer have receded, but political debris is wreaking havoc, igniting strife over relief efforts: Vladimir Spidla's fledgling Czech government teeters near collapse; Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's take-charge response in Germany halts momentum of challenger Edmund Stoiber; Jorg Haider gives up right-wing leadership bid in Austria in face of criticism over his demand that tax cut not be deferred (M)

headline: McDonald's Expands Relationship With DDB Worldwide
abstract: Accounts • The McDonald's Corporation, Oakbrook, Ill., expanded its relationship with the Chicago office of DDB Worldwide, part of the Omnicom Group, by selecting the agency to handle advertising for its

headline: Floods Keep Rising in Dresden and Now Spill Northward
abstract: Elbe River reaches record high in Dresden, and fears are mounting over devastation that river may still cause as it plows through northern Germany toward North Sea; 300,000 people are evacuated in Dresden, and volunteers step up efforts to protect centuries-old palaces and museums; flooding is worst in former East Germany and has become issue in general election, with Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, who is seeking new term, offering region hundreds of millions of dollars in aid and promising to invest heavily in reconstruction; photos; map (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: An Acquisition By Symantec
abstract: Symantec Corp purchases Mountain Wave Inc for $20 million (S)

headline: Schröder Uses London Visit To Try to Fix Rift With U.S.
abstract: Newly re-elected German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder flies to London in apparent effort to seek help from British Prime Min Tony Blair in repairing damaged relations with Washington, stemming from his outspoken opposition to any US military action against Iraq during recent election campaign (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Software Maker Sued
abstract: Konami Corp, which makes software for games, is sued by Japan Professional Baseball Players Association, which accused it of using likenesses of ballplayers without league's authorization; Konami says it has signed licensing contract with Professional Baseball Organization of Japan, operators of league and co-defendant in suit (S)

headline: A Multifaceted Machine Handles (Nearly) Everything
abstract: a multi

headline: A Catholic Is Shot to Death As Violence Flares in Ulster
abstract: Violence flares in Northern Ireland, with series of shootings in Belfast that left one man dead and two seriously wounded; Ulster Freedom Fighters, Protestant paramilitary group, claims responsibility for death of 19-year-old Gerald Lawlor; says it is in retaliation for earlier attack on Protestant; photo (M)

headline: Pressure to Plan for War
abstract: The pressure on the Pentagon to plan for a war on Iraq underscores the failure of diplomacy and covert operations to dislodge Saddam Hussein. News analysis, Page A6.

headline: Shifting Colombia's Aid: U.S. Focuses on Rebels
abstract: Little-noticed provision of antiterrorism package newly signed by Pres Bush authorizes new Colombian Pres Alvaro Uribe Velez to use nearly $1.7 billion in American military aid directly against leftist rebels and right-wing paramilitaries; previous guidelines limited use of American-supplied helicopters and soldiers trained by United States trooops to anti-drug operations; policy shift comes at time of escalating guerrilla violence (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Stock Sale Is Oversubscribed
abstract: Ericsson, Swedish telecommunications equipment maker, says that buyers sought more shares than were available in its $3.2 billion stock sale at 1992 prices; its shares are down 84 percent in 2002 (M)

headline: Readers and Writers Debate Columnist's Exit
abstract: Forced resignation of Bob Greene, Chicago Tribune's most popular columnist, in wake of disclosure that he had 1988 sexual encounter with 17-year-old subject of one of his articles is hotly debated in Chicago and among journalists; at issue is whether his conduct was personal or misuse of his position; incident came to light after he complained to FBI that he felt threatened, FBI warned woman, now 31, against extortion and harassment and anonymous letter was sent to Tribune's Web site; photo (M)

headline: Once Again, Pope Bids His Homeland Farewell
abstract: Pope John Paul II said an emotional, lingering goodbye to Poland today with words that captured how hard it was for him to leave his beloved homeland.

headline: Insurer's Chief Sees No Relief On Premiums For Businesses
abstract: Prices for business insurance are continuing to soar and American International Group chief executive Maurice R Greenberg says he expects no letup at least through next year; says premiums on commercial coverages jumped more than 34 percent and contributed significantly to 37 percent increase in net profit in second quarter; company reports net income of $1.8 billion compared with $1.3 billion year earlier (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: CenturyTel Completes Sale Of Wireless Unit
abstract: CenturyTel Inc completes sale of its mobile-phone business to its rival, Alltel Corp, for $1.65 billion (S)

headline: London Group Says Iraq Lacks Nuclear Material for Bomb
abstract: Iraq will be unable to build a nuclear weapon for years unless it obtains radioactive material on the black market, a leading security affairs research organization said today.

headline: Vilnius Journal; Is Big Brother Being Replaced by Big Oil Company?
abstract: Williams International, Oklahoma conglomerate that owns 27 percent of stock and exclusive management rights in Mazeikiu Nafta oil refinery in Vilnius, Lithuania, will turn over keys to Yukos Petroleum of Moscow, Russia's second-largest oil producer; $85 million transaction gives Yukos 54 percent of refinery's shares and control of business that not only dominates Lithuania's gasoline supply, but also contributes tenth of its gross domestic product; deal catapults Russia into ranks of Lithuania's top foreign investors, and this gives Lithuanians pause; photos; map (M)

headline: Sharing Space? Share E-Mail First
abstract: Many incoming freshman are meeting electronically before they arrive at college; some say it helps alleviate tension of living with someone new, while others voice concern about possible mistaken first impressions and are careful about styling their e-mail messages; photos (M)

headline: Anthem Reports Rise in Profit
abstract: Anthem Inc, which owns Blue Cross and Blue Shield health plans in nine states, reports that its second-quarter profit increased 47 percent as it added customers and increased premiums; net income rises to $106.2 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Decision Soon On Steel Tariffs
abstract: European Union says it will decide by July 19 whether to retaliate against American steel tariffs, keeping pressure on Pres Bush for more exemptions; US has received more than 1,200 requests for exemptions from steel import tariffs as high as 30 percent that Bush imposed on March 20; European Union says decision could lead to retaliatory duties as of Aug 1 (S)

headline: Woes of 'Donahue' Cast Shadow Over MSNBC
abstract: Phil Donahue's talk show on MSNBC has lost 40 percent of its audience in its four weeks of existence and has fallen well behind Connie Chung's new show on CNN and Bill O'Reilly's on Fox News Channel, which dominates weeknights at 8; Donahue's show is centerpiece of effort by MSNBC and its parent, NBC, to move MSNBC away from reliance on news coverage during day and documentary-style programs in prime time and toward format of opinionated talk all the time; photos; graph (M)

headline: Easing of Marijuana Laws Angers Many Britons
abstract: Six-month experiment in loosening England's national drug laws in Brixton section of South London pleases many marijuana smokers but leaves many other residents feeling that their neighborhood has turned into open-air drug bazaar; partly as result of Brixton's trial, government has announced plans to downgrade criminal penalties for smoking pot in country where estimated five million people are habitual users; plan is acknowledgment that drugs like heroin and cocaine are far more harmful than marijuana, but it gets mixed reviews and raises host of questions about loosening marijuana laws; photos; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: New Line Of Communication
abstract: North and South Korean military officers use telephone 'hot line' to place calls to each other from either side of demilitarized zone; they are coordinating work on mine-clearing for railroad track they have agreed to build through zone (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Tax Inquiry For Ousted Defense Chief
abstract: Former German Defense Minister Rudolf Scharping is being investigated for possible tax evasion; Scharping says he has reported all income (S)

headline: Greenspan Warns on Budget Deficit
abstract: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned today that the economy would suffer if Congress fails to keep the federal budget deficit under control.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: Lack Of Money For Space Station; BELGIUM: Palestinians Pursue Sharon Case; FRANCE: Camp To Stop Taking Refugees; BRITAIN: Party Is Over For Millionaire Convict; SPAIN: New Threat From Basque Group; SLOVAKIA: Prime Minister Asked To Stay;.

headline: Forbes.com Guarantees Effectiveness of Ads
abstract: Forbes.com Guarantees Effectiveness of Ads Forbes.com, the Web site for Forbes magazine, said yesterday that it would introduce a guarantee to marketers, promising them some measure of effectiveness met after 60 days of advertising or their money back.

headline: Miscellany
abstract: NFO World Group is acquiring JStreetdata.com, interactive health care market research agency (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Honduras: Rights Advocate Slain
abstract: honduras: rights advocate slain

headline: Europeans Split With U.S. on Need for Iraq Attack, Citing Mideast as Priority
abstract: Bush administration's talk of overthrowing Iraq's Pres Saddam Hussein by military force raises alarms among European governments, who fear any American miscalculation could undermine international coalition in fight against terrorism, as well as broad-based diplomacy needed to solve crisis between Israel and Palestinians (M)

abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.75       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.00       Federal funds   1.75   1.72   3.53       3-month T-bills   1.58   1.63   3.28       6-month T-bills   1.58   1.63   3.22       10-yr. headline: Maelstrom Swallows 5 Americans On a Quest
abstract: Five Americans killed in bombing of cafeteria at Hebrew University in Jerusalem apparently were strangers, but they had much in common: all were Americans on spiritual journey, passionate about their studies or work and especially about their belief in Judaism; five are Marla Bennett, Benjamin Blutstein, Janis Ruth Coulter, David Gritz and Dina Carter; friends and relatives recall their commitment to Israel; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Company in Hong Kong May Buy Stake in the Amex  The company that owns the Hong Kong stock exchanges is negotiating to buy a stake in the American Stock Exchange and perhaps even take control of it, an effort that may raise political issues about China's financial influence. Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing has been in discussions with the American Stock Exchange in New York with the goal of creating a system that would allow the same shares to be traded 24 hours worldwide, investment bankers close to the talks said. [Page C3.]    A government-appointed panel of inquiry in Hong Kong concluded that some officials had made errors in connection with the issuance of a trading proposal that set off a steep decline among penny stocks there, angering many investors. [World Business, Section W.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Telecom Profit
abstract: South Korea's SK Telecom Co says second-quarter profit almost doubled; net income rose 97 percent from year earlier, to 457 billion won ($386 million), as sales grew 42 percent, to 2.1 trillion won; graph (S)

headline: DELAY IN POWER PLANTS HURTS DUKE ENERGY'S PROFITS
abstract: Duke Energy Corp's 2002 profits will fall more than forecast because conditions forced company to halt work on three new power plants (M)

headline: Europe Calls It Vital Tax Data; Swiss Banks Call It Vitally Secret
abstract: Switzerland is resisting pressure from other European governments to ferret out tax cheats, fearing it would frighten capital out of their banks; controversy has become public, with European ministers regularly rebuking Swiss for failing to sign European financial disclosure agreement; accord could fail entirely without Swiss involvement because country's banks control about $27 trillion of world's funds and handle third of all money transferred across European borders; 15-country European Union insists that Switzerland help fight tax evasion--though that is not crime in Switzerland--by disclosing amount of interest paid to nonresidents so they can be taxed accordingly in their home countries (M)

headline: F.T.C. CLEARS AMGEN PURCHASE OF IMMUNEX
abstract: Amgen Inc wins antitrust clearance to complete its $9.6 billion purchase of Immunex Corp (S)s

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Argentina: Economy Down, Kidnappings Up
abstract: Argentine government, responding to growing clamor about increase in violent crime after collapse of economy, announces formation of special antikidnapping brigade (S)

headline: New Search At Merrill Is Reported
abstract: Criminal investigators probing Martha Stewart's sale of ImClone Systems stock search office of her stockbroker, Peter E Bacanovic, at Merrill Lynch; leave with boxes of files and documents; Stewart has not cooperated with inquiry into whether her share sale was predicated on insider information (M)

headline: Clement Stone Dies at 100; Built Empire on Optimism
abstract: W Clement Stone, who parlayed $100 in savings into insurance empire that financed millions of dollars of contributions to campaigns of Richard M Nixon and hundreds of millions to charities, dies at age 100; photo (M)

headline: G.E. Profit Rises 14%; Company Projects Gains in 3rd Quarter
abstract: Despite steep losses on WorldCom bonds, G.E. reported today that its earnings rose 14 percent in the second quarter.

headline: TRACES OF TERROR: IN HIS OWN WORDS/Donald H. Rumsfeld; 'The American People Have Got the Staying Power for This'
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld on dealing with terrorism; biographical information; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Airline Posts A Profit
abstract: Cathay Pacific Airways posts unexpected rise in first-half profit on cost reductions after the Sept 11 terror attacks and higher cargo demand; has net income of $181 million, compared with $169 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Perspectives: Sept. 11 and Beyond
abstract: Following are the first four articles in a series in which national and world figures reflect on the terrorist attacks and their effect on a year of public life and policy.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Arrow Exterminators, a termite and pest control company, named Match, Atlanta, as the first agency to handle its account, with billings estimated at less than $1 million.

headline: Unemployment Rate Fell to a Five-Month Low in August
abstract: The Labor Dept. said today employers added 39,000 workers last month, and that the unemployment rate fell to 5.7 percent.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Georgia: President Visits Rebel Area
abstract: Pres Eduard A Shevardnadze visits Pankisi Gorge, lawless region said to be home to dozens of Islamic militants and rebels fighting for independence in Russian republic of Chechnya; Georgian troops and police set up checkpoints in region in effort to establish order, as Russia has long demanded; photo (S)

headline: A TV Rush, At Times Crass, To Remember Sept. 11 Terror
abstract: Television news business is vying to line up officials and survivors whose voices will give accessible dimension to anniversary coverage of terrorist attacks of Sept 11; coverage threatens to mix reverence and solemnity with one-upmanship; newspapers and news magazines are planning special sections or series, but broadcast journalists, whose medium demands immediacy, may be feeling most competitive for exclusive access to people they believe can help recapture collective memory of attacks and aftermath; photos (M)

headline: Market Place; Eisner Critics May Demand Revived Disney By November
abstract: Dissatisfaction with Michael D Eisner by members of Walt Disney Co's board may be broader than previously realized, but few in Hollywood think Eisner is in imminent danger of losing his job; Eisner is believed to have at least until November to demonstate that he is addressing company's problems; it will take at least that long to see how fall television season is faring for Disney's ABC network--and for board to address its own organizational problems and crystallize alliances among Eisner's opponents and supporters; Eisner's boardroom critics go beyond most vocal so far, Roy E Disney, nephew of late Walt Disney, and Stanley P Gold, chief executive of Shamrock Holdings, which manages Disney family fortune; Andrea L Van de Kamp, chairwoman of West Coast unit of Sotheby auction house, expressed concerns to Eisner last month about lowly status of ABC network and seeming lack of planning for his eventual successor; graph; photo (M)

headline: For Arab Informers, Death; For the Executioners, Justice
abstract: Executions of sisters Ikhklas Khouli and Rajah Ibrahim by militant Al Aksa Martyrs Brigades in Tulkarm, West Bank, for allegedly collaborating with Israel have drawn attention as first executions of women in current Palestinian uprising; two allegedly worked for Ali Yassin, who has fled to Israel; Brigades spokesman says Ibrahim brought in bombs that killed group leader Raed al-Karmi, interview; photos (M)

headline: Citigroup and Chase Defend Their Enron Roles
abstract: Citigroup and J P Morgan Chase officials tell Senate committee hearing that they did not improperly help Enron Corp disguise portions of enormous debt that contributed to company's collapse; Senate panel produces evidence that lawmakers say seriously undermines officials' contentions; paints picture of how both banks set up supposedly independent entities that in reality were largely controlled by banks and which allowed Enron to borrow billions of dollars that it did not disclose as debt to investors; at issue are more than $8 billion in so-called prepay deals banks did with Enron, in which company received money upfront in exchange for agreeing to deliver commodities at later date; deals involved supposedly independent third parties that money flowed through; Mahonia was used in deals with J P Morgan Chase, while entity called Delta Energy was used in Citigroup deals; lawmakers say Mahonia and Delta were controlled by banks, and Enron should have been forced to count money received as debt; that would have probably resulted in credit downgrades and more skepticism from investors; documents suggest that two banks knew deals allowed Enron to burnish its financial picture; Sen Carl Levin says two banks 'were biggest participants in Enron's phony prepay transactions'; banks say dealings were commonplace and conformed with proper accounting; both banks deny they controlled Mahonia or Delta; Levin suggests that transaction with Enron called Roosevelt provided evidence of Citigroup's role in cloaking Enron's true financial picture; at issue is five-month extension of $125 million owed by Enron; bank documents say Enron agreed to repay by Sept 30, 1999; amount was not listed as debt on Enron's financial statement; Citigroup executives testifying before committee include James Reilly and Richard Caplan; representing Morgan are Donald H McCree, Robert W Traband and Jeffrey W Dellapina; photo (M)

headline: Berlin Journal; Dear Euro, They Sigh (Not Fondly)
abstract: Germans believe cost of living has increased ever since mark was replaced by euro, common collective currency of most of European Union, on January 1; embraced currency but were quickly embarrassed as it sank immediately below parity with dollar; few are heartened by fact that euro is again at rough parity; consider rise not function of euro's strength but dollar's weakness; photo (M)

headline: As Iraq Rejects New U.N. Rules, Oil Prices Hit a 19-Month High
abstract: Crude oil rises to 19-month high after Iraq refuses to accept new United Nations resolutions on weapons inspections, raising chances of US attack on Iraq, supplier of 2 percent of world's oil; crude oil for November delivery rises 87 cents, or 2.9 percent, to $30.71 per barrel in New York trading (M)

headline: Investing; A Bet on Drugstores, If Not Drug Makers
abstract: Uncertainties about new products and political pressures that plague pharmaceutical manufacturers do not extend to drugstores that vend their products; investors see drugstores as conservative, handy way of investing in health care sector (M)

headline: Dirty Laundry, Online for All to See
abstract: Jim Cissell, clerk of courts for Hamilton County, Ohio, has put together searchable Web site that contains all court records, opening huge debate about privacy; Cissell has received complaints, even threats, from people saying their privacy has been violated, but he says records were already public and electronic; all that has changed is accessibility; judges are acting to shield medical and financial records in some cases and pressure is building to remove family- and traffic-court records as well; other counties are considering similar sites, leaving states to pass privacy legislation; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Gu

headline: Mattel Expands Role Of WPP Division
abstract: Mattel Inc expands its relationship with Young & rubicam Advertising by selecting its office in Irvine, Calif, as lead agency handling worldwide advertising for its boys and entertainment division; spending estimated at $40 million to $50 million (S)

headline: AMERICAN ELECTRIC POWER REDUCES PROFIT OUTLOOK
abstract: American Electric Power Co reduces its 2002 profit outlook by 10 percent as company warns that its second-quarter profit will fall short of analysts' expectations (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Police Investigate Suicide Raid
abstract: Investigators examine body of one of three men who blew themselves up with grenades 25 miles from missionary school in Pakistan attacked earlier in week; bodies of other two men washed down river; three reportedly said they carried out attack (S)

headline: Radio Stations Appeal Ruling on Web Fees
abstract: Clear Channel Communications and other radio operators ask appeals court to review rulings forcing them to pay record companies royalties for songs played on Internet; appeal, filed by National Association of Broadcasters and several radio operators, challenges ruling by federal court that allowed Copyright Office to set royalty rates; Recording Industry of America wants court to reject appeal (S)

headline: Britain's Case: Iraqi Program to Amass Arms Is 'Up and Running'
abstract: News analysis; British government's report on Iraq's weapons of mass destruction appears clearly intended to make strong case for urgent return of UN inspectors and for necessary pressure to force Iraqi cooperation with their work (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DELPHI CORP., Troy, Mich., the world's largest maker of auto parts, said it had won contracts from General Motors, Detroit, to provide components, including steering systems and satellite radios, for the 2003 models of Chevrolet's Cavalier, Silverado and Suburban. Terms were not disclosed.    DAIMLERCHRYSLER, Stuttgart, said it would invest $600 million in an expansion of its factory in Tuscaloosa, Ala., where it plans to build its new Mercedes-Benz Grand Sports Tourer, a luxury sport utility vehicle, which is scheduled to be introduced in the United States in 2005.

headline: Parties Trade Lobs Over Issue of Lax Oversight
abstract: Democrats and Republicans try to blame each other for years of supposedly lax oversight of corporate behavior while senators debate accounting reform bill in advance of expected vote on July 15; House minority leader, Richard A Gephardt, accuses Republicans of setting stage for corporate wrongdoing through gradual drive for deregulation, starting with Contract With America in 1995; distributes pamphlet to support his point, with photographs of House minority whip Tom DeLay and Newt Gingrich, former speaker of House, on cover, along with logos of embattled companies; Republican National Committee, in e-mail response, notes that some Democrats supported bills that Gephardt's pamphlet calls 'overzealous efforts to roll back public protections'; majority of Democrats had voted against bills; senior Republican aides in Senate counter with their own pamphlet, which tries to pin lax oversight on Bill Clinton; Rep Bernard Sanders says both parties are to blame; Robert W Hahn, director of American Enterprise Institute-Brookings Joint Center for Regulatory Studies, says blame cannot be put on either party; photos of Gephardt and House Speaker J Dennis Hastert (M)

headline: Plot Confirmed, Japan Feels No Less Pain
abstract: Japanese are pained by North Korea's acknowledgement that 13 Japanese people who disappeared in late 1970's and early 1980's were kidnapped by North Korea, and that eight of them have since died; it is one of most sinister and bizarre acts of a government that was just then becoming infamous for terrorism; North Korean leader Kim Jong Il acknowledges that Japanese had been kidnapped so that North Korean agents could, essentially, assume their identities and infiltrate South Korea, posing as Japanese; Kim offers extraordinary apology for deaths of eight of them; much of mystery--including how the eight died--remains, as do roiled emotions of their relatives and millions of other Japanese; photos (M)

headline: Ad Citing Kashmir Stirs Fury in India
abstract: Advertisement run last week by Cadbury India, local unit of multinational candy and soft drink maker Cadbury Schweppes, stirs up national political controversy in India with company issuing apology; ad, promoting company's Temptations brand of chocolates, appeared in copies of Times of India distributed in and around Bombay on Aug 15, 55th anniversary of Indian independence; it included map of India highlighting state of Jammu and Kashmir--all of it, including portion that has been controlled for years by Pakistan, which also claims whole state; politicians and activists of Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party react with fury, saying ad trivialized conflict over Kashmir; Cadbury India issues statement retracting ad (M)

headline: Sales Abroad Push Profit 20% Higher At Honda
abstract: Honda Motor Co reports earnings for April-June quarter of 107.5 billion yen ($905 million), up 20 percent from a year earlier, thanks to strong demand overseas for its minivans and sports utility vehicles; global sales rose 10 percent, to 194 trillion yen; company remains confident about its prospects for rest of year despite weaker sales at home, stronger yen and potential slowdown in US; Toyota Motor raises its 2002 production forecasts by 3.8 percent, to 5.5 million vehicles, with all the projected gains overseas; photo (M)

headline: Of Corporate Lawyers And Accountability
abstract: Theodore J Sheskin letter responds to Aug 4 article about effects of new corporate-responsibility laws on lawyers

headline: Planned Bond Sales Coming This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a four-week bill being auctioned tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.69 percent; the six-month issue, 1.72 percent; and the four-week bill, 1.67 percent.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Rightist Web Site Closed ; NETHERLANDS: Rightist Leader To Step Down ;.

headline: ONLINE DIARY
abstract: Online Diary: bookcrossing.com is Web site that encourages readers to pass books on by leaving them in public places, ideally to be found by other book lovers; whatsbetter.com juxtaposes two unrelated things and asks Web surfers to choose their preference; Matthew McClintock offers Web surfers catalog of entire contents of his home on mc.clintock.com; www.the5k.org offers annual contest for Web programmers, who make up games using less than 5 kilobytes of coding; drawings (M)

headline: Hedging Learned at the Family Farm
abstract: John Henry, who owns controlling stake in Boston Red Sox and small piece of New York Yankees, is one of few investment managers making money; John W Henry & Co struggled during bull market but is prospering again, with funds appreciating sharply; Henry says he has accepted bid from Yankees' management to sell investment in Yankees, but money has not been sent; rules of baseball prohibit dual ownership; photo (M)

headline: Vivendi's Chief Is Said to Favor Bidding American Units Adieu
abstract: Vivendi Universal chief executive Jean-Rene Fourtou reportedly will propose that company separate its American entertainment division from remainder of its operations; Vivendi has sold some assets to relieve its cash shortage; photos (M)

headline: RUSSIA SAYS TOLL IN COPTER'S CRASH HAS REACHED 114
abstract: Death toll in Aug 19 crash of Russian military helicopter in Chechnya minefield is put at 114, and incident intensifies political pressure on Pres Vladimir V Putin; some officials say helicopter appear to have been shot down by Chechen rebels using portable surface-to-air missile, but conflicting accounts of what happened, along with reports of poor maintenance, encourage comparison with 2000 sinking of submarine Kursk, which cost 118 lives; Gennady A Zyuganov, Communist leader, blames government for decrepit state of armed services, which suffer from low morale and corruption and are lumbering with aging equipment; Col Gen Vital Pavlov is suspended as chief of army's air services pending investigation into crash; photos; maps (M)

headline: Israelis and Palestinians Settle Further Into Their Stalemate
abstract: Israel's outgoing army chief of staff said today that only the expulsion or replacement of the Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat might prompt an Israeli withdrawal from West Bank cities.

headline: Spain Sees Arrests of Basque Separatists as Group's Unraveling
abstract: Spanish officials hail arrest in France of two Basque separatist leaders as beginning of the end of organization that has killed more than 800 people; Juan Antonio Olarra Guridi and Ainhoa Mugika are identified as military leaders of ETA (M)

headline: Compressed Data; A Digital Video Format Is Catching in Television
abstract: Sony 24P digital video format gains popularity in TV production, with over quarter of prime-time comedies and dramas on major broadcast and cable networks using system; cinematographers, used to doing this work with 35-millimeter motion picture cameras, adapt to new technology; photo (M)

headline: A Blow to Security, and to Tolerance
abstract: Fortresslike campus of Hebrew University on Mount Scopus in Jerusalem gave students and professors sense of security, but that is gone following bombing of campus cafeteria in which seven people were killed and dozens wounded; attack has challenged efforts to maintain diverse academic community in environment rife with bloodshed and hate; bombing victims include Jews, Arabs and foreigners, including five Americans; foreign students are grappling with loss of compatriots killed in attack, waiting for news of wounded and debating with anxious relatives back home whether they should stay in Israel; photo; map (M)

headline: Browser Battle Winds Down
abstract: StatMarket reports formerly heated battle between Web browser software made by Microsoft and Netscape has all but ended, with Microsoft's Internet Explorer browser now used by 96 percent of Web surfers worldwide, compared with 3 percent for Netscape; market share graph; drawing (S)

headline: SHAKE-UP AT AOL
abstract: A PITCHMAN FALLS -- As Robert W. Pittman resigned his No. 3 post at AOL Time Warner, it appeared that he had fallen victim to his own sales pitch.   PAGE C1    WHERE IS STEVE CASE? -- For much of the last year, as problems have mounted and the stock has crashed, Stephen M. Case, AOL Time Warner's chairman, has been all but invisible.   PAGE C1

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.75        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.25        Federal funds   1.75   1.75   3.71        3-month T-bills   1.68   1.69   3.52        6-month T-bills   1.70   1.73   3.44        10-yr. T-infl.   3.11   3.07   3.43        10-yr. T-note   4.73   4.80   5.26        30-yr. T-bond   5.41   5.48   5.66        Telephone bd.   7.48   7.57   7.83        Municipal bds.   5.25   5.26   5.36          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Rosie the Star Pulls Plug On Rosie the Magazine
abstract: Rosie O'Donnell pulls out of venture with Gruner & Jahr USA to publish Rosie magazine in dispute over editorial control; each side blames other for demise of magazine, which will close with December issue; she feels her image was hijacked to market magazine she neither believed in nor controlled, while company argues she was using Rosie to pursue narrow personal agenda unsuited to mass audience; company plans to sue her; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Gunmen Kill Four Israelis in West Bank
abstract: Palestinian gunmen ambushed two Israeli cars today on a highway south of the West Bank city of Hebron, killing four Jewish settlers and wounding two others.

headline: NATIONAL GYPSUM CREATES NEW FUND FOR ASBESTOS CLAIMS
abstract: National Gypsum Co agrees to create $347 million fund for potential injury claims by people exposed to asbestos in company's building-materials products (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: A New Brewer
abstract: SABMiller says Czech Republic's best-known beer Pilsner Urquell, brewed since 1843 only in West Bohemian city of Pilsen, will be made under license in Poland; SAB's Czech and Polish beer sales rose 8 percent combined in last three months; Czech Republic is world's leading beer consumer (S)

headline: U.S. BACKS INCREASE IN PEACEKEEPERS FOR AFGHANISTAN
abstract: Senior Bush administration officials say Pentagon officials no longer oppose expanding international security force in Afghanistan; say they now feel that enlarging it and placing its troops outside Kabul may help secure country and allow American troops to leave sooner; cite difficulties in rebuilding country and establishing law and order in nation still wracked by banditry, warlords and renegade Taliban fighters; foreign nations have been reluctant to consider extending peacekeeping effort beyond Kabul until Pentagon agrees to help with logistics, command and control and intelligence; American officials say steps to enlarge peacekeeping force might not come for months and that finding nations to contribute forces would not be easy; even if force is expanded, it is unlikely to be as large as Afghan leader Hamid Karzai has proposed (M)

headline: NBC Executive Shifting to Viacom to Run Its TV Stations
abstract: Dennis Swanson, who led NBC's flagship television to dominance in New York City, accepts job running all of Viacom Inc stations, which include those of NBC's rival CBS; several NBC executives expect move to fire up rivalry between NBC and CBS stations, and predict that Swanson will try to lure away station executives and perhaps on-camera staff; Swanson hires Lew Leone, head of sales at NBC-owned station in New York, WNBC, to become general manager of WCBS (M)

headline: Taking On an Overhaul of ABC's Schedule
abstract: No one expects Susan Lyne, the new president of ABC's entertainment operations, to fix all of the network's woes in the next six months.

headline: Ambitious Plans in Disarray at Canada Utility
abstract: Corporate instability and unpredictability taint governance and future of Hydro One, Ontario, Canada's dominant power transmission company; resignation of board members and dismissal of former chief executive Eleanor Clitheroe seem to have halted company's plans to expand its ventures and offer stock publicly; control remains in government's hands; photo (M)

headline: For Israelis Wounded in Bomb Attacks, Recovery Is a Battle
