abstract: Article on physical and emotional trauma caused by suicide bombings and long ordeal facing Israelis gravely wounded in attacks; wounds are often severe, but not just physical; more than 4,000 Israelis have been injured since conflict with Palestinians began anew in September 2000, almost 10 times roughly 500 killed; among Palestinians, at least 1,450 have been killed and, according to Palestinian Authority, another 35,700 wounded; Palestinians say they are being injured and killed in larger numbers in course of resisting military occupation; Israelis say more of their own victims are noncombatants, women and children who are often killed or wounded in suicide bombings; in small nation like Israel, wounded produce ripple effect through society that partly explains strong support Israelis give military measures like recent retaking of practically entire West Bank to arrest militants and curb suicide bombings; wounded go on, publicly and painfully, battling wounds often far worse than those seen in nation at peace; recovery, when it comes, is almost always accompanied by ample parts of fear and anger; physical and mental trauma caused by bombings described; photos (L)

headline: Indonesia struggles to curb rapid deforestation
abstract: JAKARTA—  Almost every scientific expedition that sets out to explore Indonesia's forests returns with discoveries of new species. The world's fourth most populous nation has the third largest tropical forest, after Brazil and the Democratic Republic of the Congo.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Guerrilla Group Asserts Itself
abstract: Greek guerrilla group known as Nov 17 re-emerges with proclamation that it is considering hostage-taking as means of defending more than dozen members awaiting trial; reasserts group's anti-Americanism (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Yahoo's Profit Doubles
abstract: Yahoo Japan reports profit nearly doubled in April-June period, to 2.2 billion yen ($18.9 million); sales more than doubled (S)

headline: Jerusalem Journal; Atop Church, Another, Less Deadly Holy War
abstract: Age-old dispute between Egyptian Christian priests and Ethiopian Christian monks over control and use of roof of Church of the Holy Sepulcher in Jerusalem boils over into fight over position of chair used by Egyptian Christian priest, Rev Abdel Mallek, for daily sit-down; violence leaves 11 people injured; Egyptians consider compound theirs; say they allowed Ethiopians to settle on roof in 1818 only as guests; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; It's Cheaper and Cleaner Up There
abstract: American film production company Robert Greenwald Productions chooses to film its documentary chronicling final days of Enron Corp in Winnipeg, Manitoba, where costs are well below those in US (M)

headline: Israelis Maintain Weeklong Grip on Arafat Headquarters
abstract: Israeli forces maintain their siege of Yasir Arafat's ruined compound in Ramallah for seventh day despite United Nations resolution demanding their withdrawal; Israeli officials struggle to parry resulting foreign criticism; Foreign Min Shimon Peres receives pointed queries from American Amb Daniel C Kurtzer, among others; Peres claims Israel cannot fulfill its part in UN resolution because Palestinians are not meeting parallel demand in resolution to halt attacks on Israel and arrest those responsible; photo; map (M)

headline: Article 2002090592737079665 -- No Title
Justice Dept. Staff Said to Be Opposing Satellite TV Merger
abstract: Justice Dept staff urges federal government to reject as anticompetitive proposed $11.2 billion merger of largest satellite television broadcasters, DirecTV and EchoStar; say merger would reduce competition from three companies--two satellite providers and cable television company--to just two, while eliminating competition in rural areas not served by cable; satellite companies say deal should be approved since it is only way to compete effectively against increasingly large cable television companies, which control about 80 percent of subscription-TV market; argue that merger would enable combined company to be better at broadcasting local programming; rejection would be major victory for Rupert Murdoch, News Corp chairman who has sought unsuccessfully to buy DirecTV to fill important piece in media empire; would also reflect rare instance of opposition to corporate merger by Bush administration (M)

headline: Compressed Data; How One Telecom Thrives Amid Slowdown
abstract: Harris Corp, 107-year-old company, is thriving at time when most larger telecommunications rivals are ailing; secret to its survival is that half of its sales are to government agencies; sales in its government businesses are up, while commercial sales are down (M)

headline: The Bubble Has Burst, But Strengths Remain
abstract: Tom Redburn Economic View column notes that irrational stock market exuberance of 1990's has morphed into today's overdone pessimism; says productivity has improved, economy is resiliant and expectations of dismal economic decade ahead are unreasonable; chart of productivity growth (M)

headline: Thomson Is Sued Over Data Use
abstract: BOSTON, July 30 (Bloomberg News) — The Thomson Corporation, a provider of financial and legal data, was sued by CCBN.com Inc. on charges of using confidential information obtained from CCBN board meetings.

headline: U.S. Hurries; World Waits
abstract: News analysis reports that, just five days after Pres Bush allayed world suspicion about unilateral action, Iraq's sudden offer to re-admit weapons inspectors has left Bush scrambling to present his case for disarming Iraq and dislodging Saddam Hussein; Vice Pres Cheney lobbies Congress for quick resolution and Sen leader Tom Daschle indicates he will comply, but, at UN Security Council, hard work of multilateralism is just beginning; Russia, France and key Arab allies are skeptical about need for new resolutions in light of Iraqi offer, despite Sec Colin Powell's warning that Iraq has played same game before (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Trade Surplus Grows
abstract: Brazil records trade surplus of nearly $1.58 billion in August, bringing surplus for the year so far to nearly $5.38 billion; growing surplus should help to calm markets, which have been jittery because of an uncertain outcome of Brazilian presidential election Oct 6, and concern about Brazil's ability to keep up payments on $250 billion in public debt (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: From Soccer To A Bigger Game
abstract: Chung Mong Joon, multimillionaire who helped bring World Cup soccer tournament to South Korea, signals his candidacy for presidency of country as he meets coaches and members of North Korean team in match seen as major step toward inter-Korean reconciliation; photo (S)

headline: Senator Says Merrill Lynch Helped Enron Cook Books
abstract: Lawmakers on Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations argue that Merrill Lynch, using internal documents, e-mail messages and even videotape as evidence, repeatedly cut corners and compromised its business practices to win more investment-banking fees from Enron; in one deal, in which Merrill acquired an interest in Nigerian barge operation that allowed Enron to book last-minute $12 million profit for 1999, a senior Merrill executive worrried that firm might 'aid/abet' manipulation of Enron's income statement; committee investigators also say that Merrill analyst John Olson was ousted from firm in 1998 because Merrill was upset that his skeptical coverage of Enron was costing firm millions of dollars in investment-banking revenue; Sen Carl Levin, panel chmn, contends 'Merrill Lynch helped Enron artificially and deceptively create revenue;' G Kelly Martin, president of Merrill's international private client division, testifies that firm 'strongly believes that our limited dealings with Enron were appropriate and proper based on what we knew at the time'; photos (L)

headline: Market Place; HealthSouth Pulls Back Its Forecast, But Wall St. Questions Explanation
abstract: HealthSouth, nation's biggest chain of rehabilitation hospitals, surprises investors by withdrawing its 2002 profit estimate and offering explanation that some analysts say is incomplete; says new Medicare payment limit on outpatient rehabilitation charges could reduce its pretax profit by $175 million per year, about 13 percent of its projected $1.3 billion of annual pretax earnings; HealthSouth shares plunge $5.26, or 44 percent, to $6.71; two competing chains, Rehabcare Group and US Physical Therapy, are also battered; HealthSouth also announces that it is reviving plans to spin off its surgery centers operations, its most lucrative unit, later this year; chief executive Richard M Scrushy says $175 million is 'worst case' number and could be lower if company increases its portion of nonMedicare patients; says he is stepping down as chief executive to become chief of independent surgery company, but will remain chairman of HealthSouth; Salomon Smith Barney health-care analyst Deborah J Lawson says she is 'absolutely shocked' at size and effect on profits of Medicare reimbursement change; Tom Scully, head of federal Centers for Medicare and Medicaid, says he is 'just amazed' that HealthSouth did not bring matter directly to him; Scully headed Federation of American Hospitals, which lobbies for HealthSouth in Washington, before taking Medicare post; photo (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Says U.S. May Not Join Future Peacekeeping Missions
abstract: Without a grant of blanket immunity, the defense secretary today warned that U.S. forces may not join future peacekeeping operations.

headline: Business; Fallout From a Free-for-All
abstract: Interview with Ross M Miller, co-author of book What Went Wrong With Enron, who thinks that bankrupt former energy giant generally stumbled into its problems; photo (M)

headline: Heinz Says Its Quarterly Profit Fell 11%
abstract: H J Heinz Co says fiscal first-quarter net income declined to $177.8 million from $200.5 million year earlier; sales in period ended July 31 rose 6.1 percent, to $2.2 billion (S)

headline: Hong Kong Journal; Love and Money Bring Woe to a Rising Politician
abstract: Antony Leung, Hong Kong's financial secretary and third-ranking official, is struggling for political survival because of his financial management, controversial economic views and recent marriage to China's most famous athlete--Fu Mingxia, four-time Olympic gold medal winner who is less than half his age; photo (M)

headline: Simon & Schuster Sues Author Over His Lineage
abstract: Simon & Schuster has sued Michael Pellegrino, Las Vegas resident who claimed to be illegitimate grandson of late Mafia boss Carlo Gambino and author of book The Honored Society, and Artists Management Group, agency that represented Pellegrino, saying they committed fraud by giving him far darker criminal history than he actually had; Simon & Schuster signed $500,000 contract with Pellegrino, who used pseudonym Michael Gambino; Simon & Schuster filed suit in February, but not until this week--four days after it took unusual step of filling second federal fraud suit against agency--did publisher disclose publicly that it believed that it had been deceived; Pellegrino's lawyer Leon Friedman contends that Pocket Books, division of Simon & Schuster, owes his client last $100,000 of his book advance, and has countersued to receive it; adds Pellegrino fulfilled his contract by writing book he had promised, and there is nothing in contract that made reference to Pellegrino's biographical claims; Pellegrino lawyer Gus Flangas says Pellegrino does believe he is illegitimate grandson of Carlo Gambino; photo (M)

headline: GIANT HELICOPTER CRASHES IN RUSSIA
abstract: Giant Mi-26 Russian military helicopter carrying at least 132 people crash-lands in minefield near main military base at Khankala in Chechnya, killing dozens; 32 survivors reportedly taken to military hospitals; other survivors apparently died after activating mines on emerging from wreckage; accident appears to be worst air disaster since Russia began second war in Chechnya three years ago; initial reports indicated helicopter was shot down by Chechen rebels, but military officials say pilot reported engine fire; rescue effort was delayed until explosives experts could clear path for emergency workers through mines, which encircle base; maps (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Connecticut; New England Icons Are Serving a Hidden Purpose
abstract: Soaring steeple that serves as historic landmark for so many Connecticut towns has become one of more common disguises for cellphone antennas; telecommunications companies pay $1,000 or more per month to lease steeples, creating welcome revenue for congregations; Sprint PCS will apply stealthing techniques to late-19th-century windmill in Fairfield; Sprint will cover cost of restoring 1890 town-owned windmill to working condition; some of more unusual projects that have been approved by state historic commission include flagpole at Bridgeport's Beardsley Zoo and grain silo in Salem; Verizon Wireless used stealthing to rebuild spire in Unionville; stealthing of church steeples to accommodate antennas can cost as much as $500,000, nearly three times cost of new tower; photo (M)

headline: A body blow for Bates as Wendy's transfers its U.S. ad business.
abstract: Wendy's International announces it is moving its US advertising business from Bates USA to McCann-Erickson World Group; annual billings estimated at more than $200 million; photo (M)

headline: 2 Republicans Join Ranks of S.E.C. Critics
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission, already under siege from Democrats who say that its chairman, Harvey L Pitt, has not done enough to police corporate fraud, is now drawing scrutiny from two Republicans, Rep Billy Tauzin, chairman of House Energy and Commerce Committee, and Rep James C Greenwood, chairman of its oversight and investigations subcommittee; they are asking SEC whether agency had ever scrutinized five companies before problems like accounting irregularities and other disclosures surfaced in past year; companies are Tyco International, WorldCom, Global Crossing, Qwest Communications and Xerox (M)

headline: COMMERCIAL REAL ESTATE: REGIONAL MARKET -- Midtown Manhattan; A Hèrmes Headquarters With a Designer Touch
abstract: Article on Hermes' new North American headquarters on second and third floors and basement in Delmonico Plaza condominium building at 55 East 59th Street; former headquarters was located at 745 Fifth Avenue (M)

headline: Business; The Struggle to Sell A 'Green' Wrapper
abstract: EarthShell chief executive Simon K Hodson and chairman Essam Khashoggi try to promote widened use of environmentally-friendly food service containers they produce from proprietary compound Ali-ITE; EarthShell containers degrade rapidly, unlike paper and plastic foam, and take up little landfill space; photos; graph of municipal waste breakdown (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TOWER AUTOMOTIVE, Grand Rapids, Mich., a maker of vehicle frames, said it would buy back as much as $59.8 million of its common shares.    LENNAR CORP., Miami, a home builder, said it had agreed to buy two Chicago-area home builders, Concord Homes and Summit Homes.

headline: Orders for Machine Tools Were Lower in July
abstract: Association for Manufacturing Technology and American Machine Tool Distributors Association report orders for machine tools declined in July to $143.34 million, down 29.5 percent from June and 21 percent from July 2001 (S)

headline: Private Sector; Cycling for Dollars, And Business Connections
abstract: Thomas Weisel's sponsorship and ownership of United States Postal Service bicycling team, racing in Tour de France, is important to his business interests; photo (M)

headline: People
abstract: *Brian Brooker, president and chief creative officer at Barkley Evergreen & Partners Advertising is named to added post of chief executive at parent Barkley Evergeen & Partners, succeeding Scott Aylward, who continues as chairman (S)

headline: Rosie Magazine to End Publication
abstract: The former talk show host Rosie O'Donnell announced today that she was pulling out of Rosie magazine, a joint venture with Gruner & Jahr USA, bringing its publication to an end.

headline: John Cocke, a Chip Wizard From I.B.M., Is Dead at 77
abstract: John Cocke, a ChiA

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: Protesting U.S. Penalties; SOUTH KOREA: Garlic Farmers Protest; JAPAN: Joint Forces To Fight Spies;.

headline: Colorectal Cancer Drug Wins Quick Approval From F.D.A.
abstract: Food and Drug Administration approves Sanofi-Synthelabo's drug Eloxatin for colorectal cancer; approval of drug comes about seven months after Erbitux, colorectal cancer drug developed by ImClone Systems, failed to make it past FDA approval; Eloxatin is already used in more than 55 countries; approval of Eloxatin could make it more difficult for ImClone, which is also seeking approval of its drug as last-ditch treatment; company might have to show Erbitux is superior to Eloxatin or works in patients who fail to respond to that drug as well as two previously approved treatments for colorectal cancer (M)

headline: An Execution in Texas Strains Ties With Mexico and Others
abstract: Pres Vicente Fox's decision to cancel meeting with Pres Bush at his Texas ranch to protest Texas's execution of Mexican citizen Javier Suarez Medina is latest confronation over death penalty between United States and some of its closest allies; Mexico and 10 other nations, including Poland, Switzerland, Brazil and Argentina, filed court briefs or wrote letters pleading for clemency for Suarez; dispute points up how US is at odds with many other industrialized democracies as it continues to apply death sentences for capital crimes (M)

headline: David Pogue
abstract: David Pogue has written the double-award-winning Desktop Critic column for Macworld magazine since 1991. With over 2.5 million books in print, Pogue is one of the world's bestselling how-to authors, having written or co-written six books in the "for Dummies" series (Macs, iMacs, iBooks, Magic, Opera, and Classical Music), along with the Computer Press Association award-winning "PalmPilot: The Ultimate Guide," several computer-humor books, and a technothriller, "Hard Drive."

headline: REGIONAL MARKET: The Bronx; Fordham Revival Where Alexander's Once Ruled
abstract: Five-story building at 2 Fordham Square in Bronx, a white elephant for better part of decade, is gaining tenants; building, once home to Caldor, was bought by Fordham Associates in January 2001 for $25 million in cash from Vornado; since then, nine tenants have signed leases of 10 to 20 years; photo (M)

headline: Another Blow To Executives On Options
abstract: Many US corporations have halted longstanding practice of allowing executives and directors to exercise stock options without putting up their own money in transactions that are often worth millions of dollars; decision to halt these arrangements is being driven by uncertainty over whether they may now be considered loans and therefore criminal violations under recently passed law aimed at curbing corporate abuses; these arrangements, usually called cashless exercises of stock options, allow executives to quickly cash out options granted by company as part of their compensation; company in past 'covered' amount of money, usually about $1 million, until trade is settled, usually within one to three days of sale; that is period in which company is now thought to be making loan, and period in which, tax lawyers say, companies may be breaking law; cashless exercise of options are common form of employee compensation, believed, until now, to be completely legitimate; National Association of Stock Plan Professionals executive director Sandra L Sussman estimates that at least 525,000 board members and executives have been affected by decision to stop practice (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. Wins Contract From Boeing
abstract: IBM wins contract from Boeing Co for 66 servers to be used in US missile defense system; IBM's high-end p690 Regatta servers along with eServer workstations will be installed in ground-based midcourse defense program, for which Boeing is prime contractor; financial terms undisclosed; graph (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: A Mission For Fiat
abstract: World Bus4

headline: Technology Briefing: Software
abstract: J. D. EDWARDS TO USE I.B.M. DATABASE IN PACKAGE; ACCLAIM ENTERTAINMENT EXPECTS 4TH-QUARTER LOSS;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: TV Sales Help Retailer
abstract: World Cup soccer tournament, held May 31 to June 30 in South Korea and Japan, helped to drive sales at LG Electronics to $4.2 billion in second quarter, up 15 percent from second quarter 2001; increase was helped by strong sales of digital television sets for watching matches; earnings soared to $363 million, more than double from year earlier; net income was $380 million, down 66 percent from year ago (S)

headline: Pressure on Companies Using Tax Dodge
abstract: California's Philip Angelides becomes first state treasurer to penalize companies that use offshore addresses to avoid paying taxes on their American profits; bars 19 companies from obtaining state contracts and selling commercial paper to pooled state fund; AFL-CIO president John J Sweeney urges Stanley Works to cease its efforts to dodge taxes by acquiring mailbox in Bermuda (M)

headline: Patents; A tracking device that can be fitted in a child's backpack or a ball cap.
abstract: Jennifer Durst and partners patents way to track child's whereabouts through lightweight GPS transceiver that can be fitted into backpack, baseball or belt; device can be programmed to send messages directly to cellphone, pager, phone or computer if child goes beyond preset boundaries; photo (M)

headline: Turkey Warns U.S. of Difficulties in an Assault on Baghdad
abstract: Prime Min Bulent Ecevit reiterates Turkey's concerns about US military action against Iraq; warns US it faces long war if it decides to topple Pres Saddam Hussein (S)

headline: AT&T and AOL Are Said to Seek Delay in Evaluation of Joint Entertainment Unit
abstract: AT&T and AOL Time Warner reportedly agree to ask Bank of America to withhold its opinion on how much AT&T's 27.3 percent stake in their Time Warner Entertainment joint venture is worth; apparently expect to reach accord within weeks on dissolving venture; Comcast plays crucial role in deal because it has agreed to acquire part of AT&T, including its stake in entertainment unit (M)

headline: Palestinian Leader Indicted on Terror Charges
abstract: Marwan Barghouti, a prominent Palestinian leader, made clear at his indictment on terrorism charges today that he intends to turn his public trial into a political duel with Israel.

headline: Germany Says Hijackers Picked Trade Center as Target in 2000
abstract: The terror cell in Hamburg planned an attack for as early as April or May 2000, Germany's federal prosecutor said today.

headline: Article 2002090793578700927 -- No Title
Rumsfeld Says U.S. Has 'Bulletproof' Evidence of Iraq's Links to Al Qaeda
abstract: Defense

headline: Private Sector; Back to the Neighborhood
abstract: Arlen Kantarian, United States Tennis Association chief executive, professional tennis, says he aims to make United States Open one of world's top sports spectaculars; photo (M)

headline: Airlines Allowed to Stop Asking About Luggage
abstract: Transportation Security Administration announces that practice of questioning passengers about security of their luggage, which has long been mandatory, is no longer valuable and airlines are free to discontinue asking them immediately (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Cable Companies Improve
abstract: United Pan-Europe Communications, controlled by Liberty Media, reports its first profit; earned 567 million euros ($554 million) in second quarter, in contrast to loss of 914 million euros year earlier; NTL narrows its second-quarter loss to $594 million from $1.1 billion year ago (S)

headline: WAL-MART SALES ROSE TO EXPECTATIONS LAST WEEK
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc says sales last week at stores open at least year rose within company's forecast (S)

headline: Aventis Loses Crawfish Ruling
abstract: Louisiana appellate court rules Aventis must face hundreds of claims by crawfish farmers who say that company produced ICON water weevil pesticide that wiped out their catch; decision means farmers can combine in single class-action case their claims that pesticide creeped into groundwater and reduced crawfish stocks to 16 million pounds from 41 million pounds in one year; farmers' suit, filed in state court in 2000, is seeking minimum of $50 million (S)

headline: Musharraf, at Harvard, Says He Supports U.S., to a Point
abstract: Pakistan's Pres Pervez Musharraf, in Harvard University address, underscores his support for American-led international coalition against terrorism and for role of American military in rebuilding Afghanistan, but says he would not involve country in US-led war against Iraq; says Indo-Pakistan relations are at lowest ebb because of ongoing conflict over Kashmir; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Work Force: Change Could Ease Hiring
abstract: Labor Department is planning to change rules for companies seeking to hire skilled foreign workers to reduce wait for work permit to about nine months; acceleration would be potential boon for technology companies, which must now wait five years for department to process application for permanent work permit for someone from abroad; proposed rule would let companies, rather than government agencies, certify that there was lack of qualified domestic workers to fill jobs (S)

headline: JONES APPAREL TO BUY L.E.I. JEANS FOR $310 MILLION
abstract: Jones Apparel Group says it will buy RSV Sport, maker of l.e.i. jeans for women and girls, for $310 million; RSV chief executive Mel Geliebter will become chief executive of Jones' Sun Apparel private-label division (S)

headline: U.S.-Europe Group Wants to Build Nuclear Fuel Plant in U.S.
abstract: Consortium of European and US nuclear companies will apply for license from Nuclear Regulatory Commission to build $1.1 billion plant for processing reactor fuel, first in US in half century and one of largest private nuclear projects since 1980's; plant would enrich uranium for use in power plants, using technology that consumes about 5 percent as much electricity as one now used in US; would break domestic monopoly held by USEC Inc; USEC announced month ago that it would also seek to build plant but that it would first have to modernize prototype plant tested in 1980's; consortium includes Urenco, Cameco Corp, Westinghouse Electric Co, Fluor Daniel, Exelon, Tntergy and Duke Energy; consortium, known as Louisiana Energy Services, will pick site soon (M)

headline: Britain to Stop Arresting Most Private Users of Marijuana
abstract: Home Sec David Blunkett announces relaxation of Britain's laws on marijuana smoking, keeping practice theoretically illegal but making private use in discreet amounts no longer subject to arrest; government will at same time raise punishment for marijuana dealing and step up drug education and treatment of abusers; move, which follows recommendations of parliamentary committee, stirs criticism from Conservative opposition and some Labor politicians; Keith Hellawell, former antidrug chief, resigns as government adviser, saying country is moving further toward decriminalization; estimated 5 million people in Britain regularly use marijuana, and government data show it use has risen sharply in last 20 years; photo (M)

headline: Cellphone Records Of Stewart's Broker Provided to Congress
abstract: Lawyers for Martha Stewart's stockbroker Peter E Bacanovic submit records from his cellphone to Congressional committee looking into Stewart's sale of shares of ImClone Systems Inc; records are thought to hold important information about timing and amount of contact Bacanovic of Merrill Lynch might have had with Stewart before her sale of nearly 4,000 shares of ImClone on Dec 27, one day before company announced that its application for approval of cancer drug Erbitux had been rejected by Food and Drug Administration (M)

headline: Grocer to Restate Earnings
abstract: Penn Traffic, East Coast supermarket-chain operator, will restate financial results for last three fiscal years and first quarter of this year because former employee at its Penny Curtiss bakery unit overstates inventory by $10 million to $11 million (S)

headline: TRW Takeover Gets Favorable Review
abstract: Edward Aldridge, Pentagon's top acquisition official, says Northrop Grumman Corp's $11.8 billion takeover of TRW Inc has no 'showstopper' antitrust issues, even as other military contractors worry they may lose access to products the two companies produce (S)

headline: HOME DEPOT PLANS TO BUY BACK UP TO $2 BILLION IN STOCK
abstract: Home Depot Inc, with its shares having fallen to their lowest level in almost four years, plans to buy back as much as $2 billion in common stock (S)

headline: Building Materials Company Ireland Loves to Hate
abstract: Ireland's boom years have benefited construction industry, particularly CHR, supplier of building materials, which more than doubled sales and profits from 1997 to 2001; CRH employs 50,000 workers in 22 countries, including growing presence in US; has been spending average of nearly $100 million a month on acquisition over last year and half; recent purchases include EHL Group in Germany and parts of US Aggregates, bankrupt building materials company with operations in Idaho and Alabama; CHR bought 25 businesses in US last year, largest being Mount Hope Rock Products in Wharton, NJ, for $144 million; photo (M)

headline: New Software Quietly Diverts Sales Commissions
abstract: Some popular online services are using new kind of software to divert sales commissions that would otherwise be paid to small online merchants by big sites like Amazon and eToys; sites that use software, which is made by nearly 20 companies and used by dozens, are acceptable, because users agree to diversion; amounts involved are estimated to have mounted into hundreds of thousands of dollars and are likely to continue to grow, in part because most users are unaware that software is operating on their computers; diversion begins when customers get software from Internet that helps them swap music or other files or find bargains online; Shawn Collins, who feeds customers to Amazon and other online merchants, says his commissions have fallen 30 percent in six months; instructions for removing shopping software from computers noted; diagram; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Rwanda: Genocide Suspect Pleads Not Guilty
abstract: Former Rwandan army chief of staff, Augustin Bizimungu, pleads not guilty to charge of leading 1994 killing of 800,000 people, United Nations tribunal in Tanzania; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: NORTHERN IRELAND: Unionist Deadline Comes Under Fire; FRANCE: Refugee Camp Population Nears 2,000; SPAIN: Bombings Kill 3; BRITAIN: Bloody Sunday Inquiry Moves To London; UKRAINE: Another Rally Against Kuchma;.

headline: Seeing Long Trading Slump, Schwab Sets More Cutbacks
abstract: Charles Schwab Corp will shut one of its five customer call centers, eliminate 375 jobs and look for ways to save additional $200 million per year as it braces for extended slump in trading by individual investors; chief financial officer Christopher Dodds comments (M)

headline: Vu Ngoc Nha, 74, a Top Communist Spy in Vietnam, Dies
abstract: Vu Ngoc Nha, leader of Communist spy ring in Vietnam, dies at age 74; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Berlin Official Quits
abstract: Gregor Gysi, municipal economy minister in Berlin and prominent member of party of reform Communists, resigns two days after admitting making personal use of bonus air miles from official flights during his time as member of Parliament (S)

headline: G.E. Says S.E.C. to Look Into Welch's Compensation Package
abstract: G.E. said today it had agreed to cooperate with an investigation into a compensation agreement with John F. Welch Jr.

headline: 2 Home Mortgage Agencies To Register With the S.E.C.
abstract: Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae say they will begin making same kind of quarterly and annual reports as other publicly traded companies; Fannie Mae chairman-chief executive Franklin D Raines and Freddie Mac chairman-chief executive Leland C Brendsel say their companies will register their stock with Securities and Exchange Commission, committing them to filings, which will begin next year; companies will not register their debt- and mortgage-backed securities; Raines says Fannie Mae has about $70 billion in common stock outstanding; Brendsel say Freddie Mac has about $45 billion in stock (M)

headline: Option Expense Rules Seen Within a Year
abstract: Financial Accounting Standards Board chairman Robert Herz says board will decide within a year whether United States companies will have to treat stock option grants to employees as expenses (S)

headline: The Essay, IM Style
abstract: Brian Neenan letter on September 19 article holds not all users of instant messaging use terrible English

headline: As leather sales fall, small firms take stock
abstract: MILAN—  Mipel, Italy's biannual leather goods trade fair, was an upbeat affair in contrast to the subdued event last September which came in the immediate aftermath of the Sept. 11 terror attacks. Buyers were back in force, traditional quality leather is in favor again and the range of colors reflected the optimism.

headline: Indonesia's Forests Go Under the Ax for Flooring
abstract: Indonesia's timber industry is booming, but 80 percent of timber trade is illegal; large parts of country's rain forests have been turned into scarred wasteland by illegal logging; on island of Sumatra, forests have been denuded by illegal logging and sawmills; government ban on export of logs has had little impact because of loophole--once log is cut into planks it is no longer considered 'log' and thus not subject to ban; photos; map (M)

headline: S.E.C. Approves Acquisition of Bcom3
abstract: Bcom3 Group and Publicis Groupe say Securities and Exchange Commission has approved Publicis acquisition of Bcom3 for estimated $3 billion (S)

headline: 2 Top Tyco Executives Charged With $600 Million Fraud Scheme
abstract: Tyco International's former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski and former chief financial officer Mark H Swartz are indicted on charges that they reaped $600 million through racketeering scheme involving stock fraud, unauthorized bonuses and falsified expense accounts; former general counsel Mark Belnick is indicted on charges of falsifying company records to conceal $14 million in improper loans to himself; New York grand jury indictments also accuse Kozlowski and Swartz of bribing Tyco board member and several Tyco employees, apparently to try to keep their scheme secret; separate, civil lawsuit has been filed by Securities and Exchange Commission; photos (M)

headline: Compressed Data; A Tale of Evil Venture Capital, and a Fair Start-Up
abstract: Morrison & Foerster law firm hosts mock negotiation between venture capital firm and entrepreneur in need of financing; audience is composed of attorneys, venture capital managers and business executives; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Trying Yet Again For A Premier
abstract: South Korean Pres Kim Dae Jung names former Supreme Court Justice Kim Kuk Soo prime minister in third attempt to fill largely ceremonial post; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Names Financial Officer
abstract: Nortel Networks appoints Douglas C Beatty as chief financial officer; takes over from chief executive Frank Dunn, who has held jobs of both chief financial officer and chief executive since February (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Talks On Asylum Seekers
abstract: Chinese and German officials discuss what to do with group of North Korean asylum seekers who took refuge in German School, Beijing (S)

headline: From Investor Fury, A Legal Bandwagon
abstract: Corporate malfeasance and executive greed that undermined stock market and fleeced investors provide boon for securities lawyers; law firms and individual lawyers flock to sue companies, their directors or officers on behalf of investors who feel lied to and cheated; ranks of lawyers servicing this need swell; photos; graph of suits and settlements (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Internet
abstract: ANTI-PIRACY EXECUTIVE CHOSEN; MARKETING CONCERN NAMES NEW STRATEGY OFFICER; LEGISLATION ON DIGITAL TV BEING DRAFTED;.

headline: A Fight Against Junk E-Mail
abstract: Consumer groups worry that flood of unwanted, unbidden junk e-mail could lead some people to abandon e-mail altogether; urge Federal Trade Commission to draft regulations for marketers who use electronic mail (M)

headline: Mercedes Faces U.S. Inquiry on Possible Price Fixing
abstract: Justice Department begins criminal investigation into accusations that Mercedes-Benz conspired with 27 dealers to fix prices in metropolitan New York City area (M)

headline: Pentagon May Extend Reservists' Duty
abstract: Defense Department notifies more than 14,000 reservists they may be required to extend tour of duty, to serve up to two years instead of one, in move seen as contingency for possible action against Iraq (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Staying Two Wings Ahead Of Creditor
abstract: Sukhoi Aircraft of Russia will not send aircraft to arms fair in Britain for fear of seizure by Swiss tading company Noga, which is owed more than $60 million (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cuts At Lazard
abstract: Investment bank Lazard dismisses 6 of 22 bankers in its London office; photo (S)s

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Agere Systems Will Cut 4,000 Jobs
abstract: Agere Systems says it will cut 4,000 jobs, or more than third of its work force, as it leaves optoelectronics sector to focus on its integrated circuits business (S)

headline: For Cendant's Travel Business, Ride Is Bumpier Than Expected
abstract: Cendant Corp chief executive Henry R Silverman is running into problems building profitable online travel portal through his acquisitions last year of Galileo reservation booking engine for travel agents, Galileo's Trip.com Web site and Cheap Tickests Inc; Galileo has been losing market share and two travel sites have lowest purchase rates among competitors; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Citrix Shares Fall To 5-Year Low
abstract: Shares of software maker Citrix Systems Inc fall to five-year low after company says its profit for year will not meet expectations because of weakening demand for its products; shares drop 92 cents, or nearly 16 percent, to $5; graph (S)

headline: Talks Weigh Big Project On Wireless Internet Link
abstract: Several leading computer and telecommunications companies are discussing joint creation of wireless data network that would make it possible for users of hand-held and portable computers to have access to Internet at high speeds nationwide; Intel Corp, IBM, AT&T Wireless and several other wireless and Internet service providers including Verizon Communications and Cingular are exploring creation of company to deploy network based on increasingly popular 802.11 wireless data standard, known as WiFi (M)

headline: A Founder Quits Firm to Work for Coca-Cola
abstract: A Founder Quits Firm To Work for Coca-Cola.

headline: Imam at German Mosque Preached Hate to 9/11 Pilots
abstract: German police probe activities of former religious leader at small mosque in Hamburg who preached murderous hatred of US to Mohammed Atta and others who planned and executed September 11 terrorist attacks; say imam, known only by surname al-Fazazi, preached unusually heated stream of anti-Western and anti-Jewish abuse at mosque; say Atta, presumed organizer of attacks and pilot of one of planes that hit World Trade Center, attended mosque, as did other members of Hamburg cell (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Trinidad And Tobago: Another Election
abstract: Trinidad and Tobago, which dissolved Parliament deadlocked between two major parties, sets third election in three years for Oct 7 (S)

headline: Qwest in Switch To Foote, Cone
abstract: Qwest Communications International shifts agency handling its consolidated account from DDB Worldwide to New York office of Foote, Cone & Belding (S)

headline: U.N. Delegates Wait for Bush to Make Case Against Iraq
abstract: Five days of phone calls and intensive consultations by Pres Bush with world leaders have helped ease fears that US will sidestep United Nations and initiate swift attack on Iraq on its own, but UN delegates anxiously await Bush's speech there on Sept 13 to see if he will make case for contronting Iraq; there is no sign that US can count on immediate Security Council support for military strike, even though members now recognize that they must do more to press Iraqis to comply with resolutions that they have not respected; Bush's case against Pres Saddam Hussein, to surprise of many nations, is not that he supports terrorism against US, but rather than he is building some of world's most lethal chemical, biological and perhaps nuclear weapons and must be removed; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: RUSSIA: Helicopter Toll At 117; RUSSIA: Denial On Airstrikes; SLOVAKIA: Was The President Poisoned?; THE HAGUE: Milosevic Trial Resumes;.

headline: Stock Prices Drop Sharply; Nasdaq Hits Five-Year Low
abstract: Stock prices fell sharply today, led by technology issues, on worries about additional accounting scandals, new terrorist attacks and the true health of the economy.

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: WORLDCOM PLANS TO CUT 2,000 OVERSEAS JOBS; QWEST DIRECTOR RESIGNS;.

headline: Bus Bombed in Galilee; Ambushes Add to New Burst of Violence
abstract: A powerful bomb ripped apart an Israeli bus today, killing nine people. Hours later, a shootout in Jerusalem left three dead.

headline: Morgan Stanley Reports Decline That Is Worse Than Expected
abstract: Morgan Stanley says net income in its third quarter fell 13 percent from year earlier, pulled lower by sour financial markets and poor environment for investment banking; earned $611 million in quarter ended Aug 31, down from $705 million year ago; earnings were down 23 percent from second quarter, when it earned $797 million; revenue fell 11 percent from year ago, to $4.6 billion (M)

headline: GTECH APPOINTS TURNER AS CHIEF EXECUTIVE AND PRESIDENT
abstract: Gtech Holdings Corp says W Bruce Turner had stepped down as chairman to become chief executive and president, replacing Howard Cohen (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; After some hostility, AT&T shareholders approve a breakup.
abstract: AT&T shareholders give their approval to breakup of what is left of company into three pieces; plan calls for AT&T to spin out its cable operations, which will then be merged into Comcast; remaining AT&T shares will then suffer indignity of one-for-five reverse stock split, so as to get them up to reasonable price; final part of breakup approved by shareholders calls for AT&T to spin off to its shareholders tracking stock covering its consumer long-distance operations (Market Place column) (M)

headline: Economic Growth Slowed Sharply in the 2nd Quarter
abstract: The nation's gross domestic product expanded by just 1.1 percent, and revised figures show that the recent recession was deeper than was thought.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: North Korea: Warm Words Follow Bullets
abstract: North Korean government calls for dialogue in keeping with joint communique signed by two Koreas on July 4, 1972 (S)

headline: Markets Rebound as Big Companies Stand Behind Earnings Reports
abstract: A day after registering their disappointment over the Federal Reserve's decision not to cut interest rates, investors sent stocks sharply higher in late trading.

headline: Kenya's Retiring Leader Fires Vice President Over Succession
abstract: Kenya Pres Daniel arap Moi, 77, fires Vice Pres George Saitoti in effort to quash revolt within his ruling party among top aides opposed to his choice of Uhuru Kenyatta as his successor; Saitoti is among many presidential aspirants in Moi's party in December election; Kenyatta has relatively little political experience, but is son of founding president, Jomo Kenyatta (M)

headline: NEGOTIATORS AGREE ON BROAD CHANGES IN BUSINESS LAWS
abstract: House and Senate negotiators agree on broad overhaul of corporate fraud, accounting and securities laws aimed at curbing rampant abuses that have shaken Wall St; measure is moving along quickly in wake of daily disclosures of corporate scandal; it is expected to receive final approval in Congress and be signed into law by Pres Bush within days; measure closely tracks proposal by Sen Paul S Sarbanes that passed Senate unanimously last week; on Wall St, stocks register one of biggest one-day gains ever after four straight days of heavy losses; bill would create regulatory board to oversee accounting industry and punish corrupt auditors; it establishes new grounds for prosecuting corporate wrongdoing and gives broad new protections to corporate whistle-blowers; photos; chart listing provisions of new bill (L)

headline: Who Gets the Keys?
abstract: Ford North America Group vice president James J Padilla reflects, in The Boss column, on his childhood and on his lifelong relationship to automobiles; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Wal-Mart Unit Expands
abstract: Asda Group, part of Wal-Mart Stores, says it plans to spend 114 million pounds ($178 million) to open two stores, renovate eight, expand one and relocate another in London (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Moscow Official Wounded
abstract: Aleksi Busalov, midlevel property division official, is in critical condition following apparent assassination attempt in Moscow, second such attack on city officials in month (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: Deflation Continues; CHINA: Bank Accounting Woes; SOUTH KOREA: Carmaker Reports A Profit; CHINA: Brewer'S Profit Rises;.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of July 14 article listing books certain executives are reading contained: Richard P Feynman, who died in 1988, wrote one of books

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Senate Unanimously Passes Corporate Overhaul Bill  The Senate unanimously passed a broad overhaul of corporate fraud, accounting and securities laws to curb the abuses that have rocked Wall Street, and President Bush strongly hinted that he was inclined to sign almost any bill that emerged from negotiations between the Senate and the House.    The 97-to-0 vote came only a few hours after Mr. Bush, speaking in Birmingham, Ala., tried to restore shaken investor confidence by declaring that ''the economy is coming back,'' but he warned that it had to work through a ''hangover'' after an ''economic binge'' that lasted much of the last decade. [Page A1.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Jobless Rate Falls
abstract: Brazil's jobless rate fell slightly in August, ending four months of rising unemployment; seasonally adjusted jobless rate fell to 7.2 percent in August, compared with 7.4 percent in July (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: GREECE: Police Have Gun From Terror Attacks; BRITAIN: Suit In Bungled Embryo Case; FINE ON FRANCE SOUGHT IN BEEF DISPUTE; CZECH REPUBLIC: Havel Ailing Again;.

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: CHIP SALES STRONGER IN MAY; I.B.M. TO SELL AN OLD SITE;.

headline: Senate Hearing Set on Enron's Bankers
abstract: Senate probers have found that major banks helped Enron camouflage over $8 billion in financing not listed on its financial statements as loans in 6 year before Enron filed for bankruptcy; Sen Carl Levin says his subcommittee will examine extent to which banks like J P Morgan Chase and Citicorp knew of and aided Enron's accounting deceptions; banks defend deals (M)

headline: Hip-Hop Sales Pop: Pass the Courvoisier And Count the Cash
abstract: Hip-hop artists seek to cash in on free advertising in their music by rhyming about their own products as well as popular extant brands; photo (M)

headline: A Screen That Tags Along On Trips to the Water Cooler
abstract: Viewsonic introduces 10-inch wireless computer screen designed for portability; photo (M)

headline: Blair Presents Dossier on Iraq's Biological Weapons
abstract: Britain today published a dossier asserting that Saddam Hussein had plans to use chemical and biological weapons.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: New Tension Over Kashmir; SOUTH KOREA: After Battle, Phone Deal Is Off.

headline: ImClone Sues Former Chief To Recover $7 Million
abstract: ImClone Systems sues founder-former chief executive Samuel D Waksal, seeking to recover more than $7 million in severance and other compensation; wants to retrieve money because Waksal falsely assured company executives and directors that he was cooperating with federal investigators (M)

headline: More Nations Said to Back World Court Exemptions
abstract: Foreign ministers of several European Union governments say they are inclined to sign bilateral accords with Washington to exempt Americans from jurisdiction of new International Criminal Court; give governments assurance that they will hold off on any consideration of whether to act unilaterally until further European Union discussions in September; Italy and Britain have expressed support for US effort forge bilateral agreements to exempt Americans from court (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Global Trade: Russia: An Accord On Poultry
abstract: Russia and US are within days of resolving dispute over American poultry exports to Russia; Russia imposed ban on American poultry in March, citing health concerns that American officials say are goundless; Russia later lifted ban, but new disruption in shipments looms as required health certificate, set to expire on Aug 1, has not been renewed (S)

headline: Protest for Poor at U.N. Forum in South Africa
abstract: Thousands of demonstrators march in Johannesburg, South Africa, near site of UN World Summit on Sustainable Development, to demand more aid for world's poor and greater protection of environment; assail decision by Pres Bush to not participate in meeting; reserve some of bitterest attacks for South Africa's Pres Thabo Mbeki for failing to tend to needs of poor (M)

headline: Chief Dismissed At Hydro One
abstract: Hydro One Inc, Canada's biggest power distribution company, dismisses chief executive Eleanor Clitheroe; says she repeatedly used company assets for personal gain; she declines comment (M)

headline: Investing; Opposite Paths, No Middle Ground
abstract: Gus Sauter of Vanguard Group believes that stocks are substantially underpriced; Prudent Bear fund manager David W Tice says markets still have long way to fall; time will tell which polar opposite's prediction proves true; photos (M)

headline: Needing Each Other
abstract: Analysis: economic necessity is driving North Korea, one of world's most reclusive governments, to change its attitude toward Japan, which it has vilified even more than United States for last 54 years; summit meeting between Kim Jong Il and Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi has resulted in promise of enormous aid from Japan; it is unclear whether even that can prevent North Korea's descent into stunning want, or give Koizumi and his country returns for their promised largesse (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Bank's Profit Falls
abstract: BNP Paribas says profit for second quarter fell 13 percent; will release full second-quarter results Aug 1 (S)

headline: Article 2002090690262223556 -- No Title
S.E.C. Approves New Nasdaq Automated-Trading System
abstract: The Securities and Exchange Commission approved today Nasdaq's use of a new automated-trading system over the heated objections of its rivals.

headline: Nuclear Material Secretly Flown From Serbia to Russia for Safety
abstract: United States officials say more than 100 pounds of nuclear material considered at risk of being stolen or sold for use in producing nuclear weapons was secretly flown from Serbia to Russia, where it will be processed for use in commercial power plant; operation was financed by US and private foundation, involving 1,200 Serbian soldiers and scores of international observers; more than 5,000 rods of highly enriched uranium was transported from research reactor near Belgrade to Russia; American officials and nculear experts are hailing highly classified project as model of international cooperation and public-private financing that could be repeated in other Eastern and Central European countries that have bomb-grade nuclear materials considered at risk of being stolen or sold (M)

headline: Silicon Valley Concern Says It Thwarted Software Theft
abstract: Chinese software programmer Shan Yanming is arrested after Silicon Valley-based 3DGeo Development complains that he tried to steal software used in seismic imaging of oil fields; Yanming has been in US since end of April as part of contract between state-owned China National Petroleum Corp and 3DGeo; 3DGeo executives say Yanming was caught trying to use company computer password to download company software to portable computer; Shan is arrested by FBI at San Francisco International Airport while waiting to leave country (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Nigeria: Oil Workers Go On Strike
abstract: Oil workers in Nigeria, protesting proposed privatization of government-owned refineries, begin two-day strike, shutting down gas stations in Abuja and Lagos (S)

headline: India Voices Anger at Kashmir Raid That Killed 27
abstract: Death toll from July 13 attack by guerrillas on Kashmir shantytown climbs to 27; Indian officials express outrage, but government avoids accusations while preparing official response; no one has claimed reponsibility (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Talks On Bank Stake
abstract: China's Shanghai Pudong Development Bank is in talks to sell stake to Citibank NA, joining rivals in seeking foreign capital and expertise to increase competitiveness (S)

headline: When Executive Pay Depends on Revenue
abstract: S Abraham Ravid letter comments on July 14 article about potential problems of executive pay packages tied to company revenue

headline: Now Showing on Czech TV: Financial Battles
abstract: TV Nova, Czech Republic's leading TV station, says nearly million viewers tuned in to weekly program of its director, Vladimir Zelezny, who claims he is still in charge of station; he is battling with former partners and financial group PPF Holdings for control of broadcasting license; at stake is Nova's demonstrated ability to move voters and make or break political leaders; Nova is also at center of suit charging government helped Zelezny gain control from station's original backer, Ronald S Lauder; new Czech government seeks to distance itself from Zelezny political patron, Vaclav Klaus (M)

headline: AOL TIME WARNER NAMES HEAD OF MARKETING ARM
abstract: AOL Time Warner Inc hires Michael Kelly to head marketing group (S)

headline: Ready With Answers Around the Clock
abstract: Libraries nationwide are offering free, 24-hour chat reference services, often in Spanish as well as English, and patrons are logging on; some sites and services described; photo (M)

headline: State Dept. Is Holding a Seminar Next Week on Anti-U.S. Trends
abstract: State Dept will hold conference on spread of anti-American attitudes around world; Richard Boucher, spokesman, says nongovernmental specialists will be invited to exchange ideas; says meetings, on Sept 5 and Sept 6, will be closed to press, but that department has brought journalists from other countries to US in effort to educate them on American policies and traditions (S)

headline: TWO UNIONS AT US AIRWAYS AGREE TO CONCESSIONS
abstract: Bankrupt US Airways ticket agents and gate workers represented by Communications Workers of America and mechanics represented by International Association of Machinists ratify concession accords; all of airline's major labor groups have now agreed to concessions, which airline needs to get federal loan guarantee (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Telecom Bid Dropped
abstract: Norway's Telenor backs out of bid for Sweden's Song Networks Holding amid resistance from bondholders of Song (S)

headline: Business; Outside The Box? Why A Box?
abstract: Interview with Watts Wacker, co-author of book The Deviant's Advantage, on moving fringe ideas into business mainstream; photo (M)

headline: Putin Cautions Russians on Intolerance
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin strongly denounces racial and religious prejudice during meeting in Kremlin with woman who was seriously wounded when she tore down anti-Semitic sign booby-trapped with bomb in May; says incident underscores depth of racial and ethnic animosities that torment Russia; Putin recently expressed support for new legislation passed by Parliament that imposes tougher penalties for hate crimes (M)

headline: Two Media Conglomerates Suffer a Vexing Day
abstract: Jean-Marie Messier bids emotional farewell to employees at Vivendid Universal, but his ouster as chairman and chief executive is overshadowed by disclosures about company's accounting practices, which sends its stock crashing and drags down entire French market; French securities regulators demanded earlier this year that Vivendi change way it accounted for sale of shares it held in British Sky Broadcasting; original proposal, drafted with its auditor, Arthur Andersen, would have inflated its 2001 profit by about $1.47 billion; photos (M)

headline: Ford Motor Shuffles Some Executives
abstract: Ford Motor gives Asia Pacific unit president Mark Schulz added responsibilities for South American operations; decision is linked to naming of David Thursfield as head of purchasing and interntional business (S)

headline: Bankruptcy Lawyer to Join Investment Bank
abstract: Harvey R Miller, nation's most prominent bankruptcy lawyer, is leaving Weil, Gotshal & Manges, and joining investment banking firm Greenhill & Co as managing director and partner (M)

headline: The Gloves Are Definitely Gone At the Katharine Gibbs Schools
abstract: Times have changed at Katharine Gibbs schools that once set gold standard for glorified secretaries; nearly 50 percent of students are men, and while executive assistant training program still exists, school is as well known for its technical classes as it once was for stenography; some students comment; photo (M)

headline: Excerpts: Interview With Gerhard Schröder
abstract: HANOVER, Germany, Sept. 4 — Following are excerpts from an interview with Chancellor Gerhard Schröder of Germany, reflecting on events since Sept. 11. The interview was conducted in German and translated by The New York Times.

headline: Professional-Looking Labels To Go With Those CD Mixes
abstract: Neato CD/DVD labeling system from Fellowes allows user to pull title and artist information directly from Internet, put it into label template and print it to help catalog CD's and DVD's; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Rightist Web Site Closed
abstract: French judge orders neo-Nazi group Radical Unity to close down its Web site, noting it displayed anti-Semitic material in violation of law prohibiting promotion of hatred and racial violence (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Forever Archived To the Editor:.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Personal Income: Aug.    TUESDAY  Construction Spending: Aug.

headline: Worried Saudis Pay Millions To Improve Image in the U.S.
abstract: Saudi government has spent millions of dollars on lobbyists and national television advertisements since Sept 11 in drive to improve its image among Americans and is poised to spend more as anniversary of events approaches; Saudi officials say they want to counter intensified anger or skepticism among Americans toward their country, which was home to 15 of 19 hijackers and which has clashed publicly with Bush administration over possible attack against Iraq; royal family is scrambling to find gesture of solidarity with American people on anniversary of attacks, in striking sign of Saudis' eagerness to reach out to US; toward that end, Saudis have hired several public relations firms and already spent more than $5 million, according to new Justice Dept filings; Adel al-Jubeir, adviser to Saudi government and key figure in new effort, says his government is appropriating techniques of American political campaign to overhaul its image in US (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: The Netherlands: Insurer Expects Loss
abstract: Dutch insurer Aegon NV says profit this year will be 30 to 35 percent lower than expected, setting off sharp decline in its stock price; graph (S)

headline: Russia's Trial of Colonel Accused in Chechnya Shifts Course
abstract: New psychiatric evaluation is ordered for Col Yuri D Budanov, Russian army officer charged with killing of Elza Kungayeva, young Chechen woman; first test concluded that Budanov was suffering from shell shock and shrapnel wounds when he killed woman (M)

headline: American Airlines to Cut Jobs, Planes and Flights
abstract: American Airlines will lay off 7,000 workers, retire inefficient jets, retool its hub schedules and cut back on flights going into fall; says cutbacks will save it $1.1 billion per year; pilots will lose 550 jobs, all of them from St Louis operations acquired from TWA; flight attendants will lose 2,500; chief executive Donald J Carty comments; shares of UAL, parent company of United, plunge $1.06, or 28 percent, to $2.74, amid further fears that airline might seek bankruptcy protection; photos (M)

headline: LEVI STRAUSS RAISES ESTIMATE OF PLANT-CLOSING COSTS
abstract: Levi Strauss & Co says it expects to incur additional $20 million in restructuring-related expenses over next 12 to 18 months (S)

headline: Hitler, It Seems, Loved Money and Died Rich
abstract: New German television documentary focuses on Adolf Hitler's personal finances, portraying him as man who was abstemious in his public image yet liked to live grandly; Ingo Helm, who made program Hitler's Money, says Hitler spent millions in lavish gifts and payments to buy loyalty of politicians and businessmen and to keep them dependent on him; says Hitler made few distinctions between his own money and that of Nazi Party and even state; says that from time he became chancellor until his death in 1945, Hitler received equivalent of $3 billion in corporate payments; after war, his property and assets were given to state of Bavaria by Allied Control Commission; photo (M)

headline: 16 Banks Pledge Continued Commitment to Brazil
abstract: Brazil's top economic officials persuade 16 international banks, including Citigroup, J P Morgan Chase, Deutsche Bank and Banco Santander Central Hispano, to maintain their lending at current levels; what banks leave unsaid is that most have already cut back sharply on their lending (M)

headline: Sears, Riding Wave of Nostalgia, Emphasizes Heritage in Campaign
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co on Aug 25 will begin its current advertising campaign, which carries theme 'Sears, Where else?,' with now-and-then spots that painstakingly recreate scenes of everyday life from 20th century; Sears hopes to recapture consumers who have increasingly been wooed away by discount retailers; campaign was developed by Chicago office of Young & Rubicam Advertising; photos (M)

headline: Cablevision, Its Stock Price Battered, Will Retire Tracking Shares
abstract: Cablevision Systems says it will retire shares that track company's interests in television group that includes Bravo and Independent Film Channel; announcement could be precursor to Cablevision's selling some networks or other assets; Cablevision faces deficit of at least $600 million next year (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Rates On Hold; JAPAN: Mcdonald'S Profit Falls; SOUTH KOREA: Bank Privatization; SOUTH KOREA: Daewoo To Sell Bus Plant;.

headline: U.S. Jobless Rate Rises to 5.9 Percent
abstract: The U.S. unemployment rate increased to 5.9 percent in June as the number of people unemployed for at least half a year rose to the highest in eight years.

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: THE HAGUE: Milosevic Trial Resumes; BOSNIA: Empty Karadzic House Raided; CYPRUS: Deadlock, But Talks Are Planned; CZECH REPUBLIC: Vandals Hit Jewish Sites; BRITAIN: Foot-And-Mouth Culprit Sentenced;.

headline: As Prague Dries, Flood Wall Stands Tall as a Hero
abstract: Receding flood waters leave carpet of sodden destruction in Prague and beyond; 14th-century Old New Synagogue and Pinchas Synagogue flood, but rest of old Jewish quarter is hardly touched; Rabbi Karel Sidon and rescuers credit wall hurriedly put into place as Vitava's waters rose (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Deficit Falls; MEXICO: Tv Azteca To Spin Off Phone Stake;.

headline: Daddy's Girl Turns Beer-and-TV Billionaire
abstract: Profile of and interview with Maria Asuncion Aramburuzabala, Mexican who, since death of her father, Pablo, has transformed herself from unemployed, divorced daughter of billionaire into billionaire who manages Grupo Modelo, family fortune built on beer; photo (M)

headline: Tokyo Offers An Aid Plan For Its Banks
abstract: Japanese lawmakers, desperate to defend nation's banks from plunging share prices, introduces plan to bolster equity market, but critics say plan erodes Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi's credentials as reformer; ruling coalition scrambles to assemble its plan amid concerns that with stocks near 19-year lows, Japan's largest banks will report billions of losses on their equity portfolios when half-year ends in September (M)

headline: Britain Tries To Ease Enmity Over Kashmir
abstract: British Foreign Sec Jack Straw, in Islamabad, Pakistan, for talks aimed at easing tensions with India over Kashmir, says he is satisfied with discussions so far (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: Consumer Prices Fall; CHINA: Strong Demand For Telecom Shares;.

headline: Private Sector; Disney Chairman's Legacy: Don't Call It Mickey Mouse U.
abstract: California State University Northridge renames its school of education for Walt Disney Co head Michael D Eisner after his philanthropic foundation donates $7 million; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: W.T.O. Deputies Named
abstract: Supachai Panitchpakdi, who will become World Trade Organization head in Sept, names four deputies: Rufus Yerxa, Roderick Abbott, Kipkorir Aly Azad Rana and Francisco Thompson-Flores; photo (S)

headline: Nestlé Strikes $2.6 Billion Deal to Buy Chef America
abstract: Nestle says it will buy Chef America, which makes top-selling Hot Pockets and Toaster Pizza snacks for microwave, for $2.6 billion as it steps up aggressive expansion into United States; with deal, Nestle is taking big stake in frozen-food business, betting that on-the-go consumption in United States will increase, and that its popularity and profitability can be exported outside convenience-loving American market; table shows companies acquired by Nestle since beginning of 2002; photo of chief exec Peter Brabeck-Letmathe (M)

headline: S.E.C. IS INVESTIGATING CRYOLIFE'S HANDLING OF RECALL
abstract: CryoLife, provider of human tissue for transplants, says Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating whether company broke securities laws before announcing share recall last week; inquiry follows Food and Drug Administration order to recall all tissue processed since Oct 3 because company could not ensure that products were free of bacteria and fungus (S)

headline: BELLSOUTH REVISES FREE CASH FLOW DOWNWARD BY 21%
abstract: BellSouth Corp revises second-quarter free cash flow downward by 21 percent, to $1.1 billion, because it redeemed debentures, reducing debt (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Aid Worker Dies In Fighting
abstract: Sudanese-government backed forces launch major offensive against rebel positions, week after reaching agreement that was hailed as step toward ending Africa's longest-running war; map; aid worker is killed (S)

headline: Aon Reports U.S. Investigation of Its Accounting
abstract: Aon, world's second-largest insurance broker, delivers triple helping of bad news, including federal investigation of its accounting, which sends its shares plummeting 30 percent; fails to meet analysts' expectations on earnings for second quarter by wide margin; cancels spinoff of its insurance underwriting business to shareholders because of slumping markets; Moody's Investors Service downgrades Aon's debt rating (M)

headline: A New and Difficult World for Frequent Fliers
abstract: Passport Travel Spa chief executive Tracy Nixon comments on experiences she has encountered and adjustments she has made in her business travels since Sept 11 terrorist attacks; photo (S)

headline: Berkshire to Buy a Gas Pipeline From Dynegy
abstract: MidAmerican Energy Holdings, unit of Warren E Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway, will buy Northern Natural Gas Co, natural gas pipeline owner, for $928 million from Dynegy; Dynegy acquired pipeline for $1.5 billion in November as part of failed plan to merge with Enron; MidAmerican has been aggressively seeking undervalued assets owned by troubled energy companies (M)

headline: Wall Street Journal's New Head Faces Tough Business Challenge
abstract: Interview with new Wall Street Journal publisher Karen Elliott House on tough business challenges she faces; her past successes and reputation for instilling fear noted; House, who is married to Peter R Kann, chief executive of parent Dow Jones & Co, holds questions about nepotism and her brusqueness reflect implicit sexism that has dogged her for years; photo (M)

headline: Picking the Right Wine With the Help of a Hand-Held
abstract: Software programs for installation on hand-held computers offer shoppers data on quality of wines; provide information sommelier would supply; photo; drawing (M)

headline: AIDS Leaving Grim Legacy of Orphans, Report Says
abstract: By 2010, 6 percent of all children in Africa will have lost at least one parent to the AIDS virus, United Nations and United States government officials said in report issued today.

headline: How to Outbid the Fanatics: Software That Never Sleeps
abstract: Sniping software allows online auction bidders to cloak interest in items until last possible second before placing bid that is just high enough to win; photo (M)

headline: Arthur Melin, 77, a Promoter of the Hula-Hoop, Is Dead
abstract: Arthur Melin, co-founder of Wham-O, company that introduced Hula-Hoop and Frisbee, dies at age 77; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Slow-Motion Protest
abstract: About 100 Buddhist monks and nuns, demonstrating against South Korean government plan to build eight-lane highway on north side of Seoul, march nearly two miles through capital; cite environmental concerns; photo (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The consumer division of Bates Healthworld, New York, hired three employees. William A. Mulligan was named executive vice president and general manager; he had been senior partner and director in charge for North America at J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group. Andrea Gasparo and Matthew A. Hartney were named account supervisors. Ms. Gasparo had been senior account manager at Nethod Euro-Interactive, New York, the interactive unit of Lally McFarland & Pantello Euro RSCG, which is part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide division of Havas. Mr. Hartney had been manager for the healthcare practice at Burson-Marsteller, New York. Also, in the professional division at Bates Healthworld, Scott J. Baxter and Heather Lee Clark were named senior account executives. Mr. Baxter had been product manager in the medical marketing division at the Adeza Biomedical Corporation, based in New York. And Ms. Clark had been account executive at Lyons Lavey Nickel Swift, New York, part of TBWA World Health, a division of TBWA Worldwide, which is owned by the Omnicom Group. Bates Healthworld is part of the Bates Worldwide division of the Cordiant Communications Group.

headline: Snail Mail for AOL
abstract: Sy Lutto letter responds to July 21 article about merger of America Online with Time Warner

headline: TYCO RAISES $4.6 BILLION WITH CIT GROUP OFFERING
abstract: Tyco International Ltd raises $4.6 billion on sale of CIT Group, about half amount conglomerate paid for finance company a year ago; sells 200 million CIT shares at $23 each, below $25 to $29 range Tyco set two weeks ago and below $25 investors expected as recently as July 1 (S)

headline: Sagging Stocks in Japan Put Life Insurers at Risk
abstract: Sagging Japanese stock markets debilitate finances of country's life insurers, holders of huge amounts of stocks and bonds; banks, crippled by identical portfolios, have less available cash to purchase insurers' debts (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Buffett Is Said to Be Near Deal With Energy Company  Warren E. Buffett is close to a deal to invest as much as $500 million in the Williams Companies, the energy concern, executives close to the talks said. The move would be his second major investment in the debt-ridden energy sector this week and would help keep Williams from filing for bankruptcy protection.    The transaction would give Mr. Buffett's MidAmerican Energy Holdings, a unit of Berkshire Hathaway, preferred stock in Williams that would be secured by pipeline assets. Mr. Buffett appears to be nearly alone in his effort to buy energy assets, trying to take advantage of the decimated stock and debt-filled balance sheets of energy companies. [Page C5.]    G.E. Changes Way It Treats Options  General Electric joined a small but growing group of companies that are changing how they account for stock options and then went a step further by altering some terms of the options granted to executives. [A1.]    Bertelsmann May Review Offering  The new chief executive of Bertelsmann, Gunter Thielen, said the company was still preparing for a public offering as early as 2005, but he stopped short of committing to carrying it off, referring to it as a possibility. [C6.]    Uruguay Keeps Banks Closed  Uruguay plans to keep its fragile banking system closed at least through Friday. Economic turmoil in Brazil and banking restrictions in Argentina have brought the financial system in Uruguay to the verge of collapse. [C2.]    A Shift in Internet Expectations  More Internet users are showing a willingness to pay for content online, suggesting a shift in consumers' expectations that online services should be free, a new survey reports. [C4.]    Rules Proposed for Power Sales  Regulators have proposed nationwide rules for power sales aimed at eliminating a patchwork of regulations that allows or even encourages manipulation of the markets. [C12.]    Deutsche Bank Defends Chief  Deutsche Bank has defended its chief executive, Josef Ackermann, from accusations that he and other directors of Mannesmann acted improperly in awarding about $70 million to managers during its takeover battle with the Vodafone Group. [World Business, Section W.]    Financier Sells Investment Firms  Martin Ebner, left, the financier who spent the 1990's shaking up Switzerland's clubby corporations and coaxing the Swiss to invest in stocks, has sold the controlling stake in four investment companies, with portfolios worth $2 billion, to the Zurich Cantonal Bank, a regional bank. [World Business, Section W.]    Charges Seen in WorldCom Case  Federal prosecutors are expected to file charges today against former executives of WorldCom, accusing them of engaging in a fraud that led the company to misstate its expenses by almost $4 billion. [C5.]    Dow Rises on Rally; Nasdaq Falls  The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 56.56 points, at 8,736.59, helped by a flurry of late buying. The Nasdaq fell 15.93 points, to 1,328.26. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 8.84 points, to 911.62. [C8.]    The Principles of the Auction  Auctions, one of the oldest ways to buy and sell, have been reborn and revitalized on the Internet. Paul Klemperer, an Oxford economist, argues that the principles of good auction design are the same as ever: try to encourage entry, and try to discourage collusion. Hal R. Varian: Economic Scene. [C2.]

headline: Visiting Indonesia, U.S. Envoy Seeks to End Rebel Conflict
abstract: Anthony C Zinni, retired general who has been Bush administration's envoy to Middle East, travels to Indonesia in private capacity to meet with Indonesian officials to discuss solution to long-running but little publicized guerrilla conflict in Aceh Province; is unpaid adviser to Swiss-based Henri Dunant Center, group specializing in resolving civil conflicts through negotiation; diplomats in Indonesia see progress in presence of such a high-profile mediator, even though Indonesians are traditionally leery of perception of outsiders interfering in internal affairs; for this reason Zinni's first meetings with government officials have taken place secretly outside Indonesia; Zinni is thought to have told officials that after 25 years of hostilities, military solution will not work; Secretary of State Colin Powell delivered same message last week (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PROCTER & GAMBLE, Cincinnati, said it would increase the level of common shares to be bought under its stock repurchase plan. The number of shares to be repurchased was not disclosed.    HORNBECK OFFSHORE SERVICES, Mandeville, La., an operator of vessels that supply offshore drilling rigs, filed to raise as much as $127 million through an initial public offering.

headline: Serbian Presidential Vote Could Suffer From a Lack of Interest
abstract: Campaign in Serbia marked by bad blood between two faction leaders for presidential election has done little to awaken voters from disillusionment and apathy that descended after Slobodan Milosevic was topped two years ago; vote is referendum on whether to push ahead with free-market reforms to win Western friends and attract badly needed foreign investment, or to favor go-slow approach advocated by conservatives and nationalists; Pres Vojislav Kostunica, conservative favored to win in two rounds of voting, has led Yugoslavia since Milosevic's ouster; Miroljub Labus, economics professor respected in West, is underdog (M)

headline: A Rosy Forecast From G.E. As Its Profits Increase 14%
abstract: General Electric Co reports 14 percent increase in eanrings in second quarter, in line with analysts' expectations; also promises robust third quarter; company earned $4.4 billion in quarter, compared with $3.9 million year earlier; revenue rose 4 percent, to $33.2 billion from $32 billion; chairman Jeffrey R Immelt comments (M)
