headline: Powell Urges Nations to Fulfill Afghan Aid Pledges
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell, in address at World Bank, urges wealthy nations to fulfill their pledges of aid to Afghanistan, warning that country could collapse into warlordism and chaos without additional international support; complains that more than third of $2 billion pledged to rebuild Afghanistan this year has not been delivered; his concerns are echoed by Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill; their remarks are among most forceful yet by American officials seeking to cajole European, Asian and Persian Gulf countries to follow through on pledges of aid made at conference in Tokyo in Jan (M)

headline: A Site to Pour Out Emotions, and Just About Anything Else
abstract: Brad Fitzpatrick created Web site LiveJournal to keep in touch with old friends, but site has exploded into place for others who want to keep online journals; users can easily add new entries and read and comment on other journals; people pay $25 per year to maintain account; journals tend to be more inwardly focused than blogs, although categories overlap; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: JAPAN: Fujitsu Hard Drive Problem; SOUTH KOREA: Bank Deal Is Approved;.

headline: Compressed Data; Some Serious Word-Scrambling at Yahoo
abstract: Yahoo has quietly been using find-and-replace filter on HTML-formatted e-mail for years, confounding some users who see their words change mysteriously in transit; seeks to protect against attacks by hackers using Web scripting by substituting for small set of terms commonly used in scripting; some of these terms are also commonly used English words; recent attention called to resulting garbled messages has spurred Yahoo to tweak its filters; drawing (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.75       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.25       Federal funds   1.75   1.75   3.82       3-month T-bills   1.65   1.66   3.45       6-month T-bills   1.64   1.67   3.39       10-yr. T-infl.   3.55   3.13   3.39       10-yr. T-note   4.42   4.45   5.10       30-yr. T-bond   5.28   5.28   5.52       Telephone bd.   7.42   7.45   7.60       Municipal bds.   5.17   5.17   5.28          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Afghan Warlord, With a New Job and Suit to Match, Bears Fresh Burdens
abstract: Uzbek Gen Abdul Rashid Dostum, most powerful man in northern Afghanistan for much of last 15 years, remains undoubted leader in his hometown of Shibarghan, base for core of his troops; Dostum has gone through several metamorphoses: from Soviet-trained general, to regional warlord and power broker, to defeated exile, and finally to resistance leader fighting Taliban from mountains; Dostum wears Western suit and gray stubble for beard, look of new government; has been quick to ally himself with American-backed government and its leader Pres Hamid Karzai and has won himself position of deputy defense minister and presidential representative in northern Afghanistan; Dostum is taking hits from all sides, with accusations that his troops committed rights abuses appearing in international and local news media and orders from central government to hand over customs revenue; there is also constant nagging from United Nations mission and coalition forces to disarm his men and end clashes in region; Dostum no longer enjoys freewheeling pwoer he had in early 1990's, when he ran northern Afghanistan as his own mini-state, printing currency and dictating foreign policy; map; photos (M)

headline: Not Just Closing a Divide, but Leaping It
abstract: Intel Computer Clubhouse Network is program designed to foster computer skills, collaboration and leadership; program began in 1993 with grant from Intel to establish 'clubhouses' where children with limited resources turn their own ideas into games, Web pages and other technologically advanced applications; program is making effort to narrow so-called digital divide by not only providing access to equipment, but fostering more active involvement with and knowledge of technology; photos (M)

headline: Consolidated's Customers Wonder: What Next?
abstract: Customers and employees of Consolidated Freightways, trucking company that shut down on Sept 2, are trying to determine what happens next; hundreds of thousands of shipments are stuck at terminals, and more than 15,000 members of Teamsters union lost their jobs overnight; Consolidated's competitors may take over some of its shipments and hire some of workers, but changeover promises to be tedious; Consolidated spokesman Michael C Brown estimates that more than 200,000 shipments are still in company's terminals; terminals will reopen Sept 4 so other companies can pick up shipments; Consolidated has appealed to Yellow Corp, Roadway Corp, ABF Freight System Inc and USF Holland to hire its employees; photos (M)

headline: Jobless Rate Edges Up to 5.9%; Payroll Growth Remains Weak
abstract: The nation's work force rose by 36,000 jobs last month, but the increase was not big enough to prevent the unemployment rate from inching up to 5.9 percent.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Settlement Houses Merge
abstract: Euroclear and Crest, Europe's leading stock and bond settlement houses, will merge for form continent's biggest settlement system; Euroclear will control combined group, in which Crest will have 19 percent stake; new entity will be based in Brussels and take Euroclear name (S)

headline: By 2010, AIDS May Leave 20 Million African Orphans
abstract: International AIDS Conference in Barcelona is told that AIDS will leave 20 million children in Africa without one of both parents by 2010, up from current number of 11 million; report, issued jointly by United Nations program on AIDS, Unicef and United States Agency for International Development, assumes that treatment will not be made widely available soon; estimates that AIDS will have orphaned five million children elsewhere in world; Carol Bellamy, executive director of Unicef, says orphan crisis, while severe, has not yet reached point where officials are recommending international adoptions; report does not recommend orphanages as appropriate first-line response to problem, saying orphaned children benefit more from care and personal attention that families and communities can provide; graphs (M)

headline: Wyeth Criticizes Media Coverage of Hormone Replacement Drugs
abstract: Wyeth chief executive Robert A Essner criticizes media for what he terms its 'sensationalizing' of study that found that company's hormone replacement therapy Prempro did more harm than good; says once media sensation over study subsides, data will speak for themselves and hormone replacement therapy will remain important part of women's health care; Wyeth says net income for second quarter rose 26 percent, to $599.9 million from $477 million year earlier; revenue rose to $3.5 billion, from $3.2 billion; Bristol-Myers Squibb says net income in second quarter fell 63 percent; dropped to $440 million from $1.2 billion year ago; sales fell 14 percent, to $4.05 billion, from $4.71 billion year before (M)

headline: Hunt for Taliban Leaves Village With Horror
abstract: Scene of carnage in village of Kakrak, Afghanistan, following mistaken US military raid in search of Taliban and Al Qaeda forces described; what apparently began as major operation apparently turned into slaughter of children; Afghan delegation says attack killed 48 people, mostly women and children, and injured 117; Pentagon says it was responding to antiaircraft fire aimed at allied planes; local officials say faulty intelligence may have been provided by an Afghan; ferocity of attack, which encompassed four villages in Oruzgan Province, described; map; photo (M)

headline: Learning From History In Business Scandals
abstract: Harvey Schafler letter responds critically to July 7 article about timelessness of corporate scandals

headline: Dutch Accuse 3 in Plot Against U.S. Base
abstract: Dutch police say they have accused three members of militant Muslim network of planning attack on American military base in Belgium; say at least one of three may have links with Al Qaeda; say three were already under arrest, charged with preparing terrorist attack on American Embassy in Paris, when police learned during interrogation of plan to attack American base; three are Abdelkader Rabia, Algerian, Jerome Courtailler, Frenchman, and Adel Tobbichi, Algerian (M)

headline: Trying to Elude The Google Grasp
abstract: Some people are trying to reduce amount of material available about them online as information age can mean erosion of personal privacy; it is common for people to look up other people's personal information on Web by running simple search; suggestions for limiting online exposure noted; many people assume they are merely needle in haystack, but if someone takes interest, search tools allow quick and thorough access to lots of information; drawing; photo (M)

headline: U.S., in Shift, Says It Backs Latin Bailouts
abstract: Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill, who has suggested that he would oppose new financial aid for battered South American economies, signals willingness to back bailout plans for two of hardest-hit nations, Brazil and Uruguay; pointedly leaves out a third, Argentina (M)

headline: Of Ratios and Responsibility
abstract: Letter from John M Pickering comments on July 21 article concerning relevance of price/earnings ratio in stock evaluation

headline: Service Chiefs Say Afghan Battle Will Help Military Get Smarter, Stronger and Faster
abstract: Members of Joint Chiefs of Staff say America's military is applying lessons learned in Afghanistan over past year and that urgent priorities have already emerged from studying after-action reports, which could determine how tax-dollars are spent; say Afghanistan has been battle laboratory for successful tests of new tactics and weapons, and has illuminated weaknesses to be addressed before next offensive; describe how past year changed ways in which they will prepare for next stage of combat against terrorism; photo (M)

headline: World Financial Officials Back New Debt Framework
abstract: United States and world's other leading industrial countries move to assuage global anxieties by declaring their willingness to help countries caught up in economic turmoil, mentioning both Brazil and Argentina as examples; in statement issued by finance ministers from Group of Seven industrial countries, following meeting in Washington, countries acknowedge that some countries face 'considerable challenges' and say they will support those who adopt strong policies to restore growth; finance ministers are led by Treas Sec Paul O'Neill; meetings are organized mostly by International Monetary Fund and World Bank; photo of demonstrators (M)

headline: Aide Was Reportedly Ordered To Warn Stewart on Stock Sales
abstract: Douglas Faneuil, assistant to Peter E Bacanovic, Martha Stewart's stockbroker at Merrill Lynch, tells federal prosecutors that Bacanovic ordered him to tell Stewart that founder of ImClone Systems was selling large amounts of stock in late December; says that he objected to order but that Bacanovic insisted; in addition, he tells prosecutors that an explanation for Stewart's sale of nearly 4,000 ImClone shares on Dec 27 was concocted after the fact; photos of Stewart, Bacanovic and Samuel D Waksal, founder of ImClone Systems who was arrested on June 12 and charged with insider trading (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Ziff Davis Media Inc says its revamping plan has won required acceptance from bondholders holding 95 percent of outstanding bonds (S)

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: GetThere survey shows online travel booking was in use during second quarter of 2002 by about 42 pecent of companies surveyed, up from about 24 percent in year-earlier period; says companies in survey spent from $10 million to $300 million on business travel last year, with average of $55 million; Air Transport Association chief economist David Swierenga says traffic recovery in airline industry has stalled; revenue passenger miles were down 8.4 percent in July from year ago; domestic load factor was 76.3 percent; OAG says trans-Atlantic flight sfrom Kennedy International in New York to Western Europe are down 15 percent; from Los Angeles, they are down 21 percent; JetBlue Airways says it is not looking to expand into Philadelphia, where US Airways, which filed for bankruptcy protection last week, now controls most of gates and about 75 percent of departures (Memo Pad column) (M)

headline: Abu Nidal, Palestinian Terrorist Leader, Is Reported Dead
abstract: Palestinian newspaper Al Ayyam reports death of Abu Nidal, Palestinian radical whose small terrorist organization was blamed for killing or wounding more than 900 people in 20 countries since 1973; says Nidal was found dead in home in Baghdad, Iraq, with bullet wounds and is believed to have killed himself (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Police Have Gun From Terror Attacks
abstract: Greek police report finding second of two guns used by November 17 terror group in string of high-profile assassinations; say gun was in weapons den they raided after botched bombing attempt by group member; report holding three people suspected of links to group (S)

headline: A Museum Learns Leverage
abstract: Comment on expansion plans of Mexic-Arte Museum, 18-year-old home for Mexican art and homage to Hispanic culture in Austin, Texas (S)

headline: St-r-r-r-ike? If It Happens, Fans Can Keep Their Eyes on the Ball
abstract: BaseballLibrary.com is online baseball database that includes blogs, stats and latest baseball news; photo (M)

headline: Device Helps Make Arithmetic Appealing to the Game-Inclined
abstract: FlashMaster is digital study aid that mimics flashcards to help teach basic math skills; photo (M)

headline: Bid to Justify a First Strike
abstract: Implicitly, President Bush has agreed to engage the country in a discussion over a fundamental change in national security.

headline: White House Denies Texas Session Is About Iraq
abstract: White House vigorously denies that Pres Bush summoned his senior military advisers to his ranch in Texas on Aug 21 to map out potential effort to topple Saddam Hussein from power in Iraq; Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld, responding to reports of Qaeda operatives in Iraq, says members of organization left Afghanistan and other places and went to variety of countries, including Iraq; photo (M)

headline: In Speech, Pakistan's President Outlines His Plan for Democracy
abstract: Pakistani Pres Gen Pervez Musharraf outlines vision for return to democracy, in television address responding to criticism that he is seeking permanent grip on power; says repeatedly that civilian rule has failed, denies being power hungry and insists that he respects views of Pakistani people (M)

headline: Pepsi Profit Is Up, but Stock Price Is Down
abstract: The Pepsi Bottling Group, the nation's leading bottler of Pepsi Cola, said that profit in its fiscal second quarter increased 14 percent, but its sales volume disappointed Wall Street.

headline: Dow Jones Reports a 25% Rise in Earnings
abstract: Dow Jones & Co says second-quarter earnings rose 25 percent, to $54 million; says sales fell 14 percent, to $417 million; says third-quarter profit will miss estimates (S)

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES: PERSPECTIVES/Senator Richard C. Shelby; A Reaction to Sept. 11: 'This Is a Massive Failure of Intelligence'
abstract: Interview with US Sen Richard C Shelby, ranking Republican on Senate Intelligence Committee who says he will not oppose outside investigation commission to look into September 11 terrorist attacks since joint Congressional committee looking into disaster may adjourn before all facts are unearthed and who faults CIA and FBI for massive failure of intelligence; photo (M)

headline: A Celebration to Remember Liberation Unites Koreans for a Day
abstract: Largest delegation of North Korean civilians in memory joins South Koreans in Seoul, South Korea, to celebrate anniversary of ending of World War II and Japanese colonial rule; 116 North Koreans wave 'unification' flags and chant 'Korea is one' at ceremony; celebration is kickoff to series of North-South civilian exchanges; it comes just six weeks after North and South Korea fought gun battle at sea; North Korea is eager to win restoration of food aid from South Korea and repair relations demaged by naval conflict (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Egypt: 2nd Conviction For Dissident
abstract: Egyptian-American democracy activist Saad Eddin Ibrahim is convicted of defaming Egypt, other charges, at retrial and sentenced to seven years in prison; Western embassies and rights organizations score verdict; American Embassy expresses concern for his health (S)

headline: Just Sell the Peanuts
abstract: Harris Diamond, chief executive of public relations firm Weber Shandwick Worldwide, writes The Boss column on his youth, work, background and family; photo (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Cisco Beats Earnings Estimate, Raising Hope for Technology
abstract: Cisco Systems posts net income of $772 million for quarter ended July 27, compared with net income of $7 million for same quarter year ago; revenue rises to $4.8 billion from $4.3 billion year ago; for full fiscal year, Cisco earns $1.9 billion on revenue of $18.9 billion; chief executive, John T Chambers, comments; photo; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: NEPAL: New Maoist Attack; CHINA: Detour From Google; AFGHANISTAN: Factional Fighting; PAKISTAN: Arrests In Plot; JAPAN: Fujimori Spurns Peruvian;.

headline: BOEING TO BUY ALL OF PILOT TRAINING VENTURE
abstract: Boeing Co agrees to buy stake held by partner FlightSafety International in their joint venture to train pilots; financial terms undisclosed (S)

headline: A Stab at Celebrity Glamour Fails to Save TV's 'BattleBots'
abstract: Television ratings for Comedy Central's BattleBots slide; network will not renew series for next year; program had been instant hit, but when ratings began to fall, network tried to spice up show, and ended up losing even more viewers; photo (M)

headline: Top AOL Executive Resigns in Management Shake-Up
abstract: AOL Time Warner announced this afternoon that Robert W. Pittman, its chief operating officer, had resigned as part of a restructuring.

headline: Sri Lankan Says U.S. Drive on Terror Helps Peace Effort
abstract: Interview with Prime Min Ranil Wickremesinghe, first Sri Lankan leader to visit Washington in nearly two decades; Wickremesinghe holds that American-led campaign against terrorism had helped his government's chances of ending long civil war; says he will ask for increased aid to rebuild nation's economy; maps; photo (M)

headline: Clip 'n' Paste Celebrity: No-Name Web Stars
abstract: Models used in Internet advertisements do not make much money for their images; they sell rights for their images to be downloaded or packaged in CD's almost without restriction; stock photographs are not new, but digital delivery of images has increased their popularity; some have achieved levels of fame and are ubiquitous in ads for numerous products; pohtos (M)

headline: 65% Drop in Profit at Bombardier Is Tied to a Slump in Corporate Jet Orders
abstract: Bombardier Inc says sudden slump in demand for corporate jets contributed to 65 percent decline in second-quarter earnings; says net earnings fell to 101.4 million Canadian dollars ($65.2 million) in three months ended July 31, compared with 287.9 million Canadian dollars ($185.1 million) year earlier; revenue increased 16 percent, to 5.7 billion Canadian dollars ($3.66 billion); photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Leader Of Piracy Group Sentenced
abstract: John Sankus Jr, a leader of international Internet software piracy group that involved students and staff members at some prestigious universities, begins serving 46-month prison sentence in federal prison in Pennsylvania; prosecutors say group, called DrinkOrDie, pirated several million dollars of software (S)

headline: Uncle Sam Wants You (To Play This Game)
abstract: Military's latest promotional campaign is America's Army, free computer game produced by military and aimed at winning hearts and minds of tech-minded teen-agers; photo (M)

headline: ID Cards, Not Ignition Keys, at Airports
abstract: Transportation Security Administration has focused on searching passengers and baggage for weapons or bombs, but is gearing up for dealing with weak points, including airport ramp areas filled with fuel and catering trucks, all with keys left in ignition; agency is looking into system called Wireless Asset Net, which would replace ignition keys with ID card that would have to receive authorization from central computer before allowing operation (M)

headline: For Buchanan, A New Pulpit And Target
abstract: Patrick Buchanan discusses his plans for American Conservative, new opinion magazine, interview; Taki Theodoracopulos, who finances magazine, comments; biweekly magazine will be edited by Scott McConnell, with Kara Hopkins as managing editor; propensity of such political magazines to loose money noted; photos (M)

headline: DataBank; A Five-Week Winning Streak for Stocks
abstract: Summary of week's trading in financial markets; graphs; tables (M)

headline: Flaws in U.S. Air War Left Hundreds of Civilians Dead
abstract: American air campaign in Afghanistan, based on use of high-tech weaponry, has produced pattern of mistakes that killed hundreds of Afghan civilians; on-site reviews of 11 locations where air strikes killed as many as 400 civilians suggest American commanders sometimes relied on mistaken information from local Afghans; suggest preference for air strikes instead of riskier ground operations eliminated way of checking accuracy of intelligence; indicate Pentagon's use of overwhelming force meant that even when truly military targets were located, civilians were sometimes killed; map; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Just Say Oops
abstract: Thailand Prime Min Thaksin Shinawatra suggests governm

headline: For Job Seekers, an Edge (a Sharp One)
abstract: Home Front article on Career Gear, charity with new program to help jobless by giving them free haircuts; says story behind Career Gear offers some insights into changing challenges of assisting unemployed New Yorkers in current economy; photo of Gary Field, founder of Career Gear (M)

headline: U.S. Indicts 5 in Killing of Missionary in Philippines
abstract: The Justice Dept. announced the indictment today of five suspects in connection with the death of a kidnapped missionary.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BRUKER DALTONICS INC., Billerica, Mass., a provider of technology for pharmaceutical companies, said its board had authorized the repurchase of up to 1 million shares of stock over the next 12 months. The company has about 54.9 million shares outstanding.    ITT INDUSTRIES, White Plains, a maker of night-vision goggles and electronic components, said it had won a 2 1/2-year, $8.3 million contract from the U.S. Army to develop sensors for detecting agents used in chemical and biological warfare.

headline: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE IMPACT -- The Chief Executives; Trying to Deflect The Tough Reforms
abstract: As Wall Street sags and Congress moves closer toward enacting legislation on corporate governance, chief executives are trying to respond to their shareholders while opposing most sweeping new proposals; most executives accept that more rules are inevitable; Google chief executive Eric Schmidt, TRW chairman Philip A Odeen, Yellow Corp chairman William D Zollars, Pitney Bowes chief executive Michael J Critelli and Liberate Technologies chief executive Mitchell Kertzman comment (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.50        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.00        Federal funds   1.81   1.80   3.58        3-month T-bills   1.64   1.63   3.28        6-month T-bills   1.61   1.64   3.15        10-yr. T-infl.   2.42   2.49   3.31        10-yr. T-note   4.15   4.22   4.80        30-yr. T-bond   4.96   5.02   5.38        Telephone bd.   6.65   6.68   7.60        Municipal bds.   5.11   5.14   5.12          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: U.S. Bans a Method To Avoid Estate Tax With Life Insurance
abstract: Treasury Department says technique that thousands of wealthiest Americans have used to escape billions of dollars in gift and estate taxes -- one that involves buying expensive life insurance -- is not valid and never has been; experts say ruling appears to rule out all tax avoidance techniques based on using two different insurance premiums; predict that people who have bought these policies will be drawn into years of litigation with government and with their advisers (M)

headline: Georgia Tire Plant Opens
abstract: Pirelli opens its first US tire factory fitted with robot system in Rome, Ga, that cuts production time; factory will employ as many as 300 people after three years (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Banks Hold Interest Rates Steady
abstract: European Central Bank leaves benchmark borrowing rate for 12-nation euro currency zone at 3.25 percent; Bank of England leaves its base rate at 4 percent (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: U.S. and Russia Resolve Chicken Dispute
abstract: United States and Russia resolve dispute over chicken parts that had blocked US exporters from selling to their largest overseas market for six months; new veterinary certificate will accompany poultry exports to calm Russian fears about American chickens (M)

headline: Planned Schedule Of Bond Offerings
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and a four-week bill being to be auctioned tomorrow.    According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.62 percent; the six-month issue, 1.62 percent; and the four-week bill, 1.65 percent.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: Ousted Executive Sells Auto Stock; SOUTH KOREA: Hynix Directors Named; CHINA: Airline Stake Rules Relaxed; SOUTH KOREA: Hyundai Sales Fall;.

headline: Pension Officials to Weigh Influence on Wall St. Ethics
abstract: Officials who control pension investments in 12 states and 3 cities will meet in New York on Aug 12 to consider how they can force changes in way Wall Street firms do busiess; another five states will participate by telephone; summit will discuss influence of firms' underwriters on their analysts, executive pay, companies that reincorporate offshore to avoid paying US taxes and other corporate practices that institutional investors may be able to influence; photo of Comptroller H Carl McCall of New York (M)

headline: Pilots at Southwest Airlines Approve a Contract Extension
abstract: Pilots at Southwest Airlines overwhelmingly approve contract extension by two years to 2006 in surprise move that goes against union leaders' last-minute recommendation that they reject proposal; contract is set to take effect on Sept 1; extension does not bring Southwest pilots to same pay levels as their counterparts (M)

headline: World Business Briefing
abstract: AMERICAS CANADA: INTEREST RATE RAISED Responding to unexpectedly strong domestic growth, the Bank of Canada raised its trend-setting overnight rate yesterday for the third time this year, to 2.75 percent from 2.5 percent. The central bank said the Canadian economy had been moving toward full production capacity more quickly than anticipated. The core inflation rate, which excludes the volatile food and energy categories, was 2.2 percent in May, slightly higher than the bank's 2 percent target.   Bernard Simon (NYT) BRAZIL: TV CONCERN RESTRUCTURES DEBT Brazil's troubled cable TV operator, Net, has restructured $200 million of its debt due before the end of 2003, allowing the cash-short company to go ahead with an equity increase of at least $350 million. Net, part of the Globo television empire, also paid $52 million that was due Monday, according to its chairman, Antonio Viana.   Tony Smith (NYT) EUROPE FRANCE: ACCOUNTING SNARL FOR BANKER Jean- Claude Trichet, the governor of the Bank of France and the leading candidate to become the next president of the European Central Bank, was ordered by a French judge to stand trial on charges of accounting fraud. Mr. Trichet, above, is accused of helping Crédit Lyonnais hide losses in the early 1990's and a trial would jeopardize his chances of getting the position at the central bank. Mr. Trichet was the head of the French Treasury in the early 1990's and served as a government representative on the bank's board. The Paris prosecutor's office, which recommended that Mr. Trichet be cleared, has five days to appeal the decision, but has not yet announced its plans.   Kerry Shaw (NYT) RUSSIA: WATER BOTTLER ACQUIRED In a further signal of rising foreign investment in Russia, Nestlé, the Swiss food producer, announced its purchase of a Russian bottled water company called Saint Springs. The water bottler, one of Russia's first when it started in 1993, was owned privately b

headline: Lincoln National's Earnings Fall
abstract: The Lincoln National Corporation, a provider of life insurance, said its second-quarter profit fell 58 percent because of losses in investments like the debt of WorldCom and declines in revenue from sales of variable annuities and other products.

headline: A Citizen of the World With Few Allies
abstract: Jean-Marie Messier, who appears to have been forced out as chairman of Vivendi Universal, failed in his ambitious goal of turning French water utility into global media giant because of his own misjudgments and missteps as well as some bad timing; whoever replaces Messier must decide whether to stay with strategy of running Vivendi Universal as media company; graph; photo (M)

headline: Chechen Rebels in Limbo Vow Endless Resistance
abstract: Russia is demanding that Georgia extradite 13 Chechen fighters who escaped into Georgia under intense Russian airstrikes; fighters provide rare glimpse of war in Chechnya from point of view of those still resisting, despite overwhelming Russian numbers and military might; their angry bravado underscores depth of opposition that Russia faces; they say theirresistance has been hardened by Russian tactics--disproportionate airstrikes, security sweeps through villages, and hostility toward local Chechens; 13 Chechens in Georgian jails could face 10 years in prison for entering Georgia with weapons, or far worse if they are extradited to Russia; photos; map (M)

headline: China Issues Rules on Export of Missile Gear
abstract: Chinese government announces long-awaited regulations governing export of missile technology; move comes as Deputy Sec of State Richard L Armitage arrives in Beijing to discuss visit of Pres Jiang Zemin to US in fall; new regulations create system of licensing and registration for companies that export missile-related items or any 'dual use' technology that could be used to assist in launch of such weapons (S)

headline: China Muslim Group Planned Terror, U.S. Says
abstract: United States official, stung by questions about timing of US decision to designate East Turkestan Islamic Movement, little-known Muslim group challenging China's social and economic domination in Xinjiang province, as terrorist group, says group planned attacks on Western embassies in neighboring Kyrgyzstan; says Kyrgyzstan deported two Chinese Uighur members of group to China in May because they were planning embassy and other attacks (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Chip Venture May Expand
abstract: Mitsubishi Electric Corp will probably join semiconductor venture Elpida Memory run by NEC Corp and Hitachi early next year; Mitsubishi business that makes dynamic random access memory (DRAM) chips will folded into Elpida Memory; companies will hold about 11 percent of global chip market when deal is completed (S)

headline: Palm Inc. Says I.B.M. Deal Will Aid Sales To Businesses
abstract: Palm Inc will announce deal for joint technology development and marketing with IBM intended to increase use of Palm hand-held computers in corporations and broaden use of IBM's software development tools in hand-held business (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of June 30 article about consultants: Booz Allen Hamilton laid off under two percent of its consultants in 2001, not 9 percent

headline: Technology Briefing: E-Commerce
abstract: DISNEY ENTERS CONSUMER ELECTRONICS MARKET; SPORTSLINE PICKS GSI TO RUN ONLINE STORE;.

headline: Hewlett-Packard Drops Microsoft Works in Favor of WordPerfect
abstract: Microsoft suffered a blow to its most important business when Hewlett-Packard selected a rival software package for its consumer PCs.

headline: Ukraine Invites Investigation of Radar Sale
abstract: Foreign Min Anatoly Zienko of Ukraine says American accusations that his country sold sophisticated radar system to Iraq are groundless; invites international arms inspectors to visit Ukraine to investigate charges; US has said it has tape recordings of Pres Leonid D Kuchma approving sale of radar systems, and indications that several are now in place in Iraq (M)

headline: Kandahar Journal; Cradle of Taliban Reverts to Cradle of Commerce
abstract: Kandahar, traditional trading center in southern Afghanistan dating to Alexander the Great that was scene of some of bitterest fighting by mujahedeen resistance during Soviet occupation and was cradle and headquarters of Taliban movement, is snapping back to old self as crossroads of pragmatic traders; city's stark, joyless period under Taliban, recalled; map; photo (M)

headline: Palestinian Security Chiefs Deny Reports of Their Dismissal
abstract: Jibril Rajoub denies report that Yasir Arafat fired him as Palestinian West Bank security chief; Hamas demonstrators attack Palestinian Authority police station in Gaza Strip, demanding execution of man suspected of being collaborator; Prime Min Ariel Sharon says Israeli troops will remain in centers of cities in West Bank until they are certain they can contain Palestinian violence (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Intel To Sell Most Of Software Unit
abstract: Intel Corp will sell most of division that makes software to manage computer networks to LANDesk Acquisition Corp; Merrill Lynch and Credit Suisse First Boston reduce their financial targets for Intel; graph (S)

headline: Researchers Put Together Story of the Khmer Rouge
abstract: Team of independent researchers is traveling through Cambodia documenting activities of Khmer Rouge frorm 1975 to 1979 both as historical resource and evidence in future trials; researchers are seek to interview as many surviving cadres as possible, from prison guards and torturers to messengers and clerks; have compiled documents that directly implicate dozen leading former Khmer Rouge figures who are now living freely in Cambodia; among those interviewed in Bong Rim, who was recuited as teenager to work as nurse and who appears to have been an innocent (M)

headline: Collins & Aikman Loss Sends Stock Falling
abstract: Collins & Aikman Corp, maker of automotive carpet, posts second-quarter loss of $20.3 million and lowers its full-year outlook, setting off 49 percent decline in its share price; attributes loss to costs of repurchasing preferred stock (S)

headline: The Next Six Months in the Media
abstract: For those in the media world, the first half of 2002 was a time of dashed expectations. Will the second half be different? Dispatches from the magazine, television and publishing worlds.

headline: New Allegations Lead to Ouster of German Defense Minister
abstract: The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, an underdog for reelection in September, fired his defense minister following allegations of financial improprities.

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: TELECOMMUNICATIONS QWEST RATING MIGHT BE LOWERED AGAIN Moody's Investors Service, which rates about $26 billion in debt issued by Qwest Communications International and its subsidiaries as junk bonds, said yesterday that it might downgrade the securities even further. Moody's said its concerns included Qwest's ability to sell its telephone directories business quickly for a good price; the uncertainty surrounding the investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission of Qwest's accounting practices; and Qwest's operating outlook given industry conditions. As a result, Moody's said, Qwest might not be able to repay $3.4 billion in bank loans due next May.    Barnaby J. Feder (NYT) DEALS LUCENT TO SELL UNIT Lucent Technologies, a communications-equipment maker that is shedding businesses to focus on products for phone companies, agreed to sell a unit that designs corporate networks to West Coast Venture Capital. Terms were not disclosed. The business and its managers will join International Network Services Inc., a unit of West Coast Venture.   (Bloomberg News) HARDWARE DELL OPENS INFORMATIONAL KIOSK Dell Computer, the world's biggest direct seller of personal computers, opened an informational kiosk last week in its hometown of Austin, Tex., and plans to open 20 around the country in the next two months. The next two will open in Houston and Dallas. The kiosks, which will be placed in malls and shopping centers, are intended to give customers a chance to test Dell's products and services. To order the machines, however, potential customers need to place orders online or over the phone. Dell gets about 85 percent of its business from corporations, schools and governments, but is looking to increase direct sales to consumers. It has had some success — consumer sales rose 26 percent in the first quarter compared with the year before. Shares in Dell rose 14 cents yesterday, to close at $24.68.   Andrew Zipern (NYT)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Microsoft Enters Wireless Home Networking
abstract: Microsoft Corp announces 10 new wireless home networking products (S)

headline: Private Sector; Easy Come, Easy Go at Tyco: Taking a $91 Million Pay Cut
abstract: Former Tyco International chief financial officer Mark H Swartz forsakes $91 million contractually due him on termination; fears taking severance bonus might prompt legal challenge to his employment contract; photo (M)

headline: 3 Fed Bank Chiefs Hint That Another Rate Cut Isn't Needed
abstract: Federal Reserve Bank presidents Michael H Moskow, Anthony M Santomero and Robert T Parry say in separate remarks that interest rates are low enough to keep consumers spending and fuel economy's rebound, suggesting that Fed officials do not think another cut in interest rates is needed to prevent growth from faltering (M)

headline: Former Israeli Party Leader Freed From Jail
abstract: Aryeh Deri, once-powerful politician who founded and led Israel's strictly Orthodox Shas party, is released from jail after serving two years of three-year prison sentence for corruption; says he has no plans to return to political life, and will devote himself to social work to help those on fringes of society (S)

headline: Health Care Appeals Are No Snap
abstract: Michelle Andrews Money & Medicine column on appealing health plans' decisions to deny treatments patients consider essential; notes appeals process is intimidating, complex and chancy, even though 42 states and District of Columbia allow appeals to independent reviewer (M)

headline: F.B.I. Warns Local Agencies To Be Aware
abstract: FBI issues advisory to local authorities warning of possible terrorist attacks on anniversary of September 11; senior governmnent officials say warnings are precautionary and not based on specific or credible threats; Bush administration officials say possibility of terrorist strikes have prompted heightened security in places like New York and Washington (S)

headline: YUKOS TO CONTINUE OIL SHIPMENTS TO UNITED STATES
abstract: Yukos Oil Co, Russian oil producer, says it will continue to ship crude oil directly to United States through end of year; says shipments appear economical (S)

headline: Real Reform: What Bush Might Have Said
abstract: Following is a speech that might have gotten a better market reception than the one President Bush actually gave this week.      I'VE come to the financial capital of the world to speak of a serious challenge to our financial markets, and to the confidence on which they rest. The misdeeds now being uncovered in some quarters of corporate America are threatening the financial well-being of many workers and many investors.

headline: Stark history / Some see a stunt : Memory becomes battleground in Budapest's House of Terror
abstract: BUDAPEST—  The longest lines for tickets here these days are not at the National Theater's box office or at movie houses showing the latest Hollywood blockbuster. For the past five months, visitors have lined up for hours on the sidewalk of one of Budapest's most elegant avenues under a giant awning stenciled with the word "Terror."

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: RULING ON AMERICAN SUPERCONDUCTOR IS REVERSED; NATIONAL SEMICONDUCTOR POSTS $1.3 MILLION NET INCOME;.

headline: CENDANT'S REAL ESTATE DIVISION BUYS DEWOLFE
abstract: NRT unit of Cendant Corp will buy DeWolfe Companies in Massachusetts for $149 million; NRT is leading owner of residential brokerage firms (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Barnhardt, Walker & Day, Concord, N.C., is expanding operations by adding public relations and event management services, to be led by Patrick Pearson, account executive.

headline: American Gives Beijing Good News: Rebels on Terror List
abstract: Bush administration lists East Turkmenistan Islamic Movement, obscure Muslim group fighting Chinese rule in western province of Xinjiang, as terrorist organization; decision, announced by visiting Deputy Sec of State Richard L Armitage, pleases Beijing, which is anxious to portray crackdown on Uighur Muslims in Xinjiang as part of global campaign against terrorism; may bolster China's cooperation in American-led campaign; photo (M)

headline: British Workers Strike, Closing Schools and Museums
abstract: Hundreds of thousands of local government workers went on strike across much of Britain today in a bitter dispute over pay.

headline: G.E. Is Breaking Its Largest Unit Into Four Parts
abstract: General Electric Co will break GE Capital, by far its largest business, into four segments, effective August 1; reorganization effectively eliminates job of GE Capital chairman Denis J Nayden, as each new unit's chief will report directly to General Electric chairman Jeffrey R Immelt; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Outside 401(k) Plans, Stock Ownership Declines
abstract: Study sponsored by Securities Industry Association and Investment Company Institute reveals decline in number of households owning stock directly or through mutual funds, outside employer-sponsored retirement plans; concludes that 39.5 million households hold such investments, down 1.1 percent from similar study in 1999; including 401(k) and other retirement plans, however, number increased from 49.2 million to 52.7 million households during same period (M)

headline: Hewlett Takes A Step Forward In the World Of Tiny Chips
abstract: Researchers at Hewlett-Packard Co laboratories have developed manufacturing process capable of producing molecular-scale circuits vastly denser than today's most advanced semiconductor chips; discovery offers hope of assembling billions or even trillions of molecular-size switches in area smaller than fingernail at cost far lower than today's computer chips; scientists say switches exhibit swings in electrical resistance that vary by factor of 10,000; huge shift is useful for determining when switches are on or off, but cannot be explained by existing theoretical physics; Dr R Stanley Williams, physicist who is director of Quantum Science Research at Hewlett-Packard laboratory, describes research advance in lecture at symposium celebrating 175th anniversary of Royal Institute of Technology of Sweden (M)

headline: Lawmakers Say Files Show Flagrant WorldCom Fraud
abstract: Lawmakers investigating financial improprieties at WorldCom say continuing examination of company documents convinced them that company engaged in flagrant fraud; Rep Billy Tauzin, chairman of House Energy and Commerce Committee, says unfolding story of WorldCom is 'clearest and most definable violation of accounting standards that we have seen'; Tauzin and other panel members release e-mail notes, internal audit memorandums, board minutes and other correspondence that they say show that executives knew as early as summer of 2000 that treatment of expenses was improper; WorldCom is being sued by California Public Employees Retirement System and other pension funds over $433 million in bond losses; lawyers for Calpers and two other funds file suit, accusing WorldCom of misleading investors about company's finances in May 2001 bond offering (M)

headline: THE COLLECTIONS / PARIS : Stripes everywhere as Hermes captures the right balance
abstract: PARIS—  With stars making a guest appearance and stripes every which way, the Paris menswear shows give a neat example of how fashion works. Contrary to public misconception, a bunch of designers never gets together to create one single diktat in order that consumers are encouraged to spend their money on what's new.

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYInventory-Sales RatioMay.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro falls against US dollar as reports indicate stronger recovery in US than in Europe; in New York, euro settles at 98 cents, down from 98.41 cents; graph; chart (S)

headline: Dozens Killed as Russian Forces Battle Chechen Fighters
abstract: Military and security forces clash with large group of Chechen fighters in southern Russian republic of Ingushetia, in largest battle this year in Russia's war in Caucasus; Kremlin says 100 to 300 fighters recently crossed into Russia from Georgia, further straining relations between two countries and raising possibility that Pres Vladimir V Putin would carry out his threat to order strikes inside Georgia; photos; map (M)

headline: Cordiant Chairman Will Resign Soon
abstract: Cordiant Communications Group says chairman Charles Scott will resign as soon as successor is named (S)

headline: Victims in Israeli Strike Include 2 Children
abstract: Israeli helicopters fire missiles at Palestinian vehicle near Jenin on West Bank, killing three men inside and two children outside their home; target was reportedly Suliman Abu-Sayad, leader of radical Al Aksa Martyrs Brigade; he reportedly escaped; Israeli soldiers arrest Hasan Yousef, leader of militant Hamas movement in Ramallah; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Joint Bid For Retailer
abstract: Belgian retailers Compagnie Nationale a Portefeuille and Ackermans & Van Haaren join forces in bid for retail group GIB; two retailers offer $1.27 billion (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Premier's Big Gamble
abstract: Japan's Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi tells party officials he is staking his political life on visit to North Korea this week; press has expressed caution about one-day visit, calling it hurried and questioning whether prime minister can win concessions from North Korea, which does not have diplomatic ties with Japan; photo (S)

headline: After Pakistan Raid, 3 Mysterious Suicides
abstract: Three men blow themselves up with grenades when Pakistani police stop them 25 miles from Christian missionary school where gunmen killed six people; link is unclear; authorities focus probe on new coalition of Islamic militants, Lashkar-e-Omar; more than 145 Australian, European and American children survived attack on school in Jhika Gali (M)

headline: Stalked by A.T.M. Fees
abstract: Bill Bumpas letter on August 1 article notes his online bank reimburses ATM fees each month

headline: M&T Is Said to Be in a Deal for Allfirst
abstract: M&T Bank Corp, whose largest investor is billionaire Warren E Buffett, is planning to announce that it has agreed to buy Allfirst Financial from Allied Irish Banks for $3 billion in cash and stock (S)

headline: Business; Venture Capitalists Are Taking the Gloves Off
abstract: Venture capitalists are increasingly avoiding risk, preferring to invest in later stages of projects; entrepreneurs, desperate for money, decry shift and hard-knuckled deals venture capital firms demand; photo; graphs (M)

headline: New Economy; Like Narcissus, executives are smitten, and undone, by their own images.
abstract: Tim Race column holds corporate executives involved in recent scandals many suffer from narcissism, psychiatric personality disorder; holds executives accused of fraud may not have set out initially to break law, but came to imagine themselves as above law; holds stock bubble, in which paper wealth created auras of power and invincibility, seems to have nurtured narcissism; photo (M)

headline: THE COLLECTIONS / PARIS : Graphic Dior menswear scores in summer season of stripes
abstract: PARIS—  With incisive cutting and an androgynous, modern attitude, Dior menswear once again sent out a powerful message on the last day of the Paris summer season. Designer Hedi Slimane not only produced a strong show Monday, but also took a definitive stance on crucial menswear trends, especially the tailcoat reinvented as a short, cutaway jacket, rounded like a carved-up melon.

headline: EARNINGS MORE THAN DOUBLED FOR 3M IN 2ND QUARTER
abstract: 3M Co says second-quarter net income rose to $466 million from $202 million year earlier; sales rose 2.2 percent, to $4.16 bilion (S)

headline: Many Are Wondering if Eisner Can Reverse Course at Disney
abstract: Questions are being raised inside Walt Disney Co boardroom about whether Michael D Eisner, chairman and chief executive, has wherewithal to reverse fortunes of company who share price has hit an eight-year low; Stanley Gold, board member whose Shamrock Holdings is investment arm of Disney family, is reportedly trying to tap into discontent of other investors in what might end as power struggle involving Gold, aided by Roy Disney, and Eisner over Disney's future direction; Disney board has been criticized as weak and for having let Eisner stay too long; photo; graph (M)

headline: Tribunal Says Rwanda Is Stalling Inquiry Into 1994 Killings
abstract: International Criminal Tribunal for Rwanda accuses Rwanda of foot-dragging in trying suspects from wave of ethnic killings in 1994; charges Rwanda is purposely holding up trials for political reasons (M)

headline: FORD SAYS IT WILL ACCOUNT FOR OPTIONS AS AN EXPENSE
abstract: Ford Motor Co will start accounting for stock options as expense in January to reflect cost of paying executives and other employees (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Easyjet Founder To Resign Sooner
abstract: Stelios Haji-Ioannou, 35, founder and chairman of low-cost British airline Easyjet, brings his resignation forward to Nov 26; says he will remain significant shareholder in company; photo (M)

headline: Israelis Shut the Jerusalem Office of a Moderate Palestinian
abstract: Israeli authorities close down Jerusalem office of Sari Nusseibeh, leaving voice of moderation among Palestinians, and accuse him of undermining Israeli sovereignty by serving as representative of Yasir Arafat's Palestinian Authority; police take away files from office at Al Quds University, where Nusseibeh is president; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Church Tells Of Abusive Priests
abstract: Philippines Catholic Bishops Conference president, Abp Orlando Quevedo, discloses that some 200 priests have been probed for sexual offenses in last 20 years; says most of them have either been dismissed or left church voluntarily; apologizes for failures of some church leaders; says church will draft protocol for dealing with priests' misconduct (S)

headline: Judges Catch Up, With Some Cramming
abstract: Nearly 200 judges from courts in Moscow region gather at Moscow Regional Court for seminar in new Criminal Procedure Code (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: The Hague: Milosevic Trial Resumes
abstract: War crimes trial of former Serbian Pres Slobodan Milosevic resumes in the Hague after monthlong summer recess; he remains defiant; cross examines several witnesses who describe atrocities in Kosovo (S)

headline: Bid to Justify A First Strike
abstract: News analysis of Pres Bush's decision to seek approval of Congress before taking military action against Iraq; decision amounts to acknowledgment that he cannot proceed alone and that he needs to move quickly to try to resolve rift within his administration, with many of his father's cautious advisers and with his reluctant allies; photo (M)

headline: Are Higher Rates What the Market Needs?
abstract: Based on history, it is pretty clear that increases in interest rates and growth in corporate earnings, year-over-year, go hand in hand.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Cruise Line Rejects Meeting Offer
abstract: P&O Princess Cruises rejects request from Carnival Corp for meeting to discuss antitrust issues relating to Carnival's hostile bid for P&O Princess (S)

headline: As the Right Falls Into Disarray, Austrians Call Early Elections
abstract: Austrian Chancellor Wolfgang Schussel calls early elections to end government crisis brought on by feud within Jorg Haider's far-right Freedom Party, partner in his coalition government; Haider used battle over tax policy to reassert control over party and force resignations of Vice Chancellor Susanne Reiss-Passer, Finance Min Karl-Heinz Grasser, Transport Min Mathias Reichold and Peter Westenthaler, parliamentary speaker (M)

headline: Analyze This: What Those Analysts Said in Private
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column on disclosure that former Credit Suisse First Boston analysts Jamie Kiggen and Laura Martin decided against lowering firm's revenue projections for AOL Time Warner after deciding that revenues would fall short; AOL share price graph (M)

headline: California Examines Ways to Manage Energy
abstract: California is beginning to figure out how its power market will operate beyond next few months; Federal Energy Regulatory Commission in mid-July disclosed its new plan for wholesale power market in Western states; commission will continue to control California's bids to supply power, which it began doing last summer during state's energy crisis; ceiling bids will rise to $250 per megawatt-hour from $91.87 after Sept 30; Elena Schmid, vice president of Independent System Operator, says California needs to settle its plans for future before new capacity will appear; photo (M)

headline: Allied Domecq Leaves BBDO Worldwide
abstract: Allied Domecq Spirits and Wines USA and Chicago office of BBDO Worldwide will part ways in September (S)

headline: Copyright Hurdles Confront Selling of Music on the Internet
abstract: Services that want to sell music online are facing administrative and other problems getting permission from recordings companies and composers; record labels withhold rights to some songs to protect CD sales and sometimes favor own services over competitors; some artists block digital distribution of their work; getting permission from publisher who represents composer can also pose obstacles; drawings (M)

headline: Equity Offerings Set for This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:      Kinder Morgan Management, Houston, 15 million shares. Goldman, Sachs & Company.

headline: 2 Agencies Join Forces In Alliance in Dallas
abstract: Wong Doody says it will form strategic alliance with Dallas-based Gilliatt Paris; financial terms undisclosed; Gilliatt Paris will operate as Wong Doody Dallas, joining two other Wong Doody offices in Los Angeles and Seattle; Doug Gilliatt and Chuck Paris, principals at Gilliatt Paris, will own office and be managing partners at Wong Doody Dallas (S)

headline: Bush to Outline Doctrine of Striking Foes First
abstract: Today, the Bush administration will publish a comprehensive explanation for shifting military strategy toward pre-emptive action against hostile states and terrorist groups.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Dell To Offer Oracle Server Software
abstract: Oracle Corp says Dell Computer will offer Oracle9i Application Service software to Dell customers (S)

headline: Germany faces austerity measures no matter who wins
abstract: FRANKFURT:—  Regardless of who wins Sunday's national election, the next German government is likely to adopt new austerity measures to rein in its surging budget deficit to bring it in line with the strict fiscal limits imposed by the European single-currency pact, according to officials and private analysts.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Profit For Truckmaker
abstract: Swedish truckmaker Scania reports second-quarter net income rose to 1.08 billion kronor ($117 million); sales fell 20 percent (S)

headline: Article 2002090790134980548 -- No Title
Those Feeling the Pain Now Await a Remedy
abstract: Many investors across country are relieved that Pres Bush addressed issue of corporate responsibility but doubt much will be done about issue; photo (M)

headline: Hamburg Police Raid 2 Import-Export Firms
abstract: Police raid two export-import firms in Germany that are owned by Abdul Matin Tatari, a Syrian-born German, who is being detained, along with his wife and their two sons, for questioning on suspicion of using false documents and laundering money to smuggle Islamic militants to Hamburg and contribute to Holy War of violent fundamental Islamists; photo (M)

headline: AMERICAN ELECTRIC REDUCES 2002 EARNINGS FORECAST
abstract: American Electric Power reduces its 2002 earnings forecast for second time in week, after second-quarter earnings fell 91 percent; net income fell to $21.9 million from $231.8 million year earlier; revenue rose 7.8 percent, to $415.2 billion (S)

headline: COACH SAYS ITS EARNINGS MIGHT BE HIGHER THAN FORECAST
abstract: Coach Inc says expected earnings in its first quarter ended Sept 28 to be higher than forecast says profit will be at least 21 cents per share on sales of $185 million to $190 million (S)

headline: Founder of Adelphia and 2 Sons Arrested
abstract: Adelphia Communications founder John J Rigas and his sons Timothy and Michael are arrested on charges they looted company of more than $1 billion, using it as their 'personal piggy bank' in one of largest cases of corporate fraud ever; Federal prosecutors accuse Rigases of bank, securities and wire fraud; Securities and Exchange Commission files separate civil suit for 'one of the most extensive financial frauds ever to take place at a public company'; Adelphia itself has sued Rigases, including wife and daughter of John Rigas, who did not work at company, seeking three times amount it says family took improperly; very public arrests are carried out despite offers in recent days by Rigas and his sons to surrender voluntarily to authorities; Rigases are freed on $10 million bail each as part of agreement struck with prosecutors before hearing; bail is secured by $1 million in cash for John Rigas and $500,000 for each son plus family home in Coudersport, Pa, where sons still live with their father and his wife, Doris, as well as 5,000 acres of land and two vacation properties; John Rigas's lawyer Peter Fleming Jr scolds prosecutors for forcefully arresting 78-year-old man at 6 am when he volunteered to surrender; Timothy J Rigas's lawyer Jermey H Temkin hints public arrest may have been politically motivated as part of Washington's effort to demonstrate its prosecution of corporate fraud amid crumbling confidence among investors in stock market; former Adelphia executives James R Brown and Michael Mulcahey are arrested at their homes in Coudersport on fraud charges; another son, James P Rigas, is named in related SEC complaint against company and other executives but not in criminal indictment; photos (M)

headline: FX Channel Hopes to Run Joe Six-Pack For President
abstract: FX cable television channel will produce reality show called American Candidate, which it says may just find grass-roots candidate for 2004 presidential election; program will follow contestants as they campaign against one another to become viewers' choice for president of United States (M)

headline: Are Gadgets Already Too Small?
abstract: In general, few people are less interested in predicting the future of technology than I am. The high-tech business is inherently unpredictable--almost random. Just as nobody in 1980 could have seen Microsoft or the Internet coming, so nobody can imagine whatever huge development is being hatched in a garage somewhere at this very moment. Whatever any pundit tells you about technology even five years from now should be taken with a grain of salt the size of Canada. In fact, the whole exercise should be considered slightly less scientific than the horoscope column at the back of a teen fashion magazine.

headline: Papa John's Selects Austin Kelley
abstract: Papa John's Selects Austin Kelley Papa John's International in Louisville, Ky., the pizza chain, selected Austin Kelley Advertising in Atlanta to handle its strategic and creative account. Spending was estimated at $40 million to $45 million.

headline: Assessing the Future Of Vivendi, Some Expect A French Strategy
abstract: Vivendi Universal's chief executive Jean-Rene Fourtou is trying to chart strategy to take company forward; at heart of his decisions is whether Vivendi remains media conglomerate with global aspirations, or return to its French roots with few core businesses in telecommunications, pay television and waste management; decision is not expected until board meets in September, and Fourtou has so far given no indication that he has made up his mind; indications are Fourtou will return company to its French roots; graph; photos (M)

headline: Seeking Votes, German Leader Endorses Plan To Aid Jobless
abstract: Chancellor Gerhard Schroder, trailing in German election polls, embraces proposals intended to halve unemployment, persistent economic ill that is dragging down his campaign; plan is already watered down by unions that back Schroder, while conservatives promise own plan to come (M)

headline: Vivendi's Latest Spin Campaign: No Sale Option Is Left Unspun
abstract: Analysts and investment bankers are puzzled by impression that, under leadership of Jean-Rene Fourtou, any part of Vivendi Universal or the entire company is up for sale; insiders say tactic is part of campaign to give Vivendi greater bargaining power with bidders and banks; photos (M)

headline: Pharmaceutical makers and ad agencies fight to preserve campaigns for prescription drugs.
abstract: Advertising industry is stepping up fight to protect its freedom to pitch prescription drugs directly to consumers, one of its most lucrative categories; Sen Debbie Stabenow has proposed that tax deductions taken by drug makers for advertising cannot exceed tax deductions they take for research and development; graph; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Lends Support To Foes of Mugabe
abstract: The Bush administration said it was working to foster opposition to President Robert Mugabe in Zimbabwe, calling his rule illegitimate and irrational.    Using some of the administration's strongest language yet to condemn the government in Zimbabwe, senior state department officials said Mr. Mugabe won re-election in March through fraud and coercion and has since helped spread starvation in southern Africa through misguided policies.

headline: Survival of Software’s Fittest
abstract: For me, one of the most painful stories to emerge from the tech crash is that of Casady & Greene (C&G), a small software company for whom, before joining The Times, I once wrote user manuals.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Expects a Profit On Cuts and Strong Sales  Buoyed by strong industry sales and cost cuts, Ford said that it expected to post an operating profit for the third quarter. Analysts had expected an operating loss of 10 cents a share.    The profit forecast, analysts said, showed that Ford was making progress in cutting costs. The results were also bolstered by continued spending by Americans on automobiles. Ford's August sales rose 8.2 percent, though it lost market share. But Ford did sell more of its Explorer sport utility vehicle than in any other month before. [Page C14.]

headline: Europeans May Hold Their Fire on U.S. Steel Tariffs
abstract: European Union officials hint they might put off until 2003 retaliating against United States steel tariffs; apparently respond to US move greatly narrowing scope of disputed tariffs (M)

headline: HASBRO LOSS WIDENS AFTER WRITE-DOWN ON FRENCH ASSET
abstract: Hasbro Inc says second-quarter loss widened to $25.9 million from $18.3 million year earlier; sales increased 6.9 percent, to $546 million from $511 million (S)

headline: Bally Fitness Selects Foote, Cone
abstract: Bally Total Fitness Corp is expected to announce selection of Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding to handle marketing and advertising; total spending estimated at $50 million; account had been handled internally and by Colby & Partners (S)

headline: Suites Are Increasingly Doing Double Duty
abstract: Growing number of traveling executives are holding business meetings or entertaining clients in their hotel suites instead of renting traditional spaces as companies tighten travel budgets; some executives comment; photo (M)

headline: CONTINENTAL REPORTS QUARTERLY LOSS OF $139 MILLION
abstract: Continental Airlines reports second-quarter loss of $139 million; revenue was $2.1 billion; chief executive Gordon M Bethune comments (S)

headline: Shares Mixed, but Dow and S.&P. Maintain 4-Week Run
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes at 8,778.06, down 40.08 points; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 1.48 points, to 928.77; Nasdaq composite index rises 16 points, to 1,361.01; Treasury's 10-year note falls 1 4/32, to 100 13/32, and yields 4.33 percent; graph; tables of favorite stock issues and key rates (M)

headline: A campaign to tell restaurant owners that smoke-free environments don't hurt business.
abstract: Prof Stanton A Glantz, tobacco researcher at University of California, San Francisco, wants to tell restaurants and bars to go smoke free, but he is having trouble getting word out; announces new Web site, tobaccoscam, to counter what he calls 20-year campaign by tobacco industry to use restaurant industry as stalking horse to defeat anti-smoking rules; photo (M)

headline: EMULEX SAYS SALES WILL FALL SHORT OF ESTIMATES
abstract: Circuit-board maker Emulex Corp says that sales in current fiscal year will be below analysts' estimates; company's stock plunges (S)

headline: Palestinians, Meeting Powell, Urge Pullout
abstract: Three Palestinian officials appointed by Yasir Arafat met with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and the national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, on Thursday.

headline: MEMO PAD
abstract: Southwest Airlines begins using self-service e-ticket check-in kiosks to make getting boarding pass easier; continues to board passengers in groups, without assigned seats; Singapore Airlines will introduce its large new business-class seats on inaugural flight of service between Singapore and Las Vegas via Hong Kong; is spending $100 million to install seats on its flights throughout world; online columnist Joe Brancatelli jokes that Bill Gates could afford to buy and fix ailing domestic airlines (M)

headline: Screening for Ethics At Business Schools
abstract: Brown University Prof Felicia Ackerman letter on September 15 article questions why University of Chicago's Graduate School of Business is considering hiring professional ethicists to screen applicants

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Pre-Election Violence In Kashmir
abstract: Political worker is shot to death, Kashmir, as anti-India militants continue their efforts to derail state elections; gunman tries to kill candidate in second incident; Indian security forces report killing three commanders of main rebel group, Hizbul Mujahedin (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; Adding to Loss Of Investments, A Loss of Faith
abstract: Floyd Norris Market Place column assesses sharp declines in major US stock market averages in nine weeks beginning week before Memorial Day, during which stocks have lost more than 20 percent of their value; says some Americans are beginning to lose faith in stock market as sure-fire, long-term investment; notes that, historically, such rapid declines have come near end of bear markets and were often followed by rapid advances; says Wall Street analysts are talking of apitulation, term indicating that so many have sold that bottom must be near; graphs (M)

headline: Pakistan Court Bars Former Prime Minister From Election
abstract: Pakistani court rejects appeal by former Prime Min Benazir Bhutto seeking permission to run in Oct Parliamentary elections; ruling ignites violent protests, Karachi, by several hundred of her supporters; judge sentences her lawyer to six months in jail for his remarks; other main political party weighs election boycott in wake of decision barring races by ex-Prime Min Nawaz Sharif's wife, Kulsoom, and brother, Shahbaz; photo (M)

headline: Eddie Bauer is taking steps to overcome a long struggle in the wilderness of identity confusion.
abstract: Eddie Bauer is revamping its clothing line and will introduce $12 million marketing campaign next week to restore its image as retailer of rugged outdoor wear; campaign is developed by Mullen Advertising; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: BOOK-TO-BILL RATIO ROSE IN JUNE; INTEL TO INTRODUCE PERSONAL VIDEO PLAYER;.

headline: Musharraf Assails Islamic Militants, but Stands Firm on Kashmir
abstract: Pres Pervez Musharraf of Pakistan, in nationwide address, lashes out at Islamic militants for recent attacks on Christian school and hospital, calling acts 'shameful' and 'despicable' and vowing to 'break the back' of groups; Western diplomats conclude that Musharraf was aiming his harsh statement about militants at United States, since he spoke mostly in English; in matter of Kashmir, Musharraf vows that Pakistan will not back away from its demand for United Nations-monitored referendum to allow people of Kashmir to choose whether to join Pakistan or India or become independent; India adamantly opposes referendum and accuses Pakistan of supporting Islamic insurgents fighting against Indian rule in mostly Muslim region (M)

headline: PUBLIC SERVICE ENTERPRISE TO OFFER $400 MILLION IN UNITS
abstract: Public Service Enterprise Group, owner of New Jersey's largest utility, plans to sell $400 million of participating units to pay short-term debt and to spend on certain subsidiaries (S)

headline: When Stars Are Paid To Talk About Drugs
abstract: David Cox letter reacts to August 11 article concerning celebrities promoting pharmaceuticals for money

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Disclosure Says WorldCom Overstated Profits Earlier  WorldCom has disclosed that its profits may have been exaggerated as far back as 1999, or two years earlier than previously disclosed. Last week, the company said it had overstated pretax profits by $3.8 billion in 2001 and early this year.    The disclosure of new accounting problems, which could indicate that WorldCom overstated profits by more than $1 billion in 1999 and 2000, came in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. [Page A1.]

headline: Rich, but Not Comfortable, In South Africa's Black Elite
abstract: Wealth of South Africa's black elite has increased considerably since end of apartheid in 1994, but their success only magnifies enormity of struggles of those left behind; majority of blacks are still stuck in impoverished townships, with little education, few job skills and little hope of escaping poverty; statistics suggest they are getting poorer as economy sheds jobs and unemployment deepens; tensions are mounting as divide between rich and poor blacks widens; members of new wealthy and professional class of blacks are derided as material-minded elitists with little commitment to uplifting masses; sense of celebration among successful blacks is sometimes tempered by feelings of alienation; some feel lonely in traditionally white communities, while others feel guilty about enjoying fruits of their achievements while family and friends continue to struggle; photo; map; graph (L)

headline: Another Dimension Of Shareholder Activism
abstract: Efforts are in progress to distribute to shareholders some assets of cash-rich companies National Presto Industries and Farmer Brothers; stepped up shareholder activism coincides with current intense scrutiny of corporate America (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: PAKISTAN: Attack Plotters Caught, Police Say; SRI LANKA: Talks To Start Next Month; EAST TIMOR: Rights Chief Condemns Acquittals; MYANMAR: Student Arrests Prompt Protests;.

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Commodities column; natural gas falls because cooler weather is expected to reduce demand for power in Northeast; graphs (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fed to Keep Rates Steady With Rare Dissenting Votes  The Federal Reserve voted to leave interest rates unchanged, but two of its 12 voting members took the rare step of opposing the decision and instead backed an immediate rate cut.    It was the first time since 1998 that two Fed policy makers have simultaneously broken ranks with Alan Greenspan, the chairman. The split decision was a clear indication that Fed officials, like economists generally, are divided over how to deal with the fears of further weakness in the economy. [Page A1.]

headline: Technology Briefing | Biotechnology: Organogenesis Files For Bankruptcy
abstract: Organogenesis, maker of bioengineered skin substitute, files for bankruptcy and dismisses 110 workers after it stops shipping its Apligraf tissue to Novartis, its exclusive distributor (S)

headline: Talks Open In Sri Lanka Today to End 19-Year War
abstract: Sri Lankan government and Tamil Tiger separatists will begin peace talks on September 16 aimed at ending 19-year civil war that has killed more than 60,000 people and laid waste to country's economy (S)

headline: Airline Instructors Vote for Concessions
abstract: Bankrupt US Airways Group says flight-crew training instructors, Transport Workers Union of America members, have approved contract concessions needed to cut expenses; has yet to reach accord with Communications Workers of America, which represents reservation agents and ticket counter workers (S)

headline: U.S. Accuses 2 Audit Firms Of Assisting Tax Violations
abstract: Justice Department accuses accounting firms KPMG and BDO Seidman of flouting tax laws by helping hundreds of people and companies escape billions of dollars in taxes through improper transactions that firms designed to be hidden from tax auditors; also accuses both firms of refusing to turn over thousands of pages of documents about tax shelters in violation of 1984 law requiring shelter promoters to maintain lists of clients and records of transactions; suits are intended to force firms to provide those documents; Internal Revenue Service says KPMG refused to turn over any documents about tax shelter that agency said it learned about in April from article in New York Times; article described how corporations could stop paying taxes on profits earned in US by reincorporating in Bermuda and holding annual board meeting in tax haven like Bermuda; both firms say they have done nothing wrong; KPMG spokesman George Ledwith says firm has 'worked cooperatively' with IRS in responding to summons, but that it has not turned over documents where 'KPMG believes it has legitimate disputes with IRS regarding those summons' over issue of whether documents are privileged; BDO says firm is cooperating with IRS audit of its tax shelters, but that it is also committed to protecting confidentiality of its clients; clients were told by KPMG that its tax shelters were 'sure win' deals with no risk, according to suit that software entrepreneur Joseph J Jacoboni filed against KPMG on April 29 after IRS auditors disallowed his tax shelter and demanded millions in taxes and penalties; Jacoboni, using KPMG's shelters, turned $28 million profit when he sold his company into $2 million loss on his tax return, saving him $5.6 million that IRS now wants; KPMG is seeking dismissal of Jacoboni's suit (M)

headline: Tarnished Image Places Welch in Unlikely Company
abstract: Reputation of John F Welch Jr, former chief executive of General Electric whose management style, swagger and acumen were once analyzed and idolized in business schools, has lost a good deal of luster as result of questions about company's accounting, eerie consistency with which profits rose during his tenure, company's weak stock performance since his departure and disclosure of details of his retirement package; business press will even include Welch's name in same paragraph with such dubious figures as Kenneth L Lay of Enron, Bernard J Ebbers of WorldCom and Dennis Kozlowski of Tyco International; Welch goes on Wall Street Week to defend retirement package and deplore its release; photos (M)

headline: Argentine Leader Moves Election Forward
abstract: Eduardo Duhalde, Argentina's caretaker president, moves up election to choose his successor by six months, saying government must be strengthened by popular vote in order to effect the great reforms needed by country; primary elections will be held within four months and new president selected four months after that; Duhalde will not seek full four-year term; photo (M)

headline: Northern Afghan Region Still Roiled by Rivalries and Fighting
abstract: Tensions and security alerts remain high in Mazar-i-Sharif and northern Afghan region, where rivalries between warlords persist 10 months after Taliban was chased from city, heralding collapse of their rule across country; soldiers still enforce 10pm curfew and UN mission keeps staff members on high state of alert; armed groups with ties to three most powerful warlords have frequently clashed; joined forces to fight Tailban and have cooperated to share power since then; old rivalries of three, and bitter fighting between them in 1990's, have not been forgotten; map (M)

headline: SOFTWARE MAKER FIRES CHIEF AND EXAMINES ITS BOOKS
abstract: Software maker HPL Technologies investigates internal financial and accounting irregularities and fires its chief executive, David Lepejian; Elie Antoun will serve as interim chief executive; company's share price falls 72 percent before trading is halted (S)

headline: A One-Woman Show in Cosmetics
