abstract: Orrea Light, founder of Orrea Beaute, writes in My Job column about challenge of interesting investors and women's magazines in her line of cosmetics; photo (M)

headline: Many Marketers Will Forgo Ads During Sept. 11
abstract: Most marketers, ad agencies and media companies are deciding that they would rather forgo ads on first anniversary of terrorist attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon than risk being perceived as exploiting day for mercenary purposes; among those marketers that will forgo television, print and radio advertising completely on Sept 11 are Coca-Cola, General Motors, HBO unit of AOL Time Warner, Miller Brewing, Nissan North American division of Nissan Motor and Target Stores; most of companies that are choosing to advertise on Sept 11, like Ford Motor and Procter & Gamble, will keep their ads away from any coverage related to anniversary of attacks; special 96-page Sept 11 'commemorative issue' of US News & World Report, which is now being sold at newsstands, carries no paid advertising; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Pitt's Rules: Lawyers Out, Bartenders In
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Harvey L Pitt speaks on current wave of corporate scandal at annual American Bar Association meeting; photo (M)

headline: Canadian Transit Giant Having Summer of Woe
abstract: Canada's Bombardier Inc has experienced many problems this summer; company was loser in late July to widely publicized contest to build 1,700 cars for New York subway, one of world's largest transit contracts; Amtrak in early August temporarily idled Acela high-speed trains supplied by Bombardier and its French partner, Alstom, after cracks were discovered in locomotives' suspension system; company reports earnings fell to $65 million, or 101 million Canadian dollars, in three months to July 31, from 287.9 million Canadian dollars year earlier; chief executive Robert E Brown comments on setbacks in rail division and weakness in sales of business jets; photo (M)

headline: Patents; A new device that gives customer service a heads-up on which callers are spoiling for a fight.
abstract: Peter Bohacek and Dieter Schulz patent for Mitel Knowledge Corp voice-prompt system for customer service phone systems that detects outrage or anger and directs caller to specially trained operators; inventors at Discovery Communications patent system that calculates person's mood, interests and television-watching history to suggest shows they might like to see; invention uses television set-top box and is linked to incoming program guide; is part of Discovery's digital strategy; drawing (M)

headline: Article 2002090590507814510 -- No Title
Rival Parties Join in Bid to Defeat Musharraf
abstract: Pakistan's two largest political parties announce they will join forces in upcoming parliamentary elections to defeat coalition of small parties backing Pres Pervez Musharraf; say they will choose single candidate from one of two parties to run in most districts in Oct elections; officials from both parties, Pakistan Peoples Party and Pakistan Muslim League, say alliance between longtime rivals will not spread beyond their antipathy for Musharraf (M)

headline: Blair Says Northern Ireland's Militias Must All Disband
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain denounces persistence of violence in Northern Ireland; calls on province's paramilitary groups to disband and warns that government would become more 'rigorous' in punishing them for violating their ceasefire claims; large-scale organized killing has ended, but there has been upsurge of riots, shootings, gasoline bomb attacks and beatings; government believes some of violence is being coordinated by Irish Republican Army and its counterpart Protestant guerrilla groups, all of whom pledged four years ago to maintain ceasefires and abandon systematic mayhem (M)

headline: Japanese Premier to Visit North Korea in Sign of Thaw
abstract: Japanese Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi says he will visit North Korea in Sept for summit meeting with Kim Jong Il; bold move toward ending North's long isolation comes as North and South Korea set timetable to start repairing road and rail links closed since Korean War; North Korea's official news agency hails visit; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ford Appeals Crash Award, Raising Questions of Jury  In the appeal of a case where it was ordered to pay $290 million in damages, Ford has raised questions about the jury's deliberations. The jury in California, after deliberating for five days, had ordered Ford to pay millions to the family of three killed in the rollover of a Bronco. According to Ford and the judge, the deliberations were anything but thoughtful and conscientious.     The questions raised by Ford are part of a larger debate about whether jurors, lacking in technical and economic training, should be entrusted with the task of punishing corporate wrongdoing. [Section A.]

headline: SHEFFIELD ENDS JOINT VENTURE WITH ELAN, A DRUG MAKER
abstract: Sheffield Pharmaceuticals agrees with Elan Corp to end their joint venture to make products that deliver drugs to lungs; Sheffield will get rights to Elan's Updas drug-delivery system and Elan will receive royalties on two of venture's experimental products if they are brought to market; Sheffield has rights to venture's Tempo inhaler and Premaire drug-delivery system (S)

headline: FED CHIEF BLAMES CORPORATE GREED; HOUSE REVISES BILL
abstract: Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan blames corporate culture blighted by 'infectious greed' for breakdown in investor confidence; blunt testimony to Congress about executive avarice and House Republican leaders' rush to legislate reflect how question of business integrity is reshaping both politics and economic policy; Dow Jones stock average falls more than 200 points, rises some during Greenspan appearance and then falls again, defying hope that Greenspan might break negative psychology; House Republicans who had warned against overreacting now try to distance themselves from business, rushing to floor bill setting criminal penalties for corporate fraud as harsh or harsher as those passed by Senate 97 to 0; Pres Bush hints he will sign any bill; House bill passes 391-28; provisions compared with Sen Paul Sarbanes' measure; photo; Greenspan indicates Fed is not in hurry to either raise or lower interest rates; points finger squarely at chief executives who put stock option money ahead of duty to shareholders; Greenspan, who has for three years called for companies to list stock options as expenses, admits he was wrong to oppose government role in auditing oversight (M)

headline: The Businessman; Courting Customers And Making Millions
abstract: China's economy remains largely state owned, but its private sector is growing fast. There are now at least 10 million private business owners, not including millions more independent merchants, traders and street hawkers.    Xue Bing, 39, is typical of the new capitalist breed amassing wealth in the transitional economy. While most of these people shun politics, they tend to support the Communist Party as guardian of the stability on which their future depends.    Mr. Xue was a manager in a state-owned construction company until two years ago, when it began to privatize many of its businesses. He invested 80,000 yuan, his life savings, to buy 8 percent of one of the businesses, a company that manufactures paint. He holds a quarter stake in the company's Beijing subsidiary.

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: INTEL WON'T COUNT OPTIONS AS EXPENSE; PALM SHARES DROP AFTER REMOVAL FROM INDEX;.

headline: Federal Reserve Board Leaves Interest Rates Unchanged
abstract: The Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged at a four-decade low today, but it indicated it will cut rates even further if the economy slows.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Appeal Filed Against Papon Release
abstract: Paris prosecutor's office says it filed appeal against court ruling this week that released Maurice Papon, most prominent Frenchman to be tried for collaborating with Nazis; Papon's release caused public outcry (S)

headline: Controversial Pop-Ups
abstract: Nielsen/NetRatings reports that pop-up ads account for only 2 percent of all online advertisements and that fewer than 10 percent of all companies that advertise online use them; graph; photo (S)

headline: IRAQ REJECTS PUSH BY U.S. TO TOUGHEN INSPECTION RULES
abstract: Iraq rejects proposal by United States and Britain for Security Council resolution imposing tough weapons inspections, saying it will not accept any new rules for work of United Nations inspectors; diplomats from Washington and London shuttle to Moscow and Beijing after consulting in Paris, trying to overcome strong objections to draft resolution among other three permanent, veto-bearing member of Security Council; proposal gives Iraq 30 days to make full disclosure of its weapons of mass destruction and provides for unfettered inspections, authorizing military attack if Baghdad does not comply; Iraq's Vice Pres Taha Yassin Ramadan says his government has agreed to allow weapons inspectors to return under conditions laid down previously by United Nations and that it will not accept new terms; rejects as 'lies' accusations by Bush administration officials of ties between Pres Saddam Husssein and Al Qaeda; Iraq's Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz warns that United States will sustain heavy losses in attack and pledges that Iraq will fight fierce war; Bush administration quickly responds that resolution is up to Security Council to decide; White House press secretary Ari Fleischer says Iraq does not have say in matter; Pres Bush, in weekly radio address, lobbies for Congressional resolution authorizing use of force; Marc Grossman, American under secretary of state for political affairs, works to persuade Russian officials, including Foreign Min Igor S Ivanov, to accept resolution; Britain dispatches senior diplomats Peter Ricketts to Paris and Moscow and William Ehrman to Beijing for negotiations; photo (M)

headline: For the Price of a Hand-Held, A Lightweight Laptop With Juice
abstract: AlphaSmart introduces notebook-size Palm OS device with full-size keyboard and 7 1/2-inch wide screen; photo (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: The Advertising Council, New York, promoted three employees.

headline: Media and Advertising Notes
abstract: People • Steve Price, chief operating officer at Publicis in Mid America, Dallas, was promoted to chairman and chief executive. He succeeds Barry Krause, who was named chairman and chief executive at Publicis in New York. Both agencies are part of the American operations of the Publicis Groupe. • Linda de Jesús, senior vice president and managing partner at the Bravo Group, New York, was promoted to president, a vacant post. Bravo is part of the Young & Rubicam division of the WPP Group. Miscellany • The Coalition for the Prevention of Alcohol Problems, Washington, is asking the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms to significantly expand its review of the marketing practices used to sell the new flavored malt alcoholic beverages known as malternatives or alcopops. The coalition, a group of more than three dozen advocacy organizations, is urging the bureau to study extensively what effect the brand names of the products have on teenagers as well as adults; most of the products are named after popular liquor brands though they contain no distilled spirits.

headline: A Helper Who Never Forgets To Update Your Address Book
abstract: GoodContacts is Web based service that helps maintain electronic address books; at regular intervals, software sends e-mail to contacts in address book asking them to confirm or correct entries; photo (M)

headline: After a Move, Still More Devilish Details
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column on search for online store that stocks wide variety of low-priced housewares typically needed when one moves to new home; drawing (M)

headline: Canada Central Bank Leaves Key Interest Rate Unchanged
abstract: Bank of Canada, citing uncertain prospects for American economy and turbulent financial markets, says it will leave its key overnight interest rate unchanged at 2.75 percent after three consecutive increases since April (M)

headline: Spain Arrests 3 Suspects; Tapes of U.S. Sites Seized
abstract: Police in Spain arrest three men suspected of being operatives of Al Qaeda, and officials say one of them had five-year-old videotapes with hours of surveillance images of World Trade Center and other United States sites that may have been considered as targets; among sites are Disneyland, Universal Studios, Statue of Liberty, Brooklyn Bridge and Golden Gate Brige; two of men are identified as Muhammad Khair al-Saqq and Ghasoub al-Abrash Ghalyoun (aka Abu Musab); their known links with Al Qaeda operations and contents of tapes described (M)

headline: KPMG Consulting Names an Agency
abstract: KPMG Consulting names Arnold Worldwide as its first advertising agency (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: MALAYSIA: Tax Cut Only For Small Business; HONG KONG: No Plans To Drop Dollar Peg;.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Markets Continue to Rise As Second Deadline Passes  As a second deadline came and went for top executives to swear that their companies' numbers are correct, investors seemed in a mood to buy, but few market watchers would draw a direct link between the events. The Dow Jones industrial average has climbed nearly 250 points since Aug. 14, the deadline for many public companies filing quarterly reports to submit the executives' certifications.    But some investors said the rise in share prices had less to do with the certifications and more to do with fading concerns about a double-dip recession and a growing conviction that stocks had hit bottom. [Page C11.]

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Malawi: President Will Need New Job
abstract: Malawi Parliament rejects constitutional amendment that would have eliminated presidential term limits; proposed change was supported by allies of Pres Bakili Muluzi, who must retire after his second five-year term ends in 2004 (S)

headline: Week's Schedule Of Debt Offerings
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financing this week includes today's regular weekly auction of new three-  and six-month bills and a four-week bill being auctioned tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 1.65 percent; the six-month issue, 1.63 percent; and the four-week bill, 1.67 percent.

headline: Poll Shows Europeans Conditionally Back U.S. on Iraq
abstract: Poll by German Marshall Fund finds 6 out of 10 Europeans would favor US-led invasion of Iraq if US first gets support of allies and UN; finds Europeans, if not their governments, have views strikingly similar to those of Americans (M)

headline: U.S. and Iraq Differ Over Results Of Attack on Antiaircraft Site
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld vehemently denies Iraq's assertions that civilians had been injured in most recent bombing of Iraqi antiaircraft site; one official produces classified photograph to show that target was distant from any houses, stores or major roads; surveillance photograph also shows that two precision-guided weapons aimed at radar struck some distance from their intended target; official points to two scars in empty desert where ordnance apparently smacked into sand (M)

headline: Markets in Brazil Plunge On Worries Over Election
abstract: Brazil's real falls by more than 4.5 percent and stock and bond markets also fall sharply, as investors conclude from opinion poll in newspaper Folha de Sao Paulo that left-wing presidential candidate Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva may be on his way to outright victory in first round of voting Oct 6, outcome many businesspeople in Brazil dread; poll shows Silva with support of 44 percent of respondents, widening his lead over center-right government's candidate, former Health Min Jose Serra, to 25 points from 19 points of 10 days ago; main stock index Bovespa falls 3.4 percent, Brazilian real loses 4.9 percent of its value against dollar, and traders are bidding just 51.5 cents on dollar for benchmark government 'C' bond, down from 54.44 cents on dollar; graph; photo (M)

headline: At Development Talks, U.S. and Its Allies Clash Over Issues of Energy and Pollution
abstract: United States and European Union officials, attending United Nations talks in South Africa, are clashing over strategies to preserve planet; allies are battling over question of targets and time frames for conversion from oil and gas to windmills and solar panels, for cleanup of garbage and hazardous pollutants and for preservation of endangered plants and animals; dispute has aggravated tensions that have been simmering since Pres Bush refused to ratify international treaty aimed at preventing global warming; rift is most visible in debate over renewable energy; United States rejects plan favored by European Union to commit to ensuring that renewable energy sources account for 15 percent of world's total energy production by 2010; Canada and Saudi Arabia, significant producers of fossil fuels, also object; photo (M)

headline: Moscow Journal; The Kick in the Fruit Punch Could Be Atomic
abstract: Moscow has corps of atomic food inspectors to check fruit in markets for radioactive contamination; city is 415 miles from Ukraine's Chernobyl nuclear-power station, where reactor blew apart in 1986, emitting isotopes into air; only danger to consumers is from so-called forest produce, hand-picked in wild by people looking to supplement their incomes by selling at roadside stands and on street corners; photos (M)

headline: GOODYEAR TO LAY OFF 450 WORKERS IN TENNESSEE
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co will lay off 450 workers, or 12 percent of work force, at Tennessee factory after its sales declined in August (S)

headline: Regulator Voices Suspicion On First Boston Analysts
abstract: William F Galvin, secretary of commonwealth of Massachusetts investigating practices of research analysts at Credit Suisse First Boston, tells New York State Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer that his staff has found conduct at firm that might have violated criminal statues; Galvin turned up e-mail messages that show analyst privately denigrated company but publicly recommended its shares to investors; another e-mail message maintained analysts' projections of revenue and earnings for company even after one acknowledged that company would not meet forecast; it is violation of securities laws for analysts to believe one thing and tell investors another (M)

headline: To Rein In Abuses, Executives Get Watchdogs
abstract: Some troubled companies are starting to give chief executives their own personal watchdogs, in form of independent lead directors; Dynegy, Computer Associates International, Elan Corp and several other companies have named lead directors, as they try to restore confidence of investors angry about questionable accounting and executive pay packages; E*Trade Group says it will use lead director to review board practices as part of proposed settlement of shareholder lawsuit; Waste Management revamped its board in 1999, after accounting scandal, and gave shareholder activist Ralph V Whitworth of Relational Investors duties of lead director; chief executive A Maurice Myers comments; photo (M)

headline: Baker Hughes in Buyback
abstract: Baker Hughes Inc will repurchase as much as $275 million of its common stock, its first buyback since early 1970's (S)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Corn prices fall for second day as cooler weather in Midwest eases concerns about crop losses; in Chicago, corn for delivery in December falls 4.25 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $2.4175 per bushel; graph; chart (S)

headline: Americans Are Taking Care Not to Offend Afghan Hosts
abstract: American military presence in Afghanistan sits uneasily with many Afghans, and Pentagon is acting to forestall any erosion of support and is being particularly careful to avoid civilian casualties; Afghans, proud of their independence, chafe not only at blunders like US military operation in Oruzgan Province that killed about 50 civilians at wedding party, but at other perceived infringements on their sovreignty, like American soldiers who now guard Pres Hamid Karzai; issue of maintaining Afghan good will is expected to become increasingly important as nature of war shifts from active battles and bombings to smaller-scale operations and as new Afghan government attempts to consolidate its own rule; map; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Nuclear Power Scandal Grows
abstract: Scandal involving Japan's nuclear energy industry widens as three of coi

headline: Out of the Merger Rush, Merck's on a Limb
abstract: Merck & Co chief executive Raymond V Gilmartin steers clear of mergers and acquisitions rampant in pharmaceuticals industry, preferring to seek breakthrough drugs and continue to market approved medicines in Merck's stable; fears of patent expirations and industry consolidation lead investors to severely punish Merck's share price; photos; graph compares stock price and research spending of Merck and rival (M)

headline: Job Track or 'Mommy Track'? Some Do Both, in Phases
abstract: Interviews and surveys show women from 25 to 45 years of age are now more likely than they were in past to describe staying at home with their children as phase in life that gives equal importance to paid employment; that is particularly true of college-educated mothers, whose numbers in paid employment keep rising, even as many of them spend more time at home before their children are ready for schooling; studies also show that time spent at work is climbing fastest among women with high-earning husbands; graph; photos (M)

headline: Takeover of Bcom3 Is Cleared by Holders
abstract: As expected, shareholders of the Bcom3 Group in Chicago voted overwhelmingly on Friday to approve a $3 billion deal by which Bcom3 will be acquired.

headline: Court Papers Detail Welch's G.E. Perks
abstract: Papers filed in the divorce of John F. Welch Jr., the former chief executive of General Electric, by his wife contend that G.E. covered enormous living costs for them while he led the company and would continue to do so for him for the rest of his life. The company never disclosed the extent of these benefits.

headline: Article 2002090494028582624 -- No Title
World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Share Limit Raised
abstract: KT Corp, which provides most of South Korea's telephone service, plans to raise limit on foreign ownership to 49 percent of company from 37.2 percent, citing demand overseas for its American depository receipts (S)

headline: Toys to Keep Young Travelers Entertained
abstract: Michelle Slatalla Online Shopper column finds Web sites specializing in travel toys for children; drawing (M)

headline: In Kabul, Rumsfeld Aide Regrets Toll in Raid
abstract: Deputy Defense Sec Paul D Wolfowitz strikes apologetic note after meeting in Kabul, Afghanistan, with Pres Hamid Karzai about security issues that have caused serious problems for new government in past few weeks; relations between US military and its Afghan allies have been strained since July 1 following air strike in southern Afghanistan that reportedly killed 50 civilians and wounded more than 120; Wolfowitz expresses deep regret for civilian deaths in raid on Oruzgan Province; photo (S)

headline: dRush Agency To Be Dissolved
abstract: dRush, advertising agency formed in 1999 by Deutsch and rap impresario Russell Simmons to specialize in campaigns aimed at younger and urban consumers, is closing, effective in 90 days (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Allied Domecq Spirits and Wines USA, Westport, Conn., signed a sponsorship agreement for its Beefeater gin brand with People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals.

headline: Broderbund Is Acquired
abstract: The Riverdeep Group , the Irish educational software maker, bought Broderbund , a software producer, for $57.2 million to expand its school and consumer business.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Liberate Technologies Shares Fall
abstract: Shares in Liberate Technologies, interactive television software maker, fall 7.58 percent after company says its results will be poorer than expected because of internal financial restructuring and lower spending among its cable and telecommunications customers; chief executive Mitchell Kertzman comments; graph (S)

headline: Lawsuit Says Salomon Gave Special Deals to Rich Clients
abstract: During the market boom, a handful of top executives at telecommunications companies received big allotments of hot new stocks from Salomon Smith Barney, according to a former broker who has filed a lawsuit accusing the firm of unfair business practices. Jack B. Grubman, the firm's star analyst covering these businesses, played a central role in deciding which executives got how many shares, the broker said in an interview this week.    All the executives ran companies that were investment banking clients of Salomon. The executives named in the lawsuit include Bernard J. Ebbers, former chief executive of Worldcom; Joseph P. Nacchio, former chief executive of Qwest Communications International; James Q. Crowe, chief executive of Level 3 Communications; Clark E. McLeod, former chief executive of McLeodUSA, and Stephen A. Garofalo, chairman of Metromedia Fiber Network.

headline: U.S. Indicts 5 Filipino Men In Kidnapping of Americans
abstract: Justice Department announces indictment of five leaders of Abu Sayyaf, Islamic group that kidnapped three Americans in Philippines; posts $5-million reward for capture of Aldam Tilao, who may be dead, spiritual leader Khadafi Abubakar Janjalani and others; missionary Martin Burnham was killed in shootout that freed his wife; Guillermo Sobero was beheaded last year (M)

headline: White House Moves to Limit Corporate Scandals' Fallout
abstract: White House officials move on several fronts in response to criticism from Republicans in Congress and nationwide that Pres Bush has not acted aggressively enough against corporate corruption; Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill is told to cancel latest trip out of country and focus on domestic economy; Bush is expected to stress economic security as frequently as national security in his planned visits to 12 American cities in Aug; White House strategy aimed at containing fallout from accounting scandals and volatile stock market they helped produce; there is deepening anxiety within White House and Republican Party that candidates seeking election in Nov could be in peril in wake of accusations that party is too close to big business; apparent strain with White House stems from suspicion among House Republicans that Bush is more concerned with his re-election in '04 than theirs in '02 (M)

headline: Technology Briefing
abstract: TELECOMMUNICATIONS ANTITRUST PENALTY UPHELD The United States Court of Appeals for the 10th Circuit has upheld a 2000 ruling that Southwestern Bell, a subsidiary of SBC Communications, had violated antitrust laws in the pay telephone market in Oklahoma. The court, based in Denver, found the phone giant liable for more than $25 million on Tuesday. Charlie Sullivan, who with 10 partners formed Coin Link, an independent pay phone operator that sued Southwestern, said:

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Concern To Treat Options As Expenses
abstract: Computer Associates says it will begin treating stock options as expenses starting in April, cutting annual earnings by 2 cents a share (S)

headline: A Lonely Battle in Mongolia to Save Buddhist Relics
abstract: Sainshand, Mongolia, is site of small museum holding Buddhist relics that had been buried by museum curator's father in 1930's during religious persecution waged by new Communist government; curator, Altangerel, knows where his father buried many other boxes of artifacts, but fears for their safety if he reveals where they are; he dug up some relics after Mongolia opened up to democracy in 1990 and restrictions on religion were eased; photo; map (M)

headline: Qwest Discloses U.S. Attorney Is Investigating the Company
abstract: Qwest Communications International, the nation's fourth-largest local telephone company, said today that it was the subject of a criminal investigation by the Justice Department.

headline: U.S. Excludes More Steel Imports From Protective Tariffs
abstract: The Bush administration today exempted an additional 178 kinds of steel from steep "safeguard" tariffs.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Toshiba Raises Outlook
abstract: Toshiba Corp, leading maker of computer chips, raises its profit forecast for its parent company to 69 billion yen ($566 million) in full year ended March 2003; leaves sales forecasts unchanged (S)

headline: A Crisis of Family Values and a Family's Value
abstract: Ellyn Spragins Love & Money column explores plight of ImClone Systems head Dr Samuel D Waksal upon learning that Food and Drug Administration would not approve his company's cancer drug; considers ramifications on family if he had not told his father and daughter to sell their ImClone shares and had, instead, let their paper fortunes shrivel; drawing (M)

headline: The 3-D Intruder
abstract: William A Shurcliff letter on July 18 article about advances in three-dimensional movies contends technology has little merit for television viewers

headline: Jiang to keep big role, Lee Kuan Yew says
abstract: SINGAPORE:—  Jiang Zemin will maintain a decisive role in China even after he gives up the title of president soon, according to Singapore's former prime minister, Lee Kuan Yew.

headline: LILLY SUES TEVA OVER GENERIC PSYCHIATRIC DRUG
abstract: Eli Lilly & Co sues to block Teva Pharmaceuticals Inc from selling generic version of its schizophrenia drug Zyprexa until after patent expires in 2011 (S)

headline: U.S. scandals shake confidence in America's equity culture : Europe's small investors rattled
abstract: As the scandals on Wall Street rattle world markets, few places are likely to feel the aftershock as sharply as Europe, where a loss of investor confidence threatens to undermine the tenuous development of an American-style "equity culture" and slow a market-driven restructuring of the corporate sector.

headline: TANKS AND TRENCH BOTTLE UP ARAFAT IN HIS COMPOUND
abstract: Israeli army tightens choke hold on Yasir Arafat, demolishing all but one building in his compound as he and othe Palestinians call for support from outside world; photos; US and European Union urge Israeli restraint; Israeli government orders further isolatio of Arafat hours after suicide bomb explodes in Tel Aviv bus, killing six people (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: SWEDEN: More Time Needed In Hijack Case; FRANCE: Basque Rebel Arrested; CZECH REPUBLIC: Havel Tries To Play Peacemaker; ITALY: Immigrants' Death Prompts Inquiry;.

headline: Just Saying No to Gifts From Drug Makers
abstract: Jeffrey L Seglin The Right Thing column discusses Pharmaceutical Research and Manufacturers of America new voluntary code of ethics that bars gifts to doctors from drug manufacturers that are not for primary benefit of patients; holds doctors should have refused gifts in past; drawing (M)

headline: Stewart Broker Handled Shares For Her Friends
abstract: Martha Stewart turned to Merrill Lynch stockbroker Peter E Bacanovic to handle more than $10 million worth of shares offered to friends and associates when her company when public in 1999; Stewart abruptly cancels her regular appearance for July 3 on CBS program Early Show after network says it would require her to answer more questions on air about government investigations into her sale last December of shares of ImClone System; Stewart's decision to cancel her appearance demonstrates pressure she faces as three investigations unfold while she continues to deal with demands of running $296 million media empire; Morgan Stanley, not Merrill Lynch, was lead underwriter on Martha Stewart public offering (M)

headline: Investment Losses and Floods Hit Reinsurers Hard
abstract: Reinsurers Allianz, Munich Re and Swiss Re say profits have been all but wiped out by poor performance of their investment portfolios and recent flooding in Central Europe will also lower their bottom line; Allianz estimates loss of more than $1 billion from European floods; Munich Re says it lost $375 million in quarter ended June 30; Swiss Re says investment losses eroded away 90 percent of its profit in first half; reports net income of 917 Swiss francs ($604.6 million) (M)

headline: F.D.A. Staff Voices Doubts on AstraZeneca Cancer Drug
abstract: Food and Drug Administration staff finds 'several bothersome issues' with data submitted by AstraZeneca that appear to jeopardize company's chances of approval of its cancer drug Iressa, which is intended for lung cancer patients with no treatment options left; review is released ahead of meeting of advisory committee of specialists, which will make recommendations to agency about whether drug should be approved (M)

headline: Israel Demurs on Deporting Bomb Suspects' Relatives
abstract: Israel backs away from plan to deport relatives of West Bank Palestinians accused of suicide bombings to crowded, fenced-in Gaza Strip; Atty Gen Elyakim Rubinstein tells Israeli Supreme Court there are no immediate plans to deport 21 male relatives of two militants charged with masterminding two recent attacks; Prime Min Ariel Sharon concurs; opposition to plan from US, UN, European Union, Arab states and Israeli human rights groups noted; photo; map (M)

headline: U.S. Trade Bill Could Hurt Philippine Tuna Industry, Officials Will Tell Powell in Manila
abstract: Philippine officials are concerned that broad trade bill emerging from United States Congress could hurt their country's huge tuna industry; even last-minute compromise on tuna tariffs does little to appease them, and Pres Gloria Macapagal Arroyo is being asked to raise matter with Secretary of State Colin Powell, even though Congress, not administration, controls tariff policy (M)

headline: Planned Bill Would Spur U.S. Sale of Diesel Cars
abstract: Repr John D Dingell plans to introduce bill that would encourage sale of diesel cars in US, prospect strongly supported by auto industry but opposed by environmental groups; industry executives have said in recent years that modern diesel engines are far less dirty and noisy than those of 1970's and offer relatively easy way to improve fuel economy and reduce global-warming emissions; chart (M)

headline: I.R.S. Sues for Disclosure of Offshore Accounts
abstract: Internal Revenue Service goes into court in seven cities to force more than 40 companies to surrender information on customers agency suspects are hiding income in offshore accounts; summonses are first attempt by IRS to review documents from companies whose goods or services are purchased with credit cards linked to offshore accounts; action comes after agency forced Visa International, MasterCard and American Express to turn over information on cardholders in Antigua and Barbuda, Bahamas and Cayman Islands (M)

headline: Gingerly, Arabs Question Suicide Bombings
abstract: Muffled, coded debate is under way among educated Palestinians over suicide bombings, focusing on effectiveness rather than morality; Hanan Ashrawi, one of 55 signers of unusual published petition, explains need to appeal to people's self-interest; appeal stops short of blanket condemnation but says attacks do not produce any results other than confirming 'hatred, malice and loathing' between Israelis and Palestinians, and endangering chance of statehood; appeal in newspaper has garnered more than 500 more signatures on Internet; Hamas leader Abdel Aziz al-Rantisi bitterly denounces appeal (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Rises
abstract: Surplus in Japan's current account doubled in May thanks to strong growth in exports; surplus grew 108 percent from comparable month year ago, hitting 1.04 trillion yen ($9 billion); exports grew 8.7 percent while imports fell 4.6 percent (S)0

headline: SUNGARD TO BUY BRUT TRADING SYSTEM FOR $100 MILLION
abstract: SunGard Data Systems Inc agrees to buy electronic trading system Brut for $100 million to extend its reach into Nasdaq stock market trading; is acquiring 78.5 percent of Brut it does not already own from 25 broker-dealers (S)

headline: Designing the Pay Plan To Meet Long-Term Goals
abstract: Stan Kurzban letter on Setpember 8 article on executive compensation holds stock prices should more accurately reflect companies' long-term goals

headline: Paying for Tech Support
abstract: Benjamin Johnson letter on August 22 article offers mixed review of computer software tech support

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Speechworks To Cut Jobs
abstract: SpeechWorks International Inc will eliminate 17 percent of its work force and trim expenses by 20 percent as it struggles to maintain sales (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ASHWORTH INC., Carlsbad, Calif., a designer of golf-inspired sportswear, said its board had authorized the buyback of up to $6.5 million of common stock in the next 12 months.    CMS ENERGY CORP., Dearborn, Mich., a provider of electricity and natural gas, said its independent power unit sold its 66 percent ownership in a power plant in Thailand to its partner, Thailand's Advanced Power Supply Public Co., for $47 million.

headline: Canadian Teenager Held by U.S. in Afghanistan in Killing of American Medic
abstract: Canadian officials say Canadian Omar Khadr, 15, accused of killing American medic while fighting with Al Qaeda in Afghanistan, is being held there by United States; Bush administration has refused to let Canadian consular officials interview him; accounts of Khadr family's activities in radical Muslim politics have embarrased Canada as it works to tighten security in its immigration policy; boy's father, Ahmed Said Khadr, Egyptian-born Canadian citizen believed to be close associate of Osama bin Laden, is though to be hiding in Pakistan or Afghanistan; Canadian intelligence officials say they have long been monitoring family and want to question boy about terrorist activities in Canada (M)

headline: My Train Pass? Oh, Sorry, My Favorite Show Is Just Starting
abstract: New add-on program for SnapStream Personal Video Station can compress recorded television shows and video clips and transfer them to Pocket PC hand-held computers for viewing on the road; photo (M)

headline: In Palestinian Children, Signs of Increasing Malnutrition
abstract: Study under way for United States Agency for International Development is said to be finding that malnutrition among Palestinian children in West Bank and the Gaza Strip has increased substantially during conflict with Israel; preliminary results of study cause alarm within Israeli government and Bush administration, which has been pressuring Israel to alleviate Palestinian suffering; senior Israeli official says study's results could be 'disastrous for Israel'; Israeli government, already anticipating international criticism over conditions among Palestinians, has recently stepped up talks with Palestinian representatives to address needs of those in West Bank; aid workers say few Palestinians can leave their homes to work, and costs and difficulties of transporting goods have become prohibitive; diplomats say Israeli government, concerned about international criticism, has made it easier for international aid groups to distribute food; photo (M)

headline: Colombia President Declares Limited State of Emergency
abstract: Pres Alvaro Uribe moves to fulfill campaign promise for aggressive action against leftist guerrillas; declares limited state of emergency that broadens government's powers and allowing for quick expansion of armed forces; decree comes five days after rebels of Revolutionary Armed Forces lobbed mortars into center of Bogota during Uribe's inauguration, killing at least 19 civilians; photo (M)

headline: New Economy; An effort to untangle the government's haphazard approach to the acquisition of computer systems.
abstract: Bill sponsored by Sen Joseph I Lieberman and recently approved by Senate would expand definition of e-government to include how well federal agencies use technology to improve efficiency of government; would provide funds to help federal agencies work together on projects to improve their online services and establish Office of Electronic Government within Office of Management and Budget; proposed office would help federal agencies, which now spend over $1 billion on e-government efforts, spend money more efficiently; bill would require agencies to centrally coordinate development of standards for coding data so that it can be transmitted on Internet and read by different computer systems, move that in theory would enable agencies with different computer systems to read each others data; drawing (M)

headline: Beijing Journal; Here She Comes! (Will China Ever Be the Same?)
abstract: Beijing Journal column on struggle of 20-year old Zhuo Ling, who holds Miss China title, to win approval in country where beauty pageants are officially regarded as subversive; she placed third in Miss Universe contest, which she entered 'unofficially;' photos (M)

headline: Article 2002091094268072683 -- No Title
O'Neill, Upbeat in Uruguay, Faces Tough Talk in Argentina
abstract: Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill, after making efforts to prop up ailing economies of Brazil and Uruguay, arrives in Argentina, third, final and most contentious stop on his four-day tour of financially troubled region that blames Bush administration for making many of its problems worse; he declares US is 'eager to see all of Latin America succeed' (M)

headline: An Investor Helps Rebuild Research Unit At Keefe
abstract: Article on scene at Keefe, Bruyette & Woods one year after Sept 11 terrorist attacks on World Trade Center claimed lives of 67 employees at firm; Michael Corasaniti, who became firm's research director shortly after tragedy, comments on last year (M)

headline: Schumacher close to tying once-invincible record : The Red Baron of auto racing
abstract: MAGNY-COURS, France:—  When Michael Schumacher climbs out of the cockpit of his Ferrari after parking it on the starting grid before the French Grand Prix on Sunday, he will look, as usual, in that tense, anticipatory moment before the race, like the Red Baron preparing for another kill.

headline: U.S. BANCORP BUYS TRUST DIVISION FROM STATE STREET
abstract: US Bancorp acquires State Street Corp's corporate trust business for $725 million; division acts as trustee for corporate and municipal bondholders (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: China: Bank Discounts Shares
abstract: Bank of China, which is se

headline: Private Sector; An Economic Reality Check From Someone Who's Seen It All
abstract: Economist Milton Friedman, 90, sees today's economic morass as mild and trivial; only fears that overzealous governmental regulation could frighten honest chief executives into ducking risks necessary to maintain robust economy; photo (M)

headline: BUSH OFFICIALS SAY THE TIME HAS COME FOR ACTION ON IRAQ
abstract: Top national security officials in Bush administration say in near unison that Pres Saddam Hussein's efforts to build arsenal of immensely destructive weapons leaves US little choice but to act against Iraq; comments on Sunday television news programs by Vice Pres Dick Cheney, Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld, national security adviser Condoleezza Rice, Sec of State Colin L Powell and Joint Chiefs of Staff chairman Gen Richard B Myers noted; photo (M)

headline: Judge Stays Ban on Antidepressant Ads
abstract: Judge Mariana R Pfaelzer stays for at least three weeks her ban on GlaxoSmithKline advertising its antidepressant drug Paxil (M)

headline: Beijing Journal; Restoring an Ancient City's Glory Brick by Brick
abstract: Chinese government is rebuilding three-quarter-mile stretch of mighty wall, built mainly in latter half of Ming Dynasty from 1368 to 1643, that once formed protective ring around imperial capital and gave city its erstwhile romance but was demolished in 1950's and 1960's; is seeking to rebuild it with original bricks and has appealed to public to return any they may have taken when wall was torn down; quixotic, one-man crusade of 55-year-old factory worker Feng Baohua to locate and return bricks as public effort has languished; discussed; photos (M)

headline: OFFICE DEPOT SAYS IT EXPECTS A DECLINE IN SALES
abstract: Office Depot says North American sales will decline this quarter, as shoppers have been spending less on school supplies than expected; back-to-school sales at stores open at least year are 'slightly negative'; chief executive Bruce Nelson comments (S)

headline: Stocks Slump as Fed Warns of Risks
abstract: Stocks fell sharply today, with the three leading market gauges losing more than than 2 percent, after an announcement that interest rates would remain unchanged.

headline: WEBMETHODS NARROWS ITS LOSSES FROM LAST YEAR
abstract: Computer software maker WebMethods Inc will report narrower fiscal first-quarter loss of about $2.5 million to $3.5 million, helped by accounting change (S)

headline: HANOVER COMPRESSOR DISMISSES 2 EXECUTIVES
abstract: Hanover Compressor Co, pipeline equipment maker faced with federal accounting inquiry and falling stock price, ousts chief executive Michael J McGhan and chief operating officer Charles D Erwin; chairman Victor E Grijalva is appointed interim chief executive (S)

headline: Report Is Skeptical of Drug
abstract: Report by researchers from Massachusetts General Hospital, National Institutes of Health and University of Texas Southwestern Medical Center in New England Journal of Medicine says Xigris, $7,000-a-dose sepsis treatment from Eli Lilly should not be widely used until another study confirms its benefits; journal also carries response from Food and Drug Administration, which defends product's approval (S)

headline: Vivendi to Sell Fired Chief's Penthouse
abstract: Vivendi Universal SA says it will sell Manhattan penthouse it bought for $17.5 million last year to house Jean-Marie Messier, its chief executive at time; Messier currently occupies duplex and will keep paying rent for rest of year (S)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Aug 25 chart showing profits made by companies' insiders on sale of telecommunications stocks erroneously included names of two executives

headline: Investing; Is Home Depot a Fixer-Upper?
abstract: Share price of Home Depot loses 4.3 percent over last year, while its rival home-improvement chain Lowe's Companies stock shows 50.8 percent rise in same period; analysts see Lowe's growing rapidly while Home Depot begins cannibalizing its own sales with new store openings; graph (M)

headline: CHIEF OF PHILIP MORRIS ADDS TITLE OF CHAIRMAN
abstract: Philip Morris Companies says chief executive Louis C Camilleri has been elected chairman of board, replacing retiring Geoffrey C Bible; is also elected chairman of Kraft Foods, subsidiary of Philip Morris; vice chairman-chief operating officer William H Webb will also retire from both boards; company's board votes to raise quarterly dividend to 64 cents per share from 58 cents (S)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In Singapore; Learning to Have Fun While Getting Things Done
abstract: Travel article on Singapore; country's highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: GOODRICH PLANS LESS EQUITY FINANCING FOR TRW DEAL
abstract: Goodrich Corp, maker of aircraft landing gear, plans to sell assets to reduce amount of equity financing it will need for its $1.5 billion purchase of TRW Inc (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: Move To Ease Flow Of Information
abstract: China's State Council directs legal scholars to draft law defining what types of government information can be released to public, to distinguish between public data and official secrets (S)

headline: Trying to Turn Old Shopping Mall Inside Out
abstract: Mark G Falcone, leader of group of investors called Continuum Partners, demolishes Villa Italia shopping mall in Lakewood, Colo, and plans to build urban-style downtown called Belmar, which will include 153,850 square feet of rentable office space, 639,000 square feet of retail space and 105 housing units; first phase of project is expected to open in 2004; map; photo (M)

headline: A Mexican Reformer Who Looked Too Close to Home
abstract: Mexico marks anniversary of murder of Maria de los Angeles Tames, member of Pres Vicente Fox's PAN party, who was elected to City Council in Atizapan de Zaragoza, suburb of Mexico City, at same time Fox ousted ruling PRI; handful of PAN officials, including Mayor Antonio Dominguez Zambrano, are in jail, accused of corruption and of ordering murder, reportedly because Tames was close to uncovering their crimes; murder laid bare reality that violent corruption was not exclusive to PRI; outrage forced Fox to confront official misdeeds in own ranks; PRI, which Tames worked to defeat, has led probe; photo (M)

headline: Momentum Is Fleeting. So How to Capture It in Funds?
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column on efforts to use mutual funds to capitalize on fleeting patterns of stock market momentum; graph of year-over-year mutual fund performance (M)

headline: GAINS AND LOSSES IN ISRAELI PROJECT
abstract: Sprawling Israeli housing complex in East Jerusalem, which drew world criticism and Palestinian protests when proposed five years ago, nears completion; laborers from abroad, with little grasp of conflict, earn money to send home, working alongside few Palestinians, conscience-stricken but desperate for wages; project, Har Homa, is monument to shifting political geography; Israeli government sees it as Jerusalem neighborhood, not settlement, and as strategically placed buffer against Palestinians; Israelis moving in see it as affordable home with stunning view; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Phone Company Loss
abstract: PCCW Ltd, Hong Kong's main phone company, reports loss of $92 million in first half of year compared with profit of $120 million year earlier; sales fell 9.8 percent, to $1.31 billion (S)

headline: REGIONAL MARKET: Midtown South; More Leases, but Not a Surge of Activity
abstract: Raymond Crane leases space for his engineering and consulting company, Meinhardt USA, in building a 6 East 32nd Street, unassuming 1915 structure in Midtown South office market area; photo (M)

headline: WorldCom Officer Sold Almost All His Shares
abstract: WorldCom's former chief financial officer Scott D Sullivan sold almost 1.4 million shares of WorldCom stock from 1997 to 2000, making about $30 million; Sullivan held fewer than 5,000 shares by May; other WorldCom executives each retained ownership of more than one million shares earlier this year, including chairman Bert C Roberts Jr, chief executive John W Sidgmore and former chief executive Bernard J Ebbers; WorldCom's stock has fallen to 10 cents, from about $38, since Sullivan made his most recent sale in August 2000 (M)

headline: Harsh Spotlight Shines on Mexico's Army
abstract: Newly declassified archives turn harsh spotlight on Mexican Army's misdeeds, notably role in disappearances of hundreds of leftists during 'dirty war' waged by government in 1970's, but change is slow and human rights abuses and secrecy continue; Mexico's transition to democracy under Pres Vicente Fox means military's power may not continue unquestioned forever; there are signs that army is working from within to change its image (M)

headline: Business; Who's That Upstart In the Ice Cream Case?
abstract: Coolbrands International, Canadian frozen-dessert maker, is third largest company in industry led by Unilever and Nestle; contracts with other companies to produce and distribute branded products; is buying Chipwich Inc from Richard LaMotta, who pioneered sales of ice cream sandwiched between cookies; photo; graph of Coolbrands' share price (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Terayon Shares Gain
abstract: Shares of Terayon Communications Systems, large maker of cable modems, increase 40 percent after it says Cox Communications will use its modems (S)

headline: Rift Seen at U.N. Over Next Steps to Deal With Iraq
abstract: The U.S. insisted on keeping pressure on Iraq, while other nations said inspectors were enough to hold off stronger action.

headline: E-Commerce Report; More companies are working to attract gay and lesbian customers.
abstract: Increasing number of online retailers are paying close attention to gay and lesbians customers, who tend to be more affluent, have more disposable income and shop online in greater numbers than straight counterparts; some retailers offer gay sections on their Web sites and run versions of their Web sites on gay portals; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Fall Amid Renewed Fears About the Economy
abstract: Stocks tumbled today as new economic data showed that the manufacturing sector was weaker than forecast in July and several companies reported disappointing earnings.

headline: Western Hemisphere's States Support Unblocking of Aid to Haiti
abstract: Organization of American States, in policy shift for United States, resolves by consensus to back Haiti's proposal that millions of dollars in foreign aid be unblocked and that legislative elections be held next year, despite opposition refusal to negotiate political settlement; resolution is victory for Pres Jean-Bertrand Aristide; diplomats say social decline, increased violence and instability and opposition's refusal to negotiate with government increased pressure on US to pursue new strategy; resolution provides greater role for OAS special mission to Haiti, including increased US financing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Income Falls At Bank
abstract: Kookmin Bank, Korea's largest commercial bank, reports 36 percent drop in net income in second quarter; graph (S)

headline: GOLDEN STATE SHAREHOLDERS APPROVE BID BY CITIGROUP
abstract: Golden State Bancorp says shareholders approved Citigroup's planned $4.7 billion takeover of company; two banks expect to complete transaction by Sept 30, pending approval from federal bank regulators (S)

headline: Wanderlust Seems Strong
abstract: Survey by Travelocity.com Web site finds that Americans' avoidance of travel and fears for personal safety have dissipated since time following 2001 terrorist attacks (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Gemstar Shares Drop After Warning
abstract: Shares of Gemstar-TV Guide International Inc fall as much as 11 percent after maker of software to run on-screen television program guides says Nasdaq Stock Market might delist its shares; shares fall 57 cents, or 12.8 percent, to $3.91 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Hewlett To Make Low-Cost Computer
abstract: Hewlett-Packard Co will begin selling $549 business computer that includes low-cost Athlon processor from Advanced Micro Devices; computer also features graphics chips from Nvidia Inc (S)

headline: COURT APPROVES COMDISCO CHAPTER 11 RECOVERY PLAN
abstract: Comdisco Inc wins approval of federal bankruptcy judge for Chapter 11 recovery plan that will repay bondholders and other creditors almost all of more than $4 billion they are owed (S)

headline: DataBank; Stocks Follow Economy Down, Then Up
abstract: Summary of week's market trading; graphs; tables (M)

headline: Trim Stocks? Sure, but Don't Leave The Game
abstract: Jonathan Fuerbringer, in Market Insight column, interviews Rhodes Analytics chief investment strategist William E Rhodes on investors' current and future allocation of capital; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Cargo Inspections Allowed
abstract: Japan agrees to allow US customs officials to be stationed at its largest ports to help intercept shipments of radioactive material and other weapons that could be used by terrorists (S)

headline: Vladivostok Journal; Out of Russia's Gangland, and Into Cafe Society
abstract: Proprietors of stylish new Studio Coffee in Vladivostok, Russia, are members of small class of wealthy Russians who have amassed great wealth overnight mostly through criminal activities or political connections and is turning from thuggery to tamer, more lawful pursuits; co-owner Denis Berestovoi is son of official in regional government; partner Andrei Chunyak was once deeply involved in notoriously crooked scrap metal business; they comment; maps; photos (M

headline: New Economy; In the tech meccas, masses of people, or 'smart mobs,' are keeping in touch through wireless devices.
abstract: John Schwartz column on author Howard Rheingold's observations about 'smart mobs,' groups of people equipped with high-tech communications devices that let them act in concert; Rheingold argues that convergence of wireless communications technologies and widely distribute networks allows what he calls 'swarming' behavior on vast new scale; warns of benefits and perils of trend; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Machinery Orders Rise; CHINA: Bank Discounts Shares; SOUTH KOREA: Steel Maker Posts Results;.

headline: Teaching Machines to Hear Your Prose and Your Pain
abstract: Researchers are working to build subtle speech cues, known collectively as prosody, into speech recognition software in hope of creating automatic ways to detect slight differences in pitch, timing and amplitude that are easy for people to interpret and difficult for machines; wide range of applications, from espionage to automatic customer service, is expected; prosody is already present in speech synthesis but creating machines that recognize it will be far more challenging because intent of speech is more nuanced than actual words; photo (M)

headline: BUSH ASKS LEADERS IN 3 KEY NATIONS FOR IRAQ SUPPORT
abstract: Pres Bush calls leaders of Russia, China and France to seek their support as he tries to build international coalition against Saddam Hussein, but he appears, in his initial approaches, to have made little headway in convincing them that need for action is urgent; Kremlin spokesman says that Pres Vladimir V Putin has expressed 'serious doubts' about use of force in connection with Iraq; Pres Jacques Chirac of France insists that any military action has to come with approval of United Nations; UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan says after meeting with Chirac that it would be 'unwise' to attack Iraq now; Bush photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Deutsche Telekom Has Record Loss
abstract: Deutsche Telekom reports record quarterly loss of $2.04 billion in second quarter; says it is keeping 'all options open' for disposing of its American cellular phone service VoiceStream; interim chairman Helmut Sihler comments; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Novellus To Acquire SpeedFam-IPEC
abstract: Novellus Systems will buy SpeedFam-IPEC for about $220 million in stock and assumed debt; SpeedFam-IPEC develops systems used in advanced semiconductor devices and other precision surface-processing applications (S)

headline: Showdown Is Set on Bank Guarantees in Japan
abstract: Japan's lawmakers, about to break for summer vacation, have already laid groundwork for their return in September: a battle with Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi over his pledge to remove public guarantee on large savings accounts; confrontation has potential to tie government in knots, delaying overhaul of tax code and national medical plan, as well as 2003 budget; protracted battle over Koizumi's campaign for bank reform could unnerve already jittery investors; photo (M)

headline: Battered for Weeks, Dow Enjoys Its Biggest Daily Gain Since '87
abstract: Stocks break losing streak, pushing Dow Jones industrial average up 488.95 points, or 6.4 percent, closing at 8,191.29, in biggest one-day rally since rebound after 1987 market crash; investors appear comforted by agreement reached by Congress on accounting and corporate governance legislation and in display of confidence by companies pledging to buy back their own stocks; falling European markets rebound when stock prices begin to rise on Wall Street; Dow and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index turn in second-best performances since World War II; S&P gains 5.7 percent to close at 843.39, and Nasdaq composite index rises 5 percent; opinions are mixed about whether rally will continue; photos; chart; graphs (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: New Digital Media Player Software
abstract: RealNetworks begins offering new digital media player software that plays music and video in all formats, including that of Microsoft; software is available for $19.95 or as part of monthly fee for one of RealNetworks' subscription services (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Gunman Fit To Stand Trial
abstract: Psychiatrists say Maxime Brunerie, French neo-Nazi who fired shot at Pres Jacques Chirac, is fit to stand trial (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Bank Being Monitored
abstract: Martin Ebner's BZ Bank, part of his BZ Group Holding, is ordered to report daily to Switzerland's Federal Banking Commission about its finances (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Toy Importer Settles Suit On Violating Safety Rules  A California company, Ameri-China International, and its president have agreed to pay $140,000 to settle a suit by the Consumer Product Safety Commission that accused it of importing 755,000 toys with small pieces that could harm children younger than 3.    The settlement is the third case in four months against importers in the Los Angeles area. In all the cases, the companies specialize in importing inexpensive toys that are sold in independent discount and neighborhood stores or on the street. [Page C3.]    Continental Ends US Airways Talks  Continental Airlines has broken off talks with US Airways about a partnership in which the two carriers would have booked passengers on each other's flights. The decision was a setback for US Airways, which had been seeking such an arrangement, and leaves United as the front-runner for any possible agreement. [C2.]

headline: Judge Orders Drug Company To Alter Ads
abstract: Federal Judge Mariana R Pfzelzer orders GlaxoSmithKline to stop saying in its advertisements for Paxil, top-selling antidepressant, that drug is 'nonhabit-forming'; decision is one of first significant rulings on prescription drug advertising; Food and Drug Administration has asked court to reconsider; agency says it has reviewed Paxil ads and agrees that drug company can make 'nonhabit-forming' claim; agency's lawyers says are concerned that decision, which is based in part on California law, can lead to situation where there could be different requirements for drug advertising in each of 50 states; lawsuit contends that GlaxoSmithKline did not warn patients of problems that could arise if they stopped taking Paxil; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: NCR Discloses Accounting Errors
abstract: Shares of NCR Corp fall as much as 14 percent after company reduces third-quarter and 2002 profit forecasts and says service division in Canada made accounting errors; chief financial officer Earl Shanks says controls have been tightened (S)

headline: Justice Dept. Starts Inquiry At Sunbeam
abstract: Sunbeam Corp proposes bankruptcy reorganization that would wipe out shareholder equity and leave bondholders with almost nothing; reports Justice Department probes management of company during period it was run by Albert J Dunlap and Russell A Kersh, raising possibility that their recent settlement with Securities and Exchange Commission involving accounting practices that let Sunbeam overstate profits in 1997 and early 1998 may not have ended their legal problems (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Scott Franey was named vice president for marketing at Uniworld, Encino, Calif., a river cruise and land tour company. He had been a consultant.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Incentives Helped Increase Vehicle Sales 8.6% in July  Car and truck sales rose a surprising 8.6 percent in July, in large part because of aggressive incentives. The increase translated into an annual selling rate of 18.1 million vehicles, according to Ward's AutoInfoBank. Automakers sold 17.2 million vehicles in 2001.    General Motors reinstated zero-percent financing early last month, and its combined car and truck sales increased 23.9 percent in July. Ford said sales rose 1.5 percent, while Chrysler said sales fell 4 percent. [Page C3.]

headline: Rumsfeld's Search for a Way To Fight a New Type of Foe
abstract: Interview with Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld, first in series, Perspectives, in which national and world leaders reflect on Sept 11 terrorist attacks and their effect on year of public life and policy; Rumsfeld believes deadliest strength of America's new adversaries is their very fluidity, unburdened by fixed borders or conventional forces; photo; he warns that enemy 'goes to school on you,' studying how nation responds to threats and adapting at relatively little cost to plan for what Rumsfeld is certain will be new attack; Rumsfeld focuses on maneuvering steel-and-circuitry military to fight 'virtual enemy,' developing swifter, more lethal responses; is concerned that 'frenzy' over possible action against Iraq distracts from larger issue of fighting terror; says allies and enemies alike must see US as 'leaning forward, not back,' because nation seen as faint at heart invites attack; Rumsfeld, who warns that campaign will be long, costly and bloody, argued even before he returned to Pentagon after quarter-century absence that military must be reconfigured for new enemies (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.50        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.00        Federal funds   1.75   1.72   3.55        3-month T-bills   1.61   1.60   3.30        6-month T-bills   1.63   1.61   3.24        10-yr. T-infl.   2.50   2.46   3.32        10-yr. T-note   4.31   4.20   4.87        30-yr.
