headline: Iranian-American Dancer Is on Trial in Tehran for 'Corruption'
abstract: Iran's hard-line judiciary opens trial of Mohammad Khordadian, popular Iranian-American dance teacher who lives in Los Angeles; he was arrested at airport after visiting family for first time in 22 years and charged with encouraging young people to perform immoral acts, which include dancing; trial coincides with what appears to be crackdown on young people whose behavior is deemed unacceptable by traditionalists (M)

headline: Texas Pacific Goes Where Others Fear to Spend
abstract: Article profiles Texas Pacific Group, investment firm headed by David Bonderman and James Coulter; firm uses $8 billion it has under management to buy businesses out-of-favor industries, such as airlines and technology; photos; graphs; table (M)

headline: United Air's Unions Offer Plan to Save Billion a Year
abstract: United Airlines' five unions, hoping to steer carrier away from bankruptcy protection, present executives with long-awaited proposal, intended to save $1 billion per year in labor costs for five years; unions hope savings will help United receive $1.8 billion loan guarantee from Air Transportation Stabilization Board or get financing from capital markets (M)

headline: Pope to Visit a Mexico Divided Over His Teachings
abstract: Pope John Paul II will visit Mexico for first time in 23 years and will find country divided between teachings of church and beliefs of Mexican Catholics; surveys show Mexicans favor birth control, oppose religious education and are open to abortion; divide has propelled steady growth of Protestant churches, particularly in rural Indian communities, where people increasingly press to allow women to serve as religious leaders and to allow members of clergy to marry; divisions are embodied in committed Catholics, like Pres Vicente Fox and wife, both of whom are divorced and remarried in civil ceremony without having first marriages annulled by church; map (M)

headline: College Savings Plans Are a Growing Draw
abstract: Despite plummeting stock market, more than two million tax-protected college savings accounts have been created by Americans in last two and half years; in addition to tax breaks, parents are drawn by growing array of options and uneasy awareness of ever-higher cost of college; most people chose accounts that automatically move them into less risky investments as children approach college age, so recent market losses have not been disastrous for families in such plans with children heading to college soon; growing number are opting either for aggressive stock investments, in hopes of buying at low prices, or for guaranteed returns, to avoid swooning market entirely; investment choices vary greatly from state to state for so-called 529 plans, but they all shelter gains from federal taxes, and some shelter gains from state and local taxes also; in some states, including New York, even contributions are deductible from taxable income for state tax purposes; programs have special allure at time when colleges are posting sizable, sometimes double-digit, tuition increases; while tax breaks are worth more to people with high incomes, plans are also attracting people of modest means; photo; graphs (L)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Misses Profit Forecast
abstract: Converium Holding, Swiss reinsurer, reports first-half net profit of $31.6 million, compared with loss of $60.5 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Gilat's Losses To Be Larger Than Expected
abstract: Gilat Satellite Systems puts second-quarter loss at $35.7 million, compared with year-earlier loss of $14.7 million; says it must renegotiate some $450 million in debt (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: MTI To Introduce New Fuel-Cell Design
abstract: MTI MicroFuel Cells plans to introduce a simplified design for methane-powered fuel cells (S)

headline: AOL Falls 15% as Analysts Express Concern Over Ads
abstract: Shares of AOL Time Warner fell by 15 percent, to $9.64, as a gloomy outlook for online advertising sales and concerns about accounting prompted a downgrade in its stock.

headline: Irish Scandals Cast a Shadow In European Union Campaign
abstract: String of political scandals, involving corruption in government, threatens to derail Prime Min Bertie Ahern's campaign to persuade Irish voters to approve referendum on European Union expansion; Ahern and his Fianna Fail Party are determined to avoid embarrassment suffered year ago, when voters rejected it; many people say they may vote against Treaty of Nice to voice dissatisfaction with government they consider tainted (M)

headline: Paul Allen May Try to Raise Cable TV Stake
abstract: Charter Communications chairman Paul G Allen reportedly weighs steps to significantly increase his stake in cable television company and perhaps take it private in wake of stock price collapse; moves include buying up company's bonds at deep discount and making new investment in company; he now controls about 55 percent of stock and about 93 percent of voting rights (M)

headline: Mirant Says It Is Subject of Inquiry by S.E.C.
abstract: Mirant Corp says that SEC has started to look into its accounting and energy trading after company says it might have misreported $253 million in assets and liabilities last year; shares of Mirant fall 16 percent (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; September may not be stocks' cruelest month, but investors should not expect kindness, either.
abstract: Analysts see little evidence to suggest that stock market indexes are poised to move markedly higher (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Kosovo: Politician Accused
abstract: Kosovo prosecutors charge Ramush Haradinaj, leading ethnic Albanian politician and former guerrilla leader, with endangering safety of others in 2000 shootout with supporters of rival political faction; United Nations officials who run province are eager to show they will punish former Kosovo Liberation Army guerrillas who commit crimes; supporters of former guerrilla leader Rustem Mustafa protest his arrest on murder and torture charges (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Ex-Foreign Minister Leaves Parliament
abstract: Former Japanese Min Makiko Tanaka resigns her seat in Parliament, apparently over lingering charges that she used office funds to pay employees who were not on her official payroll (S)

headline: Israeli Smallpox Move
abstract: Israeli security cabinet decides to vaccinate 15,000 security, medical and rescue personnel against smallpox because of possibility that Iraq might respond to any American attack with biological strike on Israel (S)

headline: Chips of the Future, Wrought With Good Old Mechanics
abstract: Dr Stephen Y Chou of Princeton University sidesteps conventional photolithography methods of producing computer chips; devises surprisingly uncomplicated process to stamp out minuscule patterns mechanically, directly on surface of chip; Dr Chou's main innovation is to manipulate silicon in its liquid state; photos (M)

headline: France Won't Fight Ruling on Shares
abstract: France decides not to fight European Union court ruling against its practice of retaining 'golden share' in privatized companies that gives government veto over takeovers by foreign companies; court last month struck down 1993 French decree establishing golden share in what is now TotalFinaElf; government will give up share (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: 3Com Loss Narrows On Lower Costs
abstract: 3Com Corp says net loss narrowed to $32 million in its first quarter ended Aug 30 from $232.4 million year earlier; sales dropped to $304.7 million from $389.6 million (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Zambia: Ex-President Closer To Prosecution
abstract: Zambian High Court rejects ex-Pres Frederick Chiluba's bid to overturn parliamentary vote that stripped him of immunity from prosecution; appeals to Supreme Court, winning stay of ruling (S)

headline: Clinton Urges Global Planning to Halt H.I.V.
abstract: Bill Clinton says at international AIDS conference that he regrets not having done more about AIDS while he was president and that he erred in not supporting needle exchange programs to prevent spread of virus among drug users; urges leaders in Africa, Caribbean and Asia, regions hit hard by AIDS, to speak out forcefully and develop new plans to stop spread of HIV (M)

headline: Serbian Election Unlikely to End Rivalry Among Reformers
abstract: Presidential election in Serbia next month is unlikely to resolve bitter power struggle among reformers who toppled Slobodan Milosevic; Zoran Djindjic, prime minister of Serbia, and Vojislav Kostunica, Yugoslav president, formed uneasy alliance to defeat Milosevic at ballot box in 2000; personal rivalry and conflicting visions have driven wedge between them; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: UKRAINE: Government Denies Aiding Iraq; RUSSIA: More Avalanche Victims Found; GREENLAND: U.S. To Return A Town; NORTHERN IRELAND: Violence On The Rise; IRELAND: Christian Group Loses State Tv Bid; ITALY: Pope To Speak To Parliament;.

headline: Chief Executive Of Phone Giant In Germany May Be Ousted
abstract: Ron Sommer is battling to keep his job as Deutsche Telekom chief executive as German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's government, which owns 43 percent of company, maneuvers to oust him; board reportedly will weigh proposal to replace him with Gerd Tenzer, one of his deputies; photos (M)

headline: JOHANNESBURG SUMMIT : Big agenda, little action on world's problems
abstract: JOHANNESBURG:—  In the end, the UN World Summit on Sustainable Development was just too complex. The ambitious project to increase development today and rescue the destitute from their plight without further damaging the Earth's environment for future generations ended with a sprawling document that had something for everyone but few specific promises. Many of those who invested so much in the conference — like President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa or Kofi Annan, the secretary-general of the United Nations — hope that Johannesburg will be a wake-up call, a turning point for a world in crisis.

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Stricter Accounting Rules
abstract: Australian government, responding to company failures and accounting shocks both at home and abroad, sets stringent audit and corporate disclosure rules; overhaul, to be backed by legislative amendments early in 2003, stresses closer scrutiny of accounting practices and more transparent financial reporting framework (S)

headline: Work Starts on North Korea's U.S.-Backed Nuclear Plant
abstract: Work begins on foundation of long-planned nuclear reactor in Kumho, North Korea, largest Western aid project in North Korea and one in which country's future cooperation with outside world will hinge; $4.6 billion reactor was first envisaged in 1994; it has been repeatedly delayed by North Korea's jagged relations with US and other nations; succession of Western diplomats attending ground-breaking ceremony urge North Korea to take convincing steps to comply with pact that undergirds relations with US, so-called Agreed Framework; under pact, Washington commits itself to organize international consortium to build two light-water nuclear reactors and North Korea agrees to abandon and dismantle two existing graphite reactors, as well as third that is under construction; it also requires North Korea to place any plutonium it has produced under international supervision (M)

headline: AMERICAN AIRLINES TO REDUCE ITS NUMBER OF BUILDINGS
abstract: American Airlines will consolidate 5,000 of its staff members into 2 buildings from 11 by 2005, reducing annual costs by $6 million; American's parent, AMR Corp, sells its Centerport 2 site in Fort Worth, where American is based, for $10 million gain (S)

headline: Key Secret Police Official Is Assassinated in Colombia
abstract: The chief of the secret police of a leading Colombian province was shot dead today by gunmen on motorcycles.

type: Money and Business/Financial DeskMoney and Bus
headline: Yodeling All the Way To the Bank
abstract: Rancher and yodeler Wylie Gustafson, after retaining attorney, receives settlement from Yahoo for supplying trademark yodel used in Yahoo advertising; both parties express satisfaction; photo (M)

headline: Road Signs for Vagabond Computer Users
abstract: Technique is being proposed for 'vagabonds' of wireless world: set of easy-to-draw symbols to identify nearby presence of wireless networks for laptop and palmtop users; photo (M)

headline: Shares of Motorola Tumble As Its President Moves to Tyco
abstract: Shares of Motorola plunge after president Edward D Breen is named chief executive of Tyco International; investors express doubt that remaining top Motorola executives, Christopher B Galvin and Mike S Zafirovski, can return company to profitability; photo (M)

headline: ALBERTO SAYS QUARTERLY SALES AND PROFITS ARE UP
abstract: Alberto-Culver Co says quarterly profit and sales rose by at least 10 percent in fiscal third quarter ended June 30 (S)

headline: Investing; Humbled Bears in 1999. Market Sages Today.
abstract: Article profiles five men whose bearish appraisal of stock market ran against tide in 1999 but has won them respect today: Marc Faber, James Grant, Barton Biggs, James Chanos and Leon Levy; portraits (M)

headline: U.N. INSPECTORS CAN RETURN UNCONDITIONALLY, IRAQ SAYS
abstract: Iraq responds to worldwide pressure and says it will allow international weapons inspectors to return 'without conditions'; decision announced by Sec Gen Kofi Annan, who credits Pres Bush's recent speech to General Assembly and pressure from Arab leaders in galvanizing world opinion; cites efforts of Arab League and its secretary general Amr Moussa of Egypt; says Baghdad has agreed to immediate discussions to work out logistics for weapons inspection teams to begin work; Bush administration and Britain voice skepticism; administration officials say US is still determined to seek strong resolution demanding Iraqi compliance with past resolutions and threatening to act if Baghdad fails to do so; believe move is tactical step by Iraq to avoid strong UN Security Council action; Sec of State Colin L Powell presses ahead with American proposals for swift action; meets with officials from Syria, Colombia and Mexico, as well as representatives of Turkey; US clashes with France over how Security Council should proceed; Paris insists on two-stage approach that will postpone any threat of military action for several weeks; is calling for first resolution by Council demanding unfettered inspections, to be followed by later measure backing use of force, depending on Iraq's response; photos (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/O. Thomas Barry III; Bjurman, Barry Micro-Cap Growth Fund
abstract: Carole Gould Investing With article on investment style and results of O Thomas Barry III, manager of Bjurman, Barry Micro-Cap Growth fund; photo; table and graph of fund data (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Somalia: U.N. Worker Kidnapped
abstract: Five armed men kidnap United Natn

headline: Goldman Insiders May Sell Some Shares
abstract: Goldman Sachs Group Inc will permit executives and other shareholders affiliated with firm to sell as many as 28.4 million shares, worth $2.1 billion at recent prices; Goldman Sachs, in filing with Securities and Exchange Commission, discloses latest trading opportunity for restricted shareholders--who include current and former employees who are limited in selling stock received in firm's May 1999 initial public offering (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Fine On France Sought In Beef Dispute
abstract: European Commission fines France almost $160,000 for every day it continues to refuse to lift ban on British beef; European Union lifted own ban in 1999, after concluding mad cow disease had been wiped out in Britain (S)

headline: Investing; Sales of Municipal Bonds Soar, but Risks Loom
abstract: Sales of municipal bonds soar in reaction to disappointing performance of stock market and sharp decline in yields of Treasury securities; record issuance of municipal bonds brings risk of potential defaults to counterbalance tax savings; photo; graph of bond yields (M)

headline: Jumping Ship (or Not); In a Rare Limited Offer, AT&T Waives Its Cancellation Fee
abstract: AT&T Wireless notifies subscribers about two rate increases and gives customers opportunity to drop phone plans without paying customary cancellation fee (M)

headline: President of Iran Says U.S. Creates 'War-Like' Tension
abstract: President Mohammed Khatami of Iran struck out at President Bush today during a visit to Afghanistan.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Dominican Republic: Diplomat Faces Drug Charge
abstract: Dominican police charge diplomat Ornis Freddy Pena, vice consul to Haiti, with drug trafficking (S)

headline: MERRILL LYNCH NAMES LAWYER AS RESEARCH MONITOR
abstract: Merrill Lynch names Mark Goldfus to monitor research, filling post it agreed to in its $100 million settlement with New York State Atty Gen Eliot Spitzer; William Genco will be chairman of firm's new research recommendations committee (S)

headline: Fighting The Label Of 'Turkey'
abstract: Castle Rock Entertainment and Warner Brothers are struggling to save Eddie Murphy's film The Adventures of Pluto Nash, which is being released belatedly in Aug after facing production and marketing problems; Warners plans to back film, Castle Rock's first big-budget movie, with typical advertising budget despite unwelcome buzz that film is potential megabomb; is not taking any unusual steps to counter negativity; photo (M)

headline: Prigorodnoye Journal; Gas May Soon Replace Kelp as Sakhalin's Mainstay
abstract: All that is left of Prigorodnoye is three families and the ruins of a kelp processing plant.    The village is a dot on a green stretch of coast on the island of Sakhalin, off Russia's eastern coast. It began losing population several decades ago, but the process accelerated in the last 15 years as economic collapse engulfed Russia.

headline: Economic Scene; The value of different football strategies on fourth down, analyzed from a mathematical point of view.
abstract: Virginia Postrel Economic Scene column on using mathematical technique of dynamic programming--Bellman equation, named for late Richard Bellman, to analyze value of different football strategies on fourth down; says given its field position, should team punt, kick field goal or go for first down?; working paper by University of California at Berkeley economist David Romer for National Bureau of Economic Research on subject discussed; photo (M)

headline: Sighet Journal; Elie Wiesel Asks a Haunted Hometown to Face Up
abstract: Elie Wiesel opens Jewish museum, Sighet, Romania, in house from which his family was deported to Auschwitz concentration camp; appeals to Romanians to admit their country's role in Holocaust; urges them to ignore politicians who continue to make hero of Marshal Ion Antonescu, who set in motion many of World War II pogroms and was later executed as war criminal by Communists; is accompanied by Pres Ion Iliescu, whose government is struggling to show Romania is starting to face up to its troubled history; map; photo (M)

headline: Rewards of Perseverance
abstract: Consulting Group study of historical data suggests investors who have sustained heavy losses may profit by remaining in equities (M)

headline: Spanish Broadcaster Sues Clear Channel
abstract: Spanish Broadcasting Systems says in lawsuit that Clear Channel Communications thwarted its merger negotiations with rival, Hispanic Broadcasting Corp; accuses companies of conspiring to weaken or eliminate it from Spanish-language radio market (S)

headline: State Dept. Backing Pakistan Leader Despite New Powers
abstract: The State Dept. said today that the U.S. believed that President Pervez Musharraf was committed to democracy in Pakistan

headline: Lack of Basics Threatens World's Poor
abstract: Delegates at United Nations Summit on Sustainable Development emphasize importance of bringing water and sanitation to millions around world who struggle without those essential services; United Nations says more than 2.2 million people in poor countries die each year from illnesses associated with dirty water and poor sanitation (S)

headline: Selling Scrolls, No, Rolls on Our Economic Times
abstract: DIARYSelling Scrolls, No, Rolls On Our Economic Times.

headline: U.S. Divisions Of Bertelsmann Can Hear Ax Sharpening
abstract: Several executives say ouster of Bertelsmann AG chairman Thomas Middelhoff and his replacement by Gunter Thielen will bring new pressure on company's money-losing United States divisions; see cutbacks most likely at direct-to-consumer sales division; photos (M)

headline: Acme Idea Company Gets Duracell Work
abstract: The Gillette Company has shifted the creative advertising duties for its Duracell battery brand in North America to the Acme Idea Company in Norwalk, Conn., a strategic and creative consulting agency.

headline: W.R. GRACE AND SEALED AIR LOSE RULING IN FRAUD SUIT
abstract: W R Grace & Company and Sealed Air Corp lose court ruling that might make it easier for people alleging asbestos injuries to prove that Grace fraudulently sold food-packaging company to Sealed Air in 1998 (S)

headline: A New Arena for the Game Console
abstract: Switch from analog to digital television is proceeding at pace that will not bring it anywhere near completion by 2006, goal set by government when it mandated switch in 1998; only 393 of nation's 1,309 local commercial broadcast stations have started transmitting digital signal; vast majority of 25 million television sets sold annually are still equipped to handle only analog signals; only handful of cable systems now offer broadcasters digital and high-definition feeds; set-top digital decoder boxes needed for viewing digital signal via antenna or satellite dish are hard to find and cost more than most standard television sets; photos; graphs (M)

headline: Beautifying Balance Sheets Was Routine. Is It Now a Crime?
abstract: Floyd Norris column on financial maneuvers used by J P Morgan Chase & Co and Citigroup Inc in its dealings with Enron Corp; holds one clever Chase deal let Enron show millions in debt as not being debt at all, but money due to part-owner of Enron subsidiary; says Chase vice president Marc J Shapiro said this week that year ago is was seen as good thing if debt was removed from balance sheet, but now it is seen as bad; adds Shapiro told analysts that Chase had no legal liability because it believed--and still believes--that Enron's accounting for transactions was proper; graph (M)

headline: EBay to Buy PayPal, a Rival in Online Payments
abstract: EBay announces plans to acquire PayPal, rapidly growing startup that lets people make payments via e-mail, for $1.5 billion; move will let eBay take bigger share of many sales made on its own site, and to expand its business to earn money on tens of thousands of transactions made elsewhere on the Internet (M)

headline: Hyundai Predicts a Tripling Of Sales in the U.S. by 2010
abstract: Hyundai Motor America intends to sell one million vehicles a year in United States by end of decade, nearly triple its current pace; Hyundai Automotive Group hopes to become one of world's five largest vehicle manufacturers by then, selling five million worldwide; critical factor will be expansion of range and types of models Hyundai offers, particularly its penetration into truck market; graph of sales (M)

headline: Moscow Journal; Father of K.G.B. Might Return to Headquarters
abstract: Statue of KGB founder Feliks Dzerzhinsky, removed from entrance of agency's Moscow headquarters in 1991 shortly after collapse of Soviet Union, may be returned to its central pedestal on traffic island in Lubyanka Square; Moscow Mayor Yuri M Luzhkov says he supports return, calling statue excellent monument even as he denies restoration represents return to repressive past; his reversal from earlier position shocks liberal politicians and human rights advocates who represent victims of police state Dzerzhinsky helped create; they launch campaign to thwart statue's restoration; photos (M)

headline: Israel Strikes at a Suspected Bomb Maker
abstract: Israel kills at least two members of Islamic group Hamas with missiles fired from helicopter gunships into busy Gaza City street, in strike at organization's top bomb maker, Muhammad Deif; it is not certain if Deif was killed; he is elusive figure at top of Israel's wanted list for decade; Hamas promises retaliation for attack; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Beer Ads Restricted
abstract: Russian beer producers, fastest-growing segment of Russian economy, are dealt blow by Russian legislators, who vote to significantly tighten restrictions on beer advertising; bill, which faces final vote, would ban beer advertising on prime-time television, and would restrict advertising content (S)

headline: Man in Middle of AOL Deal Is Now at Center of a Storm
abstract: Stephen M Case, architect of America Online and Time Warner merger, becomes target of growing criticism by analysts and investors after chairman Robert W Pittman resigns; Securities and Exchange Commission has opened probe into accounting practices at AOL that may have inflated past revenue; some analysts say Case's role as merger's architect makes him liability as AOL Time Warner tries to rebuild its credibility; company's directors, with Pittman's departure from board, are now evenly divided between Time Warner and AOL members; photo (M)

headline: Salary Doubles for Chief of P.&G.
abstract: The Procter & Gamble Company, the largest United States maker of household goods, more than doubled the salary and bonus of its chief executive, A. G. Lafley, to $3.62 million.

headline: Now, the Synchronized Family
abstract: Marilyn and Carl Fischer are seen example of families who take advantage of digital world for their scheduling, using tools like PC-based calendars and combination cellphone-organizers to help parents and children coordinate busy lives; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MOTOROLA, Schaumburg, Ill., the mobile telephone maker, introduced its Fireground system, a specialized mobile communications product intended to improve firefighters' communications capabilities.    AMERICAN AIRLINES, Fort Worth, and United Airlines , Chicago, have received tentative United States approval to sell tickets with international partners on flights to and from Vietnam.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Robert Davidowitz was named to the new position of group publisher for sports magazines at Rodale, based in New York. He had been group publisher for the American Baby Group, New York, part of Primedia.

headline: Longer-range jets win over Asia
abstract: SINGAPORE—  For years, passengers flying between Asia and North America across the Pacific have had to put up with the inconvenience and tedium of indirect services.

headline: Free-Market Upheaval Grinds Mexico's Middle Class
abstract: Mexico's economic liberalization and emergence of free market over last two decades has done little to close huge divide between privileged few and the poor, and has left middle class worse off than before; Alma Amarillas, 43-year-old teacher who works double shifts, describes living day to day with no savings; photo; historian Lorenzo Meyer says middle class grew steadily in decades of closed economy, but is 'delusion' now, sorry outcome for nation that embraced globalization; plight is especially bitter for middle class that propelled Vicente Fox into office, ending 71-year-old dictatorial regime (M)

headline: Administration Seeking to Build Support in Congress on Iraq Issue
abstract: Bush administration seeks to shore up Congressional support for campaign against Iraq, even as it tries to head off pressure from Britain and France to work through United Nations before taking any action against Saddam Hussein; Vice Pres Dick Cheney says administration would 'consult widely with our Congress' before deciding whether to go to war; does not make clear whether administration would seek formal vote on authorization of war; seeks to undercut arguments of critics who urge return to United Nations weapons inspections, saying inspectors in past failed to uncover evidence that Iraq was in fact continuing to mass-produce deadly chemical agents; Security Council diplomats say United States has backed away from engaging in Council's pressure on Iraq about inspectors, with American diplomats calling such efforts increasingly fruitless; no other Security Council nations appear ready to give up on inspections process; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Jobless Rate Steady
abstract: Britain's unemployment rate maintained 27-year low of 3.1 percent in August; number of people claiming jobless benefits fell unexpectedly by 6,400 to 943,300; annualized wage increases in quarter to July were only slightly above expectations of 4 percent (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: A Stake In Rome Airports
abstract: Australia's Macquarie Bank aa

headline: American Arsenal in the Mideast Is Being Built Up to Confront Saddam Hussein
abstract: Defense Department is sending weapons and other supplies to Middle East that could be critical part of war stocks if Pres Bush decides to attack Iraq; hires two giant cargo ships to carry armored vehicles and helicopters, among other war materiel, and eight additional cargo vessels capable of carrying ammunition tanks and ambulances; Air Force is stockpiling weaponry at depots in Persian Guld region; senior Pentagon officials say logistical movements do not represent stealth deployment and should not be interpreted as evidence that campaign against Iraq is imminent, or even a certainty; diagram (M)

headline: F.C.C. to Require Digital Tuners in Most New TVs by 2007
abstract: The F.C.C. voted 3-1 today to require manufacturers to include digital tuners in most every television sold.

headline: Powell Treading a Thin Line In Rallying Antiterror Support
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell arrives, Brunei, for Association of Southeast Asian Nations foreign ministers meeting aimed at solidifying Southeast Asian front in drive against global terrorism; has to balance goal with longstanding concerns about human rights abuses in region; says he repeatedly raised rights issues in meetings earlier in day in Malaysia and Singapore; hints at earlier Singapore news conference that Bush administration is ready to discuss resuming military cooperation with Indonesia; met there with Prime Min Goh Chok Tong, who endorsed idea of renewing United States-Indonesia military ties to stabilize Indonesia; met with Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad in Malaysia, where he proposed forming regional training center in Malaysia to coordinate antiterrorism activities; says their talk touched on case of Anwar Ibrahim, whose trial for sodomy and abuse of power Powell says US deems flawed; Asst Sec James Kelly meets with Anwar's wife, Wan Azizah Wan Ismail; photo (M)

headline: Bush Officials Say the Time Has Come for Action on Iraq
abstract: President Bush reiterated his argument today for quick action against Iraq as he conferred privately with Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada.

headline: Iraqi Official Affirms Death Of Abu Nidal; Suicide Hinted
abstract: Tariq Aziz, Iraq's deputy prime minister, confirms that Abu Nidal, man responsible for brutal trail of terrorism through 20 countries, died in Iraq; says he shot himself to death, notion that remains suspect; Bush administration welcomes Abu Nidal's death whatever the circumstances (M)

headline: Televisions That Reduce Cable Clutter for Xbox Aficionados
abstract: New line of televisions from RCA have special connection for Microsoft Xbox that helps eliminate snarl of cables behind set; also improves game image; photo (M)

headline: Japan in an Uproar as 'Big Brother' Computer File Kicks In
abstract: Japan put into operation a national computerized registry of its citizens today, provoking two un-Japanese responses: civil disobedience and a widespread feeling that privacy should take priority over efficiency.    Yokohama, Japan's second largest city, made the national government's registry voluntary, and half a dozen other cities refused to be included in the computerized system connecting local registries, effectively leaving four million people out of the system.

headline: When Kids Are Away, Parents Will Play
abstract: Lisa Belkin's Life's Work column on how she kept in touch with her boys who are away for first summmer at sleep-away camp through camp's Web site; drawing (M)

headline: Both Sides Say Bill Addressing Business Fraud Is a First Step
abstract: Few business leaders or major investors are happy with everything in corporate-governance bill Congress agreed to, but almost everyone says it is much better than nothing; accountants, executives and investors say legislation could help restore confidence in stock markets; bill approved contains nearly all provisions passed by Senate, rather than those of milder House bill; that left Democrats and advocates for shareholders' rights generally more pleased than corporate lobbyists, who tried to alter Senate bill over last week; Securities and Exchange Commission's former chairman Arthur Levitt, US Chamber of Commerce executive vice president Bruce Josten, Council of Institutional Investors executive director Sarah Teslik, PricewaterhouseCoopers chief executive Samuel A DiPiazza Jr, National Association of Manufacturers vice president Dorothy Coleman and Columbia University Prof John C Coffee Jr comment (M)

headline: MediaTalk; Decisions Differ On Religious Ad
abstract: At least eight newspapers, including New York Daily News, Boston Herald and Philadelphia Inquirer published Unification Church advertisement presenting text of meeting 'in spirit world' in which Jesus, Muhammad, Confucius, Buddha and other religious leaders proclaimed allegiance to Rev Sun Myung Moon; at least two, New York Times and Portland Oregonian, refused ad (M)

headline: Korea Fears Spillover From U.S. Economy
abstract: South Korea is beginning to feel fallout of bear market in United States in area of consumer spending; slowing department store sales, declining real estate prices and decline in price of semiconductors cited as causes of concern, even though Korean government agencies and private organizations are still forecasting economic growth of 6 percent for year (M)

headline: Anguish Over a Flight's Deadly Delay
abstract: Fifty-two schoolchildren who died in midair collision over Germany were from Russian Republic of Bashkortostan on their way to Spain, and they missed an earlier flight because tour operator took them to wrong airport in Moscow; three days of mourning are declared in Bashkortostan (M)

headline: 3 Units of Interpublic Get Bausch & Lomb
abstract: Bausch & Lomb names three units of Interpublic Group of Companies to handle consolidated US advertising account for its eye care and contact-lens products, with billings estimated at $30 million (S)

headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
abstract: Four executives note books they ar reading (S)

headline: Palestinians Tentatively Accept West Bank Terms
abstract: The Palestinian Authority tentatively accepted Israeli terms today for withdrawing from parts of the West Bank and Gaza Strip, as Israeli forces pressed their offensive.

headline: Israelis Greet High Holy Days With a Renewed Nervousness
abstract: Israelis hunker down to celebrate Jewish New Year in state of high alert after interception of huge bomb and warning that more attacks are possible; security officials say half-ton bomb had been prepared by Islamic Jihad, small but lethal group, apparently in Jenin, in West Bank (M)

headline: Brazil Builds Up Its Trade-Talks Team
abstract: Brazil, faced with huge import tariffs, has unilaterally opened its market over last decade and is now negotiating major trade accords on three fronts: with US, to form Freed Trade Area of Americas, with European Union, as de facto leader of South America's trade bloc Mercosur and multilaterally, in World Trade Organization; Brazil still exports less than 10 percent of its gross domestic product and, though it is among world's top 10 economies, accounts for less than 1 percent of global trade; recent devaluation of its currency, the real, has made country much more competitive, especially in agribusiness; country currently runs world's biggest agricultural trade surplus, totaling $20 billion per year (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Compuware Profit Falls
abstract: Compuware Corp says fiscal first-quarter profit fell short of analysts' estimates; earnings in quarter ended June 30 were 5 cents to 6 cents per share on sales of $329 million to $341 million (S)

headline: 401(k) Investors Want More Advice, Poll Shows
abstract: Survey conducted reveals that people who participate in 401(k) retirement plans want more specific information from their employers regarding investment decision-making (M)

headline: CNN Now Says It Paid $30,000 For Its Videotapes of bin Laden
abstract: CNN says it paid about $30,000 to people in Afghanistan for videotapes of Osama bin Laden and operatives of Al Qaeda it is now televising; previously indicated that it did not pay for them; insists that money did not go to anyone connected with bin Laden or Qaeda (M)

headline: Investing; Worried About Corporate Numbers? How About the Charts?
abstract: Prof Deanna Oxender Burgess study of 70 annual reports from American companies demonstrates that at least one in ten graphics shows more positive picture than underlying financial information warrants; she is concerned that misleading graphics in reports could influence investors' decisions; photo; examples of misleading graphs (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Alcatel Raises Cash; GERMANY: Dresdner Executive Resigns; FRANCE: Software Maker Cuts Outlook; RUSSIA: Oil Executives Convicted; GERMANY: Business Confidence Falls;.

headline: Russia's Rebel Fight Threatens to Expand
abstract: In their largest battle this year, Chechen fighters and Russian soldiers clashed in the southern republic of Ingushetia, and some Russian officials said it was possible that attacks could be ordered in Georgia.

headline: TRACES OF TERROR: PERSPECTIVES/Gerhard Schröder; 'No One Has a Clear Idea About What the Effects Would Be'
abstract: Excerpts from interview with German Chancellor Gerhard Schroder on events since Sept 11 and his opposition to United States attack on Iraq; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: MEXICO: Jobless Level Rises; CANADA: Bank Profit Up 66%;.

headline: Corporate Certifications Don't Alone Lift Shares
abstract: Few stock market watchers link 212-point rise in Dow Jones industrial average to second deadline for top corporate executives to swear that their companies' numbers are correct; Aug 19 was last day for companies that had sought five-day extension; some institutional investors say rise in share prices had less to do with certifications and more to do with fading concerns about double-dip recession and growing conviction that stock have already hit bottom (M)

headline: ICAHN SAYS HE'S WILLING TO KEEP TRYING FOR MORTON'S
abstract: Carl C Icahn, rebuffed by Morton's Restaurant Group in $71.2 million takeover offer, says he is still willing to outbid Castle Harlan's $67 million takeover of company (S)

headline: PepsiCo Profits Rise 14%, but Revenue Disappoints Investors
abstract: PepsiCo Inc reports 14 percent increase in second-quarter earnings; stock tumbles on disappointing revenue; net income increases to $940 million, or 52 cents a share, in line with analysts' estimates; revenue rises 2.3 percent, to $6.18 billion (M)

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: TAIWAN: Investigators Link Cracks To Crash; CAMBODIA: Premier Establishes Reserve;.

headline: World Business Briefing | North America: Canada: Profit Outlook Changes
abstract: Canada's Bombardier Inc warns profits for current fiscal year will fall short of target (S)

headline: In Diplomacy With North Korea, Some Progress, and a Setback
abstract: North and South Korea make progress at ministerial talks in Seoul over uniting divided families and rebuilding road and rail links and North Korean general meets with American counterpart to discuss avoiding armed conflicts; even so, North Korea threatens to pull out of 1994 nuclear accord with US (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: EARTHLINK NARROWS LOSS TO $40 MILLION; NEXTEL PARTNERS EXPECTS TO ADD SUBSCRIBERS; WIRELESS TELECOM TO CLOSE HEADQUARTERS;.

headline: THE MARKETS: Market Place; A Perelman Coup in 2001 Is a Retreat in 2002
abstract: Market Place column on Ronald O Perelman's accord to unwind 2001 deal in which M&F Worldwide, company he controls, agreed to buy his controlling stake in Panavision at huge premium; Danny Breen, money manager who filed original suit challenging deal, hails victory; accord leaves Perelman in control of both companies; New York Stock Exchange says it will delist Panavision because its market value is below $30 milllion minimum; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Ireland: Chief Faces Investors
abstract: Elan Corp's chairman Garo Armen faces shareholders and analysts for first time at annual general meeting since company's chief executive Donal Geaney and vice chairman Thomas Lynch resigned last month; their departures came after wave of public concern about accounting practices at company sent its stock plummeting more than 90 percent; says internal investigation found 'no signs of impropriety'; expresses optimism for future; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Postal Job Cuts
abstract: Deutsche Post may cut 10,000 jobs, or 3 percent of its work force, as order from regulators to lower postage rates erodes profits; lower rates will cut earnings by 1.5 billion euros ($1.5 billion) through 2007; company says most of job cuts will be among mial delivery workers; postal workers union says it will fight cuts (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Saks is testing technology that determines which goods to mark down, at specific prices, and at specific stores.
abstract: Saks Fifth Avenue and other retailers utilize software to replace gut instinct in pricing goods across different stores or regions and deciding timing and degree of merchandise markdowns; Spotlight Solutions vends such software; photo (M)

headline: A Résumé From Beyond the Job Market
abstract: Lisa Belkin Life's Work column advises women on preparing resumes for returning to work after leaving jobs to raise children (M)

headline: Social security benefits : Career globe-trotters need to be wary
abstract: PARIS—  If you are banking on U.S. Social Security as an important part of your retirement, think twice if you've done a lot of globe-hopping in your job career.

headline: Airline Stocks Tumble After US Airways Files for Chapter 11
abstract: Most airline stocks tumbled after US Airways, crippled by the Sept. 11 attacks and burdened by high costs, filed for bankruptcy protection.

headline: Ashland Inc. Reports $65 Million Profit
abstract: LOUISVILLE, Ky., July 22 (AP) — Ashland Inc. reported a $65 million third-quarter profit today, down sharply from a year ago as slumping gasoline refining operations dragged earnings below analysts' expectations.

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Axa Expects Rise In Income; GERMANY: Deutsche Telekom Has Record Loss;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Citizens Communications Posts Wider Net Loss
abstract: Citizens Communications Co reports wider second-quarter net loss on higher costs for moves like job cuts; loss widens to $41.6 million from $13.3 million a year earlier (S)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Cellphones in School To the Editor:.

headline: Louisiana-Pacific to Lay Off Workers
abstract: The Louisiana-Pacific Corporation told Texas regulators that it would lay off 462 employees as part of an agreement to swap plants with the Georgia-Pacific Corporation.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Rolls Profit Down 45%
abstract: Rolls-Royce reports first-half pretax profit of 104 million pounds ($158 million) compared with 190 million pounds year earlier, 45 percent decline; sales dropped 9 percent, to 2.8 billion pounds; graph (S)

type: Money and Business/Financial DeskMoney and Bus
headline: Bake at 95 Degrees. Then Buy an Air-Conditioner.
abstract: Sales of air-conditioners rise, partly because of above-normal temperatures; Air-Conditioning and Refrigeration Institute reports manufacturers shipped 3.9 million central air conditioning units in June, 5 percent increase from same period in 2001; 5-year graphs of air-conditioner shipments and average June temperatures (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Plan For Asset Sales
abstract: ABB Ltd chairman Jurgen Dormann plans to speed up asset sales to restore profits at company (S)2

headline: Observations From the DVR Frontier
abstract: What I learned from the e-mail reactions to my column last week about the ad-skipping features of TiVo and ReplayTV: First, Americans are fed up with the current state of television. Second, the readers of this e-mail newsletter are a thoughtful and articulate bunch. Here are a few excerpts from your messages:

headline: As Tokyo Loses Luster, Foreign Media Move On
abstract: Newspapers are closing their Tokyo bureaus and using stringers, or reporters paid by the article, as Japan's economy shrinks and editors choose to cover more dynamic countries; for old Japan hands who have seen ups and downs of world interest in Japan, latest move has ring of familiarity; Bruce Dunning, Asia bureau chief of CBS, notes difficulty of reporting on change in Japan, which is generally minute, incremental, and occurring without visible social friction; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Porsche Sees Rising Profits
abstract: Porsche predicts profits will rise significantly in 2002, bolstered by its Cayenne, 911 and Boxster models; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Sept 1 On the Contrary column about worker taxation

headline: Study in Israel: American Jews Feel the Tremors and Worry
abstract: Deaths of five Americans in bombing of cafeteria at Hebrew University have sent tremors through world of American Jews who have been sending their children almost ritually to study in Israel's colleges and yeshivas as way of cementing ties to land; so many families send high school graduates or college juniors to Israel for study, both secular and religious, that it has become proud rite of passage in some circles; John Fisher, admissions official at Yeshiva University in Manhattan, says he expects latest attack to set off soul-searching, particularly among parents, who seem more worried than students who actually go; photo (M)

headline: A Deal on Fuel Economy Rules Could Increase Oil Consumption
abstract: House and Senate negotiators reach agreement on new fuel economy rules that would increase oil consumption, rather than decrease it, unless Bush administration takes more aggressive action; bill would allow Congress to extend by four years, through model year 2008, credits automakers receive for making vehicles that can run on ethanol and gasoline; automakers use credits to offset their growing production of sport utilities and other vehicles that get relatively low gasoline mileage; agreement would also direct National Highway Traffic Safety Administration to rewrite fuel economy standards so that fuel consumption by light trucks would be reduced by at least five billion gallons of gasoline by 2012 model year, compared with consumption expected under current standards; Repr John D Dingell, who sponsored bill, says package is equivalent of taking all SUV's and light trucks off road for two years, and it is good place to start; environmental groups call his calculations misleading; photo (M)

headline: A Rising Star in a Clouded Firmament
abstract: J P Morgan Chase's chief financial officer Dina Dublon's blunt and unburdened delivery has made her rising star at time when chief financial officers at many other big companies are on defensive about corporate accounting practices; she is also vocal advocate for female executives; analysts say Dublon's performance over last few months could win her one of top jobs at bank someday; photo (M)

headline: Delta Promises New Service to Compete With Low-Cost Rivals
abstract: Delta Air Lines says it is developing new product to compete with low-cost carriers, particularly AirTran Airways, which has been gnawing at Delta's market share on East Coast; several people close to company say it will start another low-cost airline, even though it already runs stagnant Delta Express (M)

headline: New Focus in Filling Audit Watchdog Post
abstract: John H Biggs, head of TIAA-CREF pension program, has emerged as top candidate to head new regulatory body that will oversee accounting profession because front-runner Paul Volcker has continued to express hesitancy over taking job; photo (M)

headline: Ramallah Journal; 'Moonlight' and Mendelssohn in the West Bank
abstract: Ramallah Journal on Daniel Barenboim's performance of Beethoven and Mendelssohn on old Steinway piano, before 200 Palestinian students at private Friends School in Ramallah; photo; map; famed conductor and pianist tells students that everyone has responsibility to do what is right, and that his way is music; he is vocal critic of Israeli crackdown on Palestinians, and had scheduled earlier concert which was canceled by army for security resons (M)

headline: U.N. and Congress Rebuff Iraq's Inspection Invitation
abstract: UN Security Council and Sec Gen Kofi Annan agree that weapons inspectors will not return to Iraq to restart talks after break of almost four years unless government of Pres Saddam Hussein agrees to abide by organization's rules on how inspections must be conducted; leading members of Congress reject Iraq's invitation to visit country and to inspect suspected weapons sites for themselves; Democrats and Republicans are equally dismissive; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: CHINA: Economic Growth; SOUTH KOREA: Telecom Profit; JAPAN: Trade Surplus Rises; JAPAN: Outlook For Merged Airline; SOUTH KOREA: Brokerage Profits Fall;.

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: On a Roll, Dell Enters Uncharted Territory
abstract: Dell Computer, undaunted by industry's current soft sales and hard times, is moving beyond making personal desktop and laptop computers into corporate data centers and large sales of business computers and servers; catering successfully to corporate customers will require marked transition in Dell's business operations; photo; graph of worldwide computer sales (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: Oil prices drop after Saudi Arabia says it will support attack on Iraq as long as United Nations backs such action; in New York, crude oil for October delivery falls 14 cents, to $29.67; graph; chart (S)

headline: Aon Is Moving to New Offices, but Will Avoid Tall Buildings
abstract: Article on scene at Aon's operations in New York one year after Sept 11 terrorist attacks at World Trade Center cost world's second-largest insurance broker lives of 175 employees; Aon's main operations in New York have been restored and company's brokers and consultants are preparing to move into new offices in Midtown Manhattan and in downtown financial district; many employees have decided not to work in New York; chief executive Patrick G Ryan comments (M)

headline: European Economic Forecast Is Cut Again
abstract: European Commission lowers its economic growth forecast for fourth time in 2002; predicts third-quarter expansion of 0.3 percent to 0.6 percent, reduced from earlier estimate of 0.6 percent to 0.9 percent growth (M)

headline: Shift at AOL Puts Time Warner at Helm
abstract: Robert W Pittman, chief operating officer of AOL Time Warner, resigns under pressure in most public repudiation yet of premises behind $165 billion merger of AOL and Times Warner; Pittman's departure leaves combined company almost entirely in hands of veterans of Time Warner's old-media business; Richard D Parsons, Time Warner chief exec, reorganizes company under two execs whose old-media businesses have performed better than expected in recent years; Don Logan, previously chmn of Time Warner magazine division, is named chmn of newly formed media group that includes AOL and Time Warner Cable as well as books and magazine division; Jeff Bewkes, previously chmn of HBO, is named chmn of newly formed entertainment division that includes television networks, film and television studios and music; Stephen M Case, chmn of AOL Time Warner, is last exec from AOL among top management; photo-chart of old management team at merger, and new one (L)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: President Tries To Fend Off Foes
abstract: Ukraine Pres Leonid D Kuchma seeks legislators' support for government reform plan that would shift some of his power to Parliament; political opponents have accused him of corruption and say he was connected with murder of opposition journalist Georgy Gongadze nearly two years ago, charge which he denies; photo (S)

headline: President to Seek Congress’s Assent Over Iraq Action
abstract: President Bush said that he would seek approval from Congress before taking action against Iraq.

headline: Using Corn-Based Plastic, A Laptop Starts to Go Green
abstract: Fujitsu and Sony are beginning to use biodegradable plastics in some of their high-tech gear; photo (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH/Patrick Cunningham and Jeffrey A. Herrmann; Exeter Maximum Horizon Fund
abstract: Carole Gould Investing With column explores investing philosophy, methods and results of Exeter Maximum Horizon fund managers Jeffrey Herrmann and Patrick Cunningham; photo; graph and table of fund data (M)

headline: Microsoft Word Formats Brought Into Full View
abstract: New version of Microsoft Word offers ability to see some formatting commands in documents; photo (M)

headline: A Lakeside Cottage: Smells Like a Deal
abstract: Henry Fountain Online Shopper column explores vast world of online vacation rentals and possible pitfalls of renting sight unseen; drawing (M)

headline: Germany Announces New Shift Away From U.S. Over Iraq
abstract: If the U.S. attacks Iraq, Germany will pull out its nuclear, chemical and biological warfare unit from Kuwait.

headline: Citing Its Price Strategy, Amazon Pares Loss
abstract: Amazon.com posts slightly better-than-expected financial results in second quarter, as its operations continued to stabilize; reports loss of $94 million compared with loss of $168 million year ago; revenue rose 21 percent, to $806 million; modestly raises its financial expectations for third quarter; chief executive Jeffrey P Bezos comments; photo (M)

headline: Irish Drug Maker Posts Loss After a Big Write-Down
abstract: The Elan Corporation, Ireland's biggest drug maker, today reported a loss of $802 million for the second quarter after writing down the value of its investments by $826.6 million. It also announced details of a restructuring plan to help it recover from setbacks in drug development and questions about its accounting practices that have pushed the value of its stock down 95 percent so far this year.    Elan said it would lay off 1,000 of its 4,700 employees by December in an effort to cut costs by $300 million a year. By selling off noncore businesses, it hopes to raise $1.5 billion and shed an additional 2,100 employees by the end of 2003, leaving merely a shell of the company that dominated the Irish Stock Exchange just six months ago.

headline: Hard Drive for the Car Lets You Rip CD's on the Way to Work
abstract: Sony introduces hard drive for car that can download music from CD's without computer; photo (M)

headline: Bomb Kills 7 in Jerusalem; Hamas Claims Responsibility
abstract: A powerful bomb placed by Palestinian militants tore apart a crowded cafeteria at Hebrew University during lunchtime today.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Forecasts 91,000 New Users
abstract: Nextel Partners expects loss of 30 cents per share in third quarter as it adds 91,000 subscribers; second quarter loss widened to $74 million from $71 million year earlier; sales rose 87 percent, to $161.1 million (S)

headline: Expensive Online Help
abstract: Susan Linehan letter on August 22 article holds computer software makers should not charge users for performance problems

headline: Bethlehem Journal; A City Ancient, Glorious, All Shuttered and Glum
abstract: Bethlehem seethes with mutual fears and hatreds of Israelis and Palestinians; Palestinians regard military patrols and curfew as further humiliation; Israelis say army's presence is needed to prevent more suicide bombings; city's division from Jerusalem to north is increasingly stark; photos (M)

headline: MAYOR PROMISING BETTER RESPONSE TO CATASTROPHES
abstract: Mayor Michael R Bloomberg pledges major changes in how New York City Police and Fire Departments handle future catastrophes; plans improvements in technology and basic emergency procedures; says major focus will be to change culture of Police and Fire Departments, which have had long history of rivalry; technological changes include outfitting high-rise buildings with special equipment to boost radio signals rescuers use; procedural changes call for fire chiefs to routinely ride police helicopters to gauge cataclysm from air; most elemental change will be effort to foster cooperation between firefighters and police officers, from rank and file to top chiefs; his major proposals detailed; Bloomberg comments; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Leading Indicators: July    TUESDAY  Balance of Trade: June  Federal Budget: July

headline: Qwest to Sell Yellow Pages For $7 Billion
abstract: Qwest Communications International agrees to sell its yellow pages directories business to group of financier for $7 million in move that would help it avert bankruptcy filing; will sell unit to politically influenced Carlyle Group and Welsh, Carson, Anderson & Stowe; sale comes as Qwest announces it will change way it accounts for yellow pages unit and restate results for at least 2001 and first half of 2002; says it will now recognize sales and expenses over life of phone directory instead of when it is published; change will reduce 2001 directly sales by 5 percent, or $80 million (M)

headline: Swiss Tell of Controller Error Before Air Crash
abstract: Swiss air traffic officials acknowledge that collision alarm system in their control network was out of operation and that one of two crucial controllers had taken break at time of midair crash that killed 71 people on July 1; disclosures increase suspicion among investigators that crash occurred at least in part because of errors on ground and not, as Swiss officials have implied, primarily because of errors by pilot of Russian passenger plain (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: PALM OFFERS REFUNDS TO SOME CUSTOMERS; AOL TO USE COVAD HIGH-SPEED NETWORK;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Malaysia: Tax Cut Only For Small Business
abstract: Malaysian government limits widely expected corporate tax cut to small companies that have paid-up capital of $685,240 or less; focuses on reducing government spending; photo (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Consumer Borrowing: May    TUESDAY  None

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Insurer Discovers Loss
abstract: Swiss Life says accounting error led it to record 253 million franc ($168 million) profit in 2001 first half when it actually posted loss; says it mistakenly booked unrealized investment gain as realized gain; chairman Andres Leuenberger says error was not fraud; photo (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Bush Adopts New Rules For Medical Data Privacy  The Bush administration formally rolled back some major protections for the privacy of medical records adopted by President Bill Clinton. But at the same time, it also set new standards for the use of personal data to market prescription drugs and other health care products.    The rules, the first comprehensive federal standards for medical privacy, will affect virtually every doctor, patient, hospital, drugstore, health insurance company and medical researcher in the United States. The rules embody more than five years of work and have the force of law. [Page A1.]

headline: The Rich Have More, and More to Lose
abstract: Research by Prof Edward N Wolff shows that middle-class Americans have almost 60 percent of their wealth in their homes and about 5 percent in stocks and mutual funds; the very rich, however, hold less than 8 percent of their net worth in their residences and more than 31 percent in stocks and mutual funds; graph illustrates (M)

headline: Congo Peace Accord Evokes Cautious Hopes
abstract: Latest agreement to bring peace to Congo, where at least 2.5 million people have perished in civil strife over last four years, raises cautious hope that complicated conflict may be nearing end; few in capital of Kinshasa expect immediate end to hostilities since either side is unlikely to stick to letter of pact, which calls for Congo to crack down on Hutu militias blamed for mass killings of ethnic Tutsi and Rwanda to withdraw troops from Congo; map; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: More Blamed In Air Disaster
abstract: Investigators cite violations, shortcomings by those involved and deviation from flight plan as causes of air show crash last month near Lviv, Ukraine, that killed 85 people and injured many more (S)

headline: Recomputing Earnings With Lawbook and Eraser
abstract: Lawyers and accountants warn that conditions are ripe for flurry of corporate financial restatements; say rarely, if ever, have so many had such strong incentives to disclose any problems with their accounting; Arthur Andersen, firm undone by its audit of Enron Corp, has been replaced as accountant for hundreds of public companies, and they are being audited more rigorously by new accountants trying to find any skeletons now, while Andersen can still be blamed; company officers and directors, fearful of shareholder lawsuits, Securities and Exchange Commission investigations and even possible criminal charges, might prefer to come clean quickly than risk being implicated in cover-up; chart (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: A Loss For Performance Technologies
abstract: Performance Technologies Inc, maker of communications and networking equipment, warns it will have third-quarter loss and will cut another 7 percent of its work force, or 12 jobs, to trim expenses; loss will be on revenue of $3.6 million to $4.1 million (S)

headline: Karachi Raid Provides Hint Of Qaeda's Rise in Pakistan
abstract: Arrest of Ramzi bin al-Shibh, senior Al Qaeda operative, in Karachi reinforces growing fear among Western officials that Al Qaeda is re-establishing its operations in Karachi and other cities of Pakistan with help of Pakistani militants; officials say Al Qaeda appears to have moved center of its operations from Peshawar near Afghan border to Karachi, perhaps hoping to make it transit point for moving personnel, money and materiel; Pakistani officials play down threat and offer account of Karachi raid that differs markedly from one outlined by American officials, saying American agents and information played no role in it; photos (M)

headline: Airline Stocks Tumble After US Airways Files for Chapter 11
abstract: Airline stocks fell today after US Airways, crippled by the Sept. 11 attacks and burdened by high costs, filed for bankruptcy protection.

headline: SEARS HAS BETTER-THAN-EXPECTED 2ND QUARTER
abstract: Sears, Roebuck & Co had higher-than-expected second-quarter profit and raises its 2002 forecast; net income was $420 million compared with loss of $197 million year earlier; sales fell less than 1 percent, to $10.14 billion (S)

headline: OBITUARY
abstract: David Whipple, 78, who worked in the U.S. Central Intelligence Agency for 35 years, died on June 24 in Fairfax, Virginia. His overseas posts included Hanoi during the French war against the Vietminh, Rangoon, Bangkok, Katanga (in the former Belgian Congo) and London. He was the CIA's station chief in Helsinki, Phnom Penh, Lisbon and Geneva before retiring in 1989.

headline: FIVE QUESTIONS for DEBRA L. DUNN; Why It's Worth Taking the Heat
abstract: Interview with Hewlett-Packard Co official Debra L Dunn, delegate to United Nations's Earth Summit, on why corporations send representatives to event where public criticism of corporations is likely; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Church Dispute Festers
abstract: Archbishop Vsevelod Chaplin, senior official of Russia's Orthodox Church, accuses Jerzy Mazur, Roman Catholic bishop barred from country earlier in year, of trying to win converts (S)

headline: Surfing at Higher Speeds
abstract: Number of Internet users with high-speed access is growing, though at slower rate than in previous years; high-speed phone lines known as DSL have more subscribers than cable broadband worldwide, but cable is currently more popular in United States; graph comparing number of cable modem with DSL subscribers in US; photo (S)

headline: A Campus for Collaboration, at a Billion Bits Per Second
abstract: Newly completed home of Weatherhead School of Management at Case Western Reserve University, Cleveland, is scheduled to open in October; building is designed by Frank Gehry and includes some of most advanced technologies integrated into classroom; it has speediest broadband computer network of any school, capable of moving one billion bits of data per second; common areas are designed to bring students and faculty together; other features noted; photos (M)

headline: When Stars Are Paid To Talk About Drugs
abstract: Dr Herve M Byron letter responds to August 11 article about celebrities who promote pharmaceutical products on television

headline: Profit Increases Sixfold at Tyson Foods
abstract: Tyson Foods Inc reports net income of $107 million in quarter ending June 29, up from $19 million a year ago (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Big Day For Great Robber
abstract: britain: big day for great robber**Ronald Biggs, 72, jailed in Britain for his role in 1963 'Great Train Robbery,' weds Raimunda Rothen, 52, in prison rite; officials say marriage could help their son, Michael Biggs, who is fighting deportation, win British passport; Biggs was jailed in mid-1960's, soon escaped, but returned to Britain last year; photo (S)

headline: New Economy; A case study in using e-mail to reach valued customers rapidly.
abstract: Airlines use e-mail messages to frequent fliers to give their versions of bad news such as bankruptcies and layoffs; seek to reassure valued customers that operations continue normally despite negative news; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: A Loss At Reuters
abstract: Reuters Group posts its first loss as public company; net loss for six months through June was 73 million pounds ($114 million) compared to net income of 269 million pounds year earlier; revenue fell 5.3 percent, to 1.84 billion pounds; chief executive Tom Glocer comments; photo (S)

headline: Business; Bloomberg, Without Bloomberg, Faces an Industry in Retreat
abstract: Bloomberg LP faces challenge of maintaining growth that was mantra of its founder, Michael R Bloomberg, now mayor of New York, at time when securities industry, which buys information Bloomberg produces, is shrinking; company denies competitors' allegations that it is discounting prices to gain market share; says it is actually phasing in increases in subscription fees; company's culture apparently remains intact during Mayor Bloomberg's absence; photo; graph of industry's growth (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Putin Sees Drug Disaster
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Putin declares drug addiction equivalent of natural disaster, citing new figures showing Russia has 500,000 registered drug users, three-quarters of them under 30; experts say true figure is far higher (S)

headline: U.S. Said to Be Investigating Another Enron-Merrill Deal
abstract: Federal investigators are looking into 1999 energy deal between Enron Corp and Merrill Lynch & Co to determine whether it was sham transaction intended to help Enron increase its year-end profit; FBI and Securities and Exchange Commission investigators recently questioned several former Enron executives about deal, which was completed at end of 1999 and resulted in $60 million profit for Enron; investigators have also contacted officials at Merrill Lynch; among other things, federal investigators want to know whether last-minute deal helped Enron meet internal performance goals that resulted in huge bonus payments to high-ranking Enron executives; Merrill Lynch says firm's dealings with Enron in recent years were entirely appropriate; people involved in deal say Merrill officials were so concerned about Enron's accounting for deal that they requested letter from Enron's chief accounting officer Richard A Causey, stating that Enron did not rely on Merrill for its accounting advice; Arthur Andersen, Enron's accounting firm, also voiced concerns about last-minute deal (M)

headline: Martha Stewart May Receive A Subpoena From Congress
abstract: Congressional committee may subpoena Martha Stewart to testify about her sale of ImClone shares (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Judge Freezes Accounts Of Ex-Enron Executive  A Houston magistrate has signed orders freezing a number of brokerage and bank accounts controlled by Andrew S. Fastow, the former chief financial officer of Enron, and members of his family, people involved in the case said.    The orders were signed by United States Magistrate Calvin Botley after some family members tried to move millions from one account to another, these people said. [Page C2.]    Insurers Halt Coverage on Big Vans  After rollover crashes of 15-passenger vans involving death and injury to sports teams, choirs and campers, a growing number of colleges and churches are prohibiting or severely limiting their use, and some insurance companies are refusing to insure them. [A1.]

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Two employees joined Colby & Partners, Santa Monica, Calif., a unit of Dentsu.

headline: Poles Greet Pope in Cracow on His 9th Visit to Homeland
abstract: Poland welcomed the pope today amid speculation that this might be his last trip abroad and denials by the Vatican.

headline: AMERCO SAYS S.E.C. INQUIRY INTO AUDITOR FIRING IS ROUTINE
abstract: Amerco, owner of U-Haul International, says it has been asked routine questions by Securities and Exchange Commission about firing of its auditor PricewaterhouseCoopers and is not being investigated by agency (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BANK ONE, Chicago, said it was negotiating with Prime Group Realty Trust, Chicago, to buy the Dearborn Center, a 1.52-million-square-foot skyscraper under construction in downtown Chicago. Bank One has leased space there and plans to open a trading floor.    ROADHOUSE GRILL, Pompano Beach, Fla., operator of 69 restaurants, said it had received approval from a bankruptcy judge for its recovery plan and would emerge from protection within a month.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Move To Block Immigration Law
abstract: German conservatives ask high court to block new law easing immigration restrictions for skilled foreign workers (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Oil Profit Falls
abstract: Oil giant BP says second-quarter net profit fell 36 percent to $2.18 billion (S))

headline: ABB to Sell Its Finance Unit to G.E. for $2.3 Billion
abstract: ABB sells most of its financing unit to General Electric Co for $2.3 billion in cash; acquisition will allow GE to expand its toehold in European structured-finance market; GE will take over loans, leases and other financial assets with face value of $3.8 billion; will also assume $1.2 billion in liabilities; photo (M)

headline: Pakistan Allows Kashmir Raids, Militants Say
abstract: Officials from three Pakistani militant groups say in interviews that government of Pakistan has allowed Islamic guerrillas to resume small-scale infiltrations into Indian-controlled Kashmir; India has repeatedly demanded that Pakistan halt that practice; Gen Pervez Musharraf, under intense pressure from United States, promised in May that his government would do all it could to stop infiltration; repeats that pledge on Sept 19, and denies that his government is 'allowing, or sponsoring, or encouraging' any movement across so-called Line of Control; United States Ambassador to India Robert D Blackwill says American officials believe infiltration into Indian-controlled Kashmir has increased recently; Ershad Mahmud, expert on Kashmir at Institute of Policy Studies, says he cannot confirm that Pakistani government is financing groups, as interviewed militants contend, but that small-scale infiltrations have resumed, and Musharraf is under intense domestic political pressure to allow them to continue; photo of funeral for Ali Muhammad Dar, activist working for Kashmir's governing party; anti-Indian rebels claim responsibility for his killing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Global Trade Increases
abstract: Taiwan's exports and imports rise sharply in July as demand from Asia continues to drive trade-dependent economy; exports grow 14.9 percent, to 379.6 billion Taiwan dollars ($11.2 billion) from a year ago (S)

headline: KERR-MCGEE RESTATES EARNINGS TO REFLECT CLEANUP
abstract: Kerr-McGee Corp restates its second-quarter earnings, showing wider loss after including costs to clean up former oil, gas and chemical sites; company reports net loss of $58 million rather than net loss of $7.6 million reported on July 24 (S)/

headline: Long in Dark, Afghan Women Say to Read Is Finally to See
abstract: Afghanistan's women, deprived of learning during years of Taliban rule, are as eager to get education for themselves as for their children; in Mazar-I-Sharif, hundreds of women's literacy classes are forming, faster than government can register them; women are meeting in neighborhood houses to learn to read and write; many illiterate women use word 'blind' to describe themselves and their confusion and difficulties as uneducated members of society already harshly discriminatory against women; they complain about not being able to decipher street signs, even for bathrooms, and not being able to understand medical prescriptions; Afghan women often are too timid to approach strangers to ask directions; photos (M)

headline: WorldCom Bankruptcy Filing Is Said to Be Set for Next Week
abstract: WorldCom Inc is planning to file for bankruptcy protection from its creditors by early next week; company is finalizing up to $2 billion debtor-in-possession financing (M)

headline: Russia Punishes Commanders for Copter Crash That Killed 119
abstract: Russia punishes several senior military commanders for lapses that contributed to crash of military helicopter in Chechnya on Aug 19, which killed 119 soldiers and civilians; investigation concludes that gross negligence contributed to death toll, if not crash itself; Defense Min Sergei B Ivanov says criminal investigation could lead to criminal prosecutions; Russian officials say shoulder-launched surface-to-air missile, evidently fired by Chechen fighter, downed helicopter, but most of recriminations focus on Russian commanders; helicopter was carrying far more passengers than it was designed to carry (M)

headline: Learning to manage urban sprawl
abstract: PARIS:—  This is the second of five articles leading up to the World Summit for Sustainable Development, which begins Aug. 26 in Johannesburg.

headline: The Common Denominator In Business Is Cash
abstract: Jeffrey Geibel letter adds dimension to June 23 article about barter; drawing

headline: A Hard Drive For the Hip Pocket
abstract: Wilson Rothman Basics column reviews new generation of external hard drives, sleek and space-saving devices that can store more than 40 gigabytes of information; they can be used for extra storage or backing up entire system; drives are simple to use, require no elaborate connections and are portable; photos (M)

headline: Bidding Emotional Goodbye, Pope Ends Visit to His Past
abstract: Pope John Paul II bids emotional goodbye to his native Poland, ending deeply personal three-day visit; thousands gather at Cracow airport to bid him farewell; pain of departure and also uncertainty that he will ever return are captured in his words and gestures; plane carrying him back to Rome flies deliberately low after takeoff giving him look at southern Polish countryside where he was born; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Profit At BMW
abstract: German carmaker BMW increases second-quarter sales by 8.9 percent, to 11.6 billion euros ($11.2 billion), and net profit by 11.9 percent, to 629 million euros ($607 million), compared with second quarter of 2001; photo (S)

headline: Japan's Financial Services Minister Is Ousted
abstract: The head of Japan's Financial Services Agency was forced out today, signalling that the government will push ahead to bail out the country's indebted banks.

headline: So Few Agencies, So Many Official Seats Unfilled
abstract: Experts and government officials say that several federal regulatory agencies remain crippled by deficits of both personnel and enforcement abilities despite tide of corporate scandals pushing Congress to reassert its oversight and regulatory powers; officials blame length of time needed to hire federal employees; only about 350 of over 500 possible appointments before Senate have been confirmed; hard-nosed politics only lengthens logjam and leaves more agencies leaderless and hobbled; list of positions vacant at federal regulatory agencies (M)

headline: Marie Claire to Offer Small Sales Cards
abstract: Marie Claire, published by Hearst Magazines, takes new tack in its October issue to stimulate ad sales; each copy of magazine will contain ATM-size card with personal identification number to let readers log on to Web site with special offers from advertisers (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Banker's Profit Falls
abstract: Julius Baer Holding of Switzerland, reporting 14 percent drop in first-half profit to $290 million, says it will lay off several hundred workers; share price graph (M)

headline: Israel to Follow U.S. Lead if Iraq Is Attacked
abstract: israel to follow u.s. lead if

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Telecom Shares Fall
