abstract: Shares of Philippine Long Distance Telephone plunge after Moody's Investors Service downgrades company's credit rating and company fights to stop First Pacific Co from selling 24 pecent sake to venture controlled by John Gokongwei (S)

headline: Blackstone and Carlyle in Bid for TRW Parts Unit
abstract: The Blackstone Group and the Carlyle Group, two prominent US buy-out funds, have joined forces to bid for TRW's automotive parts division.

headline: MediaTalk; A Business Cliffhanger: AOL Time Warner
abstract: Three books are already being written on tumultuous merger between AOL and Time Warner; HarperCollins has signed up Nina Munk, Crown will publish book by Kara Swisher and Knopf will publish book by Frank Gibney Jr; photo (M)

headline: Bhutto Plans to Return to Pakistan, and Politics
abstract: Benazir Bhutto, one of two former prime ministers of Pakistan living in exile, says she would return to her homeland to run for office in elections scheduled for Oct and would face being jailed by Gen Pervez Musharraf, country's military dictator; Musharraf says he would arrest Bhutto and former Prime Min Nawaz Sharif if either returns; both of them have been convicted by Pakistani courts on corruption charges (M)

headline: Advertising; Barney's Image Gets Makeover For New Crop Of Toddlers
abstract: Advertising column describes new $6 million advertising campaign for Barney, purple dinosaur who was dominant feature in children's television five years ago; Hit Entertainment will begin broadcasting 20 new Barney and Friends episodes on PBS, and programs will be backed by first-ever television advertising campaign along with wave of promotions, line of 16 new toys from Fisher-Price and 70-city nationwide stage tour; aim is to restore some if not all of Barney's audience and cash-making powers; photos (M)

headline: Discovering Amazon Rain Forest's Silver Lining
abstract: Residents in Xapuri, town in remote corner of Brazil's most isolated state of Acre are increasingly turning to rain forest as solution to region's chronic poverty, compared with other Brazilians who regard jungle as barrier to progress to be replaced as quickly as possible; are being encouraged to cultivate rubber and Brazil nut trees, twin pillars of area's economy before major deforestation began in 1970's; are forming cooperatives and seeking to capitalize on growing market in Brazil and elsewhere for environmentally friendly products; maps; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Russia: Genetics Rule Considered
abstract: Russia is considering ban on genetically modifed corn and soybean imports from US; ban would begin Oct 1, when new law on state registration of genetically modified products takes effect; ban would be lifted as products are registered (S)/

headline: Regional Bell Giants No Longer Invulnerable
abstract: WorldCom Inc's bankruptcy filing has added to local phone companies' problems, but their real troubles are more fundamental; Bell companies are now facing raft of strategic, technical and financial difficulties that may take years to overcome; WorldCom, in its bankruptcy filing, said it paid local phone companies about 750 million per month for access to their networks; if WorldCom, under bankruptcy court priorities, loses ability to pay those fees, it will obviously hurt Bell companies; problems facing Verizon Communications, SBC Communications and BellSouth discussed (M)

headline: Retirement Not Spoken Here
abstract: Dr Ray H Crist, 102-year-old professor of environmental science at Messiah College in Grantham, Pa, is named America's Oldest Worker for 2002 by Experience Works (S)

headline: Dispute Over New Court Perils Widened Alliance
abstract: Struggle between Bush administration and European over new International Criminal Court is placing some candidate nations for both European Union and NATO in severe political bind; United States presses EU to let individual nations sign bilateral accords with US to exempt Americans from court's jurisdiction; some EU foreign ministers, meeting, Denmark, are insisting that union reject such exemptions and continue to urge 10 candidate nations to do same; candidate nations like Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania would like to wait to see if EU and US can work out compromise, which Britain is now trying to broker; American legislators have told Baltic leaders that Senate approval of their NATO membership depends on their signing waivers; State Department has denied waiver is condition for NATO membership (M)

headline: Britain to Relax Marijuana Laws
abstract: Britain said today that it would keep the use of marijuana theoretically illegal but no longer arrest people using it in discreet amounts in private.

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Vote To Limit Indian Claims
abstract: British Colombians voting in mail-in referendum back measures to limit indigenous people's self-government land claims and tax exemptions; native groups claim nearly all the western province as their ancestral land (S)

headline: Putting Cars and Trains Up Against the Airlines
abstract: Business travelers throughout country say they sometimes opt to drive, or take train if available, on trips about 150 to 400 miles that they used to make exclusively by airplane; advantages of driving or taking train between various points on northeastern US urban corridor are readily apparent; but travel is little more complicated out West; Joe Sharkey comments on problems he and his wife encountered on business trips to Southern California and Arizona; drawing (M)

headline: A Smart Weapon for the Links: The G.P.S.-Enabled Golf Cart
abstract: ProLink introduces computer system for golf carts; display offers detailed graphic overview of every hole; relies on Global Positioning System technology although standard compass is installed to compensate for system's margin of error; photos (M)

headline: Interpublic Presses Agency Star To Play Bigger Role in Hierarchy
abstract: Advertising industry speculates on reaction of Deutsch advertising agency founder Donny Deutsch to pressure from parent Interpublic Group of Cos to give up top roles at Deutsch to assume larger role at Interpublic, perhaps trying to revive one or more of its struggling agencies; photos (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Sprint Completes A 3rd-Generation Network
abstract: Sprint completes its Third Generation network for wireless voice and data communications, making it first US carrier to get long-awaited technology in place nationwide (S)

headline: Arnell Group Gets Bank of America Job
abstract: Arnell Group Gets Bank of America Job.

headline: Making Your Own Luck
abstract: Cingular Wireless chief executive Stephen M Carter The Boss column on his life, from his British childhood to his Atlanta, Georgia, present; photo (M)

headline: Bangkok Journal; Thais With a Different Look, Flaunt Your Genes!
abstract: Generation of racially mixed Thais have all but taken over local fashion and entertainment industries; their success is product of revolution in popular taste--social transformation that has produced beginnings of new, more cosmopolitan Thailand; Sirinya Winsiri, who has American father and Thai mother, recalls being laughed at for her looks as child; has gone on to become leading model and country's first blue-eyed Miss Thailand; photos; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BELGIUM: Offices Searched; GERMANY: Business Confidence Falls; GERMANY: Axel Springer Profit Rises; FRANCE: Carrefour Profit Rises; BELGIUM: Fortis Profit Falls; HUNGARY: Vivendi To Sell Unit;.

headline: Does the Law Of Gravity Apply to The Dollar?
abstract: Edmund L Andrews Economic View column on view of bankers and finance officials from around the world that dollar is due for a drop after two decades in which US has run up steadily bigger trade deficits almost every year; graph (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Cable Deal Moves Closer To Approval
abstract: Comcast Corp and AT&T say waiting period under antitrust law for government questions about their proposed cable television merger has lapsed; say they will continue to cooperate with Justice Department on antitrust issues; graph of Comcast stock price (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Dale Lanier was named executive producer at the entertainment division of Colby & Partners, Santa Monica, Calif.

headline: Washington Allows a 12-Day Extension For U.N. Peacekeeping Mission in Bosnia
abstract: US agrees to another extension of United Nations peacekeeping mission in Bosnia without provision placing American peacekeepers beyond reach of new International Criminal Court; Sec Gen Kofi Annan, in letter to Sec of State Colin N Powell, argues that sort of politically motivated prosecution US fears is highly improbable, that Americans are putting entire UN peacekeeping system at risk and that proposed American provision 'flies in the face of treaty law' (M)

headline: Defying China, Taiwan Leader Backs a Vote On Sovereignty
abstract: Pres Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan says separate countries now exist on either side of Taiwan Strait and voices support for legislation authorizing referendum to declare Taiwan independent of China; statements are certain to anger Beijing; his comments are made in video teleconference with pro-independence Taiwanese in Tokyo; he also lends his support to pro-independence forces in his Democratic Progressive Party who want national Legislature to approve law making plebiscite on independence possible; this is closest Chen has come to endorsing independence since taking office two years ago; he does not actually say when or even whether referendum should be held (M)

headline: Radical Union Leaders Are Threatening a Hot British Summer
abstract: Resurgent British labor-union movement, egged on by new generation of radical leaders, is threatening summer of strikes in what would be biggest show of worker militancy in Britain in two decades; Prime Minister Tony Blair lost his closest union ally on July 20, when moderate Sir Ken Jackson was defeated by militant Derek Simpson in vote for general secretary of Amicus, nation's most moderate union (M)

headline: In Rare Move, U.N. Reviews A U.S. Attack On Afghans
abstract: United Nations aid mission reports probing July 1 American airstrike, Kakrak, Afghanistan, that reportedly killed over 50 civilians; probe is likely to embarrass United States military, which conducts own inquiry; Defense Department denies charges it covered up evidence of wrongdoing; foreign man involved in crash is arrested in explosive-packed car; allegedly was on way to Kabul and planned to crash car into vehicle transporting Pres Hamid Karzai (M)

headline: CENDANT TO CUT 300 HOTELS IN FRANCHISE SYSTEM
abstract: Cendant Corp, biggest franchiser of hotels, says it will increase number of poorly performing hotels it plans to cut from its system in effort to increase consumer satisfaction; will also cut 130 jobs, or 15 percent of positions inits lodging division; will shed as many as 300 hotels from its franchise system, or up to 40,000 rooms (S)

headline: A Firm Adds Staff and Woos Veterans Back Into the Fold
abstract: Article on scene at Fred Alger Management one year after Sept 11 terrorist attacks in World Trade Center cost firm lives of its chief investment officer David Alger and 20 of its 24 fund managers; says nine seasoned analysts and portfolio managers, many of whom worked at Alger early in their careers, have come back since last September, partly out of loyalty to Alger; firm has added employees beyond replacing 35 who died; Alger has staff of 245, or 15 more than it had before attacks; Alger manages more than $10 billion today, down from $13.2 billion before terrorist attacks; chairman Michael Murray, vice chairman James P Connelly Jr and David Hyun, former portfolio manager at Alger who rejoined firm, comments; photos (M)

headline: Germany Says April Arrests Thwarted Attacks on Jews
abstract: German Min Otto Schily, in news conference marking first anniversary of Sept 11 terrorist attacks in United States, says vigorous police work disrupted militant Islamic group of Palestinians and Jordanians that was plotting attacks on Israeli or Jewish targets in Germany; holds Apr arrest of 12 suspected members of group and indictment of Moroccan suspect Mounir el-Motassadeq in Sept 11 attacks show Germany has done its part in global anti-terrorism effort; apparently aims remarks at critics who say Germany should have done more to root out would-be terrorists; says anticrime agency has conducted 72 probes of Islamic terrorist groups; sees no evidence of plot against German targets on anniversary of Sept 11 attacks (M)

headline: Grieve Today, Mayor Says, And Then Grasp Tomorrow
abstract: Article in interview series Perspectives: Sept 11 and Beyond; Mayor Michael Bloomberg says that, like mourners who mark first anniversary of loved one's death by laying stone at grave, New Yorkers should take day to reflect on collective loss and then turn from grief to the future; says he understands that pain and grief may be unending for those who lost loved ones, but that his job is to balance memorializing with looking ahead, so that attack on World Trade Center becomes event of past rather than preoccupation of the present; talks while seated on bench amid tourists in Battery Park, seemingly unnoticed in way that predecessor Rudolph Giuliani would never have been; photo; his task is perhaps more daunting one of balancing conflicting demands of lower Manhattan residents, struggling businesses and victims' families, especially small but vocal group that accuses him of insensitivity; he says they do represent most families, that entire site cannot be memorial because people who live and work there need jobs, schools and shops (M)

headline: During Retirement, More Time to Explore
abstract: Burke Stinson letter identifies with July 7 article about how people retire in current times

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.75       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.25       Federal funds   1.75   1.72   3.73       3-month T-bills   1.60   1.58   3.43       6-month T-bills   1.55   1.55   3.35       10-yr. T-infl.   2.59   2.65   3.36       10-yr. T-note   4.21   4.29   5.16       30-yr. T-bond   5.16   5.22   5.60       Telephone bd.   7.29   7.37   7.74       Municipal bds.   5.15   5.16   5.27          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Private Sector; From Buffett, a Quirky Choice For New Accounting Board
abstract: Warren E Buffett suggests Carol Loomis, venerable Fortune magazine writer, as chairman of new Public Company Accounting Oversight Board, phone interview (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CONSECO INC., Carmel, Ind., an insurance and finance company, said it would sell its variable annuity business to privately held Inviva Inc., owner of the American Life Insurance Company of New York. Terms were not disclosed. The operation is one of six it plans to sell to pay down debt.

headline: Conditions Are Said to Improve in Iraq
abstract: United Nations official Benon V Savan reports that malnutrition and death rates are declining and education is improving in Iraq as result of UN program that supplies food, medicines and equipment (S)

headline: Weaker Dollar Has Yet to Spur a Boom in Exports
abstract: Commerce Department says trade deficit fell to $37.2 billion in June from $37.8 billion in May because of fourth consecutive month of rising exports; falling value of dollar has yet to spur boom in exports that could jump-start sputtering economic recovery; dollar settles at 118.69 yen in New York, up from 118.57 yen, while euro trades at 97.89 cents, up from 97.62 cents; graph; photo (M)

headline: Worries About Economy Fuel Another Selloff on Wall Street
abstract: All three major market gauges fell sharply today as new data on employment and some disappointing earnings reports stoked fears among investors.

headline: World Briefing: The Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Journalist'S Remains Recovered; ARGENTINA: Mercosur Impasse;.

headline: Personal Business; Companies Adding Benefits for Care of the Elderly
abstract: Employers find that absenteeism and loss of productivity among full-time workers diminishes when they are offered benefits to help them provide care for dependent elderly family members; photo (M)

headline: Expert Business Panel Puts Stock Options on a List of Reforms
abstract: Commission on Public Trust and Private Enterprise, panel of business leaders convened by Conference Board, proposes changes in way corporations pay top executives; calls for prior disclosure of executive stock sales and uniform treatment of stock options as expenses; Warren E Buffett, while not member of group, takes part in panel's news conference, endorsing report; deplores ratcheting up of compensation (M)

headline: Compressed Data; Happy Mac Becomes an Icon of the Past
abstract: Apple Computer has quietly dropped 'happy Mac' icon from new version of its computer operating system, replacing it with Apple logo; smiling icon has been first thing to greet Macintosh users as they start computers for 18 years; drawing (M)

headline: Less Optimism About Market
abstract: Survey sponsored by UBS and conducted by Gallup Organization finds less optimism among investors about stock markets at beginning of July than at any time since poll began in Oct 1996 (M)

headline: MALDEN MILLS IS EMERGING FROM BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: Malden Mills Industries, the maker of the Polartec fabrics used in cold-weather clothing, plans to emerge from bankruptcy protection and repay creditors in full (S)

headline: Japan Markets Resume Their Search for the Bottom
abstract: Japan's Nikkei stock index finishes erasing all its gains from one week ago, when nation's central bank startled investors by announcing unorthodox plan to buy company shares held by troubled commercial banks; Nikkei closes at 9,165.41; Mainichi newspaper reports Hakuo Yanagisawa, chief of Financial Services Agency, principal financial regulatory body in Japan, will resign because he opposes new plan to bail out banks with public funds; Yanagisawa says there is no truth to report; analysts say if Nikkei average falls below about 8,000, some of big banks will find themselves with too little capital to meet international standards (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Mass Grave May Hold Victims Of Stalin
abstract: Human rights group Memorial has unearthed mass grave near St Petersburg that may contain remains of as many as 30,000 victims of Russian leader Joseph Stalin's purge in 1937 and 1938; forensic experts say remains show evidence of executions (S)

headline: Court Tells Unocal to Face Rights Charges
abstract: Federal appellate court rules Unocal Corp must face trial in United States over claims of human-rights abuses involving villagers in Myanmar who worked on company's pipeline there; suit by villagers charges they were abused by military, which Unocal hired as security at pipeline (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Deported Family Can Appeal
abstract: High Court in London rules that Afghan family that was deported to Germany can appeal government's decision, but will have to do so from Germany (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SINGAPORE: Economic Growth; JAPAN: Trade Surplus Rises; TAIWAN: Chip Maker Offers Options; SOUTH KOREA: Shipping Concern Sold;.

headline: Brazil Teeters. Will It Be Contagious?
abstract: Brazil, South America's largest economy, could soon face mass corporate defaults unless it gets emphatic international financial support soon; its currency, the real, has lost 23 percent of its value against dollar in 2002; results of upcoming elections could determine international community's confidence in survival of Brazilian financial markets; their collapse would have big effect on both regional and global economies; photos; graphs (M)

headline: BLACK & DECKER REDUCES ANNUAL SALES ESTIMATES
abstract: Black & Decker Corp says Home Depot Inc will stop carrying some of company's Price Pfister plumbing products, reducing sales by about $15 million this year and $50 million annually; products will not be sold at Home Depot's stores in East and Midwest, but will be sold in Home Depot outlets in West (S)

headline: Clocking the Grand Prix to a Thousandth of a Tick
abstract: Article describes sophisticated methods for timekeeping in automobile racing; photos; illustration shows how system works (M)

headline: QWEST TO REFILE APPLICATIONS FOR LONG DISTANCE
abstract: Qwest Communications International withdraws applications to provide long-distance telephone service in nine states and will refile to address accounting concerns raised by Federal Communications Commission (S)

headline: G.I. Hit on Afghan Patrol In a Third Day of Attacks
abstract: American soldier is wounded by sniper's bullet while on patrol in southeastern Afghanistan, third day in row American troops come under attack while searching for members of Al Qaeda and Taliban; Col Roger King, chief United States military spokesman in Kabul, speculates that attacks could signal new offensive, though limited one made up of small groups of enemy soldiers; map (M)

headline: Not Enough Bidders for Bond Auction in Japan
abstract: Japan fails to receive enough bids for its 10-year government bond auction for first time in history, signaling investors' skepticism and confusion over direction of Japanese economy and government's economic policy; banks, traditionally largest purchasers of Japanese government debt, refrain from bidding, which is considered a seasonal phenomenon; setback eerily mimics precise plot of recent best-selling Japanese novel; surprising results of undersubscribed auction send stock and bond prices falling and yen tumbling to 123.35 to dollar from 121.42 the previous day; photo; graph of yen to dollar (M)

headline: North Korea's Leader Whistle-Stops in Siberia
abstract: Kim Jong Il of North Korea will meet with Pres Vladimir V Putin of Russia to discuss Russian plan to extend Trans-Siberian Railroad through Korea; rail route through North Korea to South Korea would cut costs and shipping times in half for containers that now go by sea from South Korea to Europe; projected half million South Korean containers a year could push Trans-Siberian Railroad into black; one stumbling block could be North Korea's military, which would be loathe to lose strategic advantage of bottling up South Korea on southern end of peninsula; photo; map (M)

headline: Corporate Apartments: A Real Home on the Road
abstract: There are about 71,000 corporate apartments across United States; corporate apartments are like hotels in some ways; they are furnished, and they often offer amenities like maid service and full-time concierge; but unlike hotel rooms, most corporate apartments are just that--apartments in standard residential complexes that are leased by third-party companies and subleased to business travelers, typically for two or three months; photo (M)

headline: A Brief Pause From Technology
abstract: D-Side Advisors president Charles DiLisio letter on Matt Richtel's September 8 Backslash column sees need to return to simpler, less technology-oriented times; drawing

headline: Vivendi Chief Said to Weigh Overhaul of Canal Plus
abstract: Vivendi Universal's chief executive Jean-Rene Fourtou is considering overhaul of Canal Plus Group, money-losing French pay television unit, including sale of some assets and creation of company that could be floated on stock market; core assets would be rolled into new company of which 51 percent would be sold to outside investors; Vivendi Universal would retain 49 percent; other assets not considered central would be sold piecemeal; new company would include Canal Plus, CanalSatellite, country's largest satellite distribution platform, and multiThematiques, national cable operator; Fourtou is expected to meet with Dominque Baudis, president of French media watchdog, to brief him on plan (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Dollar rises, settling at 97.34 cents against euro; graph (S)

headline: Ed Headrick, 78, Designer Of the Commercial Frisbee
abstract: Ed Headrick, who designed and patented the modern Frisbee, dies at age 78; photo (M)

headline: Swiss Bonanza for Bankers Fades in Flurry of Cutbacks
abstract: Swiss banks' hiring binge bursts, hurt by souring of world stock markets and banks' own excesses of ambition; banks shelve expansion plans, merge, retrench, cut costs and lay off workers in droves (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Terror Scare In Moscow
abstract: Man who threatened to blow up car filled with explosives near Moscow headquarters of Federal Security Service is arrested after standoff during which he demanded meeting with Pres Vladimir Putin; police search car and say he had no explosives (S)

headline: Tent City an Oasis of Hope For Afghanistan Refugees
abstract: Tent city in Zhare Dasht, Afghanistan, home to 6,000 war refugees, is seen as oasis despite no ground water or cooking fuel compared with other areas of southern Afghanistan where human misery afflict 500,000 uprooted by war and drought; United Nations World Food Program plans to distribute 43,000 tons of food, largely American wheat, in region this fall; little aid money has flowed beyond Kabul, and regional leaders fear that attention of US may turn to Iraq; some refugees comment; map; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Imagining the Future of the Jet
abstract: Walter B Gillette, in charge of Boeing's Sonic Cruiser commercial aircraft project, balances technical and business issues, attempting to bring plane to market in way that will insure radical craft's survival; many industry experts, including rival manufacturer Airbus Industrie, claim that Sonic Cruiser is ruse to mask Boeing's lack of real, impressive new products; photo (M)

headline: Delphi Wins G.M. Orders
abstract: Delphi Corp receives contracts to make steering columns of cars and light trucks, including full-size pickup and sport utility vehicles from General Motors Corp in 2003 model year; contracts valued at $1.68 billion over five years (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Steel Growth Possible
abstract: German heavy industry company ThyssenKrupp's steel-making subsidiary considers $180 million investment to build hot-galvanizing plant somewhere in United States (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Philippines: Brewer's Profit Falls
abstract: San Miguel, Philippine beer and food conglomerate, says first-half profit fell 21 percent, to 3.01 billion pesos ($58 million) (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Volvo Expects Order Growth
abstract: Volvo AB, maker of heavy trucks, expects strong increase in orders in Europe in second half because of demand for new models; graph (S)

headline: It's Almost September: Time to Help Parents
abstract: DIARY It's Almost September: Time to Help Parents.

headline: Suspicious Blasts Bring Fear of a Revived Afghan Conflict
abstract: Day's blasts in Kabul and near Bagram, along with rising incidence of explosions, bombings and other attacks and reports that warlord Gulbuddin Hekmatyar may be reassembling his troops, heighten concern that Afghanistan may be entering new conflict phase; Afghan officials say remnants of Taliban and Qaeda networks may be in early stages of coalescing with other armed opposition groups; say Hekmatyar seeks to convince Pashtun tribesmen in east to launch holy war against ethnic Tajik-dominated government; photo (M)

headline: Chase Counters Accusers In Disguised-Loan Case
abstract: J P Morgan Chase levels fraud charges against insurance companies that have accused it of plotting with Enron Corp to deceive them on surety bonds they issued to guarantee financial value of gas trades involving Enron, Chase and offshore entity called Mahonia Ltd; insurers, which refused to pay Chase's claim after Enron filed for bankruptcy, argue that they were deceived into believing that transactions, worth over $1 billion, involved actual delivery of gas to Mahonia when they were actually financing mechanism that used circular series of trades to pump huge loans into Enron in way that allowed company to avoid reporting it as debt; Chase, which is seeking to compel companies to pay, argues that insurers fully understood nature of transactions; first insurer involved is Liberty Mutual Insurance Co (M)

headline: Spain and Morocco Reach Deal To Vacate Uninhabited Islet
abstract: Spain and Morocco, under US pressure, formally end military standoff over uninhabited islet of Perejil; agree to improve highly charged relations between both countries; will leave islet free of flags or other symbols of sovereignty; representatives will meet in Madrid in September for talks to settle issue (S)

headline: Success of 'American Idol' To Spawn Many Copycats
abstract: TV program American Idol concluded week with record rating of nearly 23 million viewers for Fox network, but its influence as cultural and marketing phenomenon is only beginning; show will soon produce raft of ancillary products, including CD by winning contestant Kelly Clarkson and DVD of entire three-month run; new edition of American Idol will arrive in January, with much enthusiasm from advertisers; Fox hopes to beat wave of expected copycat shows, including country-music version from USA Networks and revival of Star Search on CBS; success of American Idol was partly fueled by relentless promotion by Fox, but it also received huge attention from competing media outlets; photos (M)

headline: FIDELITY NATIONAL INFORMATION TO BUY FACTUAL DATA
abstract: Fidelity National Information Solutions Inc, provider of data and software to real estate and mortgage companies, acquires rival Factual Data Corp for about $84 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Avocent To Buy 2C Computing For $22.8 Million
abstract: Avocent Corp agrees to buy closely held 2C Computing Inc for $22.8 million in cash (S)

headline: Next Big Health Debate: How to Help Uninsured
abstract: Employers and Congressional leaders, concerned that millions of workers are losing their health insurance coverage at time when health costs are surging, say next great health care debate will be over how to help uninsured; Sen John B Breaux and leaders of nation's largest pension plans are trying to drum up support for universal health insurance, proposal that has received little attention, except from labor unions and liberals, since collapse of Clintons' health plan; House Republican leaders--House Speaker J Dennis Hastert and Rep Dick Armey--have been working on package of less sweeping measures, including tax credits for uninsured, in hopes of defusing issue before Congressional elections this fall; Kate Sullivan, health policy director of US Chamber of Commerce, predicts that issue will heat up next month when Census Bureau announces number of uninsured last year, which may climb above 40 million--from 38.4 million in 2000--and when Kaiser Family Foundation reports latest double-digit increases in health costs; graph (M)

headline: U.S. Again Rejects Surrender of Mexican in a Corruption Case
abstract: Rogelio Montemayor, former director of Petroleos Mexicanos and prime suspect in corruption case involving company, tries for second time to surrender to authorities in US, but is turned away; challenges Mexican government to extradite him from US, arguing that case is one of politics, not law; US will not extradite suspect facing political charges; Mexico's comptroller general accuses former ruling part of diverting more than $170 million from Pemex to finance its campaign to stay in power (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Kashmir: Indians Meet Separatists
abstract: Delegation from Prime Min Atal Bihari Vajpayee offers separatist leaders in Jammu and Kashmir an invitation for talks, but is told that government must first release political prisoners, rescind security laws and halt rights violations (S)

headline: Change in Leadership at Marks & Spencer
abstract: Change in Leadership at Marks & Spencer**Luc Vandevelde will step aside as chief executive of British retailer Marks & Spencer in favor of his protege Roger Holmes; will remain chairman when he hands over to Holmes on Sept 1, but will cut back to part-time role beginning Jan 1; company reports total sales in first quarter ended June 30 rose 7.7 percent; adds its share of British clothing market has risen to around 11 percent, still below its peak, when it claimed more than 13 percent; photo (M)

headline: Zambian Leader Defends Ban On Genetically Altered Foods
abstract: Zambian Pres Levy Mwanawasa says government will continue to refuse corn that may be genetically modified, despite looming famine; says such food is 'poison' and his people will not be 'guinea pigs' comments at UN World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg; World Food Program is already feeding over million Zambians, with figure to approach 2.5 million by end of year; much of aid for region is from US, where crops genetically engineered for better production are widely grown and consumed (M)

headline: Jane B. Cook, 90, Board Member And an Heir at Dow Jones & Co.
abstract: Jane Bancroft Cook, an heir to Dow Jones & Co and member of its board for 36 years, dies at age 90 (M)

headline: Looking for Ways to Make Deregulation Keep Its Promises
abstract: Many mainstream economists prefer to tweak deregulation and repair its flaws rather than to tighten regulatory laws; six economists offer their views: James Poterba, Jonathan B Baker, Severin Borenstein, Lawrence J White, Eli M Noam and George A Akerlof; portraits (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Household Debt Grows
abstract: Bank of Korea says Korean households are in debt for $325 billion, 8 percent more than at end of first quarter; consumers borrowed 34 percent more in second quarter compared with quarter year earlier (S)

headline: Cable's Ultimate Endurance Test: Wiring the South Pole
abstract: Scientists and support staff at National Science Foundation's research station at South Pole have only sporadic link to outside world through obsolete and abandoned satellites that provide communications for 12-16 hours per day, depending on orbit patterns; several options are being considered for better link, including fiber-optic cable; some attendant difficulties in such a project discussed; drawing (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: New Feature Blocks Pop-Up Ads
abstract: EarthLink adds feature that will let subscribers block pop-up ads on Internet; claims it is first major Internet provider to make available free software that can prevent advertising windows from appearing above or below their main browser window; Earthlink acquired technology for service from FailSafe Technology Inc (S)

headline: Embattled, Scrutinized, Powell Soldiers On
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell's string of internal policy differences and defeats sets off speculation that he might resign; associates dismiss that notion, saying Powell is not man easily defeated; veteran diplomats say that while internal tensions and threatened resignations over foreign policy are not new in modern White House, current disagreements are worst since Reagan administration, when Defense Sec Caspar W Weinberger feuded with Secretary of State George P Shultz; almost from beginning Powell has found himself at odds with many of hard-line colleagues and Pres Bush himself on handling of foreign policy; on every issue, Powell has embraced president's position as his own, doing his best to justify administration's view to often-critical allies around world; aides and close friends say Powell's sense of discipline, loyalty and discretion means he never shows his true feelings publicly; photo (M)

headline: The War Against Spam
abstract: William R Serpe letter responds to June 27 article about ways to fight junk e-mail

headline: AOL Expects Internet Ads To Be Weak
abstract: AOL Time Warner says advertising on its America Online service this year will be 6 percent lower than its previous forecast, drop of $100 million; unit's pretax operating profit will also be $10 million below its expectations; AOL Time Warner says its other businesses are perfoming modestly better than expected and that it will meet its current profit and revenue targets for rest of year; some investors see announcement as sign that problems continue at company; company says earnings at America Online will be $1.7 billion for year; in July, it forecast earnings of $1.8 billion to $2.2 billion (M)

headline: Business; Far From Wall St., Martha Stewart Is Thriving
abstract: Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia begins first overseas expansion by entering 226 Seiyu department stores throughout Japan with Ms Stewart's brand-name products; first-year goal is for $11 million in monthly sales; Martha magazine and her television program spread popularity of her merchandise; analyst concludes that Japanese shoppers are unconcerned about probe of charges that she traded ImClone Systems stock on insider information; photos (M)

headline: Corruption Protest in China Leads to Charges, Top and Bottom
abstract: Several urban leaders in Liaoyang in northeastern China are jailed or fired after antigraft investigators from Beijing confirm accusations of fraud and theft made by protesting workers six months ago; four leaders of protests who were arrested remain behind bars; situation illustrates contradiction China's leaders face as they try to root out corruption; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Carrefour Profit Rises
abstract: Carrefour increased first-half profit 25 percent by cutting costs and prices; net income rose to 400 million euros ($393 million) from 320 million euros year earlier (S)

headline: Braving Nature and Militants, Hindus Trek for a Peek at a God's Icy Symbol
abstract: Thousands of Hindu pilgrims begin annual 19-mile trek high in Himalayan mountains of disputed territory of Kashmir, braving attacks from Muslim militants, for hurried glimpse of icy stalagmite shaped like phallus that forms each year on wall of remote Amarnath Cave and is believed to be symbol of Lord Shiva--one of Hinduism's three most revered Gods; threat of attacks by Muslims fighting for independent Kashmir has turned once-obscure pilgrimage into one of closely watched rites in ritual-filled India; more than 40 pilgrims have died in Muslim attacks over past two years; map; photo (L)

headline: COMMANDERS WANT ELITE UNITS FREED FROM QAEDA HUNT
abstract: Commanders in American military's most elite Special Operations unit reportedly want their troops freed from what they see as fruitless hunt in Afghanistan for Osama bin Laden; some have concluded that bin Laden was probably killed in American bombing raid at Tora Bora last Dec; they lack hard forensic evidence that would prove he is dead and they acknowledge their conclusions are deductive, drawn partly from lack of recent confirmed sightings or radio intercepts; other military and intelligence officials sharply disagree with their assessment; there is deepening debate under way among Special Operations leaders about how best to use super-secret counterterrorism forces, given Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld's push for expanded use of forces beyond Afghanistan to kill or capture terrorists; at least publicly, Rumsfeld and Pres Bush say they do not know whether bin Laden is alive or dead; Gen Tommy R Franks, commander of American miltary effort in Afghanistan, says he does not know bin Laden's fate (M)

headline: Nicotine-Laced Water Is a Drug, F.D.A. Rules
abstract: Food and Drug Administration says nicotine-laced bottled water, which is being marketed as dietary supplement, is unapproved drug and cannot be sold in US without federal clearance; product, Nico Water, fell in middle of debate about whether substances that contain nicotine, but do not make drug claims, should be classified as dietary supplements or drugs; Quick Test 5 is taking orders from overseas retailers (M)

headline: Drug Offers Hope With Resistant H.I.V., Scientists Say
abstract: Scientists at 14th International AIDS Conference in Barcelona, Spain, report T-20 or enfuvirtide, novel experimental drug, shows highly promising results in two large late-stage trials, offering new hope for thousands of patients who are infected with drug-resistant HIV; it is member of new class of drugs called fusion inhibitors, which attack virus that causes AIDS; photo; diagrams (M)

headline: A New Choice For Flying Coast to Coast
abstract: DB Air Ltd, New England air charter company, plans to enter New York-to-Los Angeles market beginning Dec 1 with charter flights on specially configured airliners; will offer one round-trip flight five days per week between Burbank Airport near Los Angeles and Kennedy International Airport; fares will be same as business-class service on scheduled transcontinental flights; chief operating officer Gregory Raiff comments (M)

headline: Joaquín Balaguer, 95, Dies; Dominated Dominican Life
abstract: Joaquin Balaguer, former president of Dominican Republic, dies at age 95; photo (M)

headline: New Campaign For Pert Plus
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co has begun first ad campaign in almost two years for its Pert Plus hair care line; $25 million campaign was created by Leo Burnett USA (S)

headline: When Times Are Hard, Household Names Shine
abstract: Kenneth N Gilpin, in Market Insight column, interviews Merrill Lynch household products and cosmetics analyst Carol Warner Wilke about outlook for dozen companies she follows; photo (M)

headline: Growth Up in Japan in Quarter, But Pace Already Seems to Fade
abstract: Japan's economy grew moderately in second quarter, first expansion in more than year, thanks to rising exports and increase in consumer spending, but tepid figures suggest country's mild recovery is already losing momentum; figures show that Japan remains dependent for its economic health on growth in its export markets, expecially US; Japan's six-month-old economic expansion risks collapse with many of those markets flagging; Prime Min Junichiro Koizumi is under pressure to find ways to increase growth at home and limit country's vulnerability to any slowing of exports; economy expanded 0.5 percent, or 1.9 percent at annual rate, in three months to June; photo (M)

headline: Biztech : Internet phone calling:A firm fails to connect
abstract: SEOUL—  Kim Dae Sun, vice president of Serome Technology Inc., avoided the usual euphemisms for the disasters that have befallen his once pioneering and high-flying company.

headline: G.M. TO RESUME NO-INTEREST LOANS ON 2002 MODELS
abstract: General Motors Corp will offer 60-month no-interest loans on remaining 2002 models, matching rivals' offers (S)

headline: Investing; Is There Hidden Gold In Industrial Metals?
abstract: Analysts comment on prospects for companies industrial (or 'base') metals industry, whose stocks are cyclical by nature and tend to suffer modestly during recession and soar in price with economic recovery; graph (M)

headline: US Air Reaches Deal to Reduce Pay of Pilots
abstract: US Airways and its pilots' union reach tentative agreement that will cut $465 million per year from pilots' wages and benefits; pilots also agree to let US Airways increase its number of regional jets to 465 (M)

headline: WESTAR ENERGY REPORTS RECEIVING SUBPOENAS
abstract: Federal grand jury seeks documents and testimony about use of Westar Energy's aircraft and about its chief executive, David C Wittig; demand follows company's announcement that it will limit pay and perks of Wittig and other executives (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Population Still Shrinking
abstract: Russia State Statistics Committee reports population decline of 505,900 in first six months of 2002, to 143.4 million (S)

headline: Bausch Loses Bid To Lift Ban on Lens
abstract: Bausch &

headline: E.D.S. Stock Falls 18% on WorldCom Fears
abstract: Shares of Electronic Data Systems fall 18 percent after company says financial troubles of WorldCom, client for its computer services, might hurt its profit and after move by Congress to halt Navy orders for EDS computer workstations; EDS ends talks with Procter & Gamble for contract to manage computers and back-office operations (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.50       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.00       Federal funds   n/a   1.72   2.13       3-month T-bills   1.66   1.65   2.56       6-month T-bills   1.64   1.63   2.57       10-yr. T-infl.   2.26   2.26   3.25       10-yr. T-note   3.91   3.91   4.62       30-yr. T-bond   4.76   4.77   5.42       Telephone bd.   6.45   6.48   5.55       Municipal bds.   4.83   4.93   5.15          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Pension Woes Bring Business Wealth Effect
abstract: Floyd Norris column says combination of poor stock market returns and low interest rates threaten many companies with defined pension plans, like General Motors Corp, whose retirement benefits plans, including pensions and health care, have unfinanced liabilities of $61 billion, up from $34 billion in 1999; graph (M)

headline: 10-Month Afghan Mystery: Is bin Laden Dead or Alive?
abstract: Whereabouts of Osama bin Laden remains mystery since last sighting nearly 10 months ago in mountains of southeastern Afghanistan after Al Qaeda's main base at Tora Bora was destroyed by intense American bombing; glimpses of bin Laden and entourage of Arab militants have been reported by tribespeople on both sides of Afghan-Pakistan border since bombing in December; many of tipoffs have been little more than hearsay and others have been prevarications by Qaeda sympathizers; although raids have led to arrests of scores of Arab militants, none have produced solid leads to bin Laden's whereabouts and $25 million reward offered for information leading to capture of bin Laden has not been claimed; bounty has coincided with ancient tribal traditions of secrecy in region of widespread poverty; abiding suspicion of outsiders and profoundly conservative form of Islam have favored Qaeda fugitives and isolated American pursuers; maps; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: CALPINE, San Jose, Calif., a power producer, agreed to sell oil and natural gas properties in Alberta, Canada, to NAL Oil and Gas Trust and another institutional investor for $81 million.    PRINCIPAL FINANCIAL GROUP, Des Moines, the largest provider of 401(k) retirement plans, said its board had authorized it to repurchase up to $300 million of the company's stock.

headline: When The Glitz Gives Way To Gloom
abstract: Interview with independent analyst Harold Vogel on outlook for media conglomerates; photo (M)

headline: The Export-Import Bank: Who Is Helping Whom?
abstract: California Space Authority chief executive Robert M Davis letter on September 1 article on credit aid given by Export-Import Bank of US holds satellite buyer's wealth and manufacturer's politics are irrelevant

headline: Leader of Madagascar Flees His Country
abstract: With enemy troops closing in on his last remaining stronghold, Didier Ratsiraka, the leader of Madagascar, left his country today, officials said.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Pay Package Is Endorsed
abstract: Vodafone claims victory in battle with minority shareholders on compensation of chief executive, Sir Christopher Gent; says almost 85 percent of investors had approved his pay; company notes Sir Christopher received equivalent of $3.8 million in pay, shares and pension benefits in year to March (S)

headline: Market Place; All Sides Praise Deal Dissolving Time Warner Entertainment
abstract: Comcast Corp appears to be big winner in three-way deal to dissolve Time Warner Entertainment; deal would clear one of last potential roadblocks to Comcast's plan to acquire AT&T Corp's cable unit by removing potential conflict of interest between AOL Time Warner, owner of nation's second-largest cable operation, and AT&T Comcast, which would be largest cable player; deal would also enable Comcast to turn Time Warner Entertainment stake into cash eventually and that would presumably allow Comcast to pay down some of debt it will incur in $47 billion takeover of AT&T's cable division; deal will allow Comcast to strike potentially revenue-rich agreement in which AOL Time Warner will pay generously for AT&T Comcast's cable systems to provide high-speed cable access to subscribers of America Online Internet service; high-speed-access agreement could be step toward revitalizing America Online unit; Comcast president Brian L Roberts and AOL Time Warner chief executive Richard D Parsons comment; photo (Market Place) (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Avnet Plans To Cut 775 Jobs
abstract: Avnet Inc plans to cut 775 jobs, or 5 percent of its work force, because of faltering sales of microprocessors and disk drives for personal computers; also expects fourth-quarter results to be less than expected; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Germany: Victory For Gays And Lesbians
abstract: German gays and lesbians score legal victory when Constitutional Court rejects complaint by some conservative-governed states that gay marriages contradict family values enshrined in Constitution (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Interest Rate Cut
abstract: Brazil's central bank lowers its crucial interest rate to 18 percent from 18.5 percent, dropping its anti-inflationary posture and saying it believes inflation next year will remain below its 4 percent target (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Expedia Snubs Buyout Offer
abstract: Expedia director's committee says travel Web site has 'excellent' prospects as stand-alone company, rebuffing tentative buyout offer from its majority shareholder, USA Interactive (S)

headline: Senate Backs Tough Measures To Punish Corporate Misdeeds
abstract: Senate endorses broad new criminal penalties for corporate officers who cheat investors or harm employee pensions, highlighted by penalty of up to 10 years in prison for executives who recklessly or willfully allow their companies to publish misleading financial statements; votes to extend amount of time in which defrauded investors and plaintiffs' lawyers can sue corporations; measures, approved by unanimous votes, go beyond proposals put forward by Pres Bush and legislation passed by House, but some senators, including John McCain, believe they still do not go far enough; photo (M)

headline: Job Seekers Must Create Networks of Contacts
abstract: Career management firm Bernard Haldane Associates chairman Jerold Weinger suggests ways job seekers can improve their networks of contacts and, therefore, employment prospects (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Some Orders Delayed
abstract: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co, supplier of made-to-order chips, says some customers asked to delay delivery on their orders as personal computer sales stalled; delay in shipments for orders already placed comes as company braces for decline in demand; senior vice president Kenneth Kin comments (S)

headline: Albert J. Costello, 66, Ex-Chief Of W. R. Grace & Company
abstract: Albert J. Costello, former chairman, president and chief executive of W. R. Grace & Company, died on Tuesday while playing golf at the Arcola Country Club in Paramus, N.J. He was 66 and lived in Franklin Lakes, N.J.    The cause was evidently related to heart problems he had had, said his son, Peter.

headline: New Generation of DVD Is a Boon to Multimedia
abstract: Q. A few weeks ago you wrote about Super Audio CD; what is this other new format, DVD-Audio?    A. DVD-Audio is another high-fidelity format designed to produce music on discs that sounds richer and more detailed than what standard compact-disc technology currently yields.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nortel Sells California Offices
abstract: Nortel Networks Corp sells office building in California's Silicon Valley to South Bay Development Co for about $23 million (S)

headline: Kotor Journal; On a Balkan War's Last Day, Trouble From the Sky
abstract: Montenegro scientists search for bullets coated with slightly radioactive depleted uranium fired by American warplanes at Kotor on last day of NATO's 1999 air campaign against Yugoslavia; have collected scores of bullets and fragments, but fear many uranium parts have disintegrated into potentially toxic dust; question reason for attack; work is first thorough cleanup in Balkans, where NATO says it fired thousands of rounds of such bullets, which can penetrate tanks; photo (M)

headline: AIDS Scourge in Rural China Leaves Villages of Orphans
abstract: AIDS is creating explosion of destitute orphans in China's rural heartland and is driving large numbers of families into such dire poverty that they can no longer afford to feed or clothes their children; in small village of Donghu there are 20 orphans where last year there were none, all because of AIDS; residents estimate that 200 of village's 600 families have one parent dead and other ill, often too frail to work or even rise from bed; they receive little government help; experts say blow dealt by AIDS to villages like Donghu has been sharper and crueler than anywhere else in world because of unusual and efficient way disease is spread there; in 1990's, nearly entire adult population of some villages was infected almost simultaneously as poor farmers flocked en masse to sell their blood at blood collection stations whose unsterile practices introduced hefty doses of HIV directly into their veins; now victims are falling ill and dying, almost in unison; selling blood was not banned in China until mid-90's; photos; map (L)

headline: Durres Journal; From This Poisoned Place, the Poor Can't Escape
abstract: Durres Journal on shantytown along Albanian coast that is built atop highly toxic site of closed chemical plant; photo; map; UN has desigated site 'environmental diaster area' that poses grave risks to health of poor people who have no place else to go (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Sudan: Government Halts Talks
abstract: Sudanese government suspends peace talks with Sudan People's Liberation Army after group seizes strategic town of Torit during negotiations; fighting has continued throughout negotiations (S)

headline: China Struggles To Cut Reliance On Mideast Oil
abstract: China looks to develop new sources of oil and natural gas within its borders and from Russia, Indonesia and Australia in effort to cut its growing dependence on oil from Mideast; booming economy and rising sales of cars has transformed China from net exporter of oil as recently as 1993 to big oil importer; US-China Security Review Commission, group created by Congress, warns that China's dependence on foreign oil to fuel its economic development has given it incentive to become closer to Iran, Iraq and Sudan, countries accused by State Dept of supporting terrorism; Middle East now supplies three-fifths of China's oil imports; China accounts for quarter of world's growth in oil use over last decade; during last several years it has been fastest-growing consumer of oil; consortium of domestic and foreign energy companies announced in July that it would spend $3.3 billion to develop gas fields in western China and $5.2 billion for pipeline to carry gas across country; photo; map (M)

headline: Exxon Loses Court Ruling
abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp must pay 54 Texas gasoline-station owners almost $10 million for breach of contract after losing federal appeals court ruling; owners, franchisees based in Houston and Corpus Christi, accused Exxon of trying to drive them out of business so it could convert their stations into company-operated stores; court upholds October 2000 ruling in station owners' favor by district court (S)

headline: Personal Business; Term Insurance Turns Long Term
abstract: Thirty-year term life insurance policies have quietly become available in New York for first time; advantages and disadvantages of such policies noted (M)

headline: U.S. Seeks Russian Support on Iraq
abstract: The White House expressed guarded optimism after a meeting with Russian ministers, while Russian officials said more dialogue was needed.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Czech Republic: Vandals Hit Jewish Sites
abstract: Vandals attack synagogue and memorial to Holocaust victims in Czech Republic spa town of Karlovy Vary (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: EMC And Accenture Team Up On Storage Networks
abstract: EMC Corp will team up with Accenture to sell corporate-consulting services for storage networks; financial terms of five-year agreement are undisclosed (S)

headline: Charles's Leaked Letters Land Him in Hot Water
abstract: Prince Charles, heir to British throne, is embroiled in embarrassing public dispute over his habit of writing to government ministers with letters tilting at red tape, political correctness and creeping invasion of 'blame culture' in Britain; newspapers have leaked contents of letter he reportedly wrote to Prime Min Tony Blair covering several matters, including what he sees as growing intrusiveness of social regulations; prince's contrarian forays have drawn rebukes before; photo (M)

headline: Two Inquiries Are Reported On Stock Picks Of Analyst
abstract: Jack B Grubman, telecommunications analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, is under scrutiny by US attorney in Southern District of New York and is also under investigation by National Association of Securities Dealers; has been subject of investigation for months by New York Atty Gen Eliot L Spitzer; has also been target of numerous lawsuits by investors who contend that he misled them with his relentlessly upbeat reports about industry even as companies in it were plummeting in value; subject of NASD investigation is series of upbeat research reports that Grubman wrote about Winstar Communications, which filed for bankruptcy last April; investigation, reported in Wall Street Journal, was made public on Grubman's regulatory record, which is administered by NASD, on July 18; record says association's enforcement division made preliminary determination that violations of securities regulations occurred in Grubman's research on Winstar; NASD spokesman declines comment; photo (M)

headline: SHAW WILL BUY POWER PLANT IT IS BUILDING IN MISSISSIPPI
abstract: Shaw Group, construction company that has been building 1,200 megawatt power plant in Mississippi, says that it will buy plant from its owner, NRG Energy, because NRG is unable to make scheduled payment on plant (S)

headline: Former Sunbeam Chief Agrees To Ban and a Fine of $500,000
abstract: Sunbeam Corp's former chief executive Albert J Dunlap agrees to pay $500,000 fine and to accept being banned from ever serving as officer or director of public company; neither admits nor denies allegations by Securities and Exchange Commission that he engineered large accounting fraud that inflated profits of Sunbeam after he was hired to turn company around in 1996; Sunbeam former chief financial officer Russell A Kersh also settles charges by SEC, agreeing to pay $200,000; Dunlap says he did not take any money from selling Sunbeam stock before those shares collapsed and company went into bankruptcy last year; photo (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.75       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.25       Federal funds   1.75   1.79   3.69       3-month T-bills   1.58   1.64   3.46       6-month T-bills   1.55   1.62   3.33       10-yr. T-infl.   2.65   2.73   3.36       10-yr. T-note   4.29   4.39   5.16       30-yr. T-bond   5.22   5.29   5.58       Telephone bd.   7.37   7.35   7.75       Municipal bds.   5.16   5.18   5.26          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Deals Within Telecom Deals
abstract: During telecommunications mania, many executives at large, established companies received gifts of or discounts on stock in equipment suppliers to whom they would then give business; many such deals are not disclosed in company filings; telecommunications executives, already making millions on stock options from their own companies, were able to further enrich themselves through holdings in suppliers; photos; drawing; table of 100 telecommunications insiders who made biggest profits selling stock in own companies before shares plunged (M)

headline: Spending by Consumers Is Surging in Thailand
abstract: Loose fiscal policies in Thailand have fueled surge in consumer spending that has helped Thailand produce jobs despite sluggish exports, putting its economy on course to grow 4 percent this year; government says economy grew at annual rate of 5.1 percent in second quarter; fastest rate in two years; exports rose for first time in 10 months, rising 3.4 percent; consumer confidence is at its highest level since financial crisis in 1997 and 1998, and retail sales are rising as much as 10 percent per year; photo (M)

headline: Germans Vote in a Tight Election in Which Bush, Hitler and Israel Became Key Issues
abstract: Germans vote Sunday in one of the closest elections of the postwar era with the Social Democrats of Chancellor Gerhard Schröder running only slightly ahead of the conservative alliance led by Edmund Stoiber in a race that is too tight to call.    It has been an aggressive campaign, tainted by accusations of anti-Americanism and anti-Semitism, and one that has broken some of the country's long-held taboos and challenged some traditional assumptions about the Germans.

headline: Cost-Cutting Can Start A Ruinous Circle
abstract: Louis Uchitelle Economic View column on threat to economy posed by wave of corporate cost-cutting; graph (M)

headline: 100 Steps. One Picture.
abstract: Matsushita Electric of America chief executive Don Iwatani reflects, writing in The Boss column, on his youth, his wife and his love of coffee and photography; photo (M)

headline: 'Sopranos' Draws Record Viewers to HBO
abstract: Fourth-season premiere of The Sopranos attracts 13.4 million viewers, record for HBO and for any cable channel this year and third-most-watched show on cable television since 1994; graph of show's expanding audience (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AMERICAN EXPRESS CO., New York, , said it bought Dynamic Ideas, Cambridge, Mass., a mutual fund analysis and investment company. Terms were not disclosed.    APARTMENT INVESTMENT AND MANAGEMENT CO., Denver, said it agreed to purchase 11 apartment properties in the Boston area for $500 million.

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Vivendi Gets License To Develop Marvel Comics Games
abstract: Vivendi Universal Publishing Corp signs 10-year licensing agreement with Marvel Enterprises to use 4,700 superheroes and characters in Internet-based video games; graph (S)

headline: Hebron Settlers Attack Palestinian Neighborhood
abstract: Jewish settlers in Hebron attack Palestinian neighborhood following funeral of Staff Sgt Elazar Leibovich, soldier fatally shot during ambush; kill teenage girl, beat several journalists and battle Israeli police (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: September crude oil rises 19 cents, to $26.86 a barrel; graph; table (S)

headline: Clinton Pretty Much Dismisses Idea of a TV Talk Show
abstract: Former Pres Bill Clinton, speaking on Larry King Live on CNN, says definitely that he will not become talk show host, at least in short term; says talk show might interest him in future; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Trade Surplus Rises
abstract: Japan's merchandise trade surplus grew for fourth consecutive month on back of strong exports to Asia and shrinking imports; surplus hit 1.3 trillion yen ($11.1 billion) in June, 71.4 percent above June 2001; exports were up 8.9 percent, while imports slipped 5.1 percent; trade surplus with US grew 5.6 percent as yen's rise during period made Japanese goods more expensive in dollar terms (S)

headline: Market Place; Theater Chain Still Slumps After Revealing Its Loan Deals
abstract: AMC Entertainment, one of nation's largest movie theater chains, suffers continuing share price plunge as investors fear that loans it made to and then forgave its top executives may have been part of deal to shift control of company to buyout firm Apollo Management; share price graph (M)

headline: Russian Officials Uncover Mass Grave in Chechnya
abstract: A prominent human rights organization said today that the grave contained the bodies of at least seven Chechens who had been arrested during Russian security operations in May.

headline: Test Flight Advances Plan for Regular Inter-Korean Air Link
abstract: North Korean jetliner makes roundtrip test flight to South Korea, first step in opening regular air links between both countries; map; photo (M)

headline: Sting of Last Year's Recession Was Not as Mild as Many Think
abstract: US economy looks weaker now than it did in summer and possibility of war with Iraq has created new uncertainty, leaving Federal Reserve officials to decide whether to cut interest rates for 12th time since start of 2001; National Bureau of Economic Research says employment has declined 1.2 percent, or by more than 1.5 million jobs, since March 2001, which was start of recession; adds decline is slightly worse than average falloff after last six recessions; economy appears to have performed better in period surrounding most recent recession than during previous period, but it has actually been worse in ways that more directly affect workers and businesses; graphs (M)

headline: Cuban-American Honored for Agriculture Innovations
abstract: Pedro Sanchez, soil scientist who pioneered methods for reviving tropical agriculture while saving threatened rain forests, wins $250,000 World Food Prize at ceremonies in Toronto; Sanchez is chairman of United Nations Task Force on World Hunger; award recognizes his decades of work to improve agricultural yields from depleted soil while protecting environment in South America, Southeast Asia and Africa (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Soybean Processer Acquired; BRITAIN: Stagecoach Fires Executive; A RESTRICTION ON OLD CASH; IRELAND: New Jobs At Mbna; THE NETHERLANDS: Insurer Expects Loss;.

headline: World Briefing: Americas
abstract: PARAGUAY: Emergency Lifted; CANADA: Province Won'T Appeal Same-Sex Ruling;.

headline: SOUTHWEST AIRLINES REDUCES ITS HIGHEST FARES 25%
abstract: Southwest Airlines reduces its highest one-way ticket price 25 percent; cut, to $299 from $399, applies even to tickets bought at last minute (S)

headline: 'Doing nothing is not an option,' president declares : Bush tells Congress he'll confer over Iraq
abstract: WASHINGTON:—  President George W. Bush promised legislators Wednesday that he would seek congressional approval, and foreign understanding, before taking any action against Iraq, which he accused of "stiffing the world" by continuing to rearm.

headline: World Business Briefing | Australia: Australia: Telstra Profit Falls
abstract: Telstra reports 10 percent decline in net profit in year to July, from $2.21 billion to $2 billion, despite 2 percent increase in sales; revenue was up 10 percent in period; graph (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Croatia: Tribunal Indicts Ex-General
abstract: United Nations war crimes tribunal at Hague indicts Janko Bobetko, 83,

headline: Nasdaq Wins Battle at S.E.C. On New System For Trading
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission approves use of new automated trading system for Nasdaq stock market; system, which cost Nasdaq more than $100 million to develop and has been repeated stymied by lobbying efforts of its rapidly growing competitors, will let investors view orders placed through variety of marketplaces that are now separate from one another; architects of system say that by posting stock prices and orders from all market participants and rivals, new system--known as SuperMontage--will enable stock traders to pick from variety of sources for lowest buy and highest sell prices; competiting trading companies including Instinet, subsidiary of Reuters Group, and Archipelago have steadily eroded Nasdaq's trading business to point that they now say they executive more than half trades in Nasdaq stocks; rivals have complained that Nasdaq's new system would create would create new and anticompetitive marketplace (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Says Other Nations Promise to Aid Attack on Iraq
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld tells Congress that several countries have privately pledged direct military support for any offensive against Iraq; makes claim hours after Congressional leaders say vote will be held before Nov election on whether to authorize Pres Bush to take whatever military action he deems necessary; White House says it will send to Congress as early as Sept 19 wording of proposed resolution authorizing action; Bush is said to be worried that Saddam Hussein's new offer of weapons inspections could delay effort to force both rapid disarmament of Iraq and fall of its government; Rumsfeld, in testimony in Congress, argues that inspections in Iraq would be unlikely to lead to elimination of its weapons of mass destruction; Democrats appear to be swayed by Rumsfeld's argument that, unlike what happened before Sept 11 terrorist attacks, administration is 'connecting the dots' on Iraq before it can use weapons of mass destruction or put them in hands of terrorists; photos (M)

headline: Bush and Democrats Still Deeply Split on What Needs to Be Done
abstract: Democratic-sponsored accounting and corporate-reform proposals under debate in Senate go further than plan offered by Pres Bush; administration releases statement of its policy indicating that Bush believes some of Senate proposals go too far; Bush administration says it wants some curbs on power of new accounting regulatory board proposed by bill's Democratic sponsors to oversee profession; administration favors new board but says only Securities and Exchange Commission should have power to investigate and enforce securities laws; administration would also like to scale back provision of bill that would restrict services accounting firms can sell; also wants higher threshold of misdeeds by corporate executives and directors than Democrats propose before culprits can be barred from ever holding similar jobs again; Democrats say Bush's proposals do little to address problems; administration attacks central provision of Senate bill by Sen Paul S Sarbanes that would ban accounting firms from offering nine types of consulting and other services to publicly traded clients for whom they already serves as auditor; provision is meant to ensure auditors do not relax their scrutiny in order to please company that pays them lot of money for nonaudit services; chart; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Industrial Slowdown
abstract: British manufacturing has its worst decline in more than 22 years in June; decline put at 5.3 percent (S)

headline: Silicon Valley, Without All the Trimmings
abstract: Current dot-com bust in California's Silicon Valley is forcing some recently affluent high-technology workers to quietly give up luxury goods they bought during boom as they struggle to downsize lifestyles; suffering is shared both at low end, where people are unemployed, and at high end, where reserves are running thin; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Revving Up the Labs at Pfizer
abstract: Profile of Dr Peter B Corr, new chief of research at Pfizer; notes that overcoming recent lack of new discoveries is crucial to company, especially in light of its proposed purchase of Pharmacia and additional research operations that would add if shareholders and government regulators approve merger; photo (M)

headline: Upheaval at Bertelsmann May End Plans for Acquisition of Napster
abstract: Thomas Middelhoff's ouster from Bertelsmann may be crippling blow for Napster, bankrupt online music service that Middelhoff championed; people in negotiations to revive Napster say that Bertelsmann may now be less inclined to purchase service from bankruptcy or to spend tens of thousands of dollars to settle copyright infringement lawsuits brought by major record companies and obtain licenses from them to sell their music online (M)

headline: Mexico Plays a North-South Divide
abstract: Some Mexicans disapproved of Pres Vicente Fox's visit to South America this month to increase ties with Brazil and Argentina, fearing that their country will become more likely to contract economic illness afflicting its southern neighbors; Fox, toured region, signed limited trade agreements and promised to integrate Mexico hemispheric free trade organization by 2006, but walked fine line, portraying trip as way for Mexico to show solidarity with its struggling Latin American neighbors while not suggesting to international investors that Mexico is casting its financial lot with them; benefits of partnership with US and Canada have been huge; $254 billion in trade with US last year accounted for about 78 percent of Mexico's total, while $7.3 billion in trade with Canada accounted for additional 2 percent; large part of Mexico's economic stability is result of its anchoring to North American Free Trade agreement; Mexico still feels strong cultural connection to rest of Latin America despite economic benefits of trade with US and Canada; photo (M)

headline: Denny's Selects A Unit of Publicis
abstract: Denny's restaurant chain names Publicis in Mid America to handle its advertising account, which had been handled by West Wayne; plans separate reviews for agencies to handle advertising aimed at black and Hispanic consumers (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: INDIA: Industrial Output Grows; JAPAN: Fujitsu Cuts Jobs;.

headline: CarMax Spinoff Approved
abstract: Shareholders of Circuit City Stores vote to split off CarMax Group, used-car division, effective Oct 1, when unit will become separate publicly traded company (S)

headline: Another 7,000 Jobs to Be Cut As Lucent Reports More Loses
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc announces $7.91 billion loss for fiscal third quarter and 7,000 more layoffs; company lost $3.24 billion in same quarter last year; revenue was $2.95 billion, compared with $5.37 billion year ago; chief executive Patricia F Russo says company is on road to profitability (M)

headline: Allen E. Murray, 73, Chief Who Refocused Mobil on Oil
abstract: Allen E Murray, chairman and chief executive of Mobil from 1985 to 1994, dies at age 73; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: New Police Chief
abstract: Hugh Orde takes over as chief constable of Police Service of Northern Ireland; brief profile (S)

headline: Patents; Kitchen convenience marches on: a dishwasher built into the table, an online fridge and a stirring arm.
abstract: Harold DeHart patents dining table with integral dishwasher; necessary lines are routed to dishwasher from floor beneath table; Lanna Eisaman and Jennifer Bradford patent portable stirring machine that can be placed over pot or pan on stove or counter; Young Hoon Roh, Kwang Choon Kim and Jin Cheol Cho patent refrigerator that offers Internet access and can provide diverse entertainments; Antoine Sfeir patents spring-loaded mounting bracket with foot lever to enable people to open refrigerators with hands full; drawing of table with dishwasher (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Chip Maker's Loss Narrows
abstract: Leading computer chip maker Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing Ltd reports its second-quarter loss narrowed to $90.7 million, compared with loss of $107.6 million year ago; sales rose 27 percent (S)

headline: G.E. Perks Raise Issues About Taxes
abstract: Disclosure in former General Electric chief executive John F Welch Jr's divorce action that GE paid many of his living expenses raises questions of why GE did not more fully disclose data and who should pay taxes on benefits; include lifetime use of palatial Manhattan apartment, complete with amenities, access to GE's aircraft, car and driver and tickets to top events; corporate governance experts question perks and whether company's compensation committee had independence needed to say no to Welch; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Envoy Says Pakistan Has Slowed Rebels' Push Into Kashmir
abstract: Deputy Secretary of State Richard L Armitage concludes round of talks with leaders from Pakistan and India and credits Pakistan with reducing cross-border infiltrations by Muslim guerrillas that have increased tensions between nuclear-armed rivals (M)

headline: TYCO REPORT TO THE S.E.C. IS EXPECTED TODAY
abstract: Tyco International Ltd plans to file report with Securities and Exchange Commission that will disclose results of internal investigation into company's corporate governance and accounting practices; is expected to disclose that millions of dollars of previously undisclosed loans were made to dozens of employees and later forgiven on instructions of former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski; filing is result of internal investigation by lawyer David Boies and staff of his firm Boies, Schiller & Flexner (S)

headline: U.S. Backs Off Immunity Fight Involving Court
abstract: Bush administration retreats from demand that American peacekeepers be given blanket immunity from prosecution by new International Criminal Court, proposing instead that court not investigate or prosecute officials or personnel of United Nations missions for a year, after which Security Council would vote to renew arrangement; has been harshly criticized on issue by some of its closest allies, particularly Canada and Mexico, and some UN members continue to question propriety of allowing Security Council to tamper with treaty that established court (M)

headline: Where Gentrification Meets the Marine Corps
abstract: where gentrification meets the marine corps**Oceanside, Calif, and Oceanside Crossing shopping mall hope to catch wave of resort development that is sweeping up coast; Crown Realty and Development buys shopping center, gambling that Oceanside is poised to benefit from northward wave of gentrification that has already swept up coast through Del Mar, La Jolla and Carlsbad; photo (M)

headline: Musharraf Redraws Pakistan's Constitution
abstract: President Pervez Musharraf imposed 29 amendments that expand his control of the country. The changes could allow him to dissolve the elected Parliament.

headline: Getting From Here to There . . .
abstract: America Online plans to introduce the 8.0 version of its software in October. Here are some of the features it hopes will stem defections by its members.

headline: My Identity for Hire? Why Not!
abstract: Abby Elin Preludes column explores issue of companies' sponsorship of individuals' personal events and lives; collage (M)

headline: Cheney's Role In Acquisition Under Scrutiny
