abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney's tenure as chief executive of Halliburton is under scrutiny from government investigators and his political opponents; Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating changes made by company in its accounting practices for construction projects while Cheney was in charge; another matter being probed is Halliburton's acquisition in 1998 of Dresser Industries, deal championed by Cheney, which has ended up saddling company with growing costs of legal claims stemming from asbestos in products made by Dresser and former Dresser subsidiary; at issue now is whether Halliburton under Cheney was aggressive enough in investigating asbestos liabilities it was taking on in acquiring Dresser, and whether it adequately informed shareholders of risks at time they were asked to approve deal; Halliburton's stock prices have fallen sharply as result of asbestos liability; Cheney sold nearly $40 million in Halliburton stock when he left company, when stock was selling at $50 per share; it now is $13.20 a share; timeline showing activity of Halliburton stock since 1998(M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: I.B.M. To Sell An Old Site
abstract: IBM will sell its operations in Endicott, NY, to group of local investors called Endicott Interconnect Technologies as part of retrenchment plan; Endicott Interconnect will invest $100 million to buy and try to sustain local operations (S)

headline: Range of Fears Pushes Stocks To Big Losses
abstract: Stock prices fall sharply, led by technology shares, pushing Nasdaq composite index to its lowest level in more than five years on worries about additional accounting scandals, new terrorist attacks and true health of economy; Nasdaq falls 59.41 points, or 4.1 percent, to 1,403.80; index is down 28 percent; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 21.17 points, or 2.1 perrcent, to 968.65; Dow Jones industrial average falls 133.47, or 1.4 percent, to 9,109.79; graphs; charts (M)

headline: U.S. Rebuked: Slapping the Hand That Fed Free Trade
abstract: News analysis of ruling by World Trade Organization that European Union can impose up to $4 billion in penalties on US because tax break it gives exporters amounts to illegal subsidy under international law; ruling, by far biggest trade penalty ever imposed, is rebuke that is all more stinging since it is aimed at country that routinely lectures rest of world on need to open markets; is striking since it comes from institution that would not exist if US had not pushed relentlessly for its creation (M)

headline: Personal Business; Travel Slump Is Translating Into Luxury for Less
abstract: Consumers still willing and able to travel -- sometimes at last minute -- can take advantage of travel industry's current tough times by investigating discounted luxury vacation deals; some of deals can be found online; photos (M)

headline: It's time for 20 questions and a look at cereal, contact lenses, chicken and flavored cola.
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column poses 20 questions about advertising, marketing, media and popular culture (M)

headline: Pro-Europe Leftists Gain in Old East Bloc
abstract: Pro-Europe leftists are gaining in former Soviet bloc countries in East even as Western Europe moves to right; staunch pro-market parties have virtually disappeared in region and almost every significant party supports well-woven welfare safety net; recent victories by Social Democratic parties in Czech Republic, Hungary and Poland discussed (M)

headline: The Week's Economic Events
abstract: MONDAYConsumer BorrowingJuly.

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Bridgestone Investigation; JAPAN: Nissan In China Deal;.

headline: On the Radio, Afghans Call Their Nation to a New Day
abstract: New radio program called Good Morning Afghanistan is offering Afghans zesty, up-to-the-minute and increasingly bold look at world, and at surprising ways country is changing now that Taliban have been driven from power; announcer Ghani Mudaqiq recalls Taliban days when lone radio station began news with bulletins on arrests of men for trimming beards and women for entering ice cream parlors; he and Sharifa Zurmati, woman previously banned from working, now offer more audience-friendly broadcasts; photo; training help comes from Denmark-based Baltic Media Center, with financing from European Commission; advisers with BBC and Voice of America experience offer editorial advice, but greatest gain may be that Afghans are hearing news from countrymen (M)

headline: Japan's Bad-Loan Agency Turns a Profit
abstract: Resolution and Collection Corp, agency charged with cleaning up Japan's banking problems, turned profit collecting bad loans last year; operation is still far from achieving its goals and lawmakers are weighing whether to speed up process by allowing it to use taxpayer money; group posted 284 billion yen ($2.37 billion) net profit in year ended March 31; photo (M)

headline: A Thicket Of Numbers To Stop Theft
abstract: Responsible Party column on Winston Keech, who helped found Swivel Technologies, which offers new system to prevent fraudulent credit card purchases; diagram; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Belgium: Advertising Outlook
abstract: RTL Group, Europe's largest commercial television company, says it will reach its 2002 financial targets; Bertelsmann AG controls RTL (M)

headline: Offerings in Equity Set for This Week
abstract: The following equity offerings are expected this week:    CAE Inc., Toronto, an initial public offering of 27 million shares. Credit Suisse First Boston; Scotia; and Goldman, Sachs.

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: BRAZIL: Trade Surplus Grows; VENEZUELA: Growth Is Predicted; COLOMBIA: Exports Surge;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: PeopleSoft Won't Treat Options As Expense
abstract: PeopleSoft says it will not change way it treats stock options on its financial statements, arguing that making them compensation expense will stifle innovation; chief financial officer Kevin Parker comments; graph (S)

headline: Vivendi Messages About Audits Seized
abstract: French securities regulators seize documents showing that former management of Vivendi Universal sought to press its French auditor Salustro-Reydel into accounting for sale of shares that Vivendi held in British pay television service B Sky B in way that would have inflated Vivendi's annual profit; documents include letters and e-mail messages sent and received by senior Vivendi executives, including former chairman Jean-Marie Messier (M)

headline: Personal Business; As Baby Boomers Age, More Are Catching the 'Easy Rider' Bug
abstract: Motorcycle sales triple over last 10 years, gain 28 percent in 2001 and rise 7.8 percent in first 6 months of 2002; gains come in large part from baby boomers' hankerings for road thrills; photo; chart (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Australia
abstract: AUSTRALIA: Wine Gain For Brewer; AUSTRALIA: Telstra Profit Falls;.

headline: Nursing Homes Report a Loss
abstract: Nursing home company Beverly Enterprises says it expects to report second-quarter loss of about $14 million, or 13 cents a share (M)

headline: Gap Picks Chief From Outside the Clothing Trade
abstract: Gap Inc names Paul Pressler, executive at Walt Disney, president and chief executive; chairman-founder Donald G Fisher says company was looking for someone with more expertise in international business, customer focus retailing and marketing; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Luxembourg: Tobacco Makers Rejected
abstract: European Court of Justice advocate general Leendert Geelhoed rejects arguments by British American Tobacco and Imperial Tobacco against European Union law on packaging and branding of cigarettes; Geelhoed says in preliminary opinion that law passed last year did not overstep lawmakers' mandate, as tobacco companies contended; law bans words 'light' and 'mild' from cigarette packs and calls for health warnings on front and back of all packs (S)

headline: Marsh & McLennan Is Maintaining a Policy of Silence
abstract: Executives of Marsh & McLennan are silent one year after Sept 11 terorrist attacks on World Trade Center claimed lives of 294 employees, or 15 percent of 1,900 people assigned to two towers; Barbara S Perlmutter says firm has been very protective of confidentiality and privacy of its families (S)

headline: As the Economy Slows, Risks May Decrease
abstract: Jeffrey M Leavitt letter responds to July 28 article about venture capitalists

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Waiting To Inhale
abstract: Hong Kong officials urge people with respiratory problems to avoid strenuous outdoor activity as dense smog that has covered city this week grows even darker, obscuring view of famous harbor and Peak; rapid expansion of lightly regulated factories in Guangdong Province sends pall all over region (S)

headline: U.S. Shows Off Aid Projects At U.N. Development Meeting
abstract: United States officials attending United Nations Summit on Sustainable Development in South Africa showcase series of multimillion-dollar American projects aimed at helping poor countries reduce poverty and protect their natural resources; say US plans to spend more than $1 billion over next four years to improve water efficiency on farms and factories, provide electricity to poor, help communities combat deforestation and ease hunger; American officials hope announcement will quiet relentless storm of criticism over US refusal to agree to firm time frames for reducing agricultural subsidies, reducing number of people in need of sanitation and for embracing wind and solar power; environmental groups and advocates for poor describe Americans' announcement as inadequate; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Congo: Troubles Continue As Pullout Begins
abstract: Uganda and Zimbabwe, two of five countries drawn into Congo's civil war, begin pulling out troops, but UN asks Uganda to maintain military presence in Bunia until power vacuum is filled; map (S)

headline: TELECOMMUNICATIONS EQUIPMENT MAKER TO CUT JOBS
abstract: Tut Systems, which makes telecommunications equipment, says that it will cut 39 percent of its jobs and close design center in Bridgewater, NJ, to save $5 million to $6 million a year (S)

headline: World Briefing: Middle East
abstract: IRAN: Senior Ayatollah Quits In Protest; ISRAEL: Term Limit For Imprisoned Politician;.

headline: Rich Nations Are Criticized For Enforcing Trade Barriers
abstract: World Bank and International Monetary Fund end annual meetings in Washington, DC, with many critics inside and outside elite gathering attacking what many allege is major hypocrisy of rich countries, namely, continued barrier to imports, particularly agricultural products and textiles; criticisms by World Bank pres James D Wolfensohn, IMF's deputy managing director Stanley Fischer and Oxfam International noted; critics charge rich countries with pressing poorer nations to open markets to stimulate business while keeping their own trade barriers intact (M)

headline: Bush to Outline Doctrine of Striking Foes First
abstract: Bush administration will publish its first comprehensive rationale for shifting American military strategy toward pre-emptive action against hostile states and terrorist groups developing weapons of mass destruction; document will state, for first time, that US will never allow its military supremacy to be challenged as it was during cold war; document, one that every president is required to submit to Congress, is this administration's first comprehensive explanation of its foreign policy, from defense strategy to global warming; it sketches out far more muscular and sometimes aggressive approach to national security than any since Reagan era; it includes discounting of most nonproliferation treaties in favor of doctrine of 'counterproliferation'; calls strategies of containment and deterrence--staples of American policy since 1940's--all but dead; says America is threatened less by conquering states than by failing ones; striking element of new strategy document is its insistence that president will not allow any foreign power to catch up with huge lead US has opened since fall of Soviet Union; photo; chart comparing Pres Bush's new national security strategy with Pres Clinton's in some key areas (L)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: FRANCE: Civilized Vivendi Meeting; I.B.M. ACQUISITION CLEARED; GERMANY: Beiersdorf'S Share Gain;.

headline: New Executives May Restate Qwest Results For Last Year
abstract: New Exec

headline: Experts Warn of High Risk for American Invasion of Iraq
abstract: Senate Foreign Relations Committee holds first public hearings on Bush administration's goal of ousting Saddam Hussein from Iraqi presidency; array of experts warn that invasion of Iraq would carry significant risks ranging from more terrorist attacks against American targets to higher oil prices; some experts call for swift, large-scale attack to depose Hussein before his biological and nuclear weapons capabilities mature; others argue for tighter embargo and more aggressive weapons inspections to contain him; all agree that if Pres Bush does use military force to remove Hussein, Pentagon should not underestimate ability of Iraqi military to fight or overestimate ability of Iraqi opposition forces to carry on fight alone; say American forces would prevail in invasion, but that administration should plan on keeping forces in Iraq for many years to help rebuild it; there is growing concern in Congress that administration is moving rapidly, and without public debate, toward full-scale military assault on Iraq, and there is emerging debate over whether Bush would need Congressional approval for such an invasion (M)

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Airport Standoff Ends
abstract: Standoff between Mexican government and residents of San Salvador Atenco ends peacefully; villagers claim victory and say they are determined not to sell their land to state for new international airport (S)

headline: Excerpts: Bush's National Security Strategy
abstract: WASHINGTON, Sept. 19 — Following are excerpts from President Bush's outline of

headline: U.S. Is Trying to Market Itself To Young, Suspicious Arabs
abstract: Radio Sawa, new radio station that combines pop music with news snippets, is part of new United States State Department public relations campaign to convince skeptical young Arabs of America's good intentions; station currently broadcasts in five Arab nations, and is in addition to $25 million program set up to offer scholarships for university-age Arabs to study in US; efforts are being met with suspicion among Arabs who feel under assault by American policies on Israeli-Palestinian conflict and Iraq; State Dept spokesman says public relations efforts are essential to combat misperceptions of American policy; Tony Sabbagh, veteran market researcher who is director of Middle East Marketing and Research, says hostility of young Arabs is based on policies not image and that unless Washington modifies stand on Israeli-Palestinian problem, and backs off unilateral action against Iraq, administration faces uphill sell; says while US diplomacy may be influencing some moderate governments, people remain unconvinced (M)

headline: Nazi War Criminal Sentenced to 7 Years in Jail
abstract: A Hamburg court today sentenced a former SS officer to seven years in prison for ordering the reprisal killings of 59 Italian prisoners in 1944.

headline: BANKRUPTCY HINT BY UNITED AIRLINES
abstract: United Airlines, nation's second-largest airline, says it might file for bankruptcy protection by mid-Nov if it does not receive concessions from labor unions, suppliers and others within month; airline is burdened by debt and by tense relationships with its employees, who own more than half the company; unions appear reluctant to give cuts and promise to oppose any move toward bankruptcy; two unions have seats on 12-member board of parent company UAL; more than half the board must vote in favor of seeking bankruptcy protection for company to make that move; United's announcement comes in week when US Airways, country's sixth-largest airline, files for bankruptcy protection and American Airlines, largest airline in world, says it is laying off 7,000 workers, reducing capacity and retiring dozens of jets; what United does in its labor negotiations weighs heavily on entire industry; analysts say United's generous contracts with its pilots and machinists have prompted other airline labor groups to demand match from their employers, propping up high cost structure that is helping create big industry losses; United's management says airline is being dragged down by most expensive labor contracts in business; unions maintain management has made several horrendous business moves, especially ill-fated attempt to buy US Airways; photos (M)

headline: Bush gains praise over U.S. return to Unesco
abstract: PARIS:—  The surprise announcement of U.S. intentions to rejoin Unesco, the UN body promoting global cultural and educational cooperation, helped drive home President George W. Bush's message of readiness for effective international cooperation, diplomats say.

headline: More Venture Capital Is Returned Than Raised
abstract: Report released by National Venture Capital Association and Thomson Financial reveals that, during second quarter 2002, venture capitalists returned more money to investors than they raised (M)

headline: THE MARKETS: COMMODITIES
abstract: American Petroleum Institute reports that inventories have dropped to 18-month low, sending prices higher; in New York, crude oil for October delivery rises 71 cents, or 2.5 percent, to $28.98; graph; chart (S)

headline: BUSH TO PUT CASE FOR ACTION IN IRAQ TO KEY LAWMAKERS
abstract: White House, responding to urging of senators, says Pres Bush will meet with Congressional leaders to make his arguments for confronting Saddam Hussein; Trent Lott is one of usually staunch Republican supporters calling for full debate and Congressional authorization for action against Iraq; Sec Colin Powell, in South Africa for environmental summit, says Bush will make decision in 'very near future'; some senators demand hard evidence of Vice Pres Cheney's contention that Hussein is close to producing nuclear weapon; Sec Donald Rumsfeld indicates other information will be made public; British Prime Min Tony Blair, virtually alone among US allies, gives strong backing to administration; Iraq uses summit to try to blunt momentum; Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz meets with UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan to discuss return of UN weapons inspectors; photo; European and Arab leaders say Bush's insistence on ouster eliminates any incentive for Hussein to withhold use of chemical or biological weapons if US attacks (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Lehman Takes Real Estate Stake
abstract: Lehman Brothers Holdings buys 49 percent of Banca Popolare di Lodi's real estate unit for 150.8 million euros ($148.4 million) (S)

headline: Article 2002082693646494552 -- No Title
abstract: hr size="-1" font face="Times, Times New Roman, Serif" size="+1" About This Series font size="-1" Articles in this series examine the increasing conflict and competition over the world's dwindling water resources. The last article will look at how an aquifer in the United States offers reasons for both hope and caution. HR SIZE="-1"

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Chechnya: U.N. Halts Relief Effort
abstract: United Nations suspends most of its relief operations in Chechnya after kidnapping of Nina Davidovich, Russian who leads local aid group working with United Nations Children's Fund (S)

headline: Primedia to name an editorial director of sweeping scope.
abstract: Primedia is expected to announce that Elizabeth Crow has become editorial director of company's consumer magazine and media group; chief executive Tom Rogers comments; photo (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Parental Tech Support To the Editor:.

headline: AOL Revives Focus on Creating Original Content
abstract: Executives assuming control of struggling America Online Internet service are reviving strategy company abandoned five years ago, emphasizing creation of original, exclusive content; AOL hopes to use content partly to sell goods and services directly to its subscribers; AOL virtually ceased spending money to create its own content five years ago in favor of selling and leasing space on its service to others who wooed its members; AOL's formerly booming advertising business has plummeted, leaving company hunting for new sources of revenue; AOL is racing to update its service to attract and retain consumers who get access to Internet through high-speed broadband connections like digital cable lines; new chairman Jonathan F Miller faces significant challenges in his efforts to remake AOL; internally, many longtime AOL executives believe that it should focus its energies on its existing profitable low-speed customers rather than invest in content for still-emerging high-speed business; many have also long argued that creating content is too expensive; AOL Time Warner signs its first agreement to offer America Online's high-speed service over systems of another cable company, AT&T Comcast; but AOL charges about $10 per month more than its competitors for its high-speed service, and it is struggling to justify that price to consumers (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Deficit Deadline Extended
abstract: Slowdown in economic growth in 12-country euro zone forces European Commission to grant member states additional two years to balance their national budgets; commission president Romano Prodi says members' budgets should be at or close to balanced by 2006 at latest; commission acknowledges that Germany might exceed deficit ceiling this year, and warns that France could come dangerously close; limit is 3 percent of gross domestic product (S)

headline: Former BET Officer Can Continue Suit
abstract: District of Columbia Superior Court Judge Judith Bartnoff allows to go forward lawsuit against BET Holdings II Inc, parent company of Black Entertainment Television, contending television unit went to extensive lengths to avoid paying some taxes; suit was brought against BET in August 2000 by former chief financial officer Dwight Crawford, who said he had been dismissed after raising concerns about what he called financial improprieties; suit also says BET overstated valued of its corporate assets and understated certain liabilities to advertisers; BET has called accusations frivolous and 'without merit'; trial date has not been set (S)

headline: Martha Stewart Gives Panel Records in ImClone Inquiry
abstract: Martha Stewart delivers more than 1,000 pages of documents to House Energy and Commerce Committee investigating sale of her ImClone Systems stock; documents are delivered by Stewart's Washington lawyer James F Fitzpatrick; shares in Stewart's company Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia rise on news reports that she will comply with commmittee's request; Ken Johnson. committee spokesman, says Stewart's turning over documents does not reduce committee's desire to interview her (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: BRITAIN: Telecom Shortfall; BRITAIN: Bid For Retailer; FRANCE: Vivendi Executive Leaving; SWITZERLAND: Insurer Discovers Loss;.

headline: World Briefing: Asia
abstract: REGION BUFFETED BY LANDSLIDES AND FLOODING ; AFGHANISTAN: American Copters Crash;.

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Taiwan: Possible China Talks
abstract: Taiwan's Pres Chen Shuibian calls for ta

headline: More Offerings Are Questioned
abstract: By Bloomberg News.

headline: Coors Names Two More Agencies
abstract: Coors Brewing Co is expanding its ad agency roster by naming Deutsch and Arnold Worldwide along its longtime agency of record, Chicago office of Foote, Cone & Belding, on creating campaigns for its flagship Coors Light and Coors Original beer brands; combined annual spending is estimated at $150 million to $200 million (S)

headline: Earnings Up at U.S. Steel
abstract: US Steel Corp earned $27 million in second quarter, reversing loss year earlier; sales were up by 4 percent, to $1.81 billion from $1.74 billion year earlier (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Koreas: Verbal Skirmishing
abstract: North Korea demands South Korea provide detailed outline of any plans to salvage South Korean patrol boat sunk in Yellow Sea skirmish; South Korea rejects demand, holding boat sank on its side of line below which it bans Northern boats; denies Pres Kim Dae Jung's reconciliation policy emboldened Northern commanders to challenge South; charges North with deliberate armed provocation (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Internet
abstract: HISPANICS' USE OF WEB SURGES; SUN AND AT&T IN JOINT VENTURE; ONLINE JOB HUNTING RISES;.

headline: CREDIT RATING OF WILLIAMS COMPANIES REDUCED TO JUNK
abstract: The credit rating of the Williams Companies, a leading pipeline concern, was reduced to BB, or junk status, by Standard & Poor's because less cash is available to the company. The senior unsecured debt was lowered two levels from BBB-, S.& P. said. Williams's failure to renew its $2.2 billion revolving loan is ''not commensurate with an investment-grade rating,'' S. &P. said. The drop in Williams's stock price, along with a cut in its dividend, reduces the company's ability to sell shares to raise cash and pay off debt, S.& P. said.

headline: As U.S. Talks Begin, Pakistan Says India Attacked Kashmir
abstract: Deputy Sec of State Richard L Armitage begins talks in New Delhi to reduce tensions between India and Pakistan; Pakistan accuses India of unprovoked attack across Line of Control in disputed Kashmir; India denies attack; photo of Armitage with India's defense minister, George Fernandez (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Riverstone To Lay Off 30% Of Work Force
abstract: Riverstone Networks, maker of Internet equipment whose shares have dropped 93 percent this year, plans to lay off about 30 percent of its workers, or 143 people, as fiscal second-quarter sales plunge (S)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: SPAIN: Airliner Attack; GERMANY: Jewish Restitution Talks; BELARUS: Fire In Tainted Region; NATO: New Chief;.

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Train Wreck Death Toll At 106
abstract: Death toll in derailment of train that jumped tracks of bridge, Bihar state, India, rises to 106; Railways Min Natish Kumar suspects sabotage; local officials blame poor bridge maintenance (S)

headline: Do You Know the Correct Time? And the Barometric Pressure?
abstract: Suunto, compass and sports instruments company based in Finland, introduce watches that can gather wide range of data, including weather conditions, in addition to being ordinary timepieces; photo (M)

headline: A Fund With a Fan Club
abstract: Shareholders in American Century's Global Natural Resources fund reject adviser's proposal to liquidate Global and shut mutual fund down (S)

headline: OPERATOR OF MONSTER.COM TO BUY BACK SOME SHARES
abstract: TMP Worldwide Inc plans to buy back as many as five million shares during next 18 months; shares amount for about 4.5 percent of TMP's total shares outstanding (S)

headline: Chinese Hold Their Breath as a Swollen Lake Recedes
abstract: Water levels in Dongting Lake in central China begin to recede, encouraging hope that any major disaster from summer's most menacing flood may be averted; potentially catastrophic seepages in mainly earthen dikes and embankments have been spotted by roving teams of farmers and sealed by troops with sandbags and rocks; flood control officials downstream from lake, along Yangtze River in Hubei and Anhui Provinces, brace for oncoming rush of water; photo; map (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Refugee Camp Population Nears 2,000
abstract: Refugee population in camp at Sangatte, France, swells to 2,000, in camp built to accommodate about 900; refugees use Channel Tunnel to reach Great Britain; camp is slated to be closed next year (S)

headline: Airline Clubs Aren't Just for Business These Days
abstract: Airline frequent-flier clubs, traditionally airport sanctuaries for business travelers, are increasingly popular with leisure travelers because of stressful and crowded airport conditions; are evolving into all-purpose combination of neighborhood bar, conference room and children's nursery for business travelers, who now bring their families into clubs when flying together; clubs are becoming more crowded, sometimes annoyingly so; photo (M)

headline: Business; Paper or Plastic? Currency Making Is in Flux
abstract: Growing number of countries, worried about inexpensive technology enabling counterfeiters equipped with computer inkjet printers to create real-looking fake paper money, switch to plastic; Australia, which converted entirely to plastic bank notes in 1996, licenses its technology to 15 other governments; photo; graph of counterfeiting in United States; table of countries using plastic bank notes (M)

headline: Rise in Mortgage Requests
abstract: Mortgage Bankers Assn of America reports that index measuring applications for mortgages rose for week to highest level in eight months; index increases 23.3 percent, to 1,004.3 (S)

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES: PERSPECTIVES/Colin L. Powell; Juggling the Demands of Diplomacy and a Different Kind of War
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Secretaray of State Colin L Powell in Perspectives series on terrorism and US policy in Iraq; photo (L)

headline: MASSEY ENERGY ORDERED TO PAY $50 MILLION IN DAMAGES
abstract: Massey Energy Co is ordered b

headline: A Tangled Feud, Even by Indonesian Standards
abstract: Feud continues in Indonesia over geothermal joint venture between Karaha Bodas Co, part-owned by Florida Power and Light, and state-owned oil company Pertamina; Indonesia scrapped project amid charges of corruption; Pertamina has refused to repay Karaha money it invested in venture, despite rulings in Karaha's favor by international tribunal in Geneva and courts in United States, Hong Kong and Singapore; both sides continue to spend heavily on lawyers and lobbyists (M)

headline: A War of Robots, All Chattering on the Western Front
abstract: United States military planners envision wars involving vast robotic fleets on ground, in the air and on seas--swarms of drones that will not just find their foes, but fight them, as well; such forces would need entirely new kind of network in which to function, wireless Internet in sky that would let thousands of drones communicate quickly while zooming around battle zone at speeds of up to 300 miles an hour; such a network would have to deal instantaneously with unpredictable conditions of war and cope with big losses; drawing (M)

headline: A.&P. Reports More Problems With Its Books
abstract: Great Atlantic & Pacific Tea Co says its former auditors, Deloitte & Touche, notified company of 'reportable condition' related to internal controls concerning vendor allowances; it is not clear if problems could lead A&P, which twice amended July annual report, to again restate earnings (M)

headline: An Executive-Suite Coup in Russia
abstract: Russian corporate battle took turn for absurd when Mikhail S Gutseriyev, former president of Russian oil company Slavneft, stormed into its offices with squads of special police officers and reinstated himself; Gutseriyev was removed as president in shareholders' vote in May; government, which owns 75 percent of company, appointed Yuri E Sukhanov, former oil sales manager for Sibneft, one of politically connected giants of oil industry in Russia; Gutseriyev claimed his ejection was illegal, citing ruling by regional court that annulled vote; Sukhanov reacted with fury; photo (M)

headline: China's Top AIDS Activist Missing; Arrest Is Suspected
abstract: Relatives and human rights groups report that Dr Wan Yanhai, China's most prominent AIDS activist, has disappeared and is believed to have been detained by police; he is former Chinese health official who was fired after he took up causes of gay rights and AIDS in mid-1990's; has been instrumental in exposing devastating AIDS epidemic in Henan Province in central China; his disappearance and possible detention come at time when China is contemplating plans for more aggressive strategy to combat growing HIV epidemic; his treatment by government in recent months, including surveillance and harrassment, reflects Chinese officials' persistent ambivalence about kind of openness about AIDS that virtually all experts agree is necessary to reverse crisis (M)

headline: MEN'S WEARHOUSE CUTS FORECAST FOR QUARTER AND YEAR
abstract: Men's Wearhouse lowers its earnings forecast for third quarter and year (S)

headline: Once More With Feeling: Buy American. Please!
abstract: DIARYOnce More With Feeling: Buy American. Please!.

headline: Editors' Note; War of Diplomacy
abstract: More on Page 24:  Opening Moves  Days of Change  Into Discord

headline: The Promotion Of Prescription Drugs
abstract: George J Zahka letter responds to Aug 18 The Right Thing article about drug companies' promoting their products to physicians

headline: A Palestinian Senses an Opening for Peace
abstract: Interview with Palestinian Authority member Muhammad Dahlan and Israeli journalist Nahum Barnea; Dahlan, Yasir Arafat's security chief and prominent Palestinian Authority member, has emerged as negotiating partner for Israel; he and Palestinian Min Abdel Razak Yehiyeh have met several times with Israeli Defense Min Benjamin Ben-Eliezer to discuss pulling Israeli troops back from Bethlehem and Gaza; photo (M)

headline: ON THE GROUND: In Phoenix; Technology and Rapid Growth in the Valley of the Sun
abstract: Travel article on Phoenix, Ariz; city's highlights noted; phhoto (M)

headline: Panel Urges U.S. to Revamp Efforts to Promote Image Abroad
abstract: Report by Council on Foreign Relations says US is doing poor job of countering growing anti-American sentiment overseas and must revamp way it promotes foreign policies abroad, especially among predominantly Islamic countries; says rising tide of resentment could undermine Bush administration's efforts to fight terrorism and become obstacle if US decides to invade Iraq (M)

headline: Software Buyers Find Support Has Its Price
abstract: Some software companies are reducing amount of free technical support they offer to customers, leaving many users to fend for themselves or pay fees that range from nominal to fairly steep; Microsoft is bucking trend, promising unlimited free support for software packages, but is starting to charge customers who buy individual components and need more than installation instructions; photo (M)

headline: Qwest Officials Made Millions In Stock Sales
abstract: Qwest Communications International executives made about $500 million selling company stock from 1999 to 2001 while releasing profit numbers company now says were exaggerated and based on improper accounting; recently ousted chief executive Joseph P Nacchio made $227 million, former chief financial officer Robert S Woodruff made $29 million and current general counsel Drake S Tempest made $13 million; Philip F Anschutz, board member and company's largest shareholder, made almost $1.5 billion selling shares in May 1999; table of insider stock sales (M)

headline: NORTHERN TRUST BUYS UNIT FROM DEUTSCHE BANK
abstract: Northern Trust Corp agrees to buy United States index-tracking fund business of Deutsche Bank AG for about $260 million in cash (M)

headline: Afghan Rivals Clash, Killing 17
abstract: Fighting breaks out between rival commanders in mountainous area in northern Afghanistan, just weeks after main factions agreed to disarm their men and prevent further clashes (S)

headline: Dow Jones Shuffles Officers; New Publisher at Journal
abstract: Dow Jones & Co shuffles its top management, elevating chief financial officer Richard F Zannino to chief operating officer and making Karen Elliott House, president of company's international publishing group, publisher of Wall Street Journal; Peter R Kann remains chief executive; Journal's managing editor Paul E Steiger will report to House; all of these top managers will also be part of executive committee, along with Peter G Skinner, who remains executive vice president and general counsel, reporting directly to Kann; photo (M)

headline: Bank One Jumps on Bandwagon To Count Options as Expenses
abstract: Bank One becomes third major company to announce plans to treat value of stock options as expense; International Accounting Standards Board in London directs its staff to draw up rule to require such accounting treatment (M)

headline: Bundle Up
abstract: The rising price of natural gas, while still well below the sharp spike of two years ago, points to higher heating bills for consumers this winter. Page. C5.

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Anti-Piracy Executive Chosen
abstract: Universal Music Group names David Benjamin senior vice president for anti-piracy (S)

headline: S.&P. 500 and Nasdaq Fall to Levels Last Seen in 1997
abstract: Worst bear market in generation deepens as stocks plunge for second day, leaving two major indexes at their lowest levels since 1997; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 32.36 points, or 3.4 percent, to 920.47, lowest level since November 1997; S&P 500 has fallen 40 percent since its peak in March 2000; Dow Jones industrial average plunges 282.59 points, or more than 3 percent, closing at 8,813.50; Nasdaq composite index drops 35.11 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,346.01, lowest level since May 1997; graph; chart (M)

headline: British Reopening the Debate Over Privatization
abstract: Analysis: Sizable losses by Britain's British Energy have reopened deate over limits of privatization; British Energy is latest example of problems Britain has had with its privatization program; Railtrack Group was declared insolvent and effectively renationalized through public-private partnership last October; analysts say recent trouble underscores important lessons that will serve as bellwether not just for Britain, but for other European countries in process of privatizing their industries; photo (M)

headline: Philippine Officials Detail the Trap, Set With U.S. Help, That Snared a Rebel Leader
abstract: Just off the southern Philippine coast late one night in June, a boatload of Philippine marines, equipped with night-vision goggles and guided by intelligence from American spy planes, lay in wait for a fugitive Muslim terrorist leader.    The target of the operation was Abu Sabaya, a senior leader and the cocky spokesman of the Abu Sayyaf group, which had kidnapped numerous Americans and Europeans and beheaded some of them. Transponders in Mr. Sabaya's backpack, slipped into the foam padding of the waist belt by American intelligence officials before an informant delivered it to him, helped the authorities track the rebel.

headline: Harassment Suit in U.S. Shifts India's Work Culture
abstract: Sexual harassment lawsuit was filed in US in December against Phaneesh Murthy, head of global sales and marketing for India's Infosys Technologies; litigation is forcing Indian software concerns, many of which have large numbers of employees deployed abroad, to rethink their workplace policies and processes; with about two-thirds of India's 365 billion rupees ($7.54 billion) in export revenue coming from US, where sexual harassment in workplace is treated with far more gravity than in India, companies are concerned not just about their image but also their financial welfare; Murthy quit in July after former US employee Reka Maximovitch sued him and company, contending sexual harassment and wrongful termination (M)

headline: Paris Journal; For French Girls, Playing Soccer Is a Tough Goal
abstract: Soccer is regarded as too gauche for girls in France to play; remains rough, sweaty male sport in soccer-obsessed society where gender and class play important role in who does what; only about 4 percent of children who play on organized teams in France are girls, and stigma they suffer often makes then feel need to keep it secret; photos (M)

headline: Court Favors Families in Suits Over Holocaust-Era Insurance
abstract: American relatives of Holocaust victims win important round in long legal battle to force European insurance companies to pay claims on life insurance policies of people killed by Nazis and other Axis powers with decision by Federal District Judge Michael B Mukasey rejecting requests by insurers to dismis lawsuits filed more than five years ago; insurers, Assicurazioni Generali of Italy and Zurich Life Insurance Company of Switzerland, argued that any life insurance claims should be handled by commission financed by insurers or by European courts; Mukasey ruled that neither alternative was in best interests of families; ruling opens ways for lawsuits to go to trial in American courts; lawyers for families and insurers say it will probably be years before lawsuits, worth potentially hundreds of millions of dollars, are resolved; photo (M)

headline: Drop in Overseas Sales Hurts Oracle
abstract: Computer software maker Oracle Corp reports sales for first quarter of $2.03 billion, down over 10 percent from year-earlier quarter and on low end of projections; posts profits, excluding special charge, of $386 million (M)

headline: Mutual Funds Report; Matter of Timing in Health Funds
abstract: Article explores Fidelity Group sector mutual funds invested in healthcare industry, currently one of most robust segments of economy; photo (M)

headline: For sleepy luxury, slip into silky-soft sheets
abstract: MILAN—  Fancy slipping in to something more comfortable? Try Italian sheets. After all, sheets, blankets, quilts and covers used to be called bedclothes. We spend a third of our lives in them, and they can be as much a fashion item as our apparel by day.

headline: Tired of Chasing Dustballs? Let a Robot Do the Job
abstract: IRobot introduces Roomba, fully automatic robot vacuum cleaner that adjusts to various surfaces; photo (M)

headline: Is climate change aiding spread of disease?
abstract: PARIS—  As floods rage in Central Europe and China and as drought plagues Africa and North America, it is getting harder to dismiss the scientists who claim that weather is becoming not only warmer but more extreme. Both of those trends, each in its own way, has ominous implications for the spread of infectious disease.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: 10,000 More Layoffs At Alcatel
abstract: French telephone equipment maker Alcatel will increase number of layoffs at its factories by about 10,000 before end of 2003; expects second half revenue about 10 percent below first half; demand for its products weakens further (M)

headline: In Powell's Tour, Brevity As the Soul of Diplomacy
abstract: Secretary of State Colin L Powell will have visited eight countries in eight days by time he heads home on Aug 3; unlike some of his precessors, Powell is not fond of traveling; he seems well aware that his need for speed can have diplomatic consequences, promising each foreign host to return at later date for longer visit; map showing his stops during current trip in Asia (M)

headline: Flood of Afghans Returning Home Prompts U.N. to Request More Aid
abstract: United Nations aide Dr Mukesh Kapila says UN seriously underestimated Afghanistan's needs when it projected 800,000 refugees living in Pakistan and Iran would return after Taliban's fall; says some two million Afghans have flooded back into country, crowding refugee centers and overwhelming aid groups; calls for added $300 million before end of year to avoid widespread suffering this winter; warns failure to provide enough aid would undermine Pres Hamid Karzai and encourage 'spoilers and mischief makers;' meets with Asst Sec Eugene Dewey, Washington; recently visited foreign ministers in Europe and plans appeal to Japan for added aid; Karzai, in New York, warns optimism could turn to despair if reconstruciton stalls; photo (M)

headline: Blair, Meeting With Bush, Fully Endorses U.S. Plans For Ending Iraqi Threat
abstract: Prime Min Tony Blair of Britain meets with Pres Bush at Camp David, fully endorsing Bush's drive to destroy Iraq's weapons of mass destruction and saying inaction is not policy to follow; he is first European leader to side so completely with Bush; his position carries political risk in Britain, where skepticism about military action in Iraq is running high; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: VERIZON TO CUT DEBT; NEXTEL PREDICTS STRONG YEAR;.

headline: Calpine Reports 33% Fall in Net
abstract: Calpine Corp says that its second-quarter earnings fell 33 percent as it reduces energy trading and electricity prices decline; net income drops to $72.5 million, or 19 cents a share (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Younger Historians, With Better Hair
abstract: History Channel urges documentary makers to avoid overuse of 'the old faithfuls' in their work for channel and to seek out more 'telegenic' historians in their 40's or younger; photo (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: NTT Raises Outlook
abstract: Nippon Telephone and Telegraph Corp raises profit forecast of its parent company after it sells shares in its mobile carrier, NTT DoCoMo Inc; NTT earns one-time profit of 148 billion yen ($1.2 billion) from sale; graph (S)

headline: Mining Company Withdraws From Zambian Copper Project
abstract: Anglo American PLC completes its withdrawal from Zambian copper industry, closing books on failed investment that in little more than two years will have cost company about $358 million; Anglo will pay Zambian government $30 million, and will buy out other minority shareholders International Finance Corp and Commonwealth Development Corp for $25.4 million each, turning their stakes over to government along with its own; government plans to keep mines open with additional loan of up to $26.5 million from Anglo while it searches for buyer; Simon R Thompson, chief executive of Anglo's base metals division, comments (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Exploring Belarus Merger
abstract: Pres Vladimir V Pution proposes absorbing Belarus into Russia in talks with Aleksandr G Lukashenko, Belarussian leader; Lukashenko objects to plan; says he favors more equal terms (S)

headline: NEGOTIATORS AGREE ON BILL TO REWRITE BANKRUPTCY LAWS
abstract: Congressional negotiators say they have reached agreement on bill that would rewrite bankruptcy laws, making it much harder for people to escape their debts when they declare bankruptcy; agreement is victory for credit card companies and other lenders; it comes after compromise is reached that will restrict ability of anti-abortion protesters to use bankruptcy laws to shield themselves from paying court fines resulting from protests at abortion clinics; overall bankruptcy bill has passed both houses of Congress by overwhelming margins, and appears destined for final approval in House and Senate; White House suggests Pres Bush will sign it; bill would end ability of millions of Americans to use bankruptcy system to wipe out credit card bills and other loans not secured by homes or other assets; many debts would instead have to be paid back over time; bill has been vigorously opposed by consumer-rights groups; credit card companies have sharply stepped up campaign contributions to members of Congress in recent years as they promoted legislation (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.75       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.25       Federal funds   1.75   1.70   3.64       3-month T-bills   1.63   1.59   3.33       6-month T-bills   1.63   1.60   3.29       10-yr. T-infl.   2.51   2.51   3.32       10-yr. T-note   4.30   4.33   4.90       30-yr. T-bond   5.06   5.09   5.45       Telephone bd.   6.95   7.05   7.55       Municipal bds.   5.15   5.15   5.15          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: With Focus Shifting to Iraq, Domestic Issues Fade
abstract: Prospect of weeks of debate in Congress about granting Pres Bush authority to oust Saddam Hussein is expected to dominate nation's political discussion for easily half of general election campaign this fall, rather than domestic issues pushed by Democrats; several Republicans say focus on Iraq would serve political needs of their party going into close Congressional elections; leaders of both parties say they see no evidence that voters are ready for war in Iraq, or that any member of Congress would be hurt by opposing Bush on this; critical question may not be outcome of debate about Iraq, but rather how long it lasts, and when Democrats can turn it back to home turf; photo (M)

headline: China Says Sect Is Broadcasting From Taiwan
abstract: Chinese government charges spiritual group Falun Gong is using Taiwan as base for its increasingly bold and often successful attempts to hijack satellite transmissions and beam antigovernment messages all over mainland; says its leaders have cracked code that gives access to China's satellite system (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Cuba: Bush Would Veto Easier Travel
abstract: White House spokesman Ari Fleischer says Pres Bush will veto legislation to ease restrictions on travel and cash payments to Cuba if it reaches his desk (S)

headline: Lloyd's Plans Big Changes In Financing Of Insurance
abstract: Lloyd's of London says it soon hopes to end its more than 300-year practice of financing insurance through individual investors who risk their entire net worth, but often reap fabulous profits; proposal to eliminate individual investors, called names, comes as part of broad reorganization plan for Lloyd's, which has failed to report profit for five consecutive years; reorganization is to be voted on by all of Lloyd's investors at meeting in September (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Sulzer Profit Down
abstract: Sulzer AG says first-half profit fell to $20.7 million; cuts forecast for sales and operating income in 2002 because of flat demand in crucial areas (S)

headline: Putting a Financial Crisis Aside for a Shared Moment of Grief
abstract: Putting a Financial Crisis Aside For a Shared Moment of Grief.

headline: S.E.C. Chief Draws Ridicule In Quest for Higher Status
abstract: Democratic and Republican members of Congress join Bush administration officials in ridiculing Harvey L Pitt's request that his pay be increased and his job as chairman of Securities and Exchange Commission be elevated to cabinet rank; House Speaker J Dennis Hastert and Republican Senate leader Trent Lott say there is no justification for proposal; Senate majority leader Tom Daschle, who previously called for Pitt to be dismissed, seizes on proposal as latest example of his poor judgment; Democratic National Committee chairman Terry McAuliffe says making Pitt member of Bush's cabinet will not restore investor confidence (M)

headline: Market Place; Price Tag and Local Politics Damp Interest in Hershey
abstract: Some potential suitors for Hershey Foods appear to be balking at company's high asking price and controversy surrounding auction; Cadbury Schweppes has already told Hershey that it will probably not submit offer; Nestle and Kraft Foods are wavering about whether they can afford to meet Hershey's asking price, more than $11 billion, without significantly diluting their earnings; some board members of trust that controls Hershey are reconsidering auction; without lucrative sale price, some board members have begun privately discussing possibly ending auction and buying back stock instead; Pfizer Inc plans to put its Adams confectionary unit up for sale, hoping to receive bids from many of potential buyers of Hershey; Adams could bring $4 billion or more, so some suitors are considering whether to bid for Hershey now or wait to try to buy Adams; Pfizer had hoped to begin its auction this summer but decided to wait until after Hershey completes its sale; photos (Market Place column) (M)

headline: In an Ancient Game, Computing's Future
abstract: Go is game of such depth and complexity that no computer has yet been able to achieve level of skill beyond that of casual player; game described; programmers see it as more accurate than chess in reflecting ways in which human mind works, and challenge of programming computer to mimic human process goes to core of artificial intelligence; developments in analyzing game and programming it discussed; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Resignations At Mitsui
abstract: Mitsui & Co's senior managing director Shouei Utsada will replace Shinjiro Shimizu as president; vice president Nobuo Ohashi will become chairman; photo (S)

headline: U.S. SAYS HUSSEIN INTENSIFIES QUEST FOR A-BOMB PARTS
abstract: Bush administration officials claim Iraq has embarked on worldwide hunt for materials to make atomic bomb; say Iraq tried in last 14 months to buy thousands of specially designed aluminum tubes that could be components of centrifuges to enrich uranium; say several shipments were blocked or intercepted, but decline to say where they came from or how they were stopped; Iraqi defectors who once worked for nuclear weapons establishment tell American officials that acquiring nuclear arms is again top Iraqi priority; American intelligence agencies are monitoring construction at nuclear sites; defectors also say Hussein has heightened efforts to develop new types of chemical weapons; Iraqi opposition leader gives American officials paper from Iranian intelligence indicating that Hussein has authorized regional commanders to use chemical and biological weapons to put down any Shiite Muslim resistance that might occur if US attacks; photos (L)

headline: Magazine Imitates a Catalog And Has a Charmed Life, So Far
abstract: Conde Nast Publications expects Lucky, which may be first consumer magazine in US to use advertising motifs to design every page of editorial content, to reach profitability more quickly than any new magazine in company's recent history, although it still could take several more years; magazine promised advertisers 500,000 paying readers when it was launched in December 2000, and total paid monthly circulation has grown to 780,000, 207,095 of that figure in newsstand sales; James Truman, editorial director of Conde Nast, and Kim France, Lucky editor, comment; photos (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: The Essay, IM Style To the Editor:.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: Hershey Foods Corp raises its quarterly dividend 8.3 percent, to 32.75 cents a share (S)

headline: Forever Archived
abstract: Ryan Goudelocke letter disputes July 25 article on power of search engines to track down an individual's personal information

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Canada: Saudis Must Now Get Visas
abstract: Canadian government decides to require citizens of Saudi Arabia to obtain visas to visit Canada, change reflecting Canada's desire to tighten immigration controls and security at its borders (S)

headline: Showtime, Microsoft Style
abstract: Rob Fixmer State of the Art column comments on Microsoft's new Media Player 9; used with cable-modem connection, player improves media streaming capabilities; photos; drawing (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Interest Rate Lowered
abstract: Swiss National Bank acts to curb rise in value of franc by lowering its benchmark interest rate for second time in 2002 (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Yahoo Introduces Fee-Based Game Service
abstract: Yahoo introduces fee-based video-game service for customers, featuring high-speed Internet connections; users of Games on Demand service can download and play more than 40 titles; prices start at $4.95 for rental of one game for three days, and rise to $14.95 to rent 10 games for 30 days; games are being offered through Yahoo's high-speed Internet-access service with SBC Communications Inc (S)

headline: Beijing Blocks Access to Google
abstract: China blocks access to Internet search engine Google (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Bandujo Donker & Brothers Advertising and Design, Summit, N.J., hired three employees.

headline: Citigroup Moves to Clear Up Troubles at Investment Unit
abstract: Analysts and investors say Citigroup chief executive Sanford I Weill's decision to promote Charles O Prince III, his former chief legal counsel to run Citigroup's investment bank Salomon Smith Barney, shows Weill wants to rid bank of legal and regulatory problems confronting it; latest executive shuffle at Citigroup also leads to inevitable speculation that Weill is once again hinting at possible successor when he retires; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Software: Intuit Tries To Stem Unlicensed Use Of TurboTax
abstract: Intuit, largest maker of software for preparing income tax returns, has created activation process for most new versions of TurboTax in effort to crack down on unauthorized use; new procedure will not prevent more than one person from using program on authorized computer (S)

headline: A Shaky Economy Rattles a Marriage
abstract: Lisa Belkin column on how loss of job can strain a marriage; drawing (M)

headline: Employment Data Raise Questions About Economic Recovery
abstract: Labor Department reports employers slashed hours in July, cut overtime and limited hiring to bare minimum; latest data raise fresh questions about falling economic recovery, suggesting that growth will be modest at best; unemployment rate remained at 5.9 percent, same as June, as 86,000 people who might have been listed as unemployed and job hunting dropped out of labor force instead; total employment rose bare 6,000, to 130.8 million; employers cut average workweek by unusually large three-tenths of hour, to flat 34 hours; hourly wage rose in July by 4 cents, to $14.79 per hour, but from 12-month perspective, annual increase through July was 3.2 percent; Labor Sec Elaine L Chao says good news is that July's unemployment rate was essentially unchanged from previous month; Commerce Department reports factory orders fell sharply in June, indicating setback in industrial output after several months of improvement; says consumer spending rose in June by largest amount in two years and personal incomes increased by similarly smart amount; graph (M)

headline: World Briefing: European Union
abstract: BALKANS MONEY GOING BEGGING ;.

headline: New Reasons To Wonder If the Worst Is Over
abstract: Tom Redburn Economic View column on First Quadrant managing partner Robert D Arnott's observation that now, after steep fall, stock market has reached same valuation level as at its top in 1929; Arnott sees decade of further disappointment to follow; stock price graph (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: South Korea: U.S. Helicopters Grounded
abstract: US command grounds its 70 Apache helicopters in South Korea as memorial services are held for two pilots killed when craft crashed on August 22 in hilly terrain (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: HONG KONG: Telecom Joint Venture; JAPAN: Cuts At Electronics Maker; JAPAN: Jobless Tax Increase Sought; SOUTH KOREA: Jobless Rate Falls;.

headline: Palestinian Deaths Spur Israeli Debate
abstract: A rash of recent killings of Palestinian civilians raised questions in Israel about whether restraints were slipping among Israeli troops after nearly two years of conflict with the Palestinians.     There was also concern that the recurrent civilian killings could provoke revenge attacks in Israel after a nearly monthlong lull.

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Lynn Bolger was named executive vice president for agency development at the New York office of ComScore Media Metrix, part of ComScore Networks.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: Euro settles at 98.17 cents, down from 98.40 cents on Thursday; graph; other exchange rates listed (S)

headline: Tiny Digital Camera With a Tiny Price And Many Features
abstract: StyleCam Blink from SiPix is tiny camera, measuring about 2 inches square, priced under $40; can act as Webcam when connected to PC with USB cable; photo (M)

headline: U.S., Citing Better Human Rights, Allows Aid to Colombia Military
abstract: Bush administration releases about $42 million in aid to Colombian military after determining there is enough improvement in country's human rights record to meet Congressional requirements for such aid (S)

headline: Morgan Suffers Setback in Fight With Insurers Over Enron
abstract: Federal Judge Jed S Rakoff dismisses fraud claims against 11 insurers, dealing setback to efforts by J P Morgan Chase & Co to collect $965 million for losses on gas and oil trades its Mahonia Ltd unit made with Enron Corp; rules Morgan can take its breach-of-contract claim agains insurers to trial; insurers hold trades were shams designed to hide loans to Enron (M)

headline: Tivoli Journal; A Search for Girls, Girls, Girls Around Italy's Dial
abstract: More than 10,000 women sign up to compete for role on Italian television as one of showgirls who hover almost wordlessly, providing superfluous visual adornment; women belong to one of Italy's most idiosyncratic pop-cultural phenomena: placement and exaltation of beautiful, skimpily clad extras in background or foreground in just about every kind of television show; photo (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of July 7 article: Pfizer Inc's Listerine PocketPaks breath strips are effective for 90 minutes

headline: Whiff of Chocolate, and the Sweet Smell of Success
abstract: Hershey, Pa, residents and Hershey Foods workers hail retreat by trustees who control company on plan to sell it; feared new owner would cut jobs and ruin town's image as paternalistic yet profitable sanctuary; question quality of Hershey's management; map; photo (M)

headline: Chinese Will Move Waters To Quench Thirst of Cities
abstract: Third article in series, Running Dry, on increasing conflict and competition over world's water resources focuses on major challenge facing governments in alleviating critical shortages and correlating needs with supplies, which are often far apart; discusses China's efforts to improve situation in its showcase northern cities like Beijing and Tianjin by embarking on one of history great water-moving projects; government will rechannel vast rivers of water from Yangtze basin in rainy south to parched cities of north over three pathways of nearly 1,000 miles each, at huge cost and great risk to environment; official price tag of $58 billion is more than twice that of Three Gorges Dam, China's most recent mega-project now nearing completion; project described; maps; photos (L)

headline: CREDIT SUISSE MAY SELL ITS FLAGGING INSURANCE UNIT
abstract: Continued losses from its insurance and investment banking arms could force Credit Suisse Group to sell United States-based property and casualty insurance unit of its Winterthur division, which includes Republic Underwriters Insurance Co (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Samsung Share Buyback
abstract: Samsung Electr

headline: Powell Charts Low-Key Path In Iraq Debate
abstract: State Sec Colin L Powell, whose voice has been conspicuously absent as Bush administration debate over Iraq intensifies, recently said in BBC interview that United Nations arms inspectors should return to Iraq; spoke days after Vice Pres Dick Cheney said return of inspectors would provide only false comfort; is expected to explain administration plans while attending UN-sponsored conference, Johannesburg, South Africa; Bush aide insists there is no difference of opinion or emphasis between Powell and Cheney; says inspections, while important, are not enough (M)

headline: During Retirement, More Time to Explore
abstract: Shiela and Letty Sustrin letter responds to July 7 article about modern retirement

headline: MANTECH TO BUY AEGIS RESEARCH FOR $70 MILLION
abstract: ManTech International Corp, military contractor, acquires Aegis Research Corp for $70 million in cash; Aegis provides technical support services for Defense Department and national intelligence community (S)

headline: Cutting Corporate Costs, Or Playing With Fire?
abstract: Claude M Gruener letter on Louis Uchitelle's August 25 column holds at-risk and laid-off workers will continue making fewer and smaller purchases until businesses return job stability to marketplace

headline: Vanguard Airlines Files for Bankruptcy and Suspends Service
abstract: Vanguard Airlines says that it is filing for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection because it has failed to get financing and has been operating since Sept 11 on diminishing pool of cash; Vanguard, based in Kansas City, Mo, was operating 70 flights to and from 18 cities; suspends service on July 30; it had been in business since 1994, but has not been profitable in six years it has been public company (M)

headline: Time to Change the Way Options Are Taxed
abstract: Floyd Norris column urges change in way stock options are taxed; says current tax rules are perverse; holds employees owe high ordinary taxes on stock option profits, while companies that issue options can get big tax deductions when options are cashed in; says taxing options upfront would indicate to employees that options being issued have value, and it would provide incentive to companies to reasonably estimate that value, rather than push for lowest possible number; graph (M)

headline: A Portable MP3 Player That Plays in a Tape Deck, Too
abstract: Digisette's Duo-DX E-Cassette is portable MP3 player and recorder that holds about 2-1/2 hours of music and can be inserted into tape deck to play MP3 files through conventional audio system; photo (M)

headline: Iran's President Trying to Limit Power of Clergy
abstract: Pres Mohammad Khatami of Iran says hard-line clerics make it all but impossible for him to do his job; says he will propose legislation to restore powers that Iran's president has lost to clergy; his statement seen as clear expression of frustration with clerics who hold most real levers of power and have thwarted president elected twice on promises to open economy and usher in greater civil liberties; says his dialogue with hard-liners has proved fruitless; his challenge suggests new willingness to confront them more forcefully; it seems certain to intensify long power struggle in Iran; his proposals seem certain to pass in Parliament, where his supporters hold majority; but any changes can be blocked by religious panel called Guardian Council, which has turned back reforms before; Khatami says he has already presented Parliament with bill to limit powers of council, and will soon send bill to restore presidential powers that would allow him to act as head of state, enforce Constitution and protect citizens' rights; says public disaffection is rising, stemming mostly from his government's failure to bring citizens greater freedom; photo (M)

headline: WORLDCOM FINDS $3.3 BILLION MORE IN IRREGULARITIES
abstract: WorldCom, which sought bankruptcy protection after disclosing that it improperly accounted for $3.8 billion in recent expenses, says it has uncovered $3.3 billion in additional accounting irregularities stretching back to 1999; says new irregularities will force revisions in its accounting for 2000, 2001 and first quarter of this year; says it will probably take write-off of as much as $50.6 billion related to reduced value of past acquisitions; company does not disclose whether new problems were identified by its internal investigators or by KPMG, its new outside auditor; warns investors and creditors that further problems could turn up; new disclosures include more instances of operating expenses being improperly classified as capital investments; executives say major new twist involves reserves WorldCom set up to cover uncollected payments from customers, judgments in lawsuits and other potential losses (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Singapore: Evian It's Not
abstract: Singapore will try to reduce dependence on water from Malaysia by recyling waste water back into reservoirs; photo of bottle of 'newater' (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: TV Shows Start This Week, Hoping to Get Early Jump  No fewer than 12 new television series are beginning this week, a week before the official start of the new season. The networks are hoping to find viewers willing to give the new shows an early look. ''These are shows we're trying to get sampled before they have to go against the behemoths,'' said Susan Lyne, the president of ABC Entertainment.     For ABC, which is facing one of the toughest challenges this television season, the tactic is one born of desperation as it struggles to rebuild prime-time ratings on the back of mostly new series. Advertising. [Page C16.]

headline: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Journalist's Remains Recovered
abstract: Charred remains of Brazilian crime reporter Tim Lopes, who disappeared June 2 during undercover investigation into gangs that dominate squatter slums in Rio de Janeiro, are recovered from clandestine cemetery; Lopes reportedly was executed by local drug boss nicknamed Elias the Madman; photo (S)

headline: Nils Bohlin, 82, Inventor of a Better Seat Belt
abstract: Nils Bohlin, who invented three-point seat belt as safety engineer for Volvo, dies at age 82; photo; death comes as Bohlin is inducted into National Inventors Hall of Fame in Akron; Volvo estimates that seat belt has saved more than one million lives in last 40 years (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Netherlands: Assassination Trial Opens
abstract: Prosecutors at hearing, Amsterdam, on continued detention of Volkert van der Graaf say he was arrested carrying gun speckled with blood of assassinated far right politician Pim Fortuyn (S)

headline: Hanwha Consortium Is Cleared to Buy Control of Insurer
abstract: International consortium led by Hanwha Gr0

headline: World Business Briefing | New Zealand: Verizon Sells Telecom Stake
abstract: Verizon Communications Inc sells its 20 percent stake in Telecom Corp of New Zealand for 1.6 billion New Zealand dollars ($754.7 million); Merrill Lynch, which paid Verizon about 4.35 New Zealand dollars ($2.05) a share is offering to sell them to investors for 4.45 to 4.55 New Zealand dollars a share; graph (S)

headline: Big Blast Kills 21 Afghans; Link to Terror Is Suspected
abstract: Huge blast kills at least 21 people and injures at least 85 near road construction warehouse, Jalalabad, Afghanistan; investigators say cause is unclear but suspect explosives stored in warehouse for terror attack on nearby hydroelectric dam went off accidentally, damaging dam; four construction company members are arrested (M)

headline: In Re 9/11: Law Firm Moves On, Still Recovering
abstract: Law firm of Sidley Austin Brown & Wood chose to move its 600 lawyers and other workers over Independence Day holiday weekend from temporary offices on Third Avenue to new permanent offices on Seventh Avenue at 51st Street after law firm's five floors of offices in World Trade Center were destroyed; photo (M)

headline: Private Sector; Southwest, Without the Stunts
abstract: Interview with Southwest Airlines chief executive James F Parker; he comments on labor disputes that have ruffled airline's reputation as friendly employer; photo (M)

headline: Air New Zealand Picks Airbus Over Boeing for 15-Jet Order
abstract: European plane maker Airbus wins order from Air New Zealand for 15 A320 single-aisle planes worth about $750 million, wresting longtime customer from Boeing Co; also takes options on 20 additional A320 aircraft to replace its fleet of leased Boeing planes; delivery of aircraft will begin in October 2003, as leases on Boeing 737-300's expire (M)

headline: In Two Days, Citigroup Chief Traded Halo For Headaches
abstract: Market value of Citigroup tumbles 25 percent, or $45 billion, in two days as Senate committee begins investigating whether it and main rival J P Morgan Chase enabled Enron Corp to disguise amount of debt it actually had on its balance sheet; Sanford I Weill, who built Citigroup into $1 trillion conglomerate, defends its actions and predicts vindication; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: GoAmerica Plans To Cut 50% Of Its Work Force
abstract: GoAmerica Inc, provider of wireless Internet services, plans to cut 50 percent of its jobs, or 100 workers; says it no longer needs to raise as much as $15 million in financing this year as it reduces costs and teams up with companies, including EarthLink Inc, to lift sales (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Gas-Electric Car Deal; SOUTH KOREA: Exports Surge;.

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Nextel Reports Its First Profit
abstract: Nextel Communications reports its first profit in its history; net income was $325 million compared to loss of $426 million year earlier; total sales rose 25 percent, to $2.15 billion; chief executive Jim Mooney comments; graph (S)

headline: SHARES OF CUBIST FALL AFTER VENTURE WITH GILEAD ENDS
abstract: Shares of Cubist Pharmaceuticals fall 30 percent after drug maker and Gilead Sciences end collaboration to market Cubist's experimental antibiotic Cidecin in Europe (S)

headline: French Free Top Civilian Official Jailed for War Crimes
abstract: French appeals court orders immediate release from prison of Maurice Papon, highest-ranking French civilian ever to be brought to justice for Nazi war crimes in World War II; cites his age, 92, and poor health; he was serving 10-year sentence for having signed deportation orders for more than 1,500 Jews while he was police chief in puppet state of Vichy; his six-month trial five years ago exposed extent to which French collaborated with Nazis; under terms of Papon's release, he will need authorization every time he wants to leave home; photo (M)

headline: Plan for Alexander Statue Too Great for Many Greeks
abstract: Chicago-based Alexander the Great Foundation plans to carve 240-foot-high likeness of Alexander into face of Mount Kerdyllion in northern Greek region of Macedonia; local authorities welcome idea as way of attracting tourists, but Greek classicist and preservationists are appalled, and national Culture Ministry adamantly opposes it on ground that Greek tradition is to build monuments in proportion to human scale and environment; sketch; maps (M)

headline: Flying as a Statement Of Defiance to Terror
abstract: SBC Directory Operations national sales manager Tancred Agius and marketing consultant Bob Cullinan say they will travel on Sept 11 to make statment that no crazed religious terrorist is going to tell them what to do; Agius and Cullinan comment (M)

headline: When culture has wheels : On foreign roads, just go with the flow
abstract: PARIS—  Why drive in Europe? Some travelers prefer to take a train, plane, hovercraft, riverboat — anything to avoid the Continent's tangle of differing rules, signs and behaviors. After all, Europe offers cheap, comfortable rail travel and, as of recently, bargain airfares. But with a few pointers, driving in Europe can become much less of an obstacle course.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Flextronics Will Lay Off 5,261 Workers
abstract: Flextronics International Ltd, electronics maker, says 5,261 employees are being laid off under plan announced in October to eliminate 10,000 workers (S)

headline: Reading All About Sept. 11
abstract: After Sept. 11, many book publishers were wary of moving too quickly to sell books on the tragedy. "Nobody wants to set up a lemonade stand at the nuclear bomb site," as David Rosenthal, publisher of Simon & Schuster, part of Viacom, put it at the time.

headline: A Tax Break for the Rich Who Can Keep a Secret
abstract: Some Americans are delaying taxes on their stock profits for years or decades--or, in some cases, never paying at all; deals are perfectly legal but only if one has $5 million of stocks and bonds and promises to keep it secret; executives and investors with $5 million of stocks and bonds contribute at least $1 million of their stock in single company to pool into which others in same situation contribute their own shares; in return they receive shares of partnership that owns pool; whey they are ready to withdraw from pool, partnership gives them not their original shares or cash but instead shares of varity of stock held by pool; as result, someone with too much money in one stock can quickly diversify into more balanced portfolio; unlike other investors, who have to pay taxes on profits when they sell stock, no taxes are owed on profits of shares contributed to pool (M)

headline: Jack Daniel's takes the edge off with a flavored malt beverage to appeal to prime beer consumers.
abstract: Arnold Worldwide has created print ads for $40 million campaign for Jack Daniel's Original Hard Cola that is beer, brewed and not distilled, with alcohol content of 5 percent; campaign described; photo (M)

headline: On a Single Chip, Intel Joins Realms of Analog And Digital
abstract: Intel develops new manufacturing process that it says will make it possible to blend both digital and analog functions on single silicon chip; says process will have dramatic impact on variety of data, communications and consumer products as performance increases and costs fall dramatically (M)

headline: So Who's On First? O'Neill, Or O'Neill?
abstract: Interviews with New Yorkers find they, like other Americans, remain ignorant about how markets work and about overall economy, despite their increasing investment in stocks and bonds; photo (M)

headline: Deal Is Seen For Acquisition Of Burger King
abstract: Diageo is near deal to sell its restaurant chain Burger King to consortium led by private equity firm Texas Pacific Group for more than $2.2 billion (M)

headline: Annan Weighs Reply to Iraq On Invitation To Inspectors
abstract: United Nations Sec Gen Kofi Annan welcomes Iraq's offer to open talks on UN arms inspections, but indicates Pres Saddam Hussein is still far from complying with Security Council requirements for lifting sanctions; Bush administration officials and American diplomats at UN are skeptical of offer (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Tougher Sentence For Pedophilia
abstract: Cambodian court hands down its harshest sentence yet for pedophilia, sentencing Italian man to 10 years in prison for having sex with boys age 14 and under (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Accord On Fuel From Iranian Reactors
abstract: Russia reports signing pact with Iran guaranteeing return of spent fuel from two nuclear reactors Russian engineers are building in Bushehr; Min Aleksandr Rumyuantsev says accord makes academic complaints that Iran will use plants to make nuclear weapons (S)

headline: U.S. Allies in Mideast Voice Doubts on Bush Peace Plan
