abstract: Egypt and Saudi Arabia, two main American supporters in Middle East, urge Bush administration to clarify how it intends to pursue peace in region, week after Pres Bush calls for ouster of Yasir Arafat as condition for any meaningful agreement; Egypt's Pres Hosni Mubarak and Crown Prince Abdullah of Saudi Arabia express uncertainty about how to proceed; Abdullah says Palestinian people alone have right to choose their leader; Israel's Prime Min Ariel Sharon lauds killing of Hamas bomb maker Muhanad al-Taher by Israeli commandos; says there will be no compromise with terror; approximately 4,000 Palestinians in Gaza Strip mount demonstration against Palestinian Authority's failure to address their increasing poverty; Hamas official threatens revenge for al-Taher's slaying; photo (M)

headline: Journalist of Jenin's Despair Dies of Wound
abstract: Palestinian journalist Imad Abu Zahra dies after being shot from armored vehicle while photographing Israeli tanks in Jenin, West Bank; photographer Said Shawqi Dahla, injured and hospitalized, describes incident; photos (M)

headline: Global Crossing Files Its Plan To Reorganize
abstract: Global Crossing Ltd files reorganization plan that its new owners Hutchison Whampoa of Hong Kong and Singapore Technologies Telemedia hope will allow it to become profitable after emerging from bankruptcy by beginning of 2003 (M) 'aggressive steps to reduce hassle factor at airports'; John C Hermansen, founder and chief executive of intelligence company called Language Analysis Systems, is working with Transportation Security Administration to devise workable trusted traveler system that manages to accommodate strong objection to any form of ethnic or religious profiling that has been hallmark of federal government's approach to airport security; drawing (M) is perplexed by lawsuit (S)

headline: Market Place; Court Ties Up Hershey Deal, For Time Being
abstract: Judge Warren G Morgan issues temporary injunction to block possible sale of Hershey Foods Corp after Atty Gen Mike Fisher argues that sale would cause 'irreparable harm' to Hershey, Pa; Hershey Trust Co files appeal (Market Place column) (M)

headline: BUSINESS TRAVEL: ON THE GROUND -- In San Diego; Hot Economy and Mild Temperatures
abstract: Travel article on San Diego, Calif; city's highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: Fans and Players at a Korean Soccer Stadium Root for Unity
abstract: North and South Korea soccer players play for the dream of reunification.

headline: Lawyer Proves a Thorn for Enron's Partners
abstract: Neal Batson, court-appointed examiner in Enron Corp's bankruptcy, represents one of largest hazards facing giant banks and law firms that helped create off-balance-sheet partnerships often blamed for Enron's downfall; marshals enormous resources to investigate deals and threatens nearly 400 of world's largest financial institutions with subpoenas if they fail to supply documents he demands; exasperated institutions claim he resembles prosecutor; legal analysts say they have cause for worry, as they are both creditors seeking compensation and causes of Enron's fate; photo (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | Telecommunications: Dispute Continues
abstract: Arbitration panel rules Nvidia Corp, sole supplier of graphics chips for Microsoft's Xbox video-game console, must keep selling processors to Microsoft as companies try to settle pricing dispute (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.75       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.25       Federal funds   1.75   1.72   3.67       3-month T-bills   1.69   1.68   3.56       6-month T-bills   1.73   1.69   3.50       10-yr. T-infl.   3.07   3.01   3.44       10-yr. T-note   4.80   4.75   5.34       30-yr. T-bond   5.48   5.44   5.70       Telephone bd.   7.57   7.55   7.85       Municipal bds.   5.26   5.25   5.38          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Lawyer Caught In Tyco Tangle Leaves Friends Wondering
abstract: Tyco International has accused former general counsel Mark A Belnick of being part of conpiracy to loot company of hundreds of millions of dollars; prosecutors and regulators accuse him of hiding how much money he borrowed from company; accusations have left friends, colleagues and much of New York legal community wondering if Belnick was seduced by money proffered by former chief executive L Dennis Kozlowski; Tyco is represented by David Boies; Belnick is represented by Reid Weingarten of Washington law firm of Steptoe & Johnson; Tyco's lawsuit paints Belnick as part of web of impropriety that allowed top executives to steal hundreds of millions of dollars and dole out money to other employees and perhaps even to board member, thereby encouraging others to keep quiet; Tyco wants Belnick to return all money he as paid while general counsel; photo (M)

headline: Accounting Rule Changes May Strain Small Companies Most
abstract: Effects of accounting laws approved by Congress last month might be felt most keenly at smaller companies, which lack their own armies of accountants and lawyers; requirements of recently passed laws sound simple, but lawyers say they would compel companies to change their procedures and educate employees and board members (M)

headline: To Add to Conseco's Woes, U.S. Is Looking at Its Accounting
abstract: Conseco, which is on brink of bankruptcy, says its accounting is under investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission; company, which is struggling with $6.5 billion in debt, also reports net loss of $1.33 billion for second quarter compared with loss of $30.3 million year earlier; SEC probe centers on events in spring of 2000 and earlier when chief executive was Stephen Hilbert; chief executive Gary C Wendt comments; Conseco's ratings are downgraded by A M Best (M)

headline: UNOCAL TAKES A CHARGE FOR CLEANUP COSTS
abstract: Unocal Corp will take $22 million charge in third quarter for environmental cleanup costs; lowers quarterly earnings expectations (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Italy: Campari's Profits Rise Sharply
abstract: Worldo

headline: Technology Briefing: Hardware
abstract: SHIPMENTS OF HANDHELD COMPUTERS DECLINE; TEXAS INSTRUMENTS CREATES CHIP FOR MEDICAL DEVICES;.

headline: FEDEX TO BUY 10 AIRBUS CARGO JETS IN $2.3 BILLION ORDER
abstract: Air delivery unit of FedEx Corp agrees to buy 10 Airbus SAS A380 cargo jets valued at $2.3 billion; three airplanes will be delivered annually in 2008 through 2010, with one aircraft in 2011 (S)

headline: Bush Signs Bill Aimed at Fraud In Corporations
abstract: Pres Bush signs sweeping bill overhauling corporate fraud, securities and accounting laws; bill creates regulatory board with investigative and enforcement powers to oversee accounting industry and punish corrupt auditors; sets new standards for prosecuting wrongdoing and gives corporate whistle-blowers broad new protections; sets long prison terms for executives who defraud investors; Bush, who earlier opposed bill's provisions and touted his team's corporate experience, hails bill and casts himself as protector of small investor and rank-and-file worker; vows stiff punishment for corporate wrongdoers; is flanked by key economic advisers, Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Harvey L Pitt, Atty Gen John Ashcroft and Congressional members of both parties; Democrats, led by Sen Tom Daschle, try to seize political upper hand by calling for more legislation and noting that Bush was corralled into backing bill; photos (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: SINGAPORE: Automaker In Debt Talks; CHINA: More Telecom Services;.

headline: For Collectors, a Race for a Space-Age Heirloom
abstract: Original Bulova Accutron, introduced in 1961, is prized collectable; first successful transistorized watch, it was far more accurate than any other watch on market and was major advance in timekeeping technology; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: TOWER AUTOMOTIVE INC., Grand Rapids, Mich., the world's biggest maker of stamped vehicle frames, said it paid off $200 million in debt and reduced the amount it can borrow because the company does not need the money.    KROLL INC., New York, a provider of security and private-investigation services to corporations, acquired closely held Crucible, Falmouth, Va., to expand its line of security-training services. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Shares Close Out Vigorous Week In Quiet Fashion
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 33.43 points, closing at 8,745.45; 3.18-point rise leaves Standard & Poor's 500-stock index at 908.64; Nasdaq composite index drops 10.40 points, settling at 1,306.12; yield on 10-year Treasury note drops to 4.26 percent, as its price rises 1 2/32, to 100 28/32; 30-year Treasury bond yield falls to 5.11 percent; its price gains 1 22/32, to 103 28/32; list of volatile stocks; graph of DJIA; table of key rates (M)

headline: India Injects $3 Billion To Rescue Mutual Fund
abstract: Indian government steps in to rescue country's largest mutual fund manager, state-owned Unit Trust of India, whose investment performance has fallen far short of returns it promised to tens of millions of retail investors; government injects $3 billion in tax money into trust to cover shortfalls in US-64, country's oldest and largest mutual fund (M)

headline: Frankfurt Journal; Gray-Flannel City Wants to Dance to Its Own Hue
abstract: William Forsythe's decision to quit as director of Frankfurt Ballet because of budget dispute seems to reflect waning of city's ambitions to be cultural center; fact that his edgy style could thrive has been source of pride for many Frankfurters; city's cultural director Hans-Bernhard Nordhoff denies charge made by Forsythe supporters that he wants to see more classical ballet, and Forsythe himself is rankled that financial decision by city has somehow mutated into referendum on his artistry; photos (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Court Bans Protests
abstract: Ukraine court bans planned prop

headline: AT&T, Writing Down Cable Assets, Posts Big Loss
abstract: AT&T Corp's second-quarter financial results modestly exceed analysts' expectations; says overall revenue declined about 9 percent, to $12.1 billion, from $13.2 billion year earlier; reports loss of $12.7 billion compared with loss of $191 million year ago; chairman C Michael Armstrong comments (M)

headline: Did You Buy at the Peak? Hanging On May Still Pay
abstract: Mark Hulbert Strategies column looks at markets' history and concludes that even those who bought stocks just prior to start of current market decline may, with time, still profit; 30-year graph of growth-stock prices (M)

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Doctor's Hand-Held Helper To the Editor:.

headline: THE MARKETS: CURRENCIES
abstract: US dollar rises against Japanese yen on expectations that American markets will extend four-week rally, increasing demand for currency; in New York, yen settles at 119.89 from 118.45; graph; chart (S)

headline: FORD OPENS AN AUTOMOBILE ASSEMBLY PLANT IN RUSSIA
abstract: Ford Motor Co announces official opening of its assembly plant outside St Petersburg, Russia; factory will produce 25,000 Ford Focus cars per year for Russian consumers; $150 million factory is first car manufacturing plant in Russia that is fully owned by foreign producer (S)

headline: Firm Alters Stock Ratings
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston will simplify its stock-rating system and compare equities with specific industries instead of with broad market; system, to take effect in September, will rate stocks outperform, neutral or underperform, replacing four-tier system (S)

headline: A Human Face on North Koreans' Plight
abstract: Plight of 300,000 North Koreans living terror-filled life as illegal migrants in China is given human face by Kim Han Mee, 2-year-old girl who watched in horror as her mother fought Chinese guards in failed effort in May to seek asylum in Japanese Consulate in Shenyang; incident was videotaped and broadcast, arousing public opinion and forcing China to send Han Mee and parents Kim Guang Choel and Lee Seong Hee to Philippines and from there to South Korea; Japanese, Americans, European and South Korean legislators are working to aid resettlement of North Koreans, so-called 'land people, in China; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Middle East: Iraq: European Companies Buy Oil
abstract: TotalFinaElf, Eni and Repsol YPF, three of Europe's five biggest oil companies, agree to buy oil directly from Iraq after it eliminates surcharge on sales of crude; turnaround may signal end of decline in Iraqi oil sales (M)

headline: BOEING'S PROFIT IS DOWN, BUT SHARES ARE UP
abstract: Boeing Co says profit fell 7.3 percent in second quarter; net income fell to $779 million from $840 million year earlier; sales fell 11 percent, to $13.9 billion from $15.5 billion (S)

headline: Enron Official Is Reported Set To Plead Guilty
abstract: Michael J Kopper, former managing director in Enron Corp's global finance unit, reportedly agrees to plead guilty to conspiracy to commit wire fraud and money laundering, return $12 million he illegally obtained and cooperate with investigation of others who may be responsible for company's collapse; SEC is also expected to file civil fraud complaint against him; Koppers was primary participant in establishing and running off-the-books partnerships like Southampton Place and Chewco that investigators say Enron used to hide debt and improperly increase earnings; had close personal and professional relationship with Andrew S Fastow, Enron's former chief financial officer and one of main subjects of investigation; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Britain: Chief Executive Arrested
abstract: Colin Skellet, chief executive of Wessex Water, former Enron Corp subsidiary, is arrested on suspicion of accepting bribe of close to 1 million pounds ($1.5 million); police statement links arrest to $777 million purchase of Wessex Water in March by YTL Corp of Malaysia (S)

headline: Compressed Data; Web Site Lets Visitors Peek at Corporate Carping
abstract: Philip J Kaplan plans to roll out new Web site, InternalMemos.com, on which readers can sample internal business correspondence sent to him by aggrieved employees of various companies; spins subscription site off from another site whose name is vulgarism for 'failed company,' move that may help him attract advertisers; drawing (M)

headline: It Isn't Easy, but Sandler Thrives
abstract: Article on scene at Sandler O'Neill & Partners one year after Sept 11 terrorist attacks on World Trade Center claimed lives of 66 of firm's 171 employees; says Sandler O'Neill is not only in business, but is thriving, fueled by desire to triumph over loss; holds with many new employees and new Midtown office, it is rolling up deals even in current sluggish market; senior managing principal Jimmy Dunne and chief operating officer Fred D Price comment; photo (M)

headline: Investing; Hospitals Strut in a Lurching Market
abstract: Rising admissions, higher prices and recovery from cuts in federal reimbursement during 1990's spur for-profit hospital industry to higher earnings and increased stock prices; some investment professionals foresee continued strong results; Triad Hospitals stock has risen 33 percent in 2002 as overall stock market has fallen; largest for-profit hospital companies show strongest earnings; photo; table of data of industry leaders (M)

headline: World Business Briefing: Americas
abstract: MEXICO: Oil Investment; ARGENTINA: Airline Grounded;.

headline: Counting Costs, It's the Worst In Hong Kong
abstract: Hong Kong takes over from Tokyo as world's most expensive city; Moscow is second, Tokyo third; London holds European Union title, with New York costliest in North America; survey by Mercer Human Resources Consulting measures cost of more than 200 items (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: J2 COMMUNICATIONS, Los Angeles, the parent of National Lampoon Inc., a producer of comedy in print, film and other media, said it had acquired the privately held Burley Bear Network, one of the two major on-campus college television networks. Terms were not disclosed.    INSPECTECH, Atlanta, a home inspection company and a division of LandAmerica Financial Group Inc., said it had purchased Building System Analysis Inc., Atlanta, the largest home inspection company in Atlanta. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Economic Slowdown
abstract: France's economy slowed significantly in May and June, but is showing signs of recovery; industrial production fell 0.3 percent and manufacturing outpout fell 0.7 percent; European Commission survey shows that consumer became more pessimistic in June (S)8

headline: JOHANNESBURG SUMMIT : At Johannesburg talks, warnings of AIDS' toll on the future
abstract: JOHANNESBURG:—  The head of the UN's drive against AIDS complained Friday that world leaders at the Johannesburg summit were not devoting sufficient attention to the pandemic, warning that sustainable development would be impossible without a concerted attack on the effects of the disease.

headline: Teo-Ashoo Pass Journal; Here's to the Horse! A Good Reason to Drink to It
abstract: Comment on scene in Teo-Ashoo Pass in rural Kyrgyzstan, where horses are a staple; fermented horse milk, known as kumiss, is Kyrgyzstan's de facto national drink; photo; map (M)

headline: A Child Care Solution: Help From Overseas
abstract: 11,855 au pairs were placed with families in 2001 to provide child care in exchange for chance to live and study in United States; Eastern Europe is becoming dominant source of au pairs; graphs of numbers and costs of au pairs employed in US (S)

headline: E-Commerce Report; Digital cockpits are a faster, much closer way of tracking performance in a corporation's every corner.
abstract: Growing number of companies are able to use Internet to monitor many or all of their key performance indicators daily, or even minute-by-minute, using what have come to be called digital dashboards, or digital cockpits; General Electric is pioneer in use of such cockpits; senior executives of each of its primary division can log onto intranet to check division's fiscal health; photo (M)

headline: Disclosure by Merck is latest scandal ahead of president's speech : A new jolt as Bush heads to Wall Street
abstract: WASHINGTON:—  As President George W. Bush prepared a get-tough speech on the scandals buffeting corporate America and two former top executives of WorldCom Inc. refused to answer questions in Congress, investors got another jolt Monday as the drugmaker Merck & Co. revealed that one of its subsidiaries had overstated its revenues by billions of dollars.

headline: Vivendi Plans to Sell Assets; Goal Is to Raise $9.8 Billion
abstract: Vivendi Universal SA's new chief Jean-Rene Fourtou announces $12 billion loss for first six months of year and indicates that it will begin unwinding media empire assembled by recently ousted chief executive Jean-Marie Messier by selling American educational book publisher Houghton Mifflin, among other assets, in planned $9.8 billion sell-off; also indicates it will consider selling its stake in American satellite television company EchoStar Communications, which Vivendi acquired last year; Vivendi is laboring under $18.6 billion of debt, much of it amassed by Messier's acquisition spree; Standard & Poor's cuts Vivendi's longterm corporate rating to junk status; Fourtou also announces appointment of respected French investment banker Jean-Bernard Levy as chief operating officer, replacing Eric Licoys, close ally of Messier; photo (M)

headline: The Desktop Computer As Live-TV Recorder
abstract: Technology that allows user to capture video from cable television or antenna and store it on computer hard drive discussed; works in same way as TiVo or SonicBlue's Replay TV, but requires complicated installation and takes up lots of space on hard drive; describes six different systems, including set-up and features; drawing (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: 4 Nations In Education Pact
abstract: Mercosur founding members Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay and Uruguay agree to recognize each other's university degrees in several fields; seek to have universities adhere to common standard so professionals from one country can work in others; Chile and Bolivia, Mercosur associate members, have agreed to take part in experiment (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: France: Closing Date For Migrant Center
abstract: France and Britain agree to close refugee center in Sangatte, France, near Channel Tunnel, as early as December if Britain passes new laws giving fewer rights and benefits to illegal immigrants seeking political asylum (S)

headline: Accord on Margin Rule for Single-Stock Futures
abstract: DIARY Accord on Margin Rule For Single-Stock Futures  Two major regulatory agencies have agreed on a margin requirement for trading in single-stock futures, clearing the way for the start of the new vehicles.

headline: Mexico and Brazil Sign Bilateral Trade Pact
abstract: Brazil's Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso and Mexico's Pres Vicente Fox sign bilateral trade deal opening their markets to each other in 800 industrial and agricultural product categories, Brasilia; Brazil and Mexico trade little with each other--$2.6 billion worth of goods and services last year--and both could use boost from expansion of bilateral commerce that new agreement is meant to produce; photo (M)

headline: Fed Chief Blames Corporate Greed for Investor Woes
abstract: The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, told senators that a corporate culture blighted by "infectious greed" had caused the breakdown in confidence among investors.

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Russia: Another Sign Explodes
abstract: Man dies and woman is seriously wounded when booby-trapped sign blows up, Baltisik, Russia, when man tries to remove it; death is first in string of such incidents since May; other signs had anti-Semitic slogans, but police say this sign bore someone's name and expletive (S)

headline: Citigroup Is Linked to a Deal That Let Enron Skirt Rules
abstract: Interbank documents and records of government investigators reportedly show Citigroup misrepresented full nature of 1999 transaction with Enron so company could ignore accounting requirements and hide its true financial condition; demonstrate for first time that bankers intentionally manipulated written record of dealings with Enron to allow company to improperly avoid requirements of accounting rules and law, keeping $125 million in debt off books; records show bankers knew secret oral agreement reached with company required that accounting of transaction be changed; show Citigroup left side deal out of written record and allowed Enron to account for transaction in way bankers knew was improper (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Sweden: Appliance Maker's Outlook
abstract: Electrolux AB says net income in second quarter rose to 1.85 billion kronor ($200 million) from 1.16 billion kronor ($125 million) year earlier; sales declined 0.6 percent, to 37.2 billion kronor ($4 billion); company says full-year earnings will rise; graph (S)

headline: Russian Writer, Facing Charges, Warns Free Expression Is at Risk
abstract: Vladimir G Sorokin, popular postmodernist writer facing pornography charges in Russia, says he fears he could end up subject of show trial in government effort to control free expression; charges brought recently by prosecutors is victory for youth group that supports Pres Vladimir V Putin and that is campaigning to purify Russian culture (S)

headline: Takeover of Bcom3 Is Cleared by Holders
abstract: Bcom3 Group shareholders approve $3 billion acquisition by Publicis Groupe, which will create world's fourth-largest agency company (S)

headline: Inter-Korea Talks Offer Signs Of Progress, and Frustration
abstract: North Korean officials, in highest-level meetings with South Korea in year, agree to discuss economic cooperation and to allow another round of reunions of families divided by Korean War, but they balk at setting date for key military talks that would allow construction of road and rail links across highly militarized border; North Korea is being pressed from all sides to resume talks; Japan stopped its food aid this year and South Korea reduced its aid sharply; Pres Bush included North Korea in his 'axis of evil' (M)

headline: Israel Threatens to Deport Relatives of 2 Fugitive Militants
abstract: Israeli Army rounds up and threatens to deport 21 male relatives of Palestinian fugitives Nasser Aseida and Ali Ajouri and destroys their houses; Nasser Aseida is said to be Hamas mastermind of ambush on armored bus in which nine Israelis died and Ali Ajouri is believed to be leader of Fatah-affiliated Aksa Martyrs Brigades who sent two suicide bombers to Tel Aviv, where they killed three men; Palestinian officials and Israeli human rights organizations protest possible deportations; photo; map (M)

headline: U.N. Inspectors Can Return Unconditionally, Iraq Says
abstract: Iraq, responding to worldwide pressure after President Bush demanded that it comply with U.N. resolutions, said it would allow weapons inspectors to return.

headline: G.I.'s to Guard Afghan Leader Amid Concerns
abstract: American soldiers, including Special Forces, will move into presidential palace in Kabul, Afghanistan, and assume responsibility for security of Pres Hamid Karzai; move underscores concern for Karzai's safety following July 6 assassination of Vice Pres Haji Abdul Qadir; Defense Sec Donald Rumsfeld says new responsibility will be relatively short-term; says it is important for Afghan people, who recently elected Karzai, not to have interruption in leadership; Karzai's acceptance of American security detail underscores real worries among foreign powers that carefully built power-sharing agreement in country could collapse if he is harmed; photo (M)

headline: Lawsuits and Regulators Shadow Big Lender's Future
abstract: Household International faces threats to its financial future, including suits claiming predatory lending, tougher lending laws, regulatory scrutiny and possibility that many of its low-income customers may default on payments; interviews with borrowers and former employees and report by Washington State banking regulator suggest it will be hard to shake charges of abusive loan practices despite reform pledges; photos (M)

headline: CIT Shakes Off Tyco's Leash, but Its First Day Is Bumpy
abstract: CIT Group sells shares to public at $23 each, but price falls to $22; volume is 72.5 million of 200 million shares sold; Tyco International, parent, receives just $4.42 billion, with underwriters set to collect additional $184 million paid by investors as fees; Tyco bought company in 2001 for $9.5 billion in cash and stock (M)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: I.B.M. Will Acquire Access360
abstract: IBM acquires Access360 (S)

headline: S.E.C. ASKS WILLIAMS FOR MORE ENERGY TRADING DATA
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission asks Williams Companies, under investigation for possible sham energy transactions, for more information on cash reserves and sales in its energy trading activities; also seeks data on profits in California and other Western markets (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | Internet: Priceline Reports Surge In Earnings
abstract: Second-quarter earnings more than doubled at Priceline.com, seller of discounted travel services on Internet, as company cut costs; net income rises to $6.31 million, or 3 cents a share (S)

headline: At America Online, Old-Media Veteran In Familiar Task
abstract: America Online employees await what Don Logan, who will appoint new head of AOL, thinks should be done with their unit; Logan, an old-media veteran, is now chairman of media and communications group at AOL Time Warner; photos (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Bush is talking tough on corporate ethics, but where is the regulatory bite?
abstract: Jeff Madrick Economic Scene column on Pres Bush's speech on corporate fraud and responsibility says at bottom, spech reflects belief that current scandals are merely handiwork of few bad apples; holds it is hard to believe that Bush's economic advisers to not know that something more systemic than few clever swindlers is staining America; says good economist's first instinct would be to determine whether there are incentives built into financial system that encourage deception and fraud; holds president who wanted to make business trustworthy again and renew nation's confidence would address these incentives directly; says best piece of economic analysis on subject was done by George A Akerlof, of University of California at Berkeley and Paul M Romer, now of Stanford Business School, in Brookings Papers on Economic Activity; photo (M)

headline: Mexico City Journal; The Rich, Famous and Aghast: A Peep-Show Book
abstract: Ricas y Famosas, book of photographs of Mexico's wealthy women and their world by Daniela Rossell, stirs outrage in Mexico as it highlights vast differences between rich and poor and exposes decadent lifestyles of country's rich and famous; represents seven years of undercover work by Rossell; she comments; photos (M)

headline: 'Feeling of Frustration' Makes Arab World an Explosive Region
abstract: Article in series Perspectives; Prince Khalid al-Faisal al-Saud of Saudi Arabia talks about Sept 11 terrorist attacks and aftermath; says there is dread in Arab world that Pres Bush's fight against terror might ultimately breed more violence, not less, and perception that entire effort to fight terrorism has been shanghaied by Israel to justify its occupation of Palestinian land; his remarks reflect how widening gap between United States and its traditional Arab allies has emerged because each paints other as problem and dismisses other's preceptions; prince, governor of province that was home to four Sept 11 hijackers, reiterates position Saudi Arabia adopted soon after attacks, seeking to disassociate itself entirely from what it sees as delusional, lunatic fringe trying to use warped version of Islam as route to ruling Arabian peninsula; absolute rulers in region ultimately see terrorism as effort to unseat them; prince rejects notion that what most people view as royal family's monopoly on power and its profligate ways has any connection with frustrations that lead some young men to terrorism; photo; biographical data; excerpts from interview (M)

headline: Feeling Secure, U.S. Failed to Grasp bin Laden Threat
abstract: Extraordinary confluence of American instincts appears in hindsight to have dulled nation's readiness, chief among them complacency Americans shared about security of their continent, whose shores seemed impervious to malevolent assault; before Sept 11 there was also innate resistance to kind of domestic intelligence gathering that authorities consider necessary for tracking suspected terrorists and subversives; system was also flawed as result of long degradation of American intelligence gathering; review of what some members of Congress are calling greatest failure in American intelligence since Pearl Harbor; photos (L)

headline: Citigroup Makes Changes at Lending Division
abstract: Citigroup is changing marketing and other practices at its consumer lending business, CitiFinancial, and they appear to address some of criticisms about marketing of credit insurance that were cited in FTC lawsuit; is trying to complete negotiations to settle lawsuit (M)

headline: Blair's Closeness to U.S. Raises Alarm and Distrust in Europe
abstract: Alarm in Britain over American war talk is making Prime Minister Tony Blair's role of bridge builder a tougher one.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.00       Discount rate   1.25   1.25   2.50       Federal funds   1.81   1.75   2.96       3-month T-bills   1.62   1.60   2.32       6-month T-bills   1.58   1.57   2.27       10-yr. T-infl.   2.18   2.14   N.A.       10-yr. T-note   3.76   3.65   4.63       30-yr. T-bond   4.72   4.63   5.50       Telephone bd.   6.43   6.38   7.65       Municipal bds.   4.71   4.69   5.23          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: American Adds a Shuttle to the East Coast's Busy Skies
abstract: American Airlines is set to enter East Coast shuttle market, offering hourly flights between New York's La Guardia Airport and Boston and Washington; says it can make money with shuttle service by drawing members of its frequent-flyer program away from US Airways and Delta, whose shuttle business has dropped significantly; is offering triple miles on shuttle flights until Dec 31; will use smaller regional jets and thus need to fill fewer seats to break even than rivals (M)

headline: Article 2002090590758096251 -- No Title
A U.N. Agency Is Revitalized by Re-entry of the U.S.
abstract: Unesco director general Koichiro Matsuura believes that Unesco can turn its energies away from internal overhaul toward tackling critical educational, environmental and cultural problems with US decision to rejoin organization after 18-year absence; how American participation will change Unesco is still matter of speculation; photo (M)

headline: Bargain in Mortgages Gives Only Slight Lift
abstract: With mortgage rates matching their lowest levels in more than 30 years, thousands of Americans are rushing to refinance the loans on their homes.    But the lift to the economy provided by the wave of refinancings is unlikely to be as great this time as in the past.      Article, Page 23.

headline: A Star Analyst Exits Loudly. Others Hide Backstage.
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column deplores whining resignation of former Salomon Smith Barney star telecommunications stock analyst Jack B Grubman; holds his former colleagues at Salomon's investment banking group deserve equal scorn; graph of Nasdaq telecom index (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Roundup of recent advertising account changes (S)

headline: 'Whassup?' the Calendar Says, Using Its Best Digital Voice
abstract: VoiceStream Wireless introduces T-Mobile Pocket PC Phone Edition; meshes features found in hand-held organizers with cell phone technology and includes speakerphone; photo (M)

headline: Global Crossing to Recommend Buyer Soon
abstract: Global Crossing is expected to announce deal within week to sell its international fiber optic network and other assets (M)

headline: Bush's Step Toward U.N. Is Met by Warm Welcome; Council Seems Ready to Act
abstract: Nations across globe welcome Pres Bush's declaration that United States will work with Security Council in multilateral effort to press Iraq to meet disarmament and other commitments to United Nations; many government leaders express surprise, and relief; speech appears to dispel their fears of immediate and unilateral American military first strike against Saddam Hussein; even some Arab leaders are encouraged by Bush's words, despite his angry tone; Iraq's UN envoy Mohammed A Aldouri dismisses Bush's speech as 'series of fabrications' and gives no indication of new disposition from Baghdad to meet UN's terms (M)

headline: Bankruptcy Doctors Are Most Definitely In
abstract: Cadre of Wall Street bankers find opportunity in surge of corporate bankruptcies; restructuring specialists earn spectacular fees and are in great demand by both distressed companies and their creditors; major players in burgeoning field noted; photos; graph of growth in number of public companies filing for bankruptcy (M)

headline: Kashmir Dispute Forces Powell to Weigh Claims by 2 Allies
abstract: Sec of State Colin L Powell ends day-long visit to India and Pakistan, declaring Kashmir on international agenda and pressing India to release political prisoners and allow outside observers to ensure open elections in disputed border region in fall 2002; meets with top Indian and Pakistani officials; expresses confidence that border crossings from Pakistan into Indian-controlled Kashmir by Muslim militant groups has declined; says both sides have reaffirmed desire for peaceful solution to seven-month military standoff that has brought them to brink of war; is unable to bridge continued disputes between Indian officials and Pakistani military ruler Pervez Musharraf over whether border crossings have ended altogether; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: Protest Against President
abstract: Riot squads use water cannons to break up three days of demonstrations in Paraguay demanding resignation of Pres Luis Gonzalez Macchi; protesters are described as supporters of president's main rival Gen Lino Oviedo, who lives in exile in Brazil; Oviedo is seeking amnesty that would allow him to run for presidency next year (S)

headline: Disney Board Endorses a Plan to Address Company's Ills
abstract: Walt Disney Co says its board has endorsed plan by chief executive Michael D Eisner to address problems at ailing company; Disney declines to comment on plan's details; Eisner outlines for board members long-term strategy to bolster operations at its film division, theme parks and other properties; directors also expand their governance committee by two seats and discuss several board initiatives; two board members added to committee are Judith Estrin and Monica Lozano; board member George Mitchell will be co-chairman along with Stanley Gold (M)

headline: Agency Added For Army Recruiting
abstract: Leo Burnett USA in Chicago, lead agency for Army, selects Muse Cordero Chen & Partners in Los Angeles, part of Muse Creative Holdings, as subcontractor to handle duties of marketing Army to potential black recruits; Army spends $5 million to $10 million per year to attract black recruits, out of its estimated $95 million annual budget (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Northern Ireland: Unionist Deadline Comes Under Fire
abstract: Roman Catholic politicians in Northern Ireland attack new demand for Irish Republican Army to disband by Jan 18, 2003; say it threatens four-year home rule; Unionist Party leader David Trimble says he will resign if deadline is not met (S)

headline: McAFEE BOARD BACKS PURCHASE BY NETWORK ASSOCIATES
abstract: Network Associates Inc wins support from McAfee.com board of directors to buy remainder of company's shares for $224 million in cash and stock; offer has been revised four times (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Internet
abstract: GENUITY GETS EXTENSION TO RENEGOTIATE CREDIT LINE; BIOSCRYPT EXCELS IN FINGERPRINT TECHNOLOGY TESTS;.

headline: Return of a Violence Auteur
abstract: Kill Bill, film being made by Quentin Tarantino for release by Miramax in Oct 2003, is likely to pose litmus test of whether culture will again accept films that revel in details of violence; long gap between films stirs press interest in Tarantino; photos (M)

headline: Afghans Link Civilian Deaths To U.S. Bomb
abstract: US military officials say 2,000-pound satellite-guided bomb dropped from Air Force B-52 strayed off course during attack in southern Afghanistan, and people in Oruzgan Province say at least 40 members of wedding party were killed and about 70 wounded; team of American and Afghan military and diplomatic officials is dispatched to site of attack, near village of Kakrakai, in rugged area 105 miles northeast of Kandahar; map; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: India: Industrial Output Grows
abstract: India's industrial output rises 6.4 percent in July, compared with 2.6 percent in July 2001 (S)

headline: At U.N., U.S. Calls for End to the Siege of Arafat
abstract: US proposes UN Security Council resolution criticizing Israel in unusually strong terms, while administration accuses Israel of undermining Palestinian reform efforts by confining Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat in compound in Ramallah; offers draft resolution to avert confrontation with Arab states over siege and to counter proposal by Syria calling on Israel to cease activity in and around Ramallah; cites Palestinian Islamic Jihad and Hamas, holding them responsible for recent attacks in Israel; will require that they be treated as terrorists under Security Council resolution passed in 2001 to condemn attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon; marks first time US has sought to equate in formal terms Palestinian suicide bombings and other attacks in Israel with September 11 terrorist attacks in US; American diplomats say clause may be unacceptable to many nations on Council, who will nevertheless debate American alternative to avoid drawing yet another veto on Middle East issue from US (M)

headline: Volcker Seen As Top Choice To Head Board On Accounting
abstract: Former Federal Reserve chairman Paul A Volcker has emerged as top choice to head new regulatory body that will oversee accounting profession, although Volcker has been wavering over whether to take job; new entity known as Public Company Accounting Oversight Board was created by corporate and accounting legislation approved by Congress last month; photo (M)

headline: Bush Is Doubtful Iraq Will Comply With U.N. Demands
abstract: President Bush said on Friday that it was "highly doubtful" that Saddam Hussein would meet United Nations demands to disarm.

headline: Merrill and Schwab Report Earnings Slowed by Rough Market
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co reports second-quarter net income rose 17 percent, to $634 million, even after it paid $100 million in civil penalties and $11 million in legal fees in settling investigation into conflicts of interest among its stock analysts; revenue declined 11 percent, to $4.95 billion; Charles Schwab Corp reports 4 percent drop in net income, to $98 million; revenue dropped to $1 billion from $1.1 billion year earlier (M)

headline: Talking Heads, By E-Mail
abstract: David Pogue column assesses two e-mail systems that offer communications by video clip rather than text message; VidiTalk, from VidiSolutions, is intended primarily for corporations, and Visual Communicator, from Serious Magic, is primarily for consumers; drawing; photo (M)

headline: P & O PRINCESS CRUISES REJECTS MEETING WITH CARNIVAL
abstract: P&O Princess Cruises rejects request from Carnival Corp for meeting to discuss antitrust issues relating to Carnival's hostile bid for P&O Princess (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Finland: Yahoo Takes Wireless Stake
abstract: world

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Archbishop's Farewell
abstract: Archbishop of Canterbury George Carey gives his final presidential address to Anglican Consultative Council in Hong Kong; warns that church is being undermined by disagreements about how it handles issues like homosexuality; photo (S)

headline: Technology Briefing | E-Commerce: Bluefly Reports $1.5 Million Loss
abstract: Bluefly.com, discount fashion retailer, reports operating loss of $1.5 million for second quarter; says it had good quarter because its $6.8 million in net sales were 29 percent better than in period year earlier, and its operating loss was 65 percent smaller (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Consolidation Stalls In the Wireless Industry  The wireless industry seems to be defying conventional logic. Under most circumstances, the industry would be ripe for consolidation. But despite rumors of deals, most companies do not seem to be in a buying mood.     There are several reasons for the lack of consolidations. Chief among them, perhaps, is that the nation's local telephone companies are not as strong financially as they were a few months ago. New Economy. [Page C4.]

headline: In France, the Boss Is Fashionably Late
abstract: Nation's leading business schools now try to check applicants for honesty, integrity and ethics; respond to accounting and management scandals tainting corporate America; photo (M)

headline: Joint Venture Ends After a Brief Life
abstract: Interpublic Group of Companies, Omnicom Group and WPP Group close media management agency Mediaport tha tthey started with much fanfare in April 2001; work completed by Mediaport is being turned over to American Association of Advertising Agencies and Association of National Advertisers (S)

headline: Expect a Call While Rafting? A Way to Keep Your Phone Dry
abstract: Boxit 5.0 mobile phone case by Moduleo Oy is watertight and shockproof plastic case that allows full use of phone (M)

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: QWEST NAMES FINANCE OFFICER; HIGH SHARE OF JOB CUTS; SILICON GRAPHICS SALES FALL SHORT;.

headline: Relishing Beautiful New Freedoms in Kabul
abstract: Not least of improvements in Afghan women's lives since toppling of Taliban regime is chance to be feminine again in matters of dress and appearance, and to follow that pursuit without resorting to clandestine tactics; beauty salons have opened up in Kabul, and some shops selling burkas have been forced to close, although shroudlike burka remains preferred form of dress for women on streets of city; concept of beauty remains intensely private, for woman's own pleasure, and for men in her family; photos (M)

headline: From Ice to Insurance
abstract: New York Life Insurance Co chief executive Sy Sternberg writes The Boss column, about his life and family and circumstances that led him to his career in life insurance industry (M)

headline: THREATS AND RESPONSES: PERSPECTIVES/Senator Bob Graham; 'Victory in the War on Terrorism Will Not Be Won on the Defensive'
abstract: Interview with Sen Bob Graham, chairman of Senate Intelligence Committee who calls Bush administration's focus on Iraq distraction from campaign against terrorism and says Syria and Iran should be first targets of any aggressive efforts against state sponsors of terrorist activity; photo (L)

headline: Disney Selects a Chief for Its Theme Parks and Resorts
abstract: Walt Disney Co names James A Rasulo, chief executive of Euro Disney, as president of Walt Disney Parks and Resorts worldwide; he succeeds Paul Pressler (M)

headline: MARKETS CONTINUE DOWNWARD TREND; BANKS LEAD WAY
abstract: Stocks fall again amid growing concerns about telecommunications and energy-trading segments, as Sec Paul O'Neill goes to Wall Street to talk with senior brokerage executives; photos; graphs; banks and energy stocks account for most of 1.1 percent drop in Dow Jones industrial average, which closes at 7,702.34, lowest since Sept 1998; two areas are hurt by latest Enron revelations, with Citigroup and J P Morgan Chase executives at Senate hearing deny helping Enron cover up its debt; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 2.7 percent to five-year low; Nasdaq is off 4.2 percent, to 1,229.05, and is now down more than 75 percent from peak (M)

headline: North Korea Ending Rationing, Diplomats Report
abstract: Diplomatic reports say North Korea, seeking to cope with chronic shortages, disease and starvation, is transforming its Marxist economy, including abolition of rationing system; Prof Park Nei Hei of South Korea's Songang University disputes description of changes as 'epoch-making event' (M)

headline: Rumsfeld Says Allies Will Support U.S. on Iraq
abstract: Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld says America's allies will support United States if Pres Bush decides to attack Iraq, saying leadership in right direction finds followers and supporters; says it is premature for Bush to ask skeptical allies for their backing because he has not yet decided whether to try to oust Pres Saddam Hussein; echoes many of arguments for military action made by Vice Pres Dick Cheney in Aug 26 speech to veterans' convention; American and other coalition warplanes attack Iraqi radar sites and air defense command posts in both southern and northern Iraq; photo (M)

headline: Shanghai Journal; The Brothers Are in the Deconstruction Business
abstract: Shanghai Journal on demolition of city's old European-style row houses to make way for modern high-rise buildings; photos; demolition crews like that led by Ni Daimei reap harvests of old bricks and other building materials (M)

headline: Record Sale of Nymex Seat
abstract: Seat on New York Mercantile Exchange's Nymex division sells for record $1.1 million, $50,000 higher than previous record (S)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Marc Blanchard was named an interactive director and creative director at Euro RSCG MVBMS Partners, New York, part of the Euro RSCG Worldwide unit of Havas.

headline: FOOTSTAR LOWERS PROFIT OUTLOOK, AND SHARES DROP 15%
abstract: Footstar Inc cuts its third-quarter outlook after sales in stores open more than year dropped 5.1 percent in August (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Tunisia: Trial For Attack Suspect's Uncle
abstract: Uncle of Tunisian suspected of bombing famous synagogue in April, killing 21 people, will go on trial next week; Belgacem Nouar, uncle of Nizar Nouar, is accused of concealing information and helping his nephew plan suicide attack (S)

headline: Plastic Gold: Recyclers Find Profit in Printer Ink Cartridges
abstract: Computer printer cartridge recycling programs generate income for participants; known as remanufacturers, companies like Funding Factory get used cartridges from customers, refill them and resell them at much lower prices than original manufacturers; in exchange, remanufacturers offer reward points that can be redeemed for cash or computers and other supplies; original manufacturers like Hewlett-Packard say quality of refilled cartridges is inferior to new ones and offers take-back plan that does not reuse cartridges, but recycles portion of waste; photos (M)

headline: Patents; A pool in the ocean. A tanning oil mister. Are those pasties? Inventing by the sea.
abstract: New beach-related patents include those covering beach chair for pregnant women, with big hole in middle so that expectant mother can lie prone while reading (drawing), ocean-going swimming pool, shower-like cabinet in which tanning lotions can be evenly sprayed on body, plastic sun shields for the ears and strapless swimsuit top that is held on breasts by means of waterproof adhesive and resembles pasties worn by strip-tease artists (M)

headline: The War Against Spam
abstract: Letter from Michael J Zehr responds to June 27 article concerning escalating volume of Internet 'spam'

headline: A Recovery Is Expected, but How Big?
abstract: If the prognosticators are to be believed, the second half of 2002 will bring Madison Avenue something it fervently, but fruitlessly, wished for in the first half: a recovery in advertising spending.

headline: Private Sector; He Wants All Those Millionaires To Open Accounts at Chase
abstract: Regis Philbin, J P Morgan Chase customer and shareholder, cuts ribbon at new bank branch in Times Square; photo (M)

headline: Messier is expected to resign at Vivendi
abstract: PARIS:—  Facing insurmountable opposition from members of his own board, Jean-Marie Messier, the embattled chairman and chief executive of Vivendi Universal, has agreed to resign, bringing the curtain down on a lengthy, high-stakes corporate drama over control of the world's No. 2 media company, sources familiar with the situation said Monday.

headline: Dead End for Cambodians Who Grew So American
abstract: Cambodia is one of last nations to agree to accept its citizens affected by United States law that calls for deportation of non-Americans who are convicted of aggravated felonies; plight of one such repatriate, Sor Vann, described; there are 1,400 other Cambodians in US who have been marked for deportation; most have already served their prison terms and have been released; for all of them, exile to what they regard as foreign land resonates with earlier uprooting, when they fled brutal Khmer Rouge; as deportations continue, Cambodian government will find itself burdened with hundreds of people who are lost, jobless, many of them unable to function in Cambodian language, all with criminal records; photo (M)

headline: Prosecutors Open Genocide Case Against Milosevic
abstract: The trial of Slobodan Milosevic entered a new phase today in which he will face charges of genocide.

headline: On Television; Cable Thrives, But Broadcast TV Is Hardly Extinct
abstract: Number of signs indicate new hit shows on cable and rapidly spreading 200-channel universe have not doomed broadcast television; estimates indicate NBC and CBS had best advanced ad sales in their histories, while ABC and Fox did slightly better than expected; proliferation of niche channels has made networks more valuable to advertisers still seeking to reach broad audience; networks are blending cable's franker material with own family-style sitcoms and dramas; continue to freshen and expand low-cost reality programming that attracts new wave of younger views (M)

headline: Slow Recovery May Still Feel Like a Slump
abstract: Analysts say United States economy is having weak recovery similar to one in early 1990's; say coming months are likely to feel like slump even if economy is gradually improving; economists expect both businesses and consumers to increase their spending only modestly as country continues to work off excesses of 1990's boom, which included deceptive corporate accounting and large amounts of debt; Federal Reserve governors are scheduled to meet Aug 13; most economists do not expect Fed to cut interest rates from their exceptionally low levels this week; Pres Bush will convene economic summit in Waco, Tex, to discuss strategies for improving growth; White House is concerned that nervous voters could turn Republican incumbents out of office in this year's midterm elections and that economy threatens Bush's high approval rating; graph (M)

headline: Ad Pages in Magazines Decreased in August
abstract: Publishers Information Bureau says number of advertising pages in magazines fell 5.8 percent in August from August 2001 after increasing 0.5 percent in July from July 2001; ad pages are down 8.3 percent year to date (S)

headline: U.S. Inquiry on Pricing of Prostate Drug
abstract: The British pharmaceutical company AstraZeneca said that it was being investigated by the United States government over the pricing and marketing of its prostate-cancer drug, Zoladex.

headline: Article 2002090790392364330 -- No Title
World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility's Profit Rises
abstract: Germany's RWE posts 9 percent increase in operating profit to 2.17 billion euros ($2.12 billion) in first half; sales rose 3.5 percent, to 27.7 billion euros ($27 billion), and net profit was 818 million euros ($800 million), up 11 percent from year earlier (S)

headline: No Link to Al Qaeda in Arrests in Germany
abstract: German prosecutors say they have found no evidence so far to link couple charged with planning Sept 11 attack in Germany to Al Qaeda or any other international terrorist group; arrests of Astrid Eyzaguirre and Osman Petneczi, following tipoff to American military police, prompted immediate concerns that couple was working on behalf of Al Qaeda, partly because picture of Osama bin Laden was found in their apartment (S)

headline: I.M.F. Agrees to Loan Of $30 Billion for Brazil
abstract: International Monetary Fund, confronted with prospect of another financial meltdown in Latin America, agrees to $30 billion rescue loan for Brazil; at same time, Treasury Sec Paul H O'Neill urges Argentina to move quickly to reach similar accord, saying that United States will not bail out government and believes that additional reforms of Argentine economy are needed; rescue package for Brazil demonstrates attempt to meld political and economic goals; O'Neill photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PAN PACIFIC RETAIL PROPERTIES INC., Vista, Calif., a REIT which owns or has a stake in 111 properties in the Western U.S., said it had bought two grocery-anchored shopping centers in Southern California. The company paid $28.5 million for Larwin Square in Tustin and $18.6 million for Gordon Ranch Marketplace in Chino Hills.

headline: Cheney Doubts Weapons Inspectors Can End Baghdad's Threat
abstract: Vice Pres Dick Cheney says Iraq has so diligently concealed its effort to develop weapons of mass destruction in recent years that return of international weapons inspectors might be insufficient to eliminate threat; Cheney's remarks, in speech to Commonwealth Club of California, are latest sign that Bush adminstration is likely to proceed with effort to oust Saddam Hussein even if he does allow United Nations inspectors to return; Pres Bush has said repeatedly that goal of American policy in Iraq is 'regime change,' although he also says, in speech delivered at almost same time Cheney makes his remarks, that he has not ruled out diplomatic solution to standoff with Hussein (M)

headline: In Chicago
abstract: Travel article on Chicago; city's highlights noted; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Business Confidence Falls
abstract: German business confidence falls to eight-month low as executives' expectations for economic rebound dims; Ifo institute's index of western German business confidence drops to 88.2 from 88.8 in August (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Europe
abstract: GERMANY: Babcock Borsig On The Brink; DENMARK: Web Link Ruling;.

headline: Investing; Bond Funds for Wary and Bold Investors
abstract: One type of bond mutual fund, target maturity funds, invests primarily in zero-coupon United States government bonds; funds provide both relative safety for investors who hold them to maturity and volatility for traders; chart illustrates one fund's volatility over 15 years (M)

headline: FED OPTS TO LEAVE RATES UNCHANGED
abstract: Federal Reserve leaves official interest rates unchanged, with two of 12 members of Open Market Committee taking rare step of opposing decision to back immediate rate cut; split does little to calm Wall Street, where Dow Jones industrial ends September 24 at 7,683.13, its lowest level in four years; marks first time since 1998 that two committee members simultaneously broke ranks with Chmn Alan Greenspan; highlights unease in Washington and markets about whether economy is at risk of stalling again; leaves investors and analysts uncertain about Fed's next step; comes as Democrats step up efforts to turn attention from possibility of war with Iraq to economy's problems and alleged failure of domestic leadership on part of Pres Bush and Republican Party; comments by Senate majority leader Tom Daschle and House minority leader Richard Gephardt noted; Pres Bush voices optimism; says productivity of American people, plus low interest rates and low inflation, are ingredients for growth; photo; graph (M)

headline: In Talk With Envoy, Bush Assails Hussein, but Saudis Are Firm in Opposing War
abstract: Pres Bush entertains Prince Bandar bin Sultan, Saudi Arabia's US ambassador, at Texas ranch, where he tells him that Saddam Hussein of Iraq is menance and threat to both his neighbors and US, but Saudis stick to their position that war is not acceptable and that they will not cooperate in any military action; several administration officials are taken by surprise by vehemence of Vice Pres Dick Cheney's Aug 26 speech on necessity for military action against Iraq, and it is unclear whether his comments mean that administration is no longer interested in getting weapons inspectors back into Iraq; Pres Hosni Mubarak of Egypt says that if US strikes at Iraqi people because of one or two individuals and leaves Palestinian issue unresolved, not a single ruler in the Arab world will be able to curb popular sentiment; Bush also urges Saudi Arabia to free Amjad Radwan, 19-year-old American woman who was taken to Saudi territory by her father as child and is not permitted to leave without her father's written permission; Saudi courts almost always rule in favor of Saudi fathers in child custody cases (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Ex-Premier Enters Race
abstract: Election official in Lahore, Pakistan, approves former Prime Min Nawaz Sharif's bid to run for parliament; photo; Pres Pervez Musharraf has repeatedly said Sharif is banned from running or returning from Saudi Arabia; Sindh officials will rule on similar bid by exiled former Prime Min Benazir Bhutto (S)

headline: Computer Recycling Bill
abstract: California may become the first state requiring computer makers and sellers of television sets to charge buyers to recycle the machines.

headline: Technology Briefing | Hardware: Silicon Graphics Sales Fall Short
abstract: Silicon Graphics says fourth-quarter sales fell short of forecasts; sales were $280 million to $290 million, compared with earlier estimate of $310 million to $330 million (S)

headline: President Leaving Thompson Unit
abstract: Brian Heffernan leaves as president of J Walter Thompson's Chicago office; Bob Jeffrey will head office during search for successor (S)

headline: Gunmen Raid Hindu Temple Complex in India, Killing 29
abstract: Assailants open fire with automatic weapons at Hindu temple complex in India's Gujarat State, killing at least 29 people and wounding 74, in state still reeling from communal violence earlier in year; commandos reportedly kill two assailants; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Online Travel Agent Books Directly With the Airlines  Following through on one of its most provocative business plans, Orbitz, the airline-owned online travel agent, will begin booking tickets directly in the reservation system of American Airlines. The setup allows Orbitz to bypass the reservation systems that handle nearly all of the airline bookings by other travel agencies.    Another eight airlines have agreed to create similar links with Orbitz, and the company says the fee that it will charge airlines will be about one-third what they are paying most other reservation systems. [Page C3.]

headline: U.S. Pressing NATO for Rapid Reaction Force
abstract: US will press NATO to create permanent rapid reaction force to help improve its combat readiness in face of terrorist threats; Sec Donald Rumsfeld to present plan at meeting of defense ministers in Warsaw; force would be separate from European Union unit that will operational next year and will focus on 'low end of peacekeeping' (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Corporate Wrongdoing Is the Focus on Two Fronts  In testimony to Congress, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, pointed to a corporate culture blighted by ''infectious greed'' as the cause of the breakdown in confidence among investors.    With political pressure growing and the stock market falling, the House hurriedly passed a measure that would toughen criminal fraud penalties intended to curb corporate wrongdoing. [Page A1.]

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Ukraine: Air-Show Officials Face Trial
abstract: Ukrainian prosecutor general, Svyatoslav Piskun, said officials deemed responsible will go on trial in October for air-show crash at military airfield near Lviv that killed nearly 80 people (S)

headline: U.S. Coordinates Drug Sweep in the Balkans and Central Asia
abstract: Thousands of suspects are detained or arrested in broad narcotics sweep involving25,000 law enforcement officers and coordinated by Drug Enforcement Administration across 15 countries of Central Asia and Balkans (M)

headline: Soham Journal; Girls' Killing Melts British Reserve
abstract: Britain is deeply stirred by murders of Holly Wells and Jessica Chapman, two 10-year-old girls abducted in Soham, town of 8,000 that is 70 miles north of London; Ian Huntley, 28-year-old high school custodian, is charged with murder in both cases; Maxine Carr, 25-year-old classroom assistant at victims' own school, is charged with conspiring to pervert cause of justice; suspects were known as last people to have seen girls alive on Aug 4, and they were giving television interviews a day before their arrest on Aug 17; photos; map (M)

headline: Fears of Isolated Copycat Attacks, Hard to Detect or Stop
abstract: European intelligence and police authorities, alarmed by recent arrests of nine men suspected of terrorism in Sweden and Netherlands, fear next wave of attacks by Islamic extremists might involve small operations that will be hard to detect and stop; say new dangers come from radicals tied loosely to Al Qaeda and freelance extremists inspired to copycat acts; are taking seriously possibility that Kerim Sadk Chatty, arrested in Sweden when he tried to bring gun on commercial flight, intended to hijack plane (M)

headline: GADZOOX NETWORKS FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY PROTECTION
abstract: Gadzoox Networks Inc, maker of products for data storage networks, files for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection (S)

headline: As Cellphone Options Grow, Sites Help Sort Them Out
abstract: GetConnected.com and LetsTalk.com are Web sites that sort out cellular phone service deals, hardware and promotional offers; user can compare plans but should be aware that promotions may vary from site to site; drawing (M)

headline: Private Sector; Weeding Out the Bad Apples (Before They Get to Harvard)
abstract: Prof James L Heskett of Harvard Business School says that in view of recent corporate scandals, business schools should adopt same tough screening procedures used by best-run companies to choose applicants whose ethics and integrity appear to be beyond question; photo (M)

headline: Japan Tries to Halt Use of Tainted Herbal Diet Pills From China
abstract: Japanese health officials are scrambling to halt proliferation of tainted herbal weight-loss supplements from China that have killed three people and caused liver and thyroid ailments in hundreds; many consumers bought drugs on Internet or brought them back from China, making task more difficult; Min Chikara Sakaguchi says he steps up efforts to pinpoint source of growing list of drugs, which contain banned appetite suppressant N-nitroso fenfluramine (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Student Arrests Prompt Protests
abstract: Human rights groups protest arrest of 15 students in Myanmar during past week (S)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: Party Is Over For Millionaire Convict
abstract: Jeffrey Archer, millionaire novelist and member of House of Lords, was ordered moved to higher security prison for violating his home visit rules; he is serving four-year term for perjury and obstruction of justice (S)

headline: Technology Briefing: Telecommunications
abstract: SPRINT AND EBAY IN CALLING-CARD VENTURE; CITIZENS COMMUNICATIONS POSTS WIDER NET LOSS;.

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Loans to Units of Enron Draw Regulators' Attention  By taking out loans and transferring the money to Enron in an attempt to save the company from bankruptcy, two of Enron's most valuable subsidiaries may have run afoul of federal regulations.    The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has ordered the units, Transwestern Pipeline and Northern Natural Gas, to explain their accounting practices and prove that loans they took out on Enron's behalf will be repaid. The commission has neither finalized any rulings nor accused Enron of wrongdoing. [Page C2.]

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Poland: Finance Minister Resigns
abstract: Marek Belka resigns as Poland's finance minister after losing battle with left-wing cabinet colleagues over restraining country's budget deficit; photo (S)

headline: Hello, Roommates
abstract: Janie L Rosman letter on August 15 article recalls her concerns about potential college roommates did not include whether bedspreads were coordinated

headline: Kenyan Leader Fires His Deputy in Revolt
abstract: President Daniel arap Moi fired his vice president today in an attempt to quash a revolt within his ruling party.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction: July 7 tables of mutual fund performance ratings carried some outdated data; corrected ratings are available from New York Times

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: France: Profit Falls For Oil Concern
abstract: TotalFinaElf says net profit in first half-year dropped 30 percent, to 3.05 billion euros ($3.04 billion), on 10 percent decline in revenue, to 50.2 billion euros (S)

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Uganda: Rebels Release Kidnap Victims
abstract: Lord's Resistance Army, Ugandan rebel group, releases 4 aid workers abducted last week in raid on refugee camp and nearly 100 women and children kidnapped from their villages earlier (S)

headline: Bangladeshis Sipping Arsenic As Plan for Safe Water Stalls
abstract: Tens of thousands of Bangladeshis show outward signs of arsenic poisoning from their drinking water; World Health Orgn calls this largest mass poisoning of population in history; about 35 million Bangladeshis drink arsenic-contaminated water from tube wells that tap into underground aquifers; government, Unicef and various aid groups had encouraged installation of such wells, eager to wean nation from pond water which is often incubator for lethal disease; underground aquifers were never tested for arsenic until hundreds of people fell sick; in 1998, World Bank lent government $32.4 million to test every tube well and to provide safe sources of water; project has been hobbled by unforeseen problems, and most of country's estimated 11 million wells have yet to be tested; trusting Bangladeshi people are now told that water from 'safe' tube wells may be delivering arsenic-induced cancer; photos; maps (L)

headline: Watchdog Group Is Suing Cheney And Halliburton
abstract: Judicial Watch files lawsuit accusing Vice Pres Dick Cheney and Halliburton Co, company he ran for five years, of engaging in accounting fraud; suit also names Arthur Andersen; suit accuses Halliburton of fraudulently increasing its profits through improper accounting methods in conjunction with Andersen; chief financial officer Douglas Foshee calls allegations 'untrue, unsupported and unfounded'; White House spokesman Ari Fleischer says suit is 'without merit' (M)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: India: Compensation For Muslim Families
abstract: India asks families of nearly 500 Muslims missing since Hindu-Muslim violence convulsed Gujarat State earlier in year to apply for same compensation, $30,900, awarded to families of those killed (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Indonesia: Parliament Speaker Convicted
abstract: Indonesian Parliament Speaker Akbar Tanjung is convicted of graft and corruption and sentenced to three years in prison for misusing $4.5 million intended to buy food for poor when he was cabinet secretary in 1999; Tanjung, who heads Indonesia's second-largest political party, plans appeal; photo (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: China: One Freed, Three Missing
abstract: Human Rights in China, advocacy group, says Fang Jue, pro-democracy activist, has been released from prison after four-year term but remains under close police surveillance; another advocacy group says three other democracy advocates have been missing since June 26 (S)

headline: UNITED PARCEL SHIPMENTS FELL, BUT IT MET ESTIMATES
abstract: United Parcel Service's shipments in US fell 2.6 percent in second quarter as customers began shifting business to rivals in case there is Teamsters union strike at United Parcel; contract expires on July 31 (S)

headline: MediaTalk; Epic Records Takes Steps To Seal Its Newest Music
abstract: Reviewer copies of two soon-to-be-released albums from Epic Records Group are sealed inside Sony Walkman players so that CD's cannot be fed into computer and traded online; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Exploring Baghdad Strike As Iraq Option
abstract: New concept being explored by Bush administration for deposing Iraq's Pres Saddam Hussein offers risky approach of capturing Baghdad and one or two command centers and weapons depots first in hopes of cutting off country's central authority and setting off quick collapse of government; important aim would be to shock Iraq before it could use weapons of mass destruction; 'inside-out' approach would capitalize on American military's ability to strike over long distances, maneuvering forces to envelop target; advocates of plan say it reflects strong desire to find strategy that would not require full quarter-million American troops, yet hits hard enough to succeed (M)

headline: Stocks Rally Sharply
abstract: Stocks shot higher in a rally that sent the three major measures up more than 5 percent. The gain was the third in four sessions for the broad market, which has now made a sharp rebound from its five-year low last Tuesday.     Business Day, Page C1.

headline: Stores Open in Vermont Town, but Squabbles Live On
abstract: Vermont Environmental Board has demanded that bright signs of stores in Maple Tree Place mixed-use complex in Williston be lowered; board has threatened fines or criminal charges against development company Starwood Ceruzzi; illuminated signs are only part of squabble between developer and town over use of property (M)

headline: Bottom Still Far Off for Energy Traders
abstract: Analysis: Most experts in energy trading industry say absolute bottom of crisis in industry is still months away; Dynegy and Williams Companies are at risk of joining Enron Corp in bankruptcy; their collapse could hasten that of others that do business with them, most notably AES, energy merchant whose interests are deeply intertwined with Williams's (M)

headline: Big Hollywood Hits Don't Ensure Big Profits
abstract: Some blockbuster movies that appear to be huge moneymakers generate minimal profits for studios after marketing and 'participation' costs, which give stars and others percentage of revenue; photos (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: ABC Sports College Football, New York, part of the ABC unit of the Walt Disney Company, to Dcode, New York, to handle broadcast advertising, which had been at the New York office of Fallon Worldwide, part of the Publicis Groupe. Spending was estimated at less than $1 million.

headline: House Votes to Ease Some Cuba Restrictions
abstract: House, ignoring Pres Bush's veto threat, votes to ease restrictions on Americans traveling to Cuba and sending money there (S)

headline: BJ's MISSES FORECASTS, AND SHARES DECLINE
abstract: BJ's Wholesale Club shares fall 18 percent after it reports that second-quarter profit will be about 50 cents, not 52 to 54 cents that was projected, and that results for year will also miss estimates (S)

headline: Is the Slumber Over? Signs of Life Despite a Sluggish First Half
abstract: Business magazines, which led magazine industry into downturn, may be last to recover as advertising pages continue to slump; part of problem is environmental, with advertisers shunning link to today's relentlessly negative business news (M)

headline: A Return to Profitability; Big Recall Behind It, Tire Maker Regains Its Footing
abstract: Bridgestone Corp, major Japanese tire maker, reports strong first-half profits of $203 million despite small net loss from sales in United States; expects US operations to post full-year profit; company reports on second anniversary of recall of 6.5 million Firestone tires made by Bridgestone and linked to fatal accidents, most on Ford Explorer and other sport-utility vehicles; photos; graph of company's stock price (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Newspapers Acquired
abstract: GTC Transcontinental Group agrees to pay $167 million to CanWest Global Communications Corp for all its smaller newspapers in Atlantic Canada and Saskatchewan (S)

headline: World Business Briefing: Asia
abstract: JAPAN: Trade Surplus Doubles; JAPAN: Toshiba Raises Outlook; SOUTH KOREA: Household Debt Grows;.

headline: Betting Big On Reviving 'Black Holes'
abstract: Interview with Lakshmi N Mittal, whose LNM Holdings and Inspat International have quietly assembled one of world's top steelmaking groups, largely by cheaply acquiring huge money-losing state-owned mills; he says he has turned most of mills profitable, mainly by making low-cost, lower-quality steel products and selling them through his global network; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Japan: Service Spending Dips
abstract: Japanese government says demand for services fell 0.3 percent in June from May, slightly better than economists had forecast; demand for services rose for second quarter, suggesting expansion in country's gross domestic product during period (S)/

headline: RAYTHEON TO REORGANIZE SEVERAL DIVISIONS AND CUT JOBS
abstract: Raytheon Co will split its military and air-traffic work into seven businesses, then eliminate undetermined number of jobs (M)

headline: Beware White Knights Who Wreck the Castle
abstract: CORPORATE directors, Wall Street analysts and the business press are too easily smitten with the charisma and personality of chief executives who promise sweeping change when they take over, according to a new book that will surely intensify the already hot debate on corporate governance.    The book, ''Searching for a Corporate Savior: The Irrational Quest for Charismatic C.E.O.'s'' (Princeton University Press, $29.95), argues that company directors rely too much on social connections when choosing a chief executive from outside, even when their companies face serious trouble. As a result, the book contends, boards have helped create a ''distinctly American cult of the C.E.O.'' and encouraged extreme levels of executive compensation and other ''self-interested decisions.''

headline: Keeping Clean, Italian Style
abstract: keeping clean, italian styl

headline: Urgent Task For Rumsfeld
abstract: Analysis of urgent task facing Defense Sec Donald H Rumsfeld as he presses case for ground action against Iraq to eliminate its weapons of mass destruction; he must make sure American military forces are ready should Pres Bush elect military option in coming months (M)

headline: World Briefing: Europe
abstract: GEORGIA: Region Under Control; FINLAND: Military Ready To Join Nato; NORTHERN IRELAND: New Police Chief; NORWAY: 'Willy' The Whale Has Some Fun;.

headline: Industrial Complex Available for $1
abstract: Bayer, which is phasing out million-square-foot complex of assembly lines, offices, laboratories and warehouses in Elkhart, Ind, joins forces with several chambers of commerce and economic development groups and is offering complex for $1 to buyer outside pharmaceutical industry that will bring jobs to town; map; photo (M)

headline: Ireland May Do More to Help Its People Abroad
abstract: Irish government task force has recommended that financial assistance that Ireland has extended for years to needy Irish citizens abroad to increased sharply, to $33 million by 2005 from $3.1 million this year, that new educational programs be created in Irish schools to help young people who are thinking of leaving, and that elderly emigrants be assisted in returning to Ireland for vacations and be resettled permanently; proposals are aimed at Irish citizens who left country out of economic necessity or social pressures and now find themselves on margins of society in their host countries; government estimates there are about 1.2 million Irish-born people living abroad, equivalent of nearly one-third of Ireland's resident population (M)

headline: Glacier Pushes Avalanche of Ice Onto Village; Scores Are Missing
