abstract: Mammoth chunk of ice splits from glacier in Caucasus Mountains and sweeps downhill, leaving perhaps 100 people dead and 12-mile trail of devastation across roads, rivers and at least village of Karmadon in southwestern Russia; about 500 rescue workers search for survivors, and officials say missing include 27 members of film crew led by Sergei Bodrov Jr, one of Russia's most popular directors and actors; Pres Vladimir V Putin calls avalanche grave catastrophe; map (M)2

type: Money and Business/Financial DeskMoney and Bus
headline: Who Says Baseball Is Slow?
abstract: Major League Baseball's Web site offers condensed games, 20-minute versions containing all major action of complete games; about 10,000 subscribers pay $4.95 monthly for service; photo (M)

headline: Happy Birthday :-) to You: A Smiley Face Turns 20
abstract: Carnegie Mellon University's Dr Scott E Fahlman originated use of typographical characters to create smiling and frowning faces in e-mail messages 20 years ago; his original posting is found by colleagues to mark anniversary (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Day   Year       Yesterday   Ago   Ago               Prime rate   4.75   4.75   6.75        Discount rate   1.25   1.25   3.25        Federal funds   1.69   1.71   3.77        3-month T-bills   1.68   1.69   3.44        6-month T-bills   1.69   1.71   3.41        10-yr. T-infl.   2.87   2.88   3.36        10-yr. T-note   4.61   4.68   5.10        30-yr. T-bond   5.41   5.46   5.53        Telephone bd.   7.67   7.51   7.68        Municipal bds.   5.21   5.21   5.30          (Sources: Salomon Smith Barney; Telerate; The Bond Buyer)

headline: Prescription Drugs For the Elderly
abstract: Arthur M Kroll letter on Medicare funding holds he would prefer support of universal health care for young people; drawing (M)

headline: People and Accounts of Note
abstract: Mark Battista was named senior partner and management director, overseeing the ThermaSilk account, at the New York office of J. Walter Thompson, part of the WPP Group.

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Bid For Miner Is Raised
abstract: Placer Dome of Canada adds 35 cents a share in cash to its hostile, all-stock bid for AurionGold of Australia; revised bid values Aurion at 2.97 Australian dollars ($1.59) a share (S)

headline: Bush Signs Trade Bill, Restoring Broad Presidential Authority
abstract: Pres Bush signs 'fast-track trade' bill restoring presidential authority to negotiate trade deals with foreign countries without having them changed by Congress; says he will move quickly on trade deals with Chile, Singapore and Morocco and negotiate Free Trade Area of the Americas; Bush then leaves for monthlong vacation at Texas ranch (M)

headline: Canada and U.S. Raid Bikers and Arrest 42
abstract: Dozens of members of Outlaws motorcycle gang are arrested in raids on clubhouses in Canada and United States; charges against Canadian suspects include attempted murder, drug trafficking and weapons violations; among those rounded up in US, including international president Frank Wheeler and vice president Dennis Pellegrini, charges include racketeering, murder, extortion and drug trafficking (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Bank Leaves Rate Unchanged
abstract: Thailand's central bank leaves benchmark interest rate unchanged at 2 percent; economy is still expected to grow as much as 4 percent this year (S)

headline: Bush Signs Broad Changes in Business Laws
abstract: President Bush today signed into law a broad overhaul of corporate fraud, accounting and securities laws.

headline: ANDRX GETS TENTATIVE F.D.A. APPROVAL FOR GENERIC DRUG
abstract: Andrx Corp says Food and Drug Administration has granted tentative approval of its generic version of extended-release allergy medicine Claritin, made by Schering-Plough; Schering's patent on drug does not expire until Dec 19, and Andrx cannot get final regulatory approval until Dec 20 (S)

headline: US AIRWAYS ASKS BANKRUPTCY COURT TO VOID LABOR PACTS
abstract: US Airways Group asks Judge Stephen S Mitchell presiding over its Chapter 11 bankruptcy case for permission to reject collective bargaining agreements that cover more than 18,500 of its employees; agreements are with mechanics and fleet service employees represented by International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, and with reservation agents and ticket counter workers represented by Communications Workers of America; these groups have not ratified cost-reduction agreements (S)

headline: World Briefing | Asia: Thailand: Blacklist Critique
abstract: New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists condemns blacklistings of journalists during latest skirmish between Thailand and Myanmar (S)

headline: So That a Disaster Isn't a Communications Disaster
abstract: Communications mixups of sort that plagued emergency crews responding to attacks on World Trade Center and Pentagon might be prevented in future by InfraLynx comprehensive communication center; InfraLynx, installed in modified Humvee by Naval Research Laboratory, is designed to provide commanders at emergency scenes with land lines, cellular service, wireless Internet, fax and streaming video and to all emergency workers from various agencies to talk via radio; drawings (M)

headline: Harvesting the First Crop of Enron Tales
abstract: William J Holstein Book Value column on first three books purporting to explain demise of Enron Corp: What Went Wrong With Enron by Peter C Fusaro and Ross M Miller, How Companies Lie by A Larry Elliott and Richard J Schroth and Building Public Trust by Samuel A DiPiazza Jr; photo (M)

headline: The Easter Bunny Lives: Treats in Your Software
abstract: Q.  How can I find out whether any Easter eggs are hidden in my software?    A.  For those who have never stumbled across one when using a computer, an Easter egg is a wry surprise from the software's programmers that is not found in the user's manual. It can be a secret message that pops up after a series of actions in a program, for example, or an animated character that appears onscreen when a certain series of keys is pressed. (Easter eggs are usually whimsical or humorous, although not all are in the best of taste.)

headline: U.S. vs. U.N. Court: Two Worldviews
abstract: News analysis of looming showdown between US and other members of UN Security Council, notably Western European nations, over American refusal to join new International Criminal Court; at heart of divergence is fundamentally different visions of global organizations; Europeans, accustomed by their history to think in terms of multilateral arrangements, have always placed greater premium on international organizations, which have always been viewed with suspicion in US; emergence of US as sole military, economic and cultural superpower has only deepened resistance, especially among American conservatives, to any potential international restraints on American powers; photo (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Yugoslavia: Serb Convicted Of War Crime
abstract: Ivan Nikolic, former Yugoslav Army reservist, is sentenced to eight years in prison in Serbia's first war crimes trial for killing two Kosovo Albanian brothers in 1999 during Yugoslavia-NATO conflict (S)

headline: S.E.C. Chief Seeks Promotion; Chances Look Dim
abstract: SEC chairman Harvey L Pitt asks Congress for raise, to $166.700 from $138,200, and for cabinet-level status, even as critics call for him to step down because of way he is handling financial crisis; proposals, which would catapult SEC chief to higher rank than CIA and other top officials, is ridiculed by Democrats and disowned by White House; SEC is chronically pinched for money, but Pitt himself earned about $3 million as Wall Street lawyer in 17 months before joining government (M)

headline: Deaths of Arab Civilians Prompt Israeli Inquiry
abstract: Rash of killings of civilians stirs questions in Israel about whether restraints are slipping among troops after nearly two years of deadly conflict with Palestinians; also raises concern about revenge attacks in Israel after nearly monthlong lull; Defense Min Benjamin Ben-Eliezer orders military probe; critics cite interviews in which militiary commanders Lt Gen Moshe Yaalon and Maj Gen Dan Halutz suggested civilian casualties are acceptable when attacking militants responsible for deadly attacks on Israelis; map (M)

headline: U.S. Combs Indochina For Clues to the Missing
abstract: Article on relentless search for remains of Americans still missing in Indochina; remains of 733 missing Americans have recovered and identified since US withdrew in 1973; special task force headquartered in Hawaii, with annual budget of $40 million, mounts 10 search and recovery missions to region each year; US military still lists 1,908 Americans missing or unaccounted for from war in Southeast Asia; photo; map (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Canada: Inflation Edges Higher
abstract: Canada's inflation rate, measured by consumer price index, rose 1.3 percent in year to June (S)

headline: Saudi Sought By the F.B.I. Is Said to Be In Custody
abstract: Saud A S al-Rasheed, 21-year-old Saudi man sought by FBI for possible links to Sept 11 hijackers, has turned himself in to authorities in his homeland and denied any involvement with terrorist conspiracy; man's father, Abdulaziz al-Rasheed, says his son has no ties to Al Qaeda and cannot understand why his photo turned up among others of Sept 11 hijackers; American law officials say FBI issued worldwide alert for Rasheed after agents reviewed compact disc seized by Pakistani authorities that contained image of his passport and photos of some of 19 hijackers (M)

headline: Full Text: In Cheney's Words
abstract: Remarks by Vice President Cheney at the Opening Session of the 103rd National Convention of the Veterans of Foreign Wars

headline: Economic Scene; Business 'reforms' should not ignore the positive roles of incentives and competition.
abstract: Virginia Postrel Economic Scene column on pending business 'reforms' says those reforms should not ignore positive roles of incentives and competition; says if auditors were hired by exchange, rather than company, and given forensic mandate, they would enjoy both more freedom and more prestige; holds turning audits into independent investigations might help solve one of accounting's biggest problems: auditing is too boring to attract and keep best accountants; concludes 'reforms' that ignore role of incentives and competition will turn out to be monsters themselves; photo (M)

headline: Vivendi Is Expected to Receive New Loans as It Tries to Pay Debt
abstract: Vivendi Universal is expected to get 2 billion euros ($1.94 billion) in new loans from group of banks; analysts say loans will last only through end of year, making sale of businesses key part of Vivendi's debt-cutting effort; talks for sale of several units have reportedly intensified in recent days (S)

headline: Top Forecaster Cuts Estimate for Growth in 2002 Ad
abstract: The executive considered the dean of advertising forecasters is cutting his estimate for ad spending in 2002.

headline: World Briefing | Africa: Ivory Coast: Rescue Of Foreigners Completed
abstract: French soldiers finish evacuating foreigners out of rebel-held city of Bouake, as mutinous soldiers prevent Ivoirians from leaving (S)

headline: Avis Is Courting Leisure Travelers
abstract: Avis Rent a Car Systems, reacting to sluggish business-travel market, is shifting its focus to leisure travelers; will begin campaign to pick up more vacationers, who it hopes will help offset its heavy dependence on business-travel market; about 65 percent of Avis's rentals come from business travelers, highest percentage among largest car rental companies, while only 35 percent are from leisure travelers; chart (M)

headline: World Briefing | Europe: Epidemic Threatens Harbor Seals
abstract: Epidemic that killed half of Northern Europe's harbor seals in 1988 has appeared this summer and already killed about 2,500 seals (S)

headline: Aversion to U.S. Airports Is Rooted in Stress Factor
abstract: Growing number of business travelers are choosing other forms of travel other than airlines, including automobiles, because of stress factors at airports; Kathy Ewing, who has racked up 1.8 million frequent-flier miles on Delta Airlines alone, says she prefers travel by car because it is less stressful; drawing (M)

headline: MyTravel to Start a Low-Cost Airline
abstract: Already-intense competition among established airlines for intra-European travelers becomes fiercer as MyTravel Group of Britain discloses plans for its own low-cost airline, MyTravelLite; MyTravel Group was known until recently as Airtours (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Europe: Germany: Utility Acquisition Approved
abstract: Germany's E.ON wins approval for its 10.7 billion euro ($10.47 billion) acquisition of Ruhrgas with more conditions as government aims to remove court injunction blocking takeover; Economics Ministry was forced to reassess purchase of Ruhrgas after court blocked it on July 13, citing procedural errors; E.ON must sell more stake in other utilities and natural gas to rivals (S)

headline: Kyrgyzstan Seeks Reward For Helping Fight Terror
abstract: Kyrgyzstan Pres Askar Akayev says country is moving to strengthen democratic and human rights and should be rewarded with increase in American aid for supporting US in its campaign against terrorism; brushes aside criticisms by human rights advocates that he stifles opposition and has become increasingly autocratic in recent years; recent meeting with Pres Bush and Sec of State Colin Powell in Washington noted; photo (S)

headline: Kaliningrad Journal; A Russian City Digs Up Its Past and Finds Germany
abstract: Kaliningrad, former German city of Konigsberg that was ceded to Soviet Union at end of World War II, is gradually recovering its past after nearly half century in which 700 years of its history was systematically destroyed by Soviets; new efforts have raised questions whether region of 900,000 inhabitants is Russian or German at heart; some have suggested restoring old name of Konigsberg; map; photos (M)

headline: Life Without a Land Line
abstract: Harry Wolf letter notes August 29 article on wireless-only use failed to address home alarm systems that are monitored by phone

type: Money and Business/Financial DeskMoney and Bus
headline: WHAT THEY'RE READING
abstract: Five executives reveal books they are currently reading, and why (M)

headline: Embattled Analyst Donated to Democrats
abstract: Jack B Grubman, analyst at Salomon Smith Barney who is under investigation for potential conflicts of interest, gave $100,000 to Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee in June (S)

headline: RED ROBIN RESTAURANT CHAIN TO ADD 17 FRANCHISES
abstract: Red Robin Gourmet Burgers plans to add 17 restaurants in next seven years to expand in Connecticut, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Michigan (S)

type: Money and Business/Financial DeskMoney and Bus
headline: Rallying Point For Investors
abstract: $100,000 Rockefeller Family Fund grant enables Nancy M Smith to found Restore the Trust, organization dedicated to garner popular support for Sen Paul S Sarbanes' proposed legislation designed to minimize future corporate misdeeds; photos (M)

headline: German Outcome Casts Renewed Chill Over Economy
abstract: Investors abandon German stock market in droves on September 23, reflecting fears that re-election of Chancellor Gerhard Schroder will consign country to economic paralysis; Frankfurt market plunges nearly 5 percent, to lowest level in more than five years; investors seem worried that Schroder may be unable to revive Europe's largest economy or carry out needed reforms; even though elements in coalition government will prod Schroder to overhaul stagnant economy, experts say campaign may not previal in Parliament in which coalition is fragile majority and revitalized conservative opposition still yearns to oust him; graph (M)

headline: Pick Up the Proxy, Fill It Out and Exert Some Control
abstract: Gretchen Morgenson Market Watch column urges apathetic shareholders to vote shares on key corporate decisions; warns that brokerage-firm votes of shares held for customers help management maintain control; lauds proposed new Securities and Exchange Commission rules governing stockholder voting; graph of proxies exercised (M)

headline: Iraq Stance Puts Blair at Odds With Party
abstract: Intensifying debate within his Labor Party over Iraq thrusts British Prime Min Tony Blair into unusually vulnerable position; Britons are alarmed by Bush administration's talk of war and by Britain's apparent acquiescence to United States policies; Blair refuses to address growing view that Britain is losing its ability to temper US policy (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: Hong Kong: Ousted Executive Sells Auto Stock
abstract: Brilliance China Automotive Holdings says former chairman and chief executive Yang Rong sold all of his stock in company, worth $11 million, when he was removed from his posts two weeks ago (S)

headline: TRADE PANEL SAYS EUROPE CAN IMPOSE PENALTIES ON U.S.
abstract: World Trade Organization rules European Union can impose $4 billion in retaliatory tariffs on United States exports because of US tax break that promotes exports it twice previously ruled was illegal; European leaders have made it clear that they will not invoke penalties, largest ever imposed by WTO, soon, giving US time to change law; ruling gives Europeans leverage on range of trade disputes; Bush administration plays down significance of ruling, predicting law will soon be rewritten; ruling could provide ammunition to US critics who see WTO as threat to national sovereignty (M)

headline: Calpers Adopts Policy on Analyst Conflicts
abstract: DIARY Calpers Adopts Policy On Analyst Conflicts.

headline: EXXON MOBIL BUYS STAKE IN OIL PIPELINE SYSTEM
abstract: Exxon Mobil Corp acquires 25 percent stake in pipeline system that will carry oil from field in Gulf of Mexico; price undisclosed; buys fourth of both Proteus Pipeline Co and Endymion Pipeline Co, which plan to build pipeline system that will be operated by BP (S)

headline: Slovaks, Casting Ballots, Seem Likely to Choose Change
abstract: Slovakians are unlikely to allow Vladimir Meciar, thrice-elected, thrice-ousted former prime minister, to regain office in elections to be held Sept 20 and Sept 21; NATO and European officials have warned that if he is in next government, Slovakia will not join their organizations; strong majority of Slovak voters see both NATO and European Union as guarantees of prosperity and political stability sorely needed; for nearly decade, Meciar's rough ways and anti-Western rhetoric won him support of bedrock third of voters; corruption and crony capitalism were his hallmarks, as were various scandals (M)

headline: Robert O. Jordan, 69, Ex-Chief Of New York Advertising Office
abstract: Robert O Jordan, who helped create advertising campaigns for clients as diverse as Procter & Gamble and The National Enquirer, dies at age 69 (M)

headline: Financier Who Shook Up the Swiss Is Himself Shaken Up
abstract: Martin Ebner, financier who spent 1990's shaking up Switzerland's clubby corporations and coaxing famously thrifty Swiss to invest in stocks, yields to slumping market and gives up control of four main investment funds; his holding company, BZ Group Holding, says it had sold controlling stake in four listed companies, with portfolios worth $2 billion, to Zurich Cantonal Bank; photo (M)

headline: World Business Briefing | Asia: South Korea: Hynix Board Installed
abstract: New board representing creditor institutions that have taken over Hynix Semiconductor is installed at shareholder meeting in Ichon, South Korea (S)

headline: World Business Briefing | Americas: Brazil: Utility Rights Sold
abstract: Brazil sells oncessions to build and operate eight hydroelectric plants to local and foreign investors who will invest more than $1.3 billion; 1.087-megawatt plant in northern Tocantins state is bought by utilities group Tractebel, leading consortium including Alcoa, British-Australian group BHP Billiton and Brazilian companies Vale do Rio Doce and Camargo Correia Energia; cost for 35-year concession will total nearly $900 million (S)

headline: Trading Pioneer to Retire
abstract: Merrill Lynch says E E Geduld will retire as head of its Nasdaq trading operations this month (S)

headline: World Briefing | Americas: Paraguay: Protests Taper Off
abstract: Protesters mostly stay off streets of Asuncion, Paraguay, after declaration of five-day state of emergency to quell demonstrations against economic policies (S)

headline: Dike Patrols Expand as Lake in China Springs More Leaks
abstract: Citizen patrols step up along hundreds of miles of dikes that hem in huge, swollen Dongting Lake in central China; officials say weather upstream during coming week would determine whether flooding threat and need for vigilance along dikes should abate or be prolonged (M)

headline: S.E.C. Is Posting Statement Dates
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commissin, trying to avoid confusion about deadline for executive certifications of company financial statements, posts due dates for each company on its Web site; new rules requires certification on or after Aug 14 (S)

headline: Without Fanfare or Cases, International Court Sets Up
abstract: New International Criminal Court begins operations in The Hague over strong objections from Washington, ready to receive complaints about gross abuses of human rights anywhere in world; created by Treaty of Rome in 1998, court has jurisdiction over war crimes, crimes against humanity and genocide; organizers say it is likely to be year before first trial takes place (M)
